description:
Hands down the best Pad Se Ew ("Pad See You") I've ever had. You can choose between your choice of tofu, minced pork, pork, or chicken, but I *highly* recommend the minced pork option. Farmhouse is the only place I know that serves it with minced pork, and trust... it's amazing. I've also ordered their Pad Se Ew multiple times on Caviar, and it tastes equally amazing delivered. Not to mention, portions are extremely generous and it hits the spot for all your late night cravings. 

Their cocktails are also delicious, one-of-a-kind, and aesthetically beautiful. I started off with one Summer Spritz (ingredients: Aperol, Sparkling Wine, Pressed Grapefruit, Lemongrass Simple) and ended up ordering three glasses. It's light, fruity, and not too strong or sweet - the perfect "girly" cocktail. 

This place is always packed, so make sure you make a reservation beforehand or walk-in before 6pm! I came here at 5:30pm on a Friday night and didn't have to wait, but the place definitely filled up by 6pm.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Little off the beaten path and slightly pricey($20ish per entrée), but the food reflects the quality. Haven't tried anything that wasn't delicious. 

This place has sister restaurants in Oakland and Portland. The atmosphere and staff def reminds me a lot of the places we visited in Portland. Reservations are not hard to get and if you come early when they open, the place is empty and you get seated right away. The staff is super helpful, but sometimes it can be hard to get their attention depending on where you sit. A lot of the tables are close together so be prepared to get cozy! The table next to us was basically face first in our fried chicken trying to stare at what we were eating. 

We ordered the pad see ew with pork. If you add certain proteins there is an upcharge. This dish has a lot of flavor and you can taste the "wok hai" which is the taste of the pan. I've ordered this spicy and non-spicy. Be careful as their spicy is CRAZY spicy. Like mouth numbing. They also offer a holder full of sauces. Try the house made one, tasty and makes your mouth feel like it's on fire. 

We also ordered the Hat Yai Chicken which is their signature fried chicken with yellow curry, roti, and blue jasmine rice. The portions for this dish are generous and enough to share. The blue rice is cool but doesn't taste any different than white rice, but it was BOMB with the curry. The roti was placed on top of the fried chicken so it was slightly soggy, but still great with the curry. Def a must try!

We rounded out our experience with their bread pudding as dessert. Theirs comes in a muffin shape with vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. It comes out hot and delicious! Not too sweet and not too soggy.

The best part is the quality is consistent. Every time I've visited I've left satisfied and full. Great place to visit if you're craving Thai food.
author: Junella T.

description:
I had an awful experience at Farmhouse during the evening of Folsom Festival.

I entered the restaurant and it was extremely busy and way darker than what a restaurant of this size and level of crowdedness.

I was with a party of four and we ordered four dishes to share. The dishes came out sooner than we expected given how crowded the restaurant was and the food tasted decent, but was honestly nothing special and did not stand out as being any better than the hole-in-the-wall Thai restaurants I normally go to.

What drove me absolutely crazy about this place was, every 20 minutes a crowd of employees would run around the already very loud restaurant banging on (what sounded like pots and pans) celebrating the birthdays in the room.

I had a bad headache and this made want to curl into a ball and cry hopelessly. It didn't happen once, not twice, but THREE times during the course of our dinner.

To add insult to injury, the portion sizes of the food we ordered were a complete joke and considering the average price of the dishes we ordered were $20+, there was no excuse for this. I want to say each person in our party had maybe two large table spoons of fried rice before we were scraping the bottom of the plate.

I left this restaurant hungry, absolutely miserable from the excessive noise, and I had to pick up a $35 bill BEFORE tip (meaning our total bill was $140 for four dishes).

It's possible it was just an off night, but I left so remorseful of this restaurant pick, you can bet I'll never return here again.
author: Nima A.

description:
We came in on a Sunday night for dinner, and it was packed! Luckily we made reservations, so we got seated right away. 

The menu takes awhile to read through. There are lots of options and everything sounds so appealing. I ended up ordering the Hat Yai fried chicken (~$23). My friend ordered the 24-hour broth. We also ordered a dessert to share. The fried chicken was SO good. It comes with Thai fried chicken, roti, rice, and curry. I can't even express how delicious the curry was! I think this was large enough for 1 people to share. I was stuffed! Oh, and the 24-hour broth.. so delicious! 

I suggest asking for their spices if you like spicy food. the Godmother really adds a special kick to your food. 

If it's someone's birthday, a whole group of the servers come out and sing to you while playing the drums. It's really entertaining! However, they still charge for the dessert.. 

The beers are kind of expensive ($7-11) for a can. Their hot tea was also $5, which is really pricy!

The lights got dimmer and dimmer as we ate, which made it hard to see each other and the food we were eating. However, it sets the mood of the restaurant. They have really nice decor and a screen playing Thai things. Their servers are dressed in Thai attire!

The price ranges around $20-30, but the portions are large and so good! The servers were great, and they really complimented the Thai feel of the restaurant.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Located along Jack London Square, in between Forge and Belcampo, with parking available in Plank garage or along the streets. The restaurant has been pretty busy so if you come during prime time dinner hours, I'd recommend making a reservation in advance or plan on waiting 30+ min.

The menu is expansive, and gives you a variety of apps, salads, entrees, noodles and soups. I personally like the variety available, but it can be overwhelming to others. I've been here a few times now and would recommend two entrees: 1.) The Panang Neau, a fall-off-the-bone short rib served over blue rice with broccoli I spears. I usually eat half and save the other half for leftovers, but don't be surprised if you don't want to share and eat it all.  The meat is just so tender! 2.) The Hat Yai Fried Chicken, fried chicken with an Indian asian flare, served with to roti (similar to an Indian style tortilla), this delish potato curry sauce, blue rice. The dish is flexible giving you options to mix and match each bite...mix it all together, eat it similar to a taco...you can't go wrong bc the flavors just work! 

As for other items: expect A LOT of spice in the papaya salad (they note it's spicy on the menu). The mieng salmon is supposed to be wrapped but the way they present the filet works better eating as is. The Neua Yang steak has a great presentation (they light it on fire in front of you...see my video), but I felt the alcohol either didn't burn off or they marinated it in the rum bc it overpowered the taste of the meat. Also not as tender as I expected it to be. Looking for a fun drink? Get their Thai iced drink, it looks like a snow cone with the mound of shaved ice when it comes out.

Looking to celebrate a special occasion? The staff comes out banging a drum and shaking cups of silverware...it's so loud, everyone in the restaurant will know you're turning 50, 32, or 21 (there seem to be a lot of celebrations when we go, lol).
author: Amber H.

description:
This place probably had the best Thai food that I've found in San Francisco.  This is coming from someone who lived within walking distance of quite a number of decent Thai restaurants in the city too.  We came here after we got shafted from a supposed lunch omakase at a nearby sushi restaurant, and thankfully this place did not disappoint!  The things we tried included:

Chicken and Waffles:
PROS:
- great quantity, definitely enough to share and take some home if you get other dishes
- good balance between chicken and waffles
- chicken was not too greasy
- curry/dipping sauce had great flavor: it's good to put it on the side because it allows the patron to dip or pour as much of it as they would like.
- also comes with a side of rice so get your carbs on!
CONS:
- breading on some chicken pieces were a bit too heavy: it's not your standard "fried chicken" (see picture)

Papaya Salad: definitely one of the dishes that I use to gauge how good a Thai restaurant is.
PROS:
- fantastic quantity: I was almost 1/3 full just by nibbling on this before our main orders came out
- good balance between all the ingredients: I am a fan of the sliced grape tomatoes
CONS:
- a bit on the tart end but nothing that I would say is a true con

Pad See Ew (Thai Street Food): their meat options for this section on their menu is AMAZING.  I ordered this with the house crispy pork belly and that's what sold me on giving this 5 stars.
PROS:
- great quantity: definitely shareable
- not mushy noodles: it's hard to do fried rice-noodles without overcooking the noodles or having them break apart on you.  These are perfectly done!
- CRISPY PORK BELLY IS GOLD: this literally made the dish.  My friend also agreed hands down.
- well balanced in flavor and not super greasy
CONS:
-NONE

I also ordered the typical Thai Iced Tea - it was super nice how it came with a perfect ice ball on top.  Service was 100% on top, never had to ask for a refill and only for the check.  I would definitely come back here again.  They also have a secondary location in Oakland and for you Oregon people, they have one in Portland as well.
author: Vera L.

description: First visit to Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Cuisine and I really enjoyed myself. It appears small on the outside but is fairly spacious on the inside. The decor is modern and funky. The staff wear colorful Taiwanese  outfits and there is unique swanky music playing in the background. The food is fresh and tasty. Check it out. I went back to Farmhouse for the Crab fried rice and bone broth with their house made special spices. It was expensive but delicious
author: Rhett B.

description:
Hat Yai Fried Chicken: 5/5
Neua Num Tok Rolls: 4/5
Panang Curry with Beef: 4/5

One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, Farmhouse Thai has delicious, aromatic, savory offerings in a fun (if loud) dining space. Expect to pay around $18-30 for a dish with very generous portions! Must eats: Hat Yai Fried Chicken.

Ambiance:
Don't expect a quiet dining experience here; the music is turned up quite loud and it can get hard to hear your dining companions at peak hours. However, the restaurant is bustling with energy, and sometimes servers will walk around offering snacks (like fried grasshoppers!) on little platters. The restaurant is decorated in bright, bold colors, though it's a bit dimly lit. 

Food:
Though the Panang Neua is delicious, the Hat Yai Fried Chicken never ceases to blow me away. I like to order new dishes every time, but I'll make an exception for the Hat Yai. It's so simple yet delicious; the chicken breast is so tender it cuts like butter, and somehow Farmhouse Thai perfectly fries it to have a perfect crunch. Paired with the potato yellow curry with blue rice and the wonderfully flaky and buttery roti, it's a beautifully balanced set in a generous portion. 

The Neua Num Tok Rolls (cilantro/mint/cucumber wrapped in wagyu beef strips) were made with very tender wagyu beef, but the standout for me was the cilantro-lime vinaigrette drizzled on top. The aroma and tang of the vinaigrette perfectly balances the richness of the beef. 

The Panang Curry has the slightest bit of kick to it, and the aromas are so rich and delightful. The beef add-in didn't do much for the flavor or experience of the curry; I'd skip since the beef itself wasn't that exciting and a bit chewy.
author: Jen R.

description:
Right off the bat, I'm going to say this place is very pricey. They give a pretty good amount of food, but still not quite worth the price. This place gets full so you either need reservations or plan on waiting a little bit. We got lucky cause they squeezed us in to eat for 1 hr since the table was reserved.
Despite the price, I tried the basics and they were all very good.

Pad Thai - just the right texture and I enjoyed the flavors. It wasn't like other places that make it super saucey and ketchupy. It was dry, but in a good way, and a little sweet, but with the lime it balanced out nicely. 

Thai fried rice - solid fried rice. Rice texture was on point, not mushy. The only bad part was the meat seemed a bit on the dry side (this one in a bad way). But it smelled great and tasted great.

Mieng salmon - they're like lettuce wraps. They gave two large pieces of salmon with vermicelli, veggies, and some type of sauce that went so well with it all. Thoroughly enjoyed this dish.

Papaya salad - very spicy for myself but still really refreshing and had good fish sauce to go with it.

I do want to come back and try some of the other special/more unique dishes but that'll probably also have to be for a special occasion when I'm feelin like spending some money.
author: Rachelle C.

description:
Farmhouse just did not meet my friends and I's expectations unfortunately. The portions were so small and imo very, very overpriced. We got the large Tom Yum soup, the Hat Yai friend chicken, Pad kee mow, eggplant with sticky rice, and 2 Thai teas which totaled our bill after tax to $105. Service was fine. Their dishes though at least for my friends and I were not cleaned thoroughly, double check your utensils before using!! As for the food: 

Tom yum: Everyone has their preferences, I thought flavoring was just right for me. Good balance of sour and spicy.
Hat Yai: Best dish out of all of them, price wise too. Fried chicken was super crispy, rice was cooked right, and the roti and curry were on point. 
Pad Kee Mow: Good spice, but so oily and so little portions. There were barely any noodles and I added the "Wagyu beef" for another $2 totaling to a known basic Thai noodle dish to $17 dollars. They had this under the "street food" options in the menu which I thought was very ironic.
Eggplant with sticky rice (side): Eggplant was cooked unevenly, some were still raw in the middle.
Thai Tea: Literally Thai tea with a huge ball of just ice shaved iced. You're paying another $2 for hella ice..

Overall, nothing stood out to me for me to give this place another try. There are soo many other more authentic and quality Thai places in SF. But they did outdo themselves on the decor of this place, very nice spacious seating on the inside as well as tables on the outside.
author: Erica L.

description:
Farmhouse is an amazing restaurant for Thai food. My friend and I came on a late afternoon so we got seated right away, but I can see this place getting packed during lunch and dinner. The atmosphere is quite lively and it'd make an amazing date place.

For my drink, I got the spiced chai latte and let me tell you.. the chai latte here was probably the best I ever had. Not too spicy and not too sweet - it was perfect. For food, I got the yellow curry with a side of jasmine rice. My rice was interestingly blue and my yellow curry came with a roti. What a pleasant surprise! The curry was delicious and although I came super hungry, I was a stuffed turkey by the end of the meal.

Overall, I really enjoyed this place. The only downside it is pricey. My meal costed me $30 (including tips) easily. Pretty pricey lunch, but definitely worth it when you want to splurge on yourself. I'd love check out this place for dinner next time!
author: Julian Y.

description:
I love this place. The food is a little pricey, but given the quality of food and the cool environment, I will pay a little more for Thai food than other places.

The place can get loud where they sometimes have drum line parades for people's bdays and also given all the people that fill up the restaurant it's definitely a place that sometimes you may need to try to out talk the person next to you so your friends can hear.

I appreciate that they mention what items they can make gluten free. Ive had many of their items and for the most part really liked it including the fried rice with shrimp, pad se ew, and drinks. I was disappointed by their eggplant dish... I love eggplant and for the price you would expect a good portion of it. I remember I got the dish with my friend and we both were in disbelief that we only got 4-5 pieces of eggplant. In my opinion I don't think it's worth getting again.

I also have enjoyed the drinks. I've gotten the bowl which is strong and we shared at a table of 4. Last time I got a sake based sangria and it was really good! However, I tried my friend's flower spritzer and it had a really weird after taste...
author: Gita r.

description:
Incredibly fun atmosphere for any occasion, be it a casual lunch or a group dinner celebration. The menu offers all the staples: fried noodles, curries, meat dishes accompanied by a generous array of sides. At dinner, there's also a waiter walking around carrying street food that you can grab for your table. 
Whether it's in presentation or taste, all the items have a creative spin to it, and the meal is truly a feast for the taste buds and the eyes. I've tried many items and liked them all, but fell in love with their yellow curry recently. The accompanying roti is seriously amazing. 
Expect a lively atmosphere with multiple interruptions throughout the meal as the staff celebrates birthdays all around you. They even provide sparklers, and I'm pretty sure will let you bring in your own cake too.
author: Amy C.

description:
After wanting to come here for a while, I was finally able to snag a timely reservation (aka not at 9pm). My boyfriend and I came for a weekend lunch and it was quite packed.

We ended up ordering the tom yum, pork belly salad, and short rib. The tom yum, to me, was underwhelming and I felt like the only thing so could taste was salt - but with that said, my boyfriend REALLY liked it so it could just be a personal taste issue. The real star to me was the pork belly salad. I'm not exactly sure how it classifies as a salad because the dish was definitely mostly pork belly. On top of being a great value, I loved the perfect crispness and succulence of the pork belly cut through by the sharpness of the sauce. The short rib was also very tender and the sauce was also delicious. The amount of rice given was perfect and ultimately it was a really well balanced plate. 

I did get quite a bit of food envy just looking at everyone else's dishes and so I'm sure to be back!
author: Janice L.

description:
Delectable Thai food, in the Mission! Right off of the main strip, and adjacent to Southern Pacific Brewing, lies this little gem! There is easy parking and public transport to this area.

They have a fun, colorful awning and some art on the wall outside. The inside has a modern feel to it, but the wall to their kitchen has tin awning kind of like most houses in Thailand. So kind of rustic modern. Unlike other authentic places in the city, this eatery cares about presentation. When I went the host had an authentic Thai costume on, and there was a guy with a chili hat walking around with a carrying pole with two buckets that had an arraying of chili sauces to try. It does get loud seeing as the space is somewhat on the smaller side. The do have a nice long communal table, so I wouldn't be scared to come with a large group!

Be careful when they say "Thai spicy"!!! This place actually means it. I came in knowing exactly what I wanted because I had seen something on Instagram. We got the cup noodles with braised beef and seafood fried rice. Everything was flavored appropriately with all the right ingredients, except the noodles! I accidentally asked for Thai spicy and and after a couple bites, it was hard to eat. They also have a nice wine list, which isn't very Thai, but I really appreciated it because who doesn't like good wine with dinner. Their desserts also mean business! Check out my photos for the beautifully presented "Bread Pudding." It comes with a Kouign-Amann style "bread" and vanilla ice cream. I'll definitely be returning to have those noodles again with less spice, and to actually read the whole menu!
author: Navila H.

description:
Mr. Farmhouse...

You are amazing. I pay an arm and leg each time to eat here, but that is the thing.. I actually walk away saying.. that was totally worth it.

I know, I know, people like me will always say... I'll never pay that much money for Asian food! I can just go to XXX restaurant and pay $10 for good decent Asian food! Why would I pay $$$ for the same thing!

Foolish hobbit. I am just like them actually... but I tell them, just trust me and go. Not... by yourself or just randomly. But on a special occasion, open up that little wallet of yours and just give it a try. You won't regret it. I've been hear a few times now and each time I come to see you I think... it couldn't have possibly been that good. What am I doing? But then man does the food live up to the hype every time.

Your 24 hour beef noodle soup. Amazing. Wait what is that GIANT leg of some god forsaken animal doing in my soup. (sorry for that graphic image. extra sorry to vegetarians, but OH MY)

Your Hat Yai Fried Chicken. How do you make it so crispy yet light, yet filling. I must learn how to fry a chicken like that. 

I'll be back. I will be back...
author: Paul L.

description:
This was the BEST restaurant that I visited on my trip to San Fran. This was kind of hard to find at first as the area is pretty quiet and 'warehouse-y' feels. I made a reservation but got here early and was hoping to get seated earlier but it was a full house. We did get seated about 45 minutes later from when we arrived which was still earlier than our original reservation time! Also, food is very instagram worthy!
This place is VERY loud at night which I wasn't a fan of. They literally do a lion dance on people's birthdays. There were probably 5 different birthdays the night I was there and I probably went deaf LOL. 

My boyfriend and I ordered 2 thai ice teas, ahi scoops, hat yai fried chicken, and panang neua. 

Thai ice tea - Delicious very standard thai ice tea. This place serves it with two snow/ice balls on top. I'm not sure what purpose it serves but was pretty.

Ahi scoops - Ahi scoops was good but nothing memorable. I would get again but I wouldn't crave for it.

Hat yai fried chicken - This dish is delicious. Listen to everyone else and get this! Chicken was fried to a crisp but the meat was SO juicy. I'm pretty sure it was chicken breast too. Served with a sweet chilli sauce. Dish comes with blue rice, roti and curry. 

Penang Neau - The braised pork was delicious as well. Worth the price as they do not skimp on the meat. The meat is so tender it literally falls off the bones. Also served with rice and onions/peppers.

This will be a go to spot if I am ever in San Fran again. Farmhouse was the most memorable restaurant for me.
author: Flora L.

description:
A really fun Thai place! The host who greeted us had the most amazing, vibrant traditional (?) costume on, and the interior is just as colorful and fun. We came for an early dinner on Saturday night and there was a pretty short wait (by the time we left, though, the line that had formed was very long so be sure to plan ahead)!

I took off a star because of value for the price point. We got pad thai with tofu (15) which was very fragrant and flavorful. However, the grilled prawns (~23 I think) -- while beautifully presented in a coconut -- weren't worth it, as I'm pretty sure there were only about 6-8 shrimp in the whole thing? Nevertheless I had a ball eating this meal, especially because I didn't expect the blue flower rice to actually be blue (I'm easily entertained, clearly).
author: Shelley P.

description:
I judge all my Thai places on their Pad Thai but being veggie, I order without the Fish Sauce......Farmhouse Kitchen makes theirs with Oyster Sauce and they will not leave it out

Showstopper......
author: Adrienne G.

description:
My new favorite Thai restaurant in SF! I always enjoy eating Thai foods whenever I go to Portland and I thought there's nothing like that here in the bay area, until I found Farmhouse! We ordered:
- chicken wings(good, crunchy)
- neua num tok rolls(very good! The beef melts in your mouth!)
- hat yai(huge portion! Everything on this plate taste really good)
- panang neua(soooo good!, the blue rice is just like regular white rice, no taste)
- 24 hours beef noodle soup(great! Good broth, the short ribs is very good too!)

Will definitely return. Parking is a bit tough though, only street parking. I didn't see any parking lot/garage nearby.
author: Prisilia P.

description:
Unfortunately I didn't find the dining environment particularly comfortable. It was like dining in a nightclub with loud music and people shouting over each other. I had a really hard time having a decent conversation with my friend because we could barely hear each other. I think next time, I will just take my food to go!

Otherwise, the food was pretty bomb. We ordered the Neua Num Tok Rolls as our appetizer and got the Hat Yai Fried Chicken and Pad Thai for our entrees. I would highly recommend going with a large group of friends so that you can try an assortment of the menu items! 

The pad thai was decent, but there was nothing particularly special about the Farmhouse pad thai. I thought the Hat Yai Fried Chicken was a very unique dish though! The chicken breast is deep fried to perfection. The outside was crispy but the inside was super tender and juicy. My mouth is watering just thinking of it! The buttery, coconut curry served with the chicken went well with the rice and the roti (which was also perfectly cripy on the outside and doughy on the inside). My only gripe was about how little of the curry there was on our plate! It barely covered the bottom of its serving bowl and was dressed with just two lone pieces of potato. I would have appreciated a more generous portion of the curry!!

They do a pretty fun routine for people celebrating their birthdays at the restaurant. I'm not sure if this is something you have to coordinate beforehand, but they do a little song-and-dance (actually a very LOUD song-and-dance) and present the birthday boy/girl with a plate of dessert and some props for photos. It was quite entertaining to watch!
author: Sherry L.

description: I put off going here for a while because I did not want to wait. Finally, with friends, I made it in. While the ambiance is almost a caricature or kitsch of classic Thai style, the food was as authentic as it comes (okay, maybe a little more sanitary than the streets of Bangkok). Full of flavor, the perfect amounts of spice, and wonderful service. TOTALLY WORTH THE WAIT.
author: Sahra S.

description:
Next level 
Vegan spring rolls 
Peanut sauce 
Very authentic 
Excellent atmosphere

I'm
Only writing this additional stuff because yelp said my review was too short.  Trust me all you need to know is next level
author: Keith G.

description:
I had an excellent Saturday morning brunch here where I ordered the Chef's special (Khao Kha Moo -five spice pork shank with onion garlic, plum sugar in black soy sauce served with broccolini, half an egg, pickled veggies and white rice) and the whole young coconut. 

The food was great and having grown up in the Philippines, eating a young coconut never fails to evoke a little bit of my childhood.  The ambiance here is nice and festive but the restaurant can get a bit loud. 

Service is good and I recommend getting a reservation through yelp since this place gets really busy.  With tax and tip, this was about $40 - good value for money, in my humble opinion. 

The only complaint I have is that they have one single unisex bathroom and the wait can be long when they are busy.  Highly recommended!!!
author: Andrew S.

description:
How has it taken so long for me to review one of my go-to's in San Francisco?

Farmhouse Kitchen is such a unique dining experience with exquisite food. My wife and I were fortunate enough to discover this place when it first opened, but it quickly became a hotspot for the "new Mission crowd" on any given night, so definitely make a reservation if you can!

My favorite dish (and really the only thing I ever order) is the Panang Neua--a house special that depicts a dish the head chef would serve to his family. It is a bone-in short rib topped with panang curry served with blue rice. It is tasty, fall-of-the-bone tender and very filling! I can never bring myself to order anything else. My wife always orders the Hat Yai Fried Chicken, which comes with curry, roti, and rice--also flavorful and sizable.

*Highly recommend coming here for a birthday and having the staff sing to the celebrant. Even better if you can, come here for Thai New Year.  Farmhouse really creates a festive dining experience on this night with Muy Thai exhibitions, cultural dancing and singing, games, and dishes individually served "dim-sum style."
author: Ryan M.

description:
I greatly enjoyed the casual, lively atmosphere with old Thai music playing in the background and the delicious food here. 

Ordered the following:
Thai sausage appetizer - nicely seasoned and flavorful
Pad see ew with chicken - the wide noodles were soft and had nice texture, the sauce was perfect
Fried chicken breast with roti, curry dipping sauce, and blue rice - chicken was crispy and flavorful and went well with the rice, roti dipped in the curry was delightful 

Everything I tried was delicious, and would definitely come back to try more items. The restaurant gets pretty packed, so make a reservation if you can.
author: Alice W.

description:
Our lunch was very delayed because there was some issue with staff missing keys. I wasn't there, but my friend who called in the lunch order and went to Farmhouse right when they opened on a Sunday (noon) basically had to wait outside with a growing crowd for 30 minutes before he could get inside and get the lunch he'd pre-ordered. 

Nonetheless, the food here never really disappoints. And is legit spicy!

I'm not sure exactly what our friend ordered but here's my best description of the dishes below:

* Leaf-Wrapped Salmon - 3.5 stars
Soft texture, interesting with a pesto-like sauce. I do like my salmon a little pink and undercooked, so I would've preferred that. But the leaf keeps the filet nice and moist.

* Yellow curry w/ eggplant, string beans - 3.5 stars
Great flavor, and love the crunch to the veggies, but wow this is spicy!

* Spring Rolls - 3 stars
Fine but a bit plain/boring compared to the other dishes!

* Beef w/ Rice - 4 stars
Lovely tender beef, really good quality cuts, and flavorful sauce.

* Pad Thai - 4 stars
Soft noodles, tons of great veggies. Really good!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Very good Thai place in the Mission area. Came by for a late lunch and most of their table were still full, must indicate their popularity :) We were seated pretty quickly (there is a person up front to check in with if there's a wait). They also do a lot of take out orders, so if you don't have time to dine in, that's also an option. They do take reservations, so if you have a decently sized party, it would be best to reserve. I hear they do fill up completely during peak hours. 

I've had the pad see you and pad spicy eggplant. The pad see you was pretty standard, good portion size, nothing super special. The eggplant was solid, not too salty or overly oily, though the flavors are pretty heavy. You can ask for mild spiciness too :D I got the eggplant with crispy pork belly, which was delicious. Each piece had some tenderness of the fatty part and then crispy in the lean parts. Good amount of pork belly for the extra $4 on top of the base dish price. Generally, their dishes have higher price tags than other other Thai places I've been too, but its decent for the food you get. 

Service was pretty good, though they were a bit curt when taking our order. All in all, I would recommend Farmhouse if you're feeling Thai in the Mission area. Pretty decently sized restaurant as well.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
After reading about this place on multiple food blogs and seeing the high rankings by my fellow Yelpers, I really wanted to like this place! I loved the lively environment, how engaged and fun loving the staff is, and the psychedelic decor, but the food was somewhat of a disappointment.

First up, why can't we make reservations on the phone? I called up to get a table for two, and was told that there would be a 45 minute wait no matter when we reached. The only way to make a reservation was through the Yelp app, and no slots were available for this particular day. This makes it a little cumbersome to check out this place on a whim!

We were turned off by the one hour plus wait when we got there, but were offered the choice of bar seating. Since it was just the two of us, and the bar has full service, we went with this option.

The food menu is extensive, grouped into appetizers, curries, noodle dishes, street food, and entrees and each dish is clearly explained. Pictures would've been helpful, as most of the entrees come with multiple components. Spicy dishes are marked as such, and it would have been great to have crowd favorites/chef recommendations marked as well. The drinks menu is almost as extensive as the food menu, with a dozen cocktails, beers, and wines.

We ordered the Hat Yai fried chicken meal and the "Run Juan" sizzling seafood platter. We also got a Thai-chelada (Thai version of a michelada) and a Tsingha beer.

The complimentary pickled salad that they serve before the food is so, so good! I finished the whole plate by myself and had to order for a second serving so that my dad could taste it as well.

My order of the fried chicken came within 10 minutes, but my dad's order took much longer, and we had almost finished my entree by then.

Hat Yai Fried Chicken - Southern Thai style fried chicken which comes with paratha, blue rice, yellow curry, pickled cucumbers, and a sweet ans spicy dipping sauce.The curry was really flavorful, and paired with the paratha would have made a perfectly adequate meal by itself. The blue rice was... well, blue. i couldn't detect any special flavor to it. The fried chicken was perfectly crisped, but was bland and a bit soggy on the inside, and no amount of the dipping sauce could remedy it. The portion was huge, and we struggled to finish it.

"Run Juan" sizzling seafood platter - The platter consisted of shrimp, calamari, scallops, and some sort of catfish in a spicy peppery sauce, with green and red peppers and onions, and came with a side of white rice. This dish was much better, and I could've licked the platter clean, had it not been a burn hazard. My dad and I agreed that we should've only ordered this entree and tried out one of the appetizers.

The thai-chelada was eh. I ordered it because I've never had a michelada, so I didn't quite know what to expect, but it was sour and tangy and I was able to finish it, so I guess it was okay.

At several points of time during dinner, the staff emerged from the kitchen with with raucous birthday chants, some sort of a hat for the birthday celebrator, and a cake of some sort (?). That looked like a lot of fun, so if I lived in SF, I'd definitely want to celebrate a birthday here.

Service was attentive even though we were at the bar, and the bartender was very merry and chatty and made us feel like we were a part of the regular dining crowd.
author: Shivani P.

description:
Been here for the first time and I was wowed by the ambience. The outside certainly does not ready you for what will it look like on the inside. I love the decorations and music they play throughout the night. 

We came here for a friends birthday and we were not disappointed. It's great that they also take reservation online which makes it easier for large parties (we were 6). There is parking around the area but it is scarce so I recommended perhaps the nearby parking garages if no street parking. The food was presented very beautifully and was just as delicious. 

I highly recommend telling the waiter if there is a birthday in your party, you definitely will not be disappointed ;)
author: Robbie P.

description:
Very interesting place on a Friday night. We walked into the restaurant and it was very lively and loud. Several parties were celebrating their birthdays, and it seemed like a fun place for that.  I had the vegan rolls, and the pad Thai with no eggs (I'm vegan) and my boyfriend had the tofu noodle soup. 
The rolls were good, and I really liked the peanut sauce they came with. My pad Thai was very flavorful, but a little odd with asparagus in it. My bf liked his soup, but said it could have used some hot sauce for more flavor.
author: Kearsten K.

description:
We were craving for Thai food around San Fran's is I area and seen this place through yelp they have a good ratings so we decided to try it.. 
place and ambience was felt the Thai vibe inside with their cool custome Muay Thai shorts and flower polo shirts lol. They were pretty busy when we came in. I didn't like the sittings and small tables  too small and the chair are hard to sit on. 

Food 5/5
We ordered beef soup 24/7 it was so tasty and so good.. u can taste the sweetness and mix of fat and great flavors in it. Papaya salad was so good also it was mixed well. Pad see you was so flavorful also and for dessert Thai vacation that's coconut with coconut ice cream, and sticky rice so yummy . The price was a little pricey compare to other Thai reataurant but it's definitely worth it. Can't wait to go back for more and try other things they have to offer.

Service 3/5
They were too busy to see all the customers I guess and they put my dessert to go and I've been waiting for it for a while and by the time they realize they put it to go the ice cream melted already . They need to pay more attention even they are busy.. 

Ambiance/place
Needs more improvement. I can see that they are busy. They prolly need the restaurant to be bigger and better chairs . On a Monday they are busy. Wow. 

All in all my rating is solid : 4  and we will come back for more food to try. Thanks
author: Paula C.

description:
Like Gus's market people come out of the woodwork that work in this area for this restaurant; it is definitely the place to go at the moment.  It can get super busy during lunch hour (probably dinner too but I've only been here for lunch) so I'd recommend a reservation or going closer to 1:30 because they close at 2pm for lunch.

I'm very impressed with the visual presentation of all the dishes.  It all looks so colorful and thoughtfully put together making me want to take a picture of everthing (and I'm not one of those people that is always taking pictures of food).  Many of the alcoholic drinks are garnished with flowers, so pretty and presentable.

I'd recommend the Hat Yai fried chicken.  It comes with roti bread, curry, and the ever famous blue rice.  

Farmhouse is a little more on the pricey side, not that it's overpriced but you aren't going to find something here $10 for lunch.  For me it's more of a special occasion lunch than the regular meal but I like to come here because it's always a good experience.
author: Joan W.

description:
Multiple friends recommended Farmhouse Thai and I finally made it this weekend. We ordered the Hat Yai fried chicken, Panang Neua braised bone-in short rib, Tom Yum soup, and Thai iced tea. 

I loved the entire fried chicken plate! It comes with blue rice, yellow curry, and roti--all super super yummy. I wanted to put that curry on everything. The short rib tasted good but I think it could've been more tender, and I wish it came with more sauce/curry too. The Tom Yum soup had lots of vegetables but medium spice wasn't enough for my boyfriend. The Thai iced tea snowball was really cute but didn't really serve a purpose, so it made it kind of hard to drink!

Our total was $70 before tip. Overall, it's a pricey meal especially for Thai food, but the portions are large and every flavor is spot on.
author: Katy Y.

description:
I has been here many time . Good place and great meal. Sweet staff . Highly recommend to be here.....yeah yeah yeah !!

 Farmhouse have 2 locations in the Bay Area ( San Francisco ,Oakland ) also in Portland,Oregon.  and this location is definitely one of my favorite!
author: Tanasak I.

description:
a cozy slice of awesomeness with decent plating skills brimming with deliciousness.

My wife loves this place almost as much as i love the The House [sic].

I only wish they could cater large events.
author: Roger B.

description:
Generously rounding up a 3.5 review.

I came here with my out-of-state family members and entered with high hopes from all the reviews, but the crafted "cultural" feel was a big turn off for my parents. I think overall the place felt really noisy and chaotic, possibly due to just the loud music. The birthday pot clanging happened way too frequently and honestly was so disruptive to conversations at hand.

We ordered the pad Thai, Tom yum soup, jerk chicken, samosas and another dish that I didn't really get to try. A bit difficult to share in family-style and nothing was really that amazing. The medium spicy level was also way too much for me. Chicken was a bit too dry, pad Thai was too sweet and rice was too much. I really liked the samosas tho.

I found out that the rice is blue bc they cook it with flowers! No special flavors tho. Def would not go out of my way to eat here, but maybe would come for a noisy bday celebration (with drinx).
author: Juliana P.

description:
Probably one of the best Thai spots in San Francisco. The Panang curry with beef was super flavorful, and was a large portion size. I'm always skeptical of ordering noodle dishes at "upscale" thai places like Farmhouse, but flavors of the pad thai was on point!

In terms of the restaurant, expect it to be totally packed and loud. Make a reservation ahead of time on Yelp if you want to eat at a reasonable time. The prices are totally within an acceptable range for a nice sit-down dinner in the city (expect to spend around $30 if you're just getting mains).
author: Kedar V.

description: I had been wanting to check this place out for a while. A friend treated me to lunch here and we both enjoyed it very much. We had the Pad Thai with extra peanut sauce and it was very tasty. We also had green curry that came with a festive blue rice. The tom ka soup was delicious and the chicken very tender as well. The Thai ice tea was great and not as sweet as in other places. We are coming back. Parking is a challenge no matter what day or time of the day you go so ride sharing is highly recommended. Service was friendly and prompt.
author: Moy V.

description:
Farmhouse is the best Thai spot in the city.

I know, I know. It's a risky statement, among hundreds of Thai places, some of them even holding Michelin Star accreditation (I'm lookin at you, Kin Khao). But you trust me right? Farmhouse is theeee best. I am convinced this spot will satisfy picky eaters and Thai-food enthusiasts alike. This is THE spot, y'all.

GET:
The Panang Neua - Slow braised bone-in short rib drenched in panang curry, ISSA GAME CHANGER. I could drink the sauce alone with a straw. The meat falls off the bone, melts in your mouth, and launches your mind into a blissful state of euphoria. If you pass up on this dish, I feel sorry for you.

GET:
The Hat Yai Fried Chicken - I get cravings for this chicken every other day, it's THAT good. The chicken is fried with a light batter making it perfectly crispy without ruining the freshness of the chicken. It's comes in a huge platter surrounded by nasi kerabu, roti & yellow curry. Side note, contrary to popular belief the rice is blue from butterfly pea flowers, not smurf tears. Totally safe, totally delicious, totally worth it.

GET:
The Neua Nom Tok Rolls - This appe'thai'zer was recommended by our server, and I will echo in his recommendation. One order comes with four beef rolls made with wagyu, mint, cilantro, cucumber, drenched in a yummy cilantro lime vinaigrette. Perfect portion size for 2 people.

REGRET:
The Thai Tea. Great tea, ruined with too much ice. It comes served with a giant snowball balancing on the edge of the cup. I don't know who thought this was a good idea. Someone must have watched Frozen too many times. I do not want to build a snowman, and neither do I want any of it in my Thai tea. Anyway, it ended up being very watery, and I couldn't get past 2 sips. What a waste, but ya live and ya learn.

Already planning my next trip to Farmhouse. They actually have a location in Portland now too, and another coming in Oakland. I'm tellin' ya, people, Farmhouse is legit. Dont @me.
author: Noimee L.

description:
This place is a hidden gem! Came here based on yelp reviews and the recs were good. We had the fried chicken that came with a curry sauce, rib covered in panang curry, deep fried shrimp appetizer, and this udon noodle soup (forgot the name) which was money!! 

Parking is hard to find as there are several famous places in the area and residential buildings so if you get here during the dinner rush you'll be scrounging around for parking. 

Place is pretty spacious and can accommodate a stroller if you have a baby. Staff is friendly and there are multiple restrooms (front and back of restaurant). 

The blue rice was unexpected but tastes like rice so don't let the color throw you off. It's hard to be disappointed by the food here.
author: Mia S.

description:
The festive-ist of festive. 

Know someone who's about to have a birthday? Take them here. There's a musical parade complete with dancing, singing, instruments, an interesting dessert platter, and candles. It's the best celebration I've seen at a restaurant for birthdays! 

Drinks: Think cocktails that make you feel like you're on vacation; complete with flower garnishes, funky glasses and interesting combinations. 

Appetizers: The coconut prawns are AMAZING. Seriously! Probably my favorite thing I tried. 

Entrees: I was torn between the grilled salmon wrapped in banana leaves and the chicken pad Thai. I went with the pad Thai because well, it's such a classic and resembles the measurement between Thai restaurants for me. It was yummy but what I'd come back for is still the coconut prawns. 

Dessert: The dessert platter came with a variety of about seven different sweets: a macaroon, watermelon, coconut shaved ice (my favorite), a mini chocolate cake, and ice cream with boba-type mini bubbles on it (anyone know the technical term?). 

The service is super fast, so don't be discouraged if there's a wait! You can also make reservations.
author: Niki K.

description:
Exceptional Thai food. I was blown away by this restaurant, and it was my favorite one I tried in sf this trip. I usually am a sucker for the normal Thai dishes, like pad see ew or glass noodles, but there are some really unique dishes here they I was super excited to try as per my friend's recommendations! 

First off, the decor in this restaurant is super neat! It has so much to look at and that is a good thing because chances are, without a res, you'll be waiting a long time! Thankfully for us, there was a two seat opening right at the bar and it worked out that we were able to be seated right away! 

The restaurant is known for its fried chicken. It's more of a Thai chicken and waffles, if I may, but the flavors feel so much more complex than just that. They have this super neat blue rice that accompanied the dish. The fried chicken is not dripping in oil, which I appreciate. It is served with some curry and potatoes with some leavened bread and oh my gosh is it good!!!!! It just all works so so well together. I have never had food like it. The sweetness from the honey dipping sauce, the crispiness of the fried chicken, and the soft bread, wow. It was so good! 

And we also split their herbed rice salad. Normally I order papaya salad, but have heard that is spicy. This dish, the herbed rice salad, is super flavorful and really delicious. It's unlike anything I have had too! I loved the small kefir lime flavor because it balances out the dried shrimp on top! 

I love this place and I will return every time I'm in the bay! 

Water review: 9/10 they even put it in a metal cup like the one you'd use for camping! Cool!
author: Amanda P.

description:
It had been a few years since I visited Farmhouse, and I can tell you that it is still as fabulous as I remember. Fabulous decor, cool vibe, great people, interesting food.

This time, I tried the green curry with crispy pork as my dinner entree. It was SPICY but in a satisfying, delicious way with a great mix of colorful vegetables and of course, their must-try blue rice. Not for the faint of heart. My favorite thing about Farmhouse is that there is truly no way to order something bad on the menu - as I mentioned in my past review, if the food was any more authentic, you'd be in Thailand!

Oh, and the staff did a high-energy, loud and brilliant Happy Birthday song with drums for our friend (I was visiting with a group), and unlike a lot of other birthday songs, this one was such fun and totally awesome! The staff really goes out of their way to make it a special experience. Whether you're local or visiting, you should absolutely visit Farmhouse Thai for an amazing meal!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Thai food is my #1 pick, my go-to, the answer any time someone asks me "what are you craving?" 

I could essentially eat it 24/7. I'm so thankful for a friend who pushed me to try a new place and introduced me to this gem. There is already a Thai spot in the city that I know and love so it's hard for me to want to venture anywhere else. But let me tell ya, this place is equally amazing.

We had a reservation so we were seated immediately. This place filled up fast while we were there so I would highly recommend making one, just in case. The service was great. Everyone was festive, lively and friendly. I also loved the vibe and ambience. THE AESTHETIC. It was beautifully decorated, bright and fun!

We started with the Neua Num Tok Rolls ($15.50) as our waitress recommended and I have no regrets. The wagyu beef was so tender and just melted in your mouth. It was wrapped with mint, cilantro and pickled cucumber, and served with a fragrant cilantro lime vinaigrette. 

I quickly browsed Yelp to see what I should order for my entree and the Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($21.50) stood out. BEST DECISION I MADE. It's comes with a Thai southern style fried chicken breast, delicious roti, super tasty yellow potato curry, and blue rice. Yes, blue rice. It's probably food coloring, but I dig it.

My friend ordered Panang Neua ($27.95) and that was perfectly cooked. It's a dish with their slow braised short rib in a rich panang curry with grilled broccolini, bell pepper, onion and fried basil. It also comes with a side of blue rice. It's the most expensive dish on the menu, but may possibly be worth it.

For dessert, we had the Farmhouse Bread Pudding ($10) with organic vanilla ice cream and caramel. It's warm, gooey, and a perfect amount of sweet to end your meal. If it's your first time here, I'd recommend this house favorite.

Farmhouse is pure magic. Go now.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Farmhouse has amazing food! I went there with a group of friends so I got to try quite a few different dishes. The ambiance is nice and the decor is really cute. 

For apps, we shared the Thai fish cakes and Ahi scoops. My friend and I shared the crab fried rice and pork belly pad see you.

Everything was super good! I definitely recommend the crab fried rice. The side of bone broth is amazing.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Definitely a unique dining experience here.

I came here for a birthday dinner and had a wonderful time. They make your birthday celebration real festive here. The food was also great and had a wide range of flavor and spices!

A lot of their dishes are spicy so double check with a server to make sure what you are ordering ahead of time. My personal favorites include the Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($19) and Panang Neua ($25). The fried chicken was so crispy and juicy, it was unbelievable. Mix that with the curry and it was heaven! The braised short rib/ panang neua was also so perfect. The meat just falls right off the bone and getting a mix of the veggies made this dish a treat to eat. The blue rice was also a fun surprise, but it tastes like normal rice. I'd agree that the price point here is pretty pricey in my opinion with a lot of the entrees going for $15-$25, but the food does really speak for itself. 

Big big parties over 14 have a set menu and a price per head of around $50. So keep that in mind if you want to come here on your next big celebration :)
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Long awaited review! I made a reservation two days prior and was able to get a good dinner time. I checked again the next day and most slots were taken. 

Got to the restaurant 10 minutes before the reservation time and was seated right away. Everyone is so welcoming and friendly! The vibe of this restaurant is like no other. Very different from a traditional restaurant- loud, fun and beautifully decorated. 

I already knew what to order ! We got a beef roll (neua nim tok rolls), fried chicken and a green curry. Also got two drinks-mama San and a beer. 

Highlight of the dish was the fried chicken! Juicy, crunchy and was flavorful. I really like the blue rice and curry as well  

Babe liked his curry and the fried chicken. 

I really wanted to try out the peach jello drink. However they were out that day. I'm going back to try that, as well as the braised bone in short rib. 

My only complaint? They creep up on you to fill water, ask if everything is okay, etc. The restaurant is pretty loud and seats are close to each other, so you won't know they're there. I mean I guess.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Great foods, great drinks, overall a fun cultural experience.  It was my first time trying Thai food and I was not disappointed. 

I came here with friends last night and since I do not anything about Thai food, I let them do all the ordering.  We ended up getting a few dishes to share.  We got the fried calamari and chicken wings to start off.  Then for main dishes, we ordered the Fried Chicken, Pad Thai, and a curry dish.  All were excellent!  The calamari was very crispy and it was some of the biggest calamari I had ever seen.  The fried chicken came with delicious sweet and sour sauce and blue rice which I thought was very unique. The pad thai was delicious as always.  To end the meal, we shared the Thai Vacation dessert which is basically vanilla ice cream with coconut and sticky blue rice in a coconut shell.  I loved the little umbrella they put in it.  I loved everything I tried.  

All dishes are very aesthetically pleasing and very instagrammable if that's your thing.  The restaurant is also very lively and festive! 

The staff is very friendly and are willing to give out recommendations if you need them.  The food comes out really fast as well.  The staff came around to our table all the time to refill our waters throughout our entire meal.  

I recommend making reservations because it gets busy quickly!  We had 5:30pm reservations and that is the perfect time to come because it is right before the busy dinner hour.  

Farmhouse defiantly sets the bar high for Thai food.
author: Sara G.

description:
Dined with a friend I haven't seen in way too long. Probably not the best place to catch up, however. The atmosphere is raucous and loud, with decor that is in your face and lively. Beware the frequent birthday celebration parades that are noisy as hell and hard to ignore. 

I was hung up on having the Hat Yai fried chicken and while I enjoyed the dish that was served, I don't think it really captures the true Southern Thai fried chicken experience complete with sticky rice and extra fried shallots. The batter is a little too flaky and thin. Still delicious, however, and I love the presentation. 

We also ordered soup, a tom kha gai that was tasty. The server steered us away from ordering any more, but looking back, I wish we would have had a few more items!
author: Kelly Z.

description:
While the food here was good, I feel that it is a bit overpriced, and that most of the high price comes at how well presented the food items are. My meal looked gorgeous, and all the dishes were beautiful, but taste wise it is just standard, good quality Thai restaurant.

I had the Hat Yao Fried Chicken, and it was delicious! The curry sauce was very well made, and served as a perfect dipping sauce for both the chicken and the roti, which was also very well made.

The chicken was well fried and juice, the curry sauce was rich and savory, and the sweet and sour dipping sauce added a nice alternative taste to the dish.

Overall the food was delicious, just a bit pricey.
author: Tyler T.

description:
This place is amazing. 

HIGHLY recommend making reservations (they get booked really fast). They take walk ins but wait time can vary.. I would suggest getting there when they just open or shortly after to avoid the long wait. 

Everyone here is so nice & service is really quick. We didn't wait longer than 10 minutes until our food arrived. Everything was on point and spice level was just right. If you haven't been here, you need to go!! Best thai food in town!
author: Raiza C.

description: This spot is great! Good service, nice meal, and if it's your birthday they will sing loud to you! Will def be back!
author: LB D.

description:
Okay, where do I start...

First off, the service was unfortunately poor. The waiter had seated me (without greeting me) after leaving me hanging for about 10 mins at the door. Then, seated someone who came right after I did and seated the individual immediately and greeted him and took his order before me! Excuse me?! What is up with that. Am I an invisible Panda bear or something, geez... I used to serve plenty but c'mon it's common sense to go ahead and get the order and at least say "hi." 

Second off, I was told to hurry up and rush my order because the kitchen was going to close/shut down (still had just about an hour before closing lunch) with an unpleasant attitude and tone of voice. I understand, the servers are probably having a bad day or just don't want to be there but you're at work suck it up and leave the issues and nasty attitudes at home because I'm coming to pay for a service and food...

And lastly, the food...the food was good but not phenomenal or anything marvelous. The presentation was very pretty so I'll give credit for that. I ordered the "Hat Yai Fried Chicken." It's just about $22.50. It comes with fried organic chicken breast, roti bread, blue jasmine ice and yellow potato curry. The chicken was very tasty and well cooked. The curry was a bit disappointing as the temperature was more on the cold/warm side and very salty. But everything else was good! I recommend you try it. 

Hopefully next time I come the service will improve and it will be better overall. I am willing to come give it another try.
author: Jessica K.

description: I absolutely loved the food here! Definitely make a reservation beforehand because this place is PACKED. Everything from the food to the waitstaff's Thai boxing attire was beautifully Thai. The fried chicken and curry were amazing and FILLING. I would almost say you can share it. We also had the dessert board - the coconut ice and taro ice cream were my favorite! I will be coming back as soon as possible!
author: Alice L.

description: Food was ok. Papaya salad was tasty. Noodle Tom yum soup was lacking flavor and noodles were clumped together. Pork belly was good though a bit chewy which is not what I would expect for pork belly. So maybe they had a different chef tonight
author: Oliver C.

description:
I made a quick reservation on Yelp and was able to be seated quickly on a Saturday afternoon.  The place has many tables and a very festive vibe.  Here's a breakdown on the food:

1. Herbal Rice Salad - It's a complicated dish with almost 10 ingredients.  Definitely something I could not make at home!  Hearty dish, but not memorable enough to order again.
2. Ahi Scoops - Great appetizer to share.  It comes with 4 pieces with the following layers: seared ahi tuna, cucumber, seaweed salad, crispy yam.  It's best to eat all in one bite!  The flavors meld well together and the crispy yam gives great texture to the dish.
3. Khao Kha Moo - This was on the secret (or not so secret) menu of the day.  Braised fall off the bone pork, rice, vegetables, and boiled egg. The pork was very tasty, but unfortunately there were a lot of fatty pieces.  The dish came with a spicy sauce that I could not get enough of!  

I enjoyed the different variety of Thai foods that this place offers, but felt that $35 a person (no drinks) was pretty steep for what we ordered.
author: Helen T.

description:
Got the hat yai (fried chicken dish with curry) on takeout. The rice was blue, but otherwise tasted pretty standard. A lot of fried stuff on the chicken, flavorful yet not too spiced. Curry was really flavorful, unique smell, I really enjoyed this. Didn't like that the potatoes were giant chunks but no biggie. Goes well with the chicken, a bit hard to eat as takeout food.

Also got an order of raita and a pork belly side. The raita is crispy, sweeter in nature, not as chewy as the one at Rangoon Ruby. The pork belly side was tiny but the taste was spot on, light without any sort of pork flavor, a bit too crunchy for my personal tastes but I thoroughly enjoyed the chewy parts.
--

Edit: Man it's a party in here! Came by for dinner with a friend, and I've never really used the word "delightful" to describe a restaurant's attitude toward customer service, but that's what this place felt like. Upon being greeted by a waiter in bright eye makeup and shiny clothing, we were promptly escorted to our seats. 

We ordered the barbecue chicken and 24 hour beef noodle soup. They provide a plate of pickled veggies, which were tasty and refreshing on a hot day. Food arrived within 5 minutes of ordering, and portions were very generous (price point ~$20-25 for most dishes, with portion size being 1.5-2x your average portion). 

Pickled veggies were in a light sweet vinegar. Crunchy-ish and a good way to stimulate the palate. There was a tiny fly buzzing around, which was annoying, but it eventually went away.

They portioned the beef noodle soup into 2 bowls for us. The broth was a very dark brown, and had an acidity to it that reminded me of Chinese black vinegar egg and pork knuckles. Didn't really taste too much of beef to me, but you could definitely tell that there was a lot of time and depth that had been put into the broth. The beef was tender (strippy kind) and fell apart easily. Noodles were the thin egg kind, and a bit less memorable to me. [Edit: Upon eating leftovers, the broth was still a bit sour but less vinegary] 3.5/5.

The barbecue chicken (half) came on a giant skewer, with a healthy portion of green papaya salad on the side. The chicken and the skin were both pretty moist. The papaya salad was fresh and well seasoned. The sticky rice was a bit dry and very sticky. 3.5/5.

Atmosphere-wise, this was a blast. One of the waiters came through halfway with a carrying pole balancing two baskets, asking people if they wanted to try the special of the day (coconut worms). She had a bicycle horn she beeped to get peoples' attention. All the staff came out with various musical instruments to celebrate another patron's birthday. You could tell that they truly delighted in their jobs, which is always a plus.
author: Nicole H.

description: We had an incredibly fun and delicious dinner at Farmhouse Kitchen. The ambiance of the restaurant is lively and festive - there were two parties celebrating birthdays that night and a whole parade of staff came out each time, complete with drums and a dessert with a sparkler! The food comes out quickly, and the portions are big. I ordered the tom yum noodle soup and the spicy cabbage, and my dining companion got the fried chicken. The soup was amazingly flavorful and rich, and came with seafood, veggies, and a hefty portion of egg noodles. The cabbage was a nice vegetable complement, and was crunchy and spicy! Servers also come around during the meal with baskets offering little dishes which you can order.
author: Molly M.

description:
Came by with a friend. This place has a great atmosphere, attentive and nice staff. Saw them do a whole big todo for someone's birthday and it looked like fun. Definitely coming back. Service was fast and food tasted great. 

Price wise: one appetizer and 2 meals were about $63 w/o tip or drinks. A little pricey for lunch but all in all worth it.
author: Yasin S.

description:
If you need mid to high end Thai look no further because this is your place. 

Found it one afternoon after a weekend of traveling and hangovers while searching for a fresh coconut in the mission. So, if you are ever in the situation look no further as this is your place. 

However, beyond the coconuts I still love farm house. It is hip and new while still maintaining authentic food. I love the fresh spring rolls and their tom kha is to die for!

Cocktails would be the only thing I feel are somewhat lacking. They are a little too out there/ sweet for my taste. I would welcome if they did something more simple with coconut milk etc (kafir lime margarita?!) or had something even a little more spirit forward. However, these are all picky details since the take home is I love this place. 

Newly discovered tip:  they deliver for free via the yelp app! (You can thank me later)
author: Adele T.

description:
They accept reservations via yelp which is super helpful considering how popular Farmhouse is. 

I loved their Instagram-worthy plates and the vibrant energy of Farmhouse but the food can be a little bit overpriced and the restaurant is loud.

We ordered:
- Young coconut ($6.50) and Thai Tea ($5) to drink
-  24 hrs beef noodle soup ($24): The broth was a little bit salty, but the beef was fall-off-the-bone soft. The noodles were somewhat stuck together. 
- Mok salmon ($22): The presentation was great -- salmon comes wrapped in a banana leaf and you get blue jasmine rice on the side.
- Neua yang steak ($28): A little bit overpriced because the quality of the steak wasn't great and the sauce was overpowering. It's really fun when the waiter sets the steak on fire. I probably wouldn't order this again.
- Red curry ($15) add prawns ($4): The waiter will ask if you want rice, which is an extra $3. The curry had a great coconut flavor and wasn't too spicy.
- Papaya salad ($14) with prawns ($4): Really really spicy.
author: Kristina H.

description:
Came here for my birthday. The boyfriend reservations ahead of time 

Thai street Green curry noodles - very very good and packed full of veggies. Only complaint here is that it's way spicier than any green curry I've ever had. The noodles were a good , cool , compliment to the dish. Would order again if I can adjust the spice level!

Panang Neua (Panang beef short rib)  - so good. Parts of the meat were very tender and parts were dry but the curry sauce helps a bunch. It comes with a side of blue rice which we found to be more hard than brown rice, it was ok! Would probably order again!

Neua Nom tok rolls (Waygu beef rolls)  appetizer. Must order. The most tender beef. Would order again!

Hat yai fried chicken - my favorite dish. Perfectly fried chicken cutlet with the most yummy curry sauce and roti like discs. Soooo so good! It was the first dish to completely be devoured . We loved the sauce so much we also dipped the beef rib in it.

Thai iced tea - very good but the snow presentation isn't necessary. Felt like it was more for show- it didn't really compliment the drink (hard to drink with it on top!)

Dessert (don't recall the menu name but it was the Thai iced tea iced cream with a Thai wafer and whipped cream) ice cream was good and that's it. Would not order again!

Service was good. Attentive waitresses and waiters although I must say half of them didn't look very happy at all. 

I was embarrassed by the birthday song and dance but they are nice- they come out with a hat and lei (not for yours to keep!). The boyfriend mentioned that they did pressure him into ordering a dessert to do the song and dance though.
author: Karen H.

description:
Good food, shitty service. We had reservations for 7, only got in at 7:40. It was really upsetting having to wait outside for almost an hour, constantly being told that our table was almost ready. On our part, we did add 2 more people to the reservation, which might have thrown things off a bit. 
I ordered the Hat Yai fried chicken which was totally amazing, and samosas which were just as good (especially the sauce). Loved the Thai tea too. Everyone in the table (7 people) was really happy about the food.
However, my family said to them that it was my birthday 3 times and they kept saying they were going to sing. Nothing ended up happening, and we were super excited to see the waiters singing, until they ended up going to another group. Pretty disappointing. 
I will say the food was great. Very flavorful and presented nicely. Wish I could have enjoyed it more.
author: Leah Z.

description:
HMMM... not so sure I can agree with the 1000 plus yelpers here. We had Farmhouse bookmarked since we really enjoyed their Oakland (Daughter Thai) establishment. Came in on a Friday night, pretty early in the evening. Were seated in the furthest back wall table. Which is fine, we didn't have reservations, so can't complain. The entire place filled up quickly! 
The decor?  Look at the pictures... Southeast Asian all the way. The servers were fun to watch. . . and since I was facing the kitchen, I could see the workers in the back room. No frantic rushing... it was all very well choreographed service.
Our server came to our table quickly, but since we were first timers here, we weren't quite ready. She left, and it took quite a while for her to come back to us. 
The food:
Started with the Mieng Kum Kung - tiger prawns that were spectacular
Papaya Salad - This had good flavor, BUT warning!  I love spicy foods, and this salad was so extremely spicy hot that my tongue became numb. I actually ended not liking it because I could no longer taste anything.
Kai Sam Ros - this was a special chicken dish for the day. Basically, sweet/spicy chicken tenders with pineapple and served in a pineapple. Fun presentation. But, nothing really exciting for me. Topped it off with an order of Thai fried rice with veggies. 
It was a lot of food that we ordered. and the bill, with an iced tea and one beer, came to $90.
author: Greg S.

description:
Great decor and environment. Value difficult to assess as whole region is expensive, and depends on what you get. Would give 4.5 stars if allowed. Most dished $20 plus. Went with friends and tried several dishes. Favorite were Panang neua and panang curry. 
Kai yang, som tum: half organic BBQ chicken. It was good, I'd get it again.  

Khao soi kai: mixture of chicken and noodle stew. I thought the flavor was great and really liked the noodles. 

Pad char shrimp (red curry sauce, peppercorn, Kaffir lime, galangal, Karachi.): Dish looked big at first, but after I gave away 5 shrimp pieces, found I only had 2 left. Pretty salty and part of the dish was not that edible (like the peppercorn, galangal, seasoning stuff). Kaffir lime tasted OK. Prob won't get this again. 

Panang neua: slow braised bone in panang curry. That was really yummy and tender! 

Hat yai fried chicken: also yummy and recommended. 

Panang curry: with pork belly that was perfectly cooked and crispy on the outside. Went very well with the curry. Recommended as well.

They also came around dim sum style with specialty dish you can buy/sample and they sing for birthdays. Fun place.
author: Yi W.

description:
Omg. The kitsch. Such. Kitsch. In almost the best way.

I've been here twice in the last few months. The first time was as a function of needing food after boozing in the area, and Farmhouse came up on Yelp as close enough to stumble to. Thanks, yelp!

That time, I don't remember as much of the food as I did the environment. It was super dark (or my eyes were blurry from the booze). I had a relatively positive feel, and remember it being super loud there.  I do remember a fried pork thing in a dipping sauce (and a quick look at old pictures show that it DOES INDEED EXIST), which was delicious. Pretty sure we had some other noodle stuff, which was solid. I did mention that was a while ago, and I had been drinking, right??

The second time I went was more recent, and was for an early dinner. So I remember it all, and well!

Calamari - I'd skip unless you just need something fried (but then...go with the pork I remember). The squid was thick cuts of the rights, beer battered and fried. It was good, but not very special.

Kao Soi: Since having this in Chiang Mai, I've ordered it EVERYWHERE I've gone. But, alas, nowhere is as good as Chiang Mai. So grain of salt. This one was solid, and I liked the pickled veggies thrown in there. The balance of the noodles to soup was good, though I'd like a smidge more of the crunchy noodles. The soup was of a good flavor and salt for me to drink too.

24 hours beef noodle soup: This was crazy good. A little extra salty, but really delicious. I would bathe in that soup if I could. Or, maybe that's a waste of good broth. It was good. Worth the 2x cost for the noodles.

Both times I was here, I saw them bring out birthday celebrations and the kitsch goodness I mentioned before. Both times I was here, my dining companion said they wanted to bring another person over. Just for this birthday celebration/some dessert you order that comes with a show. 

Food - great. Environment - great. Service - awesome. CLEARLY a 5-worthy spot!
author: Lily W.

description: Never disappointed with the food here. Always great.
author: Michael N.

description:
Finally made it here after it has been on my bucket list for 5ever! I got the highly recommend Hat Yai Fried Chicken Plate, I would give it 4/5. First off it's $23, second, flavors are on point. The curry is absolutely heavenly, the rice is soft and fragrant, the chicken is hella oily, but what can you do? The paratha is amazing dipped in the curry. They also give a little sweet chili sauce to dip the chicken into.

MY ONLY COMPLAINT IS WHY DO THEY GIVE A LITTLE PUDDLE OF CURRY (It's literally less than an inch in depth, and the pictures look deceiving)???? GIVE MORE PLSSSSSSS.

Can't wait to come back and try other things on the menu.

P.S. It's like a huge party in here, they sing a lot of birthday songs with drums and instruments, so it can be a little hard to hear your dinner buddies.
author: Hanna M.

description:
Excellent food. But pricey for what it is. Would come again if portions were bigger. 

The southern fried chicken with the roti was great. So was the bread pudding.
author: Thomas L.

description:
This place is very unique. Honestly the most memorable part of this place was seeing a guy(server) in a halter top dress rambunctiously singing happy birthday to several tables. Definitely entertaining, but to some it may be disturbing.

The food was also memorable. I had the fried chicken, Thai iced tea, beef noodle soup, and one of the salads. It was really good, especially the 24 hour beef noodle soup!

However, this place is pricier than your typical Thai place, which is why I subtracted one star.
author: Andrea T.

description: Over hyped and got me over hyped, wagyu beef appetizer is a total fail because the beef tastes very chewy and way far from my expectation like "oh wow, $15 for wagyu beef appetizer!" We came on weekday so it was less crowded; definitely Thai Fusion and I still vote Lessro Thai is still my number one after all these years trying out Thai food from so many places! Slow braised beef and HatYai Fried Chicken sure taste awesome. Ahi Tuna Scoop is above average. Not bad experience at Farmer Thai.
author: Jenny N.

description: Great vibes, decent thai, but underwhelmed. Wished it was better. Still nice, but could be better. Pad thai was not the right flavors. Papaya salad didn't have enough flavor.
author: Aakash G.

description:
It was an ok meal... eh Not wonderful not too awful. But definitely would never ever ever recommend. I wouldn't go back for anything so I can't say three stars. Small portions for the prices especially given the fact that it's Thai. Since when are Thai portions small?? I get Thai like once a week and a friend told us we HAD to come here... none of us understood why after the meal. 

Ambiance is cool, loved the outfits. 

We got the green curry and didn't like it at all. Tasted off. 

The calamari had a neat sauce. But otherwise it was whatever 

Seafood rice was ok, but tasted weird with the bone broth. We used it for the weird green curry 

Phad Thai: I get this everywhere and this was the worst I've ever had. I was shocked. 

Tom kha kai: also get this everywhere and it was ok. Nothing compared To others I've had but not awful
author: Hayley G.

description: Good food with fair price. Its unfortunately a little too loud.
author: Wo Y.

description:
Let me say first and foremost that this was the most unique and vibrant Thai restaurant experience I've ever had, ever. A group of friends and I had reservations here for 6:30 on a Tuesday night, and the place was already filled with energy and lots of humans ready for some dinner.

I immediately noticed that the decor and ambience were unlike most restaurants: A tall blue wall was along the back of the room covered with rows of hose nozzles, there were plants hanging from the ceiling, television sets on one wall near the bar, and colorfully-clad waiters and waitresses in large hats and huge smiles on their faces sauntered about. 

The menu *really* impressed me, though. Which is probably what you're reading this for!

Farmhouse Thai's menu features an array of colorful cocktail mixes, and each is presented in a cheerfully gaudy manner that will make you beam when it's placed in front of you. Fair warning: It'll also make you want to try everyone else's drink at the table. 

My drink recommendation: The Mama-san, made of unfiltered sake, red wine, lemongrass, lemon, and orange bitters. I'm also a sucker for a drink with a flower in it, and the Mama-san made that happen.

Appetizer recommendations: Some waiters were walking around with what looked like mini hot air balloons, but in the baskets were different appetizers and foods to try. We saw fried chicken in one of the displays, which we ordered and tasted fantastic. I love this idea: Show me and let me smell your best treats, and I'll probably give in. We also ordered spring rolls which I will ALWAYS eat, and a rice salad complete with blue rice (!!!).
