For my entree, I ordered the beef salad. The waiter told me it'd be "slightly spicy" and asked if that was alright, to which I responded, "yes, that'd be fine!" Unfortunately I do not understand my own tolerance for spicy foods and it was a little spicier than I personally prefer... but I was warned! I mixed in some rice to spread out the spiciness a bit (if that's a thing? I'm bad at science.) But I was able to handle the dish a little better after that. The beef was juicy, the vegetables were cooked perfectly, and my Mama-san went perfectly with the meal. Yay!

Last but not least, dessert. There were several instances throughout the night in which the staff would emerge from the kitchen with a giant dessert platter, dancing and singing "happy birthday" to people at various tables. One of the people in my own party had a birthday coming up in the next few days, and someone was slick and made a birthday celebration happen at our table. This meant we got a lovely, upbeat song and dance, along with a mouthwatering dessert platter that included watermelon, chocolate lava cake, coconut shaved ice cream, and my absolute favorite, BREAD PUDDING. If you want just one dessert recommendation, bread pudding would be my go-to rec here! 

And finally, I always say I'm a sucker for a good aesthetic, and Farmhouse Thai's bathroom is a part of that fun aesthetic. I'm not sorry for pointing out how great the bathroom is! The walls are painted rainbow and there's a cute mini ladder that doubles as a toilet paper holder. There's only one toilet so lock the door behind you when you walk in, but there are two sinks because I think it used to be a multi-toilet bathroom. I tried to take a selfie but then I realized I was taking a selfie next to a toilet. But if I were good at taking selfies, this would be an ideal spot. Helloooooo, rainbow walls!

Anyway folks, I loved Farmhouse Thai for the exciting menu items, energy, and decorations that excite you, even in the bathroom!
author: Anna K.

description:
What a fun place! 

The waiters were dressed in strapless Thai style dresses, wearing very eye-catching accessories. The decor is true to the name - farmhouse, with a bit of Thai flavor.

The presentation of the dishes were very appetizing. We were also very entertained by their birthday celebration traditions. I'm definitely taking a friend who's never been here for their next birthday! 

Tom Kha Soup with Chicken was very flavorful, the coconut soup was mild and soothing. The amount of chicken was pretty generous. 

We also got the popular Hat Yai Fried Chicken. Obviously you have to get the blue rice. The potato yellow curry for dipping was very rich in flavor - it's been haunting my dreams. I'm not sure what they did to the chicken breast but the texture was very relaxed - along with the super crispy outside, you just can't get enough! even though they give you a really big piece already...
author: Iris H.

description:
Uhm, wow. This is hands down the most unique Thai place I've ever been to! Definitely one of the most standout dining experiences I've had as of late.

From the outside, Farmhouse doesn't look like much. Looks very hole-in-the-wall, but those are always the places that are the best. However, I was super surprised to step into a restaurant that was trendy, eclectic, and a bit artsy! 

One of the first things that I noticed was that one of the employees, a male employee, was dressed in a colorful hat, a red corset, had makeup on... He was doneeee uppppp, girl. Fast forward through the rest of the night and he was the star of several happy birthday performances (we saw three, including one at our own table!)  All of the employees were in bright clothing, and all equally very kind people, but they definitely stood out! 

I was here for a team dinner, so we opened up with ordering several apps to share. The appetizer that stood out to me the most was the egg plant & bell pepper dish - I'm not sure of the actual menu name. I think that might've been my first time having eggplant... And it was SO god damn good. So much flavor. I could've had a whole dish of that! 

I ended up getting Chicken Pad Thai (I know, basic) for my entree as that's usually a safe option. It was really good. Not overwhelmed with peanuts, tender & flavorful chicken, and deeeelicious flavor! I nearly ate all of it! 

I got a Thai Iced Tea as well, which came with shaved ice in it (which I didn't realize was described on the menu). At first I was annoyed because you have to drink the tea down a little to make sure it doesn't overflow with the shaved ice + regular ice. However, once you drink it down and mix that ice in, it's super yum.

Farmhouse isn't just a place to get good food - it's a place to dine and be entertained. There's a ton going on (it's borderline chaotic), and it just makes for a really fun time!
author: Lauren P.

description:
I actually mean for this to be a 3.5, but overall I think that this place was way too hyped up for me. The flavor of the food was okay, sometimes a little too salty, sometimes not enough flavor. Overall, I just thought it was okay, and maybe I just went on a bad night.
- Penang Neua: This was sooo salty too me. If they had just laid off the salt a little bit, this dish would be so much better.
- 24 Hour Beef Noodle Soup: I think that the flavor in this soup was very basic. it honestly didn't even taste like authentic thai food in my opinion. There was not much garlic flavor at all even though it said "pork fat garlic oil"
- Hat Yai Fried Chicken: This was definitely my FAVORITE dish of them all, and I actually really liked this dish. The curry was good, and it went really well with the roti bread. The fried chicken was also very tender.

I would definitely try this place again to see if I just went on a bad night for some reason.
author: Amanda C.

description:
My absolute favorite Thai Restaurant in the city! The ambiance is very colorful, festive, and also has a fun quirkiness factor to it. Once you walk into the restaurant, you might feel like you're at a club with all the loud music and wondrous lights. It's no wonder that this place will still has lines out the door on a Thursday night at 9:00 PM!

Some of my favorite dishes include the Hat Yai Fried Chicken (the blue rice is phenomenal and that curry dipping sauce is addicting!), 24 Hour Beef Noodle Soup (Rich flavor and the meat literally falls off the bone so easily), Pad See Ew, Pad Thai, and the Samosas. You really can't go wrong with any of the dishes here because they all taste great!

I recommend coming here in a small group since the portions are huge and meant for sharing. My boyfriend and I ordered 1 appetizer and 2 main dishes and we still had enough food to feed us for lunch the next day!
author: MyTien P.

description: Absolutely amazing food, with incredible way of presenting food, the place has a super cool decoration, servers have funny clothes and everything about it is incredible. This is one of SF hidden gems. Good for celebrations but also casual friend meet ups
author: Maria O.

description:
So fun. And so delicious. Farmhouse Thai pretty much nails it on all levels. This well-known Thai eatery packs 'em in and pleases 'em all, whether it's service, flair, style, or flavor... there's a lot going on in this package. 

First off, it's crazy in here. Just like the vibe in Thailand. It's loud, hectic, colorful, crowded, and packed with sensory overload. If you want a subdued romantic spot for dinner, this ain't it. Those in the know make a reservation, those that don't wait a while for a table. The staff is dressed in a riot of color, and the decorations are a mish-mash of styles and elements. It's all around fun. 

The food? Legit. It's not your average collection of stoplight curries. Sure they have red/green/yellow on the menu, but they're not the center of attention. The real fun is found in the more unique dishes, like the bone-in short-rib slow-cooked with Penang curry. Or the slow-cooked beef noodle soup. The Hat Yai chicken is pretty amazing (although not quiiiiiite as good as the Hat Yai at Hat Yai in PDX... just sayin'). The papaya salad offers fermented crab and fermented fish options - not for the faint of heart/palate. And while they do have a regular pad Thai, farang-style, the better version comes with the grilled river prawns. 

I could go on and on about each dish on the menu. I've had many, and they're all great. I've never had a bad or even mediocre experience here, and I can't imagine anyone else having less than an excellent time either.
author: Don B.

description:
Can someone please take me here on my birthday? 

This is definitely the most interesting Thai restaurant I've been to - and I mean that in the best way! 

As soon as I walked in, I was greeted by a host who was filled with energy and dressed in traditional Thai attire. They also had a little Photobooth area by the check-in stand, which was already a little more interesting than your average Thai restaurants. 

As soon as we sat down, I looked around the restaurant and took in the vibrant energy of the restaurant. The staff seemed super excited to be there and were all full of life. 

A few minutes after we sat down, I noticed one of the workers carrying fried chicken on her shoulders in a way that seemed to be mimicking street food in Thailand - umm..that was cool! 

As far as my entree goes, I decided to go for the Hat Lai Fried Chicken - it was highly recommended to me by my fellow colleagues, and I'm glad I took their advice! My entree came with a curry with potatoes, along with the fried chicken, and blue rice - yes, I said BLUE rice! I don't know exactly what they did to make the rice turn blue, but it sure was amazing. I mean, the overall entree put together seemed well thought out. 

The best part about the evening was when the staff congregated around one of my colleagues to sing "Happy Birthday" to him. Let me just say that it is definitely a special way to sing happy birthday to someone at a restaurant. It all makes a full circle as to why I want to come here for my birthday sometime in my lifetime!
author: Margaret P.

description:
I did not expect this place to be so...THAI.  It's a very interesting experience to have dinner here, almost to the point of being gimmicky/cheesy.  I can't quite explain it.  Don't let that sway you from coming here: the food is AMAZING and the atmosphere is something worth checking out, it's very lively. The decorations are a bit eccentric.  We sat next to a wall of water faucets...but you know what, it goes with the place.

DINNER
Kai yang, som tum:  BBQ chicken, papaya salad & colored sticky rice
Pad thai with chicken

I definitely want to try some of the other food, especially the hat yai that comes with their famous blue rice. What we had was delicious and everything else looks good too.  Also, if you're celebrating a birthday, come here.  You'll be in for a treat.  It'll be like you're at a Chevy's in Thailand.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Ordered the seafood tom yum noodle soup. Not sure how 3 pieces of 2 inch fried salmon, 3 squid rings, noodles and bean sprouts is expected to be filling and called a full size meal.

Requested for it to be extra spicy and it hit the mark. Was not happy with the portion sizes and clearly expected more from a place that has such high ratings. Will definitely give it a try again sometime soon.
author: Carmen P.

description:
Right off the back, it was noticeable how energetic and quirky this place was.  The staff were wearing bright outfits, the dining room was really lively, and someone received a super exuberant birthday song just as we were sitting down.  

The menu had a lot of options to choose from in addition to waiters walking around with carrying poles featuring the special of the night.  It seemed a bit like Dim Sum.  We ordered the Thai green curry noodles and the Panang Neua.  The green curry noodles was really good.  But, the Panang Neau was amazing.  The slow braised short rib was super tender and had great flavor with the addition of the Panang curry.  It didn't hurt that this dish included blue rice giving this dish a lot of color, great for photos.  

Overall, I really enjoyed this place.  The food was great and the atmosphere was super quirky.  We even got a free apron with a recipe for ordering the curry noodles.  The only knock I had against this place was that our waitress was so soft spoken, it was hard to hear her in the lively dining room.  But, after such a great experience, this was the least of my worries.
author: Mitch T.

description:
wanted to come here so bad but it didn't live up to the hype. loved the lively environment and the decor but the food fell a little short of amazing. 

HAT YAI CHICKEN (3 stars) - comes with fried chicken, rice, roti, and curry. curry was really good and the outer layer of the chicken was so crispy but the chicken didn't have any flavor at all. you're supposed to dip it in this sweet sauce but even with the sauce, you can still taste the blandness of the chicken... not a fan. 

24 HOUR BEEF NOODLE SOUP (3 stars but 4 stars for the beef itself) - i enjoyed this dish but there wasn't that much flavor to it. it was just salty. the beef was amazing though. the bone just fell off and the beef was so tender. 

TOM YUM SOUP (2 stars) - don't even bother getting this... i loved tom yum soup but like their beef noodle soup, it was just salty. i always thought tom yum soup was supposed to be a mixture of sweet, sour, spicy and salty but this does not seem to be the case here. 

tl;dr i wouldn't come back. for the price of their dishes and the absent wow factor, this was a disappointment.
author: Yan L.

description:
My group of 6 had reservation for 8:15 PM on a Wednesday night. I definitely recommend taking an Uber/Lyfting there since parking was a hassle. We ended up parking pretty far away. We waited about 10 minutes to be seated. Surprisingly, this place was packed for a Wednesday night. If you don't have reservations, expect to wait a while. 

The restaurant itself is pretty tiny and from the moment we walked in, it felt like we stepped into Thailand. [Or so my group said so since they all recently went to Thailand]. The waiters are dressed in Hawaiian shirts and the whole restaurant has a "tropical" theme to it. 

The whole experience was very authentic. They had people walking around offering different types of food on carts (cheese ragoons and fried grasshoppers). My table ordered the Fresh Vegan Rolls to start us off. I was expecting a couple of small rolls, but they were pretty large and cut up in bite size pieces on a bed of peanut sauce! 

I ordered the Panang Curry with Tofu and the regular rice (blue). The curry was delicious! It was SPICY! So beware - I'm also a wimp when it comes to spice so there's that. But to my surprise, the portions were small (not family sized like a lot of Thai places). So order for yourself. I finished my Panang Curry and rice. I was pretty full and didn't order dessert but the portions are definitely doable for yourself.

Overall good experience and delicious! I'll be coming back for sure.
author: Joscelynne R.

description: Colorful food - very insta worthy. We ordered dishes that were fried and a bit too greasy for us but this is a nice thai place. Go for dinner - not lunch! During lunch, you will not be able to try to silk worms or crickets.
author: Kaitlynn L.

description:
Farmhouse kitchen was an incredible find. The food was perfect, the ambience is original, and the place is just so energetic. We started with tom yum soup and had green curry with prawn, pad ka pow with minced pork. They were all fantastic. They also offer pickled veggies for free. Mango sticky rice and bread pudding were also mind blowing. I also strongly recommend the coconut water. I think Farmhouse kitchen and Sai Jai Thai are the two contenders for best Thai food in the area. 

Farmhouse kitchen is a great place if you are looking for great Thai food and enjoy some lively atmosphere.
author: Doruk B.

description: We made a reservation for six at 5:30pm on a Saturday. They only seat parties when everyone is present. Farmhouse Kitchen seems like a popular spot for large groups, and was pretty full when we arrived. Farmhouse Kitchen is basically a more upscale Thai restaurant, with the staff dressed in traditional garb and the funky colorful decor. We ordered numerous dishes to share. The papaya salad had a decent kick to it. My favorite was probably the crab fried rice. Although the showstopper of the night was the rice that came with the curry, which was inexplicably blue! To this day I'm not sure why or how. Although not Thai at all, I liked the sweet and soft bread pudding dessert. The flavors were not too different than the average Thai restaurant in the Bay Area, of which there are many, but the environment is elevated so it'd be a good spot for a date night or special night out with friends. It appeared as if Farmhouse Thai might also be a popular spot to pre-game for going out as they have festive drinks in large containers with multiple straws. The most amusing part of the dining experience was watching the staff strut out with gongs and various other loud clanging instruments to sing someone happy birthday. For the amount of food we ordered as well as nice plating and ambiance, the price was very reasonable at ~$30 per person.  Would be a fun destination for a happy hour type outing.
author: Amy G.

description:
This place had delicious food with a decent price! We got an appetizer along with our entrees and it was perfect. The broth was great and savory and the ingredients tasted fresh. Inside is pretty large, but the tables are pretty close together so it can fit a ton of parties. This means it does get a little loud. 

The only negative thing about my review it that the service was so slowwww. I understand that there is a lot of people and it was crowded, but it took about 45 minutes for us to get our food. Other than that, the food was great.

Ambiance: 3.5/5
Food: 5/5
Service: 3/5
Overall Experience: 3.5/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Discovered this place on my way to taking the workshop tour at Heath Ceramics today. It was super busy for lunch, and when I came back for dinner later, it was still busy, with people waiting outside.

OWNER, PLEASE TAKE NOTE:

This may have actually been a 5 star one for me, had I not felt so rushed by the staff.
I totally understand the importance of the turning of tables, but I'm a paying customer too. Staff was omnipresent, chipping at the bit to quickly whisk away your food once you set your utensils down. As I was signing the check, the host came and told me they had another reservation waiting for the table. Look, buddy, I'm by myself eating just a bowl of noodles, for $23.95 no less, and I'm already signing the bill! Don't be overly money grubbing, or this will backfire and word will spread by word of mouth and all over Yelp! I'm willing to overlook it this time, because there was much I liked, but I really hope this isn't a standard business practice.

AMBIANCE: Super lively, hip and fun. Cool, modern, elevated decibels, but still fine for chatting.  I really liked the vibe here! Granted, I was here on Friday night, so I'm not sure if this is typical, but this place sure seems popular!

FOOD:  24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup. I'm positive Fred Flinstone dines here. If you order this, you'll know what I mean. Or just check out my photos of this dish, and you'll see why I stated this. The broth was slightly sweet, and filled with a good amount of fresh crunchy celery and celery leaves. And that hunk of meat...Well, I literally just used chopsticks, and the perfectly braised meat effortlessly separated off the bone. Ok, I'm a believer that this really took 24 hours to prepare.

MUST KNOW:  You'll be asked if you prefer your dish prepared with no spice, mildly spicy or very spicy. I decided on mild, and I'm sure glad I did. Unlike the majority of Thai restaurants in the Bay Area that tend to lower their level of spiciness to accomodate the American pallette, Farmhouse reminds me of the spiced up foods I've had in Bangkok. Translating to self - "Keep it mild, if you actually want to taste the flavors of the food, and complete your meal without going through wads of tissues to blow your nose with. Don't you dare go beyond mild! Hear me"?

EXOTICS: There was a waiter, in traditional Thai garb, offering cooked grasshoppers from a basket that he had around his neck. Now, I love my deep fried foods, but I passed on this one. In retrospect, they may have been wok fried. Whatever, irrelevant for me when it comes to grasshoppers!

I'll be back to try their other dishes, for sure! But no grasshoppers, keep it mild, and please don't rush me!
author: Lori N.

description:
​
After a couple visits I can confirm that all the hype is true and this is indeed likely the best Thai restaurant in SF (or anywhere I've been for that matter, which has not included Thailand).

The vibe is energetic and fun, from the decor to the staff and music. But most importantly, the food is de-lish! The paratha is phenomenal, almost certainly thanks to the extra butter or oil to give it that crispness and taste of indulgence. On my last visit I opted for the yellow curry with tofu and a side of rice (which is blue). The curry flavor is really unrivaled - I take a few spoonfuls plain just to bask in its deliciousness. If you're decently hungry, it's plenty of food for one, especially if you put a dent in the rice.

Properly full, we opted to take a mango sticky rice to-go to enjoy later in the evening. It wasn't in season on our last visit in December, which was disappointing, but after tasting how perfectly ripe the mango was, I can admire how they only want to serve the best. Not usually a fan of sticky rice (I'm pretty adamant that rice is not a dessert), this black rice, coconut milk, sesame, and mint won me over. I liked it much more than the "Thai Vacation" coconut with sticky rice, ice cream, and other toppings.

They have lots of inventive cocktails, beer, and wine, but no hard liquor. Not a problem for me as I'm happy to lap up a Thai Iced Tea topped with a ball of shave ice or sip on a whole coconut.

Do yourself a favor and make a reservation on Yelp, as there aren't a ton of tables and the wait can be a bit given its popularity.
author: Cristina S.

description:
This is far and away the best Thai place I've ever been to.  The decor is outstanding and very San Francisco- avant-garde artwork in the walls, and the outside of the building is covered in vines like an urban farm.  The host wears authentic Thai clothing and greets everyone with a smile.  

As for the food- it's just downright amazing.  They have some of the best samosas I've ever had, mixed drinks were great, but the main course just blew me away.  I got the Masaman Gai, which is a combo with masaman curry chicken, anchan (blue) rice, fried roti, and salad.  The curry was amazing and flavored with just a hint of cinnamon, the roti was delicious, and the blue rice was really cool, although it tastes mostly just like coconut rice.  Even the cucumber salad was good and I normally hate that stuff.  

Truly an incredible experience and I'm absolutely going there again next time I'm in town.
author: John F.

description:
Ambiance
Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Cuisine has a flair to it.  All the staff are in tropical gear. There was a birthday that happened while we were there and they had an interesting birthday song for them. It's over the top in a good way.  It is good for a group dinner as they have ways to make a long table. 


Food
The food is delicious. Definitely try and get a group to get the kickboxing bowl. Loved it.  We had the fish cake, oysters, wings, pad Thai, khao soi, and hat yai fried chicken.  Our favorite was the khao soi. 


Service
They have very good customer service.  Always on top of taking away dishes, refilling our water, and coming back for any other asks.
author: Simon N.

description:
3.5 stars. One time I went to Guam and sat on the beach with my friends, sipping on a coconut. Some kid came by to try having a conversation while selling us some beaded necklaces. He was in our faces and persistent, but we finally caved in, much to our chagrin.

That's kind of how I felt at Farmhouse Kitchen Thai. I've been wanting to come here for awhile, but the experience doesn't compel me to return. Don't get me wrong. The food is good. It's just the service I didn't quite fancy, but I don't want to offend anyone if it's a cultural thing. The atmosphere was hectic, and I felt rushed to get in, eat, then get out.

I made reservations for dinner with Nina Y. Thank goodness, because there's no way we would have gotten a table within an hour during busy time. We still had to wait, though. Once we sat down, we quickly decided what we wanted. I got a small bowl of Tom Yum soup and the beef rolls.

It was the perfect amount of food, but I should have specified to have the beef rolls and Tom Yum soup come out at the same time. Instead, the beef rolls came out first (because they were under the appetizer section of the menu) and I was just awkwardly eating by myself while we waited for the other two items. They were good, though! Surprisingly spicy. My mouth is watering while typing this.

While eating the beef rolls, someone came around and said something quickly. I nodded, thinking they were asking how things were, but he put a salad on our table and walked away. I was like wtf. I felt so swindled and didn't realize what was going on. But it was too late. We were already charged. It turned out to be only $5 but still.

The crawfish and fruit salad was insanely spicy. Interesting flavors. I wouldn't have ordered it myself. Not on purpose, anyways. The Tom Yum soup was spicy too, of course, and it was the perfect amount. What would have been a perfect ending is mango with sticky rice... but they didn't have the dish. Maybe it's not an authentic Thai dessert. Anyways, that was the biggest disappointed, which I drank off at a nearby bar afterwards.

Anyways, I'm glad I came here to try Farmhouse once since I've heard so many good things about it, but there are other Thai restaurants around San Francisco I prefer... that have equally good food and a far better customer and culinary experience.
author: Stefanie C.

description: So disappointed in Farmhouse Kitchen after wanting to try it for a couple of years. We wanted a light little lunch and a couple of beers. We ordered the Chicken Fried Rice and two beers. When they served us Corina and I looked at each other in puzzling ways. The serving was super small. It had good flavor and wasn't overcooked. But......The serving size sucked. Plus, it came to $32. Would have been $10 less in any Thai restaurant in our area and there would have been 2 or 3 times more rice. Screw you Farmhouse Kitchen.
author: Bruce S.

description: The wait was really long , over 30 min. And we had reservations. We had to bug the hostess to have us seated. The food was average. The next day I had major stomach cramps
author: Asmara H.

description:
Saw this place on Check Please a bunch of years ago. The short rib and the chicken were calling my name.

It is way over in Protero Hill in a neighborhood I have never visited.

We went here fairly early on a Saturday afternoon. It was Thai New Year week, so it was "extra" decorated. 

The service is efficient, Though there wasn't a lot of food travelling around the restaurant as was mentioned in reviews and on Check please. The only thing brought by the table for sale was the Cotton Candy ($4) and we were not interested in that.

I had wanted to try the coconut rice pudding for dessert but was way too full.
author: Amy W.

description:
As a Thai person, it pains me that place is priced as $$$.

I get it!  If Italians, Frenchmen, New Americans, Japanese, Koreans, 
etc... can charge what they define as elevated cuisine... Thais can do it too.  Besides me complaining about the price, the food....

The food is tasty and as authentic as you could get in Thailand.  The restaurant atmosphere is lively, hip, fun, super cool and just place you wanna go to and have a fun night out with friends, a date or just want an adventure.  

I have never paid so much for crab fried rice in the US or even in Thailand but you know what, the restaurant is giving you chucks of silky and lushy clumps of crab in your fried rice.  The rice to crab ratio is actually about even. If you afraid of Thai food, the crab fried rice is a nice start before being adventurous to the other parts of the menu.

Hat Yai Fried Chicken... hmmz... the presentation of this dish totally grabs your attention, it is just too many things going on one platter for me.  I am sure to non Thai people, this is a dope dish.

Thai Iced Tea... I would skip it... order something alcoholic instead.  Those drinks looked hella FUN.

SOmetimes in the middle of a meal, some one comes around as a street vendor asking you if you want to try a $3 sample, do it!!!! We tried a tasting of Moo Ping (marinated pork on a stick), spicy dipping sauce and sticky rice.  It was SOOOOOOOOOOO good.  It totally reminded me of Thailand.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
Went here with my aunt to grab a late lunch on a Friday afternoon. It was almost 2pm, so we were able to be seated right away.

After perusing the menu we decided to split a few items--the vegan fresh rolls and the Hat Yai fried chicken.

The vegan fresh rolls we just ordered on a whim and were pleasantly surprised by how delicious they were. The outside wrap was so soft and pillowy and paired nicely with the peanut sauce--definitely a must-order.

The Hat Yai fried chicken--one of their specialties, was also outstanding. The chicken was super tender and juicy and had great flavor. In addition, the rice, roti, curry, and other ingredients were all super yummy.

Overall, this is definitely one of the best Thai places I have ever been to and is worth the trip if you are in search of fantastic Thai food. The service was friendly and attentive and the food came out quickly. Prices were also reasonable as the dishes were both quite large.
author: Ryan R.

description:
Everything about this place is spectacular. The interior is very festive, service spot-on, and the food delicious! We went with the crispy pork belly salad, hat yai chicken, Panang curry, and pad Thai. The flavors of each dish did not disappoint!

Definitely try the crispy pork belly salad (yum moo krob) and the hat yai chicken. The hat yai chicken is a generous serving for one person, so share if you're willing! Chicken is super crispy and you get roti to mop up your yellow curry. I honestly don't think you can go wrong with any of the dishes, I personally have yet to try the panang neua and it's definitely next on the list for me. 

If you've been to Thailand and want to reminisce on how flavorful the cuisine is, go here! Or if you love Thai food and want a new place to try, go here! Maybe you haven't had a good experience with Thai food, if so then go here! Or maybe you've spent your whole life eating a bland diet and want to know what it means to add color to your life, then go here!
author: Christene M.

description:
Chicken very juicy and tender but bones. Noodle curry insanely tasty. Curry tasty. Hard to eat but in. Lots of veggies wish the chicken was boneless. Good atmosphere even in the afternoon. Good service they honored our reservation even though we ewere 30 mins late (LOL) and kitchen was closing.
Parking impossible to find. Funny music. They have a bar.
author: Arjan N.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen Thai is more of an experience, so I wouldn't do take out. I came here for dinner last night (my second time here), and the servers were all dressed in intricate bejeweled Thai clothing, drums and Thai music boomed in the background as they wished someone a happy birthday, and of course the restaurant was packed with people and a line at 9pm on a Thursday, so my bf and I opted for bar seating. My senses were overloaded in a good way, and the food, besides the popular fried chicken, was a bit too salty for me. Excellent vibes, but okay food. 

Food:
-Hat Yai Fried chicken: definitely order this dish! The fried chicken is amazing, crispy, tastes like it's coated with coconut (don't quote me on this), and is served with roti, curry dipping sauce with 2 potatoes, blue rice, and a sweet and sour sauce. I recommend dipping everything in the curry sauce. You definitely get a variety in this dish.

-Shrimp dish: we ordered a shrimp dish that came with bell peppers and a mound of blue rice. It was too salty and flavorful even with the rice. We didn't like this one.

Drinks:
- Thai tea: Yum! Can't go wrong with this classic. It's photogenic with an ice bomb too.

-Elderberry cocktail: I can't remember the specific name, but this drink is cute, small, and pretty, topped with lime and a flower. Very unique and tasty.

The total was a little under $70. A little on the pricier end for Thai food, but definitely worth a visit for the chicken and atmosphere. 

Tip: Coming for lunch? This place closes at 2pm and reopens at 5pm. Don't make a booboo like me and book at 1:30 pm because parking can be hard.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Hooolllllyy prices here are high, even for San Francisco, however...

I came here by myself on a Saturday as it was around the corner from Mission Cliffs. From the outside and the name you wouldn't have thought that it was a Thai restaurant. The outside was extremely pretty and the inside was even prettier. I was given the option for a table or the bar and was seated at the bar since I was just by myself. The waiter placed down a menu and gave me a few minutes to look. Almost all the tables were filled and there was loud Thai music blasting. 

I really wanted to order the Thai Iced Tea as it had a ball of shaved ice sitting on top which was different than anything I've seen anywhere else... But I had just gotten a deep tissue massage and my blood pressure was extremely low (dizzy and slightly nauseated) - so I just opted for a Vegetable Pad See Ew. 

Whenever I try a new Thai place, I either generally get a Pad See Ew or a Pad Thai before I try anything else - if they can't get the basics right, how can I trust anything else on the menu?

My food came, pretty average portions, plating wasn't very pretty either for $15.50... but dang was it good. The soy sauce flavor was spot on and wasn't sour like many other subpar Thai places I've been to. There were plenty of vegetables mixed in with the noodles so there were not just a couple pieces of broccoli and the rest were noodles. The only sad thing was since I wasn't feel so hot, I could only take 2 bites before I had to stop (to no fault of the restaurant). One of the waitresses noticed that I wasn't really eating my food and came over and asked whether I was enjoying my meal. 

I asked for a to-go and also if they had Mango Sticky Rice (my obsession) - She put the order in for me and after a while came back to check on me and went to the kitchen and came back with my order. My bill came out to be $27 for a Pad See Ew and Mango Sticky Rice pre-tip. 

When I got home and felt better, I devoured the Pad See Ew and the Mango Sticky Rice. The sticky rice was BLUE! (so pretty...) and the mango was ripe and the coconut milk was thin and pleasantly sweet without being sticky and thick and overly sweet. 

Despite the high prices and I live nowhere near the mission and rarely come to this area, I would definitely go out of my way and come back because it was one of the best Pad See Ews I've ever had and I really want to try the Thai Tea.
author: Judy H.

description:
First time here for my buddy's bday.
Heard great things about this place.

I have to say this is one of the best Thai Restaurant in SF!  

Services was great! 

Will definitely be back.
author: Mack A.

description:
Good spot, but more appropriate for drinks or a night out. The food was solid, and the service was ok, but it did seem a little pricey. Tried green curry noodles and also the wagyu steak.

Wouldn't be the priority spot for super authentic Thai food, but it is obvious that the chef/staff puts effort into making the dishes tasty. The green curry was flavorful and went well with the noodles/veggies it came with. On the other hand, the steak was tasty, but the dip was a killer. Steak itself was good, but again, I would say a little overpriced. My real issue was with the service. I felt like we were being rushed out of the restaurant right when we got there, and sure i understand if there is a huge line outside, but toward the end there were open tables yet we were still rushed out. Overall a fun and tasty place to try!
author: Raymond F.

description:
Had a fantastic time here, definitely not your ordinary neighborhood Thai restaurant. I'm a big fan of all the photogenic details, faucet wall, trinkets from Thailand, as well as the artfully presented food. Defiinely date night worthy. 

Went to a surprise birthday party here for a group of 10 and our menu was their most popular dishes. Here's some of my favorites. 

- Chicken wings - Best in the city. Crispy, juicy, plump, flavorful and the sweet chili plum sauce brings the Thai-ness to the dish. Must order. 

- Herbal rice salad - Loved the contrast in colors and textures of this dish. toasted coconut, shredded green mango, crispy shallots, purple rice, etc make for a memorable dish. 

- Panang Neua - The slow braised bone in short rib with the panang curry sauce was incredibly tender. Recommended. 

- Hai Yai fried chicken- It was like a flying saucer of light and crispy deliciousness, the curry dipping sauce for the roti had good flavor as well. 

- Thai chelada - crisp and refreshing like it's Mexican cousin but uses Singha beer instead. 

What earned the 5th star for me was their dessert and when about 5 staffers they came out to sing Happy Birthday with a drum. It was awesome, had everyone laughing, and definitely made for a memorable birthday. 

The dessert platter had macarons, fresh shaved coconut, cantaloupe, molten lava cake, and this sweet black rice with lychee and gelatin cube ice with cream.
author: Earl G.

description: Great food that's very unique in terms of flavor. Not the common dishes that you find in run of the mill Thai restaurants. Interesting ambience . Very well priced with large portions.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Good food and super good environment!
The food is a little bit pricer than the usual but the size deserved it. 
I order the special fired chicken. The cover of the fired chicken is pretty thick but it kept the chicken soft and juicy! The curry is good with the chicken and the rice!
Impressed by the environment it's so pretty and comfortable!
author: Yantong Z.

description:
Anytime I'm greeted by a man wearing red lipstick and (what I assume is) traditional women's clothing from Thailand, I know I'm in for a good night. At the surface, Farmhouse Kitchen might look like a hoky (Thai) dining experience. But with the truly flavorful food and an atmosphere that couldn't be replicated elsewhere, what Farmhouse Kitchen yields is a remarkable dining experience.

First things first, let's booze it up. I ordered the Makram (Hahn Fire Soju, FH Tmarind Shrub, Bittermens Habanero, CO2- Don't ask me what any of this means). The Makram starts on your tongue as a refreshing summer drink and ends with just enough sting to remind you that you ordered a spicy drink that packs a punch. I also sampled a friend's "Coconut Island" (Carpano Antica Vermouth, Dolin Blanc, Coconut Cream, Lemongrass, Lemon), which unsurprisingly tastes like vacation.

Liquored up? Let's add in some carbs and enough curry to make you feel even warmer on the inside. I ordered the Panang Curry (basil pepper, basil, crispy yam). If you're sensitive to spice, I might direct you elsewhere. It's not an overwhelming heat, but it's the kind of spicy that builds. Coated over the blue rice (what makes it blue? no idea, but it's delightful), The Panang Curry is a warming (and quite spicy) comfort food that I cannot recommend enough.

If you're gonna get wet, you may as well go swimming. Time for dessert. I have never cared for bread pudding and always found it to have a repulsive consistency. Farmhouse Kitchen made me a believer. The bread pudding at Farmhouse Kitchen was the right consistency and the perfect amount of sweet and savory. If someone in your party is having a birthday you're in for a real treat, I won't say anymore than that.

tl;dr: Go to Farmhouse Kitchen, eat curry, eat bread pudding, be happy.
author: Tyler M.

description:
My friends were in that starving rush decision making and so went here since we saw "thai" - we had no idea what we were getting in to.

Once you walk in, you see how fun the place is. The decor of the place is vibrant and the energy of everybody was on high. We probably should have reserved through Yelp but since we walked in and loved in, we made of the most of our hour wait and grabbed drinks nearby.
First off we got the kick bowl since drinking out of a large container is always fun It was a lot for four people and I think is a hefty endeavor for any party less than that as the couple next to us left theirs half full (wimps.) The food itself was great. We had pad thai, pad see ew and a red curry. Flavorful and everyone's dish tasted great.

This place is a must for celebrations as the entire wait staff makes a spectacle of it and it was really fun even though my table wasn't celebrating anything.
It's a pretty big turnaround place as the wait can stack up, wouldn't go here for a long conversation times. My friends and I needed to catch up and definitely felt watched - though understandably
author: Stephen P.

description:
This review is LONG overdue for me. Heard about this place through the grapevine and thought that some basic b's were confusing this restaurant for Farmerbrown -- this place has had mad hype since its opening and I can see time and time again just why that is!! Farmhouse is def a must-go on my SF foodie list, and never fails to impress the folks that I bring over. 

I'm adding some photos from my most recent visit for a birthday dinner. We got the ahi scoops, the beef noodle soup, the staple hat yai fried chicken and the mango sticky rice.  Quality is on point every time: tuna is flavorful, beef is brisket tender and slides right off the bone ~~~ and ya really can never go wrong with any of their chicken dishes. Portions are always flavorful and big (noice)

 Make a reservation or not, it's been worth the wait every time ;) Do yourself a FAVOR and eat family style with whoever you come to this lit funktion of a restaurant. Call ahead for different lit funktions (some of my favs include thai night, raffle nights, the pageant competition)
author: Julia L.

description:
We came here since it was around the corner from mission cliffs. 

I should have scrutinized the menu more thoroughly because I think the items we ordered were really basic and I could have had better anywhere else. The only thing I enjoyed was the ginger milk tea. 

I ordered a pad kee Mao with chicken and it was so freaking salty. Like I didn't enjoy it at all.  The Thai sausage we ordered was good, but not worth the price.   My friend had a tom yum soup that he enjoyed but which I also think was too salty. 

Total came to $60 with 2 drinks which is ok priced,  i would come again to try their other items, probably for dinner.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen is not your ordinary Thai restaurant. 

This place is so unique and quirky. I absolutely love the vibes and atmosphere here. If there's a birthday, there will be cymbals and sirens going off - it's lit. I promise you've never been anywhere like this. 

Thankfully, I've always dined here with a big group so I've had a chance to try (or mooch off of) a lot of things. Some of my favorites:

+ Samosas
+ Papaya Salad 
+ Pad Char Shrimps: super flavorful and love the blue rice! I preferred this over the Mok Salmon which also comes with blue rice.
+ Crab Fried Rice: theeee best crab fried rice I've ever had, no skimping on the crab! 
+ Pad See You
+ Pad Thai 

For dessert, durian sticky rice. Ya, you heard me! No mangos since it's not in season so we went with the dankest fruit out there. If you're up for something adventurous, this would be it. I used to not be able to stand the smell of durian, but developed some strange immunity and fascination to it ever since coming back from Thailand..

Good food, fun times! My favorite Thai spot in SF!
author: Laverne N.

description:
What a fun dinner tonight! Amazing food, quick service, a funny hat and mild public embarrassment - this place has it all! 

I went with some colleagues to Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Cuisine as part of a team dinner. We were sat shortly after our entire group arrived. 

And while Farmhouse was packed, the entire staff runs it so efficiently. 

We were given menus, and our drink orders were quickly taken and fulfilled. I can personally vouch for the Thai tea, which comes with a snowball in the glass. This keeps the tea cool and was such a fun extra. 

We then ordered our entrees, and they were placed in front of us not even 10 minutes later. 

Enticed by the pics on Yelp, I ordered the Tom Yum Noodle Soup. This soup is packed with seafood, with salmon, calamari, shrimp and scallops. My favorite part was the egg noodles. It's hard to pinpoint why these were so good, but they just were. Maybe they soaked up some of the flavor from the spicy broth. I'm not a huge spice fan, but this was the right amount of heat. 

I almost got the pad thai. And happily two of my colleagues did, so I was able to try it. The Grilled River Prawns Pad Thai, in particular, is beautiful and delicious. The prawn was huge, and the noodles had a slight sweetness to them. 

So where is the funny hat and public embarrassment?

To celebrate something in my life, my boss told the restaurant staff it was my birthday. And for birthdays, Farmhouse Kitchen does it right. Several of the staff members start from one side of the restaurant and clap, cheer and sing their way to your table. And once they get to you, they put a straw hat on your head and a plastic lei around your neck. 

It's mortifying yet so fun and endearing at the same time. I hated/loved my coworkers for this. 

And to top it off, the staff puts a large tray with a sampling of desserts in front of you. This is a serious dessert selection. It included some lychee ice cream, coconut milk shaved ice served in a hollowed-out coconut, chocolate and large slices of watermelon, among some other items I'm forgetting. The coconut shaved ice was my favorite, though it was all delicious. 

We had so much fun at Farmhouse Kitchen, and we were in and out in roughly an hour and a half -- an hour and a half of delicious food, fun and now good memories.
author: Emily H.

description:
I've been dreading this review. I care here with a party of four, because they highly recommended it. It was insanely busy, but a really fun environment with the staff! 

Unfortunately we sat right next to the kitchen, ordered a big drink that really was not good at all. We almost asked to send it back, but decided against it. We ate a few grasshoppers which weren't as scary as I thought, but we quickly ran out of our beverage and bugs when we realized our food was taking much longer than everybody else's.

The table next to ours had dessert, left, sat a new party, and got their dinner before our server came back to tell us that she had forgotten what we ordered. Shame.

Anyway, the food finally came and it was SPECTACULAR! They nailed everybody's dishes. I had fried chicken and perfectly flavored yellow curry. The blue rice was really good, I ate it when I didn't have room for anything else.

Unfortunately the service is the reason for the 2 lost stars. Can't wait to try it again.
author: Clifford M.

description: The food was good, but it was not worth the money. I ordered their Pad Kee Mao ($15.50), and you're definitely paying more for their aesthetic/ambience than their portions. When the server brought out the plate, it looked appetizing but I knew I wouldn't be full. The portions here are way smaller and more expensive than normal Thai places. The servers are nice and the food was flavorful, but if you're really hungry, you're better off looking elsewhere or be prepared for an expensive bill.
author: Aileen J.

description:
Wowowow! Take me back ASAP.

This place is funky, loud and delicious! I was lucky enough to try a bit of everything with our large group sharing some dishes. 

We had a reservation for 8 at 8PM on a Wednesday. The restaurant was full and a small group of people waiting. So, yes I encourage a reservation.

Highlights:
- papaya salad - YES ORDER. I've finally found another Thai spot that does this right. Limey, fishy, crunchy, spicyyy
- Chicken Wings - super crispy with a spicy vinegar fish sauce 
- Tom Yum Noodle soup w/ seafood - bean sprouts and broccolini as added veg was a nice touch
- Elderflower cocktail - light and refreshing with edible flowers!

Other stuff: 
- 4 birthdays celebrated within the 90 min of being there. Let me tell you, this is no ordinary "restaurant sings you happy birthday song"....check video out haha
- Every once in a while a server comes around with small dishes to purchase from them. Fried crickets and other Thai snacks that aren't on menu!

Such a a fun and lively place!
author: Heather H.

description: We went here with a group of 8 and tried pretty much all the vegetarian dishes. I was blown away by the food. It was full of flavor, the presentation was great, the ambience was great and so was the service. It is a tad pricey for the portions but we thoroughly enjoyed it. Be prepared to wait a while for a table (as almost places in SF)!
author: Ruchi M.

description:
I was having a really non-planny kind of day. Didn't yelp anywhere I went for once, just went to what was closest to where I was. REGRETS. 

Immediately after eating, I looked this page up and I was so confused by the high rating. Most of the comments complained about price (which yeah is ridic, but I honestly don't care if the food is good). My issue with this place is their food.

A thai place for me has to do 3 things well: Tom Yum, Pad Thai, and Pad See Ew. Tom Yum - good. Pad Thai - Okay, but I still wouldn't order again. Pad See Ew - One of the worst I've ever had. They should change the name of this pad see ew to "Plain Jane" (except maybe not cause A$AP Ferg made Plain Jane cool!). This was the plainest pad see ew I've ever had. I remember seeing the waiter bring it out, already eyeing how light in color the noodles were. As soon as I took a bite, I knew. Since I paid $15.50 and I was starving though, I finished it, hoping that with each bite I took, it would magically get better, and suddenly have flavor, but it never did.
author: Maleah M.

description:
This place is always jam packed so make sure you make a reservation before coming here. My group of 5 came here at 8 PM on a Tuesday and still ended up waiting an hour for a seat. There's a bar right around the corner to grab a drink while you wait. They text you as soon as your number is close to being called. Great waiting system. 

Once you enter the restaurant, you are greeted by waiters and waitresses in traditional clothing. Wait staff were all amiable. 

My group ordered family style so we were able to try all the different dishes.

Highlights of the night:
Hat Yai Fried Chicken 
The curry was absolutely delicious. The blue rice was something I have never seen but it was way better than normal rice. The fried chicken was just bursting with juices yet the crispy skin had a great crunch. Highly recommend this dish.

24 hours beef noodle soup
The Meat literally falls off the bone with no effort needed. The full flavors of the soup from the beef is pleasant and the smell is aromatic. 

You can skip:
Crab Fried Rice
You can skip this. Yes, the fried rice comes with big chunks of crab, but the flavors weren't outstanding. I ended up pouring curry all over the rice to give it a kick. Curry made it 10x better.

Chicken wings:
Nothing really special about this appetizer. 

Kick Boxing bowl:
The drink itself is very appealing to look at, but it is on the sweet side. It is also awkward leaning forward to drink this drink with the long straws provided.
author: Timothy C.

description:
I am probably a small sample of people in SF that have not been impressed by Farmhouse Kitchen.  

1.) It is tooooo loud to eat casually, or on a date, unless you love loud banging and can't hear your friends talking.

2.) Food was super oily that I felt a little sick, my panang curry was mediocre at best.  Price was so expensive, I have paid less for way better quality.

3.) Staff was friendly and loved the outfits they were.  

In the end, I do not see myself pushing to come back, but when I do, I will try again maybe a better dish.
author: Raja D.

description:
4.5 stars

Great food, huge portions, and colorful & decadent plating that just makes you want to eat it all up - after all we eat with our eyes first right?

The vibe is also energetic / slightly over the top, and fits the presentation of the food. Be prepared to listen to the birthday serenade, which generously features percussion instruments, at least three times during your meal.

Highly recommend the:
*  panang neua(HUGE beef rib)
* 24 hour beef noodle soup
* beef rolls w/ mint appetizer
* fried chicken with blue rice entree

Only reason it's not a 5 is some dishes are consistently a little under seasoned - they look delicious but are just missing some flavor.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I've been to this restaurant before, but I must have had amnesia or something, because I completely forgot how good it was!!!

My sister came into town, and like most great hosts, I wanted to show her a great time and help her eat her way through SF. She happens to be gluten-free, so Thai was a perfect choice (since most items are gluten-free).  

We didn't have a reservation, but that wasn't a big deal. They said it would be 45-1 hour wait for a party of 5 (3 adults, 2 toddlers), but we got seated on about 25-30. The place is pretty stroller friendly (for those of you rocking the double stroller life like myself), and they have a good amount of high chairs. There are some options where children can eat off your plate (such as the fried rice dishes) however no dedicated children's menu (which is fine, since mine are still young enough to eat off our plates and purees that we bring). 

Speaking (rather, writing) of the menu, there were so many options and things to choose from! I literally wanted to try almost everything on that menu. We decided to get an appetizer and several dishes to share. The portions are pretty large (so either you can eat half and take the rest home, share, or go ham and devour it all yourself!) We got the Mieng Kum Kung to start (which was excellent!!!), then got the Hat Yai Fried Chicken (which was cooked to perfection!!!! I'm a picky eater and didn't need to substitute a thing!), the Kai Yang, Som Tom (BBQ chicken marinated to perfection!!!), and the Thai Fried Rice with Prawns (so delicious and flavorful!) 

There was so much food and deliciousness, I honestly wanted to be rolled out in a food coma, but we ended up boxing some up to go (whew!) 

Totally deserving of the best Thai in SF, and I can't wait to go back and keep working our way thru this menu.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Cool hidden Thai restaurant! Super fun loud ambiance, service was attentive and quick after being seated. The servers were dressed up in Thai clothing even a girl was dressed as a Thai boxer! Super cute and cool restaurant!
I came on a weekday and there was a wait for about 25 minutes which actually was 35 minutes. It was clear though they were packed and busy.
We ordered samosas and the ahi scoops as a starter. The samosas were so tasty, crispy, flakey, and fresh! Highly recommend that! The ahi scoops had cucumber, seaweed salad, yam, dill, and cilantro vinaigrette which was all matched perfectly! Must try it! Beautiful presentation as well. 
As for the main dishes we got a tom yum which was very lemongrassy, in a good way.  Thai shrimp fried rice and pad Thai were also good basics to get if you don't want anything too fancy.
But the star of the night was Hat yai fried chicken! Get it! The yellow curry was so delicious with the fried chicken and roti bread! I was eating all the roti bread with all the curry! 
I'd definitely come back to try other items!
author: Sherene H.

description:
My new favourite Thai place! 
We love the decor to the service and oh-for-sure the FOOD!!! 

We ordered the Pad ka pow minced pork, Tom yum soup, yellow curry, pad Thai, roasted pork belly salad. Everything was amazing! But don't forget to order the BLUE RICE. Thats prob the only blue coloured food I'd ever eat. It's not a life changing rice but definitely v fragrant and it goes v well with the food we ordered. And instagrammable! Hahaha 

We ordered the Thai Ice tea which comes with a ball of shaved ice (so pretty!). Coconut juice was amazingly fresh and sweet, I need to know where they got their coconut juice supply!!! 

Last but not least, we ordered the dessert sampler! I love that coconut ice cream with coconut cream. Jesus!!!!!! I'll be back!!!
author: Kelly L.

description:
This place seems to be really popular for birthdays. Folks can expect music and birthday song for bday boy/girl. The decor and look had a lot going on and the theme seemed kind of a mashup between 2-3 different styles. Overall, a lot going on. We reserved a table for evening of 3rd July and the restaurant was quite packed. The service was decent.
The samosas were good...The hat yai fried chicken dinner was amazing with its offering of roti, curry, rice and fried chicken. The roti, curry and rice were delicious. My vegetarian friend ordered fried rice. It was dismal with no flavor or any taste. I couldn't help feel bad for her. I think fried rice is something pretty basic which a really popular/highly rated should get right.
author: Tejashree M.

description:
Oooooo boy Farmhouse Kitchen definitely exceeded my expectations! I've been wanting to try this place for a while, so my bf and I decided to come for a casual birthday dinner for yours truly.

Before we went, I already knew what I wanted to order: the neua num tok rolls, ahi scoops, and the hat yai chicken to share The neua num tok rolls and ahi scoops came out first, since they're appetizers and all. The neua num tok rolls are wagyu beef rolls wrapped with cucumber. The meat is super tender and flavorful, and there's a good portion of it for 4 rolls. There's also a spicy thai chimichurri sauce on the bottom of the dish to dip in! As for the ahi scoops, I expected the same ones from Kitchen Story and Blackwood, but these had different sauces and were much spicier!!! I was pretty shook with the spice level, but I ended up eating 3 of 4 haha. The hat yai chicken came out and it's actually a pretty hefty portion, so I was glad the bf and I decided to share! I first tried the roti dipped in the yellow curry and I was happy to find a thin, flavorful curry. Next, I tried the fried chicken and I reallly liked the batter on it. It was so crunchy, yet light. I dipped it in the sauce they provided and it was the perfect combo! I also enjoyed the blue jasmine rice and spooned the yellow curry sauce over it.

Overall Farmhouse was a solid choice! I want to try the 24 hour short rib soup next :P
author: Tara A.

description:
Thought prices were a little high, until we saw the portions! Sooo muchhh food! But hard to share... food was so good I wanted my dish all to myself Haha.

I ordered the Hat Yai Fried Chicken. Favorite things in life: fried chicken and curry. A combination I've never had together, but just sounds...right! Never had blue rice before but it was soft and fluffy. After I devoured the fried chicken I still had maybe half of my curry left, which was perfect because the dish also comes with Roti so I was dunking away.

My partner ordered the crab fried rice and pad Thai. They were both very flavorful. Fried rice came with broth and decent amount of crab meat on top.

For dessert we asked for their recommendation, which was the Thai Vacation. Black rice pudding with coconut cream topped with ice cream and coconut meat served inside a young coconut! 


Everything Amazing:)
author: Mary R.

description:
Farmhouse is authentic as it gets, the Samosas are a must! The service is wonderful, prices are reasonable, I don't mind paying for quality. This spot is a hole in the wall!! 

When you walk into Farmhouse everyone is super welcoming, it feels like your in Thailand ( never been there before) but I imagine that's how it is. 

I definitely recommend Farmhouse if you haven't been to it yet. 

Make sure you have a small snack before it can get pretty packed and might wait for some time before getting seated, but don't eat too much! You definitely want to save your appetite for this spot!
author: Mar A.

description: Best Thai Food EVER!!!! Thank you so much Farmhouse Kitchen for our Delicious Dinner. The Papaya salad was amazing. My husband ordered the slow braised short ribs, and it was so tender fell right off the bone. Yum Yum Yummmm... We will be returning
author: Justice M.

description:
I adore this place! This is my second time here and just as last time it was a wonderful experience. Got seated right away, we there @5 just when they open...we were starving from shopping all day  if you haven't been to this place you're missing out. The place has character and that's important to me in a restaurant. From the shirts everyone is wearing. They have great customer service, the ambiance is awesome, decor and everything. 
Now the food...
Starters: fried calamari & vegan rolls *****
Mains: salmon & house fried rice w fried pork belly *****
Drink: lavender hot tea
author: Patricia H.

description:
Being a huge lover of Thai cuisine, I've been to many Thai restaurants around the world and I'm very sure when I say, this place has the best Thai food outside of Bangkok.  

For starters we ordered Papaya salad and Herbal rice salad and both were fresh and tasted amazing.  Then we ordered Pad Thai, Pad Ke Mow, Pad Kaprow and Khao Suey. Each and every dish had its own individual taste and flavor.  

The service here was exceptionally nice and very prompt. Our server, Cartoon was very helpful and friendly.  

Strongly recommend trying this place. You'll love it!
author: Tanvir H.

description:
This is probably my favorite Thai place. The atmosphere inside is so friendly and welcoming, the employees are all really helpful and friendly. I went for Valentine's Day dinner and they had the entire restaurant decorated with heart balloons and a little spot for photos to be taken too. On a normal day, I think the aesthetic of the restaurant is still really cute and homey feeling.

I ordered the Hat Yai Fried Chicken, which comes with blue jasmine rice, yellow curry, and roti. The Fried Chicken was delicious, the chicken tasted fresh and flavorful while the fried breaded outside was light and crispy! I'm a huge fan of roti and curry, so I was happy it was included in with this dish. The yellow curry also tasted great with the blue jasmine rice.

What really brought me to 5 five stars though was the Neua Num Tok Rolls. They're wagyu beef wrapped with cucumber, mint, and cilantro with a cilantro lime vinaigrette. I've never had wagyu beef before and I'm honestly so sad I haven't. IT WAS A 10/10, so freakin good! The beef was soft and so full of flavor and tasted delicious with the cilantro lime vinaigrette! After this, I definitely recommend ordering anything with wagyu beef on their menu!
author: Kathryn T.

description:
I'm surprised I haven't heard of this place sooner!

We arrived during opening and there was already a line outside the door, but we got seated pretty quickly. The interior is SUPER cute and the service was pretty good as well.

After several minutes of deciding what we wanted to get, we both got the Hai Yai Chicken (fried chicken, roti, yellow potato curry, and blue jasmine rice) since it seemed the most popular. 

The food was amazing. The chicken was perfectly fried, the roti was exceptional with the curry, and the portion was too big for me to finish (my friend finished it though). This place is pretty pricey, but worth coming once in a while!
author: KT L.

description: A rousing party, a night market. Farmhouse is a delight to the senses. They have a gluten free menu, flavors abound. Fun for larger groups and I cannot recommend it more highly.
author: J A.

description: I always order from this place when I house and dog sit in the mission. They are always on time, food is warm and in tact (huge plus with delivery). I'm a Thai food lover and always get the coconut soup. It's to die for! All of the apps are tasty. All of the rice dishes are mouth watering! Go there, or don't, order delivery! The portions are great for two or leftovers for one (which is how I typically roll) ;-)
author: Parasto S.

description:
Love this spot for get togethers with friends or for birthday celebrations.It can get super rowdy and noisy because of all of the "birthdays", so if you're looking for a quiet-ish place or something romantic, this definitely isn't the spot.

I've been here a few times, and so far our favorite dishes have been the 24h beef noodle soup, fried chicken, Hat Yai fried chicken, and the pad thai. All of the dishes  were amazing and really flavorful. Can get a little pricey as the dishes are $20+, but worth the experience. Service here has been decent and the waiters as attentive as they can be considering how packed it is usually. Be sure to make a reservation ahead of time to avoid a wait. Overall a really fun and festive experience with great food and drinks!
author: Angela K.

description: LOVED THIS PLACE!! The environment was so fun and trendy I absolutely enjoyed every dish we ordered! Definitely recommend it!
author: Lydia P.

description: This is one of the better Thai places in SF. The food here is really good. The flavors are exceptional and perfectly balance. Minus a star because it is super expensive and the portions are really small. For example the chicken wings are like $18 for 4 wings!!! Like seriously! Granted they were really flavorful and really good, but they're chicken wings...common! If you are willing to splurge a little than do it here because the food it really good. Maybe, go for date night or something because we went as a group of 6 and there was definitely not enough food and it was like $40-50 a person. Guess, all my friends are just gluttonous monsters...lol.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
I had very little expectation of this restaurant outside of the kitschy website and that it was Thai. Our group easily booked reservations on a Friday night even though there did seem to be wait when we checked in. Be warned, the outside does not reflect the inside. The decor is unique and does bring you back to a Thai market or stall. It is also pretty loud and chaotic with music blaring and people randomly walking around with baskets (of what we found out later are fried grasshoppers. Our group of three split chicken wings, chicken noodle soup, yum moo krob (pork belly). Everything was delicious but nothing stood out as very memorable.  An interesting point of the restaurant that they do a huge parade of noises for anyone's birthday; which was exciting the first time but got a little much the fourth time. 

Overall, I think this place would be great for parties or large groups where you want to get a little rowdy while eating delicious Thai food. It's certainly a more extensive menu than your average place and that gets big points for me.
author: Teresa T.

description: Really delicious food. I got the green curry and jasmine rice. It was bomb. The servers are fun and the atmosphere is super pretty. It can get pretty loud though (for the ongoing "birthday" chants). Overall, very yummy and we will be back.
author: Lulu K.

description:
Great place for a group or party. High energy, great decor, lively service.
Dishes are small and overpriced. We thought we ordered plenty based on the number of dishes and the final bill, but most of us left hungry.
Food is "Thai confusion" style.
If you go, go for the fun then plan a trip to a wine bar with snacks afterwards (we chose Blush! in the Castro, but that's for a another review...)
author: Bruce J.

description:
This place has a long wait, but it is definitely worth! 
Everyone here is super nice and friendly. On top of that, they will tell you when you're over ordering which is also a place for me (I always over order)‍

Food: 
Ahi scoops: 4/5 ehh these were good but, you can definitely live without it if you have a small stomach.

Chicken wings 5/5 this is a must order! Batter is not super heavy, but also very crunchy. They cooked it so perfectly that the wings were still dripping with their delicious juices. 

Green curry noodles: 4/5 super flavorful and goes so well with the noodles. It is a little spicy though, so be warned 

Hat yai fried chicken: 5/5 the curry that goes with this dish is my all time favorite. This dish was soo good. The chicken was so tender that you don't even need to cut it with a knife. You have to order this dish, you will not regret

Panang neua: 5/5 braised to very tender and delicious. I loved this dish as well. 

Everything really tasted delicious, the only thing I wished is that they could served substitutes with dishes. Since we ordered so many entrees, we got so much carbs. Anyway, this place is a definite bookmark though.
author: Elsa W.

description:
We waited for an hour on a Friday night, but honestly Farmhouse is really worth it. To start off, it's a bit dark and cramped inside, but the atmosphere is fun- lots of singing for people's birthdays. Service is super hospitable and you're well taken care of. 

The food is on another level. We got staple dishes like papaya salad and pad thai, but they were very fresh and tasty compared to other Thai restaurants. 
Loved the fried chicken plate; it had so much food and a bit of everything, but words can't describe how moist and crispy the chicken was. I got the steak with sticky rice and it doesn't look like a lot, but you get a great cut of meat cooked really well. The sticky rice fills you up too. 

My favorite thing though was their honey milk lavender. It's honestly just a foamy hot milk, but it was so silky and rightly sweetened and it tasted and smelt heavenly. Very much worth $6. 

Though it can be a wait, the quality of food and service makes your experience here worth your time. The food also comes out relatively fast once you are seated.
author: Olyvia Y.

description: This place is fun! Great ambience and very entertaining. The food is pretty good too. It's super busy though, so by the time we sat down, the kitchen was close to closing and we did feel slightly rushed (mind you, it was late). I enjoyed everything we ate, especially the random cart that came around with mystery meat.
author: Jeanne R.

description:
This place was packed, even on a Monday night! Despite having a 6:30pm reservation, we still waited half an hour for a table. The management was super nice though and sent over a complimentary appetizer. I love the ambiance of this place - there are so many plants and shrubs outside, and inside it is dimly lit with a light display that almost gives the restaurant a party atmosphere.

The items on the menu are definitely on the expensive side for Thai food, with even a curry or pad thai costing around $19. Specials are in the $20-28 range. However, the food is very beautifully and artistically presented, and well-cooked. I got my pad thai with a crispy pork belly supplement (+$4), which ended up not quite being worth it for the few small pieces of pork belly that I got. The pad thai was delicious though, and was not too oily or too sweet, and the new pieces of pork belly that were there were deliciously crunchy and rich. The amount of food was enough for two meals for me.

They also frequently would gather the staff and bring our birthday cakes to much fanfare and cymbal smashing to other diners - definitely looked like a fun place to come celebrate your birthday. All of their desserts looked really appetizing - definitely was tempted to have some after seeing them despite being very full!
author: Amy C.

description: I love it! Food is reach in flavors. Soups are great, and they have a good selection of vegetarian options. Service is fast and very friendly. If it's your Bday, don't forget to let them know ;)))
author: Tatiana Z.

description:
Farmhouse has often been heaped praises upon praises by friends as THE best Thai place in San Francisco. And oh boy, there are a LOT of Thai places in SF. R is super, duper into this place. We tried to come like 2 times (?) before actually making it happen. Always, always reserve beforehand. No reservations? It feels like any time of the day that you walk in, prepare to wait at least an hour to be seated, if you didn't make a reservation ahead of time. Yeah, that's how popular this place is. The restaurant always reminds me of lakorns (thai dramas). It's super quirky. They always have random lakorns playing, some of which I think the workers videotape themselves as a parody. Old style Thai music. Super bright colors,etc etc. I like it (haha) because when you step in, you're already thinking this is so cute to eat at. At least I do. We got the ahi scoops, crab fried rice, Thai street green curry noodles, and the infamous Hat Yai fried chicken. Ahi scoops-skip. The other stuff were much better. The fried chicken was super delicious and flavorful, no wonder it's so famous. Food was excellent! We also had the Thai Tea. So much ice. why do the ones in the US so far don't taste like the ones in Bangkok???
Cut to unpopular opinion- I got takeout from here once. Pad Kee Mow. Nope nope nope. It was so average and bland. I was sorely disappointed. It wasn't until I got the other stuff above and ate at the restaurant that my disappointment was absolved. 
Make an appointment if you really want to try food here. Yes it's pricey but its SF. And have fun!
author: Michelle R.

description:
My favorite spot for Thai.  Had:
Fried Chicken special dinner
Calamari dinner
Crab fried rice dinner(gets an extra hell yeah)!
Green curry chicken
Pad see ew vegetables and tofu with a fried egg on top(hell yeah)!
author: Danielle Y.

description: I ordered on Caviar. Each dish was either dripping in oil, or had at least a 2 inch layer of oil on top of it (curry). Inedible. Don't do it!
author: Gabriela W.

description:
I've visited Farmhouse Kitchen three times in the past two months, and each time I go, I have to fight the urge to lie about it being my birthday.  Who wants to be surrounded by merriment and don an awesome hat?  This gal right here.  Is it September 2018 yet?  Oh well, I guess I have 9 more months to try everything on the menu, right?

Here's what I've tried so far - 

crispy calamari - 14
^this might sound weird, but I want to swim in a pool of the cilantro lime sauce that comes with this appetizer.  yes, the squid seemed fresh, perfectly battered and fried (though I couldn't necessarily tell that it was "curry" battered), but the sauce... I'd put that on a car tire and eat it. 

crab fried rice - 25.95
^ordered this two out of the three times I've been and have never tried the bone broth that comes on the side, haha.  am I missing out?  in any event, they do not skimp on the crab meat - hallelujah!

hat yai fried chicken - 21.50
^the friend who originally put FT on my radar just loooves this dish.  I'd give points for the juiciness of the chicken and the perfect texture of the fried shell around it (probably the exact same batter and technique used with the calamari), and also for the addition of roti, potato yellow curry and blue rice to round everything out.  however, if you come to FT for something that has a knock-your-socks-off flavor profile just know in advance that this is not the one.  but if you'd like one mild dish, perhaps for a less adventurous friend/family member, this one is a winner.

neua yang steak - 27.95
^one of my friends saw "wagyu flank steak" and added this to our order.  the surprising thing?  while the flank steak was good, I just couldn't get enough of the bed of Thai long beans underneath.  Paired with the ginger rice, too?  Holy heck... I thought it was good enough to skip the meat and just go vegan.  small note: get ready to take a video once they light this on fire - so Instagram worthy, haha.

pad see you beef and chicken - 16.5
^i prefer getting this with beef rather than chicken, but either way they're both good.  this dish also made me think about being a little more "strategic" when ordering from Farmhouse.  you could probably enjoy pad see you at a number of different Thai restaurants throughout the city at about half the price.  unless pad see you is an absolutely must, i think you could forgo it in order to get something that you'll only really see at Farmhouse.  just a thought!

panang neua - 27.95
^i'll be honest and say that i had some reservations about this dish because some photos make the rib look pretty small.  honestly, though, the panang curry that this is cooked in, and whatever dry rub they might use in addition to it, makes a little short rib meat go a looong way.  this is not a dish you need a lot of in terms of quantity; just a small piece with rice and broccolini = perfection.

kick boxing bowl - 24
^delicious cocktail WITH A DISCO LIGHT?!  sold.

thai vacation - 10 
^the menu says it's a "half fresh coconut filled with black sticky rice, vanilla ice cream topped with peanut and sesame".  i'm a fan of fresh coconut, black sticky rice and vanilla ice cream and thought this was a good, but not great, choice.  next time i'll go for gold and get the ruk na platter.

Assorted Notes:

It is super easy to make a reservation through Yelp so DO IT; this place can get packed during dinner and there isn't a huge waiting area so you'll have to wait outside in the (California) cold during our winter months.

I've never had to park more than a block away from Farmhouse (I'm guessing most SF locals choose to Lyft, Uber, Muni in?), but this part of the Mission doesn't necessarily feel unsafe when you're walking around at night.  

Post Farmhouse option (I have tried this after dinner on a weeknight) - Boba Guys further down on 19th (between Lexington and Valencia) and then people watching at Mission Playground or a couple blocks further at Dolores Park.  It's 10 city blocks from the restaurant to bubble tea, and a little over half a mile, but it's a good way to fend off a food coma, clear room in your tummy and then enjoy BG's "grade A balls."
author: Iona C.

description:
Parking is free and easy. Service is great!
Chicken wings - delicious! Good portion for 2 or 4 people. The sauce is amazing. Definitely recommend it as a starter.
Chicken noodle soup - to be honest, we don't really like the flavor. But it should be authentic Thai food for people who love it.
Street food with ginger sauce - good. Nothing stands out but you won't be disappointed.
Thai vacation - my top 1 like. The black sticky rice is very chewy and coconut is delicious.
