To sum up, I would recommend the dessert and starter.
author: Tianjia C.

description:
Food and service is amazing! 
I highly recommend the coconut curry fried chicken and fall off the bone panang neua. Both can be pricey, but given the area, this is expected. Servings are more then enough for one person, so I usually will split these 2 plates with 1 or 2 other people. 
The food is delicious with layers of flavor, and the view of the bay makes the experience that much better. 
This is a great lunch spot, as prices are a bit lower then at dinner.
author: Alejandra A.

description:
I wasn't really a fan of Thai food before this place - the sweet and sour acidity of Thai food just doesn't really jive with me. After Farmhouse Kitchen, I do like Thai food more, but probably not enough to brave the long wait to get it. 

We waited almost 2 hours for our party of 6 to be seated, so we were all grumpy and hangry. Do not try to get group seating on a Friday - it is an absolute nightmare, and you will have to murderously glare at the drunk parties gathered around their Kick Boxing Bowls or listen to the sound of their birthday drum concerts enough times to make your ears bleed. 

I tried the Hat Yai Fried Chicken, Tom Kha Soup, and Thai Street Green Curry Noodles. They also give you some complimentary pickled vegetables, which took the edge off our hunger. While the blue rice served with the chicken is fun, it tastes like normal rice and wasn't too exciting. The chicken was fine for fried chicken, but why pay $21 for that when you can get it at a sketchy fast food joint? The roti bread and yellow curry dipping sauce that came with the chicken were really tasty, though - I could've put that sauce on anything. 

Similarly with the noodles and soup, the flavors were incredible when they hit my tongue. My favorite was the soup, which was just delicious with every slurp. The chicken in the noodles was kind of tough, but the green curry was good. All the plates are hearty and big, but they have raised their prices substantially (dinner prices are $1-$3 higher than what you see on their online menu).
author: Sophie W.

description:
Love this place! We always get the fried chicken dish, beef wagyu apps, short rib dish, and mango sticky rice. Everything is SO DELICIOUS and i definitely would recommend coming here! 
The atmosphere is loud, but so fun! We went on a double date here and ordered 2 of the kick boxing bowls to share, so good and definitely a creeper. 
They have a great selection of drinks too! For birthdays, they sing to the celebrant and bring it sparking candles, it's very entertaining. The staff's costumes are so fun too, they really play their role and are so quick with service and have great customer service! 
If you are unsure of what to order, they will not disappoint you in what they recommend. You have to go here!
author: Frances C.

description: atmosphere is FABULOUS. Food is Divine, though for thai the portions may be smaller than what you are used to. Can't recommend the Panang Curry enough!
author: Sarah H.

description:
I got the 24 hours beef noodle soup ($19) and the Pad Ka Pow ($15). Both were great, but the noodle soup was definitely the star of the show. It had this amazing big beef short rib with the bone in that made for a wonderful combination with the flavorful broth. This is definitely not pho, more like a thai ramen if you will. The pad ka pow was good as well though tasted more standard.

I also like that this place has the perfect lunchtime ambiance - bright colors and open spacing.

Meal Value (from 1-10, my measure of quantity/quality of the meal compared to price): 8
I would say this restaurant is on the pricier side for normal thai, though not necessarily for the quality/quantity you get. They serve most dishes family style so you definitely get a bigger portion than what you expect. For that reason, I'd say this is pretty good value (above average).
author: Hung Yu C.

description: Best Thai place hands down, the flavors or each dish we well rounded and complemented each other. The meat was cooked well and was so tender it fell apart. We also ordered the fried chicken which was crispy and moist.  Definitely would come back to try the many other dishes. The hostess wasn't the best at customer service and they cleaned up our dishes with out asking if we were done. Oh well, id still go back for the food!
author: Jean L.

description:
Arguably one of the best Thai places I've been to in the area. The restaurant was located in a peaceful, hip part of the Mission district. The wooden tables and the tropical decor made for a cute lunch spot. I adored the little succulents potted in empty sauce cans. Overall, I loved the energy of the place. I remember one waiter wearing a red chili hat? 

[Pad See You] The presentation of the dish was beautiful. Very vibrant colors! The flat rice noodles had a wonderful texture and the flavoring was just right. Only complaint is that the chicken was a little dry.
author: Annie Z.

description:
One of my favorite Thai places in the city. Hidden in the Outer Mission, Farmhouse is a fun restaurant to check out for a birthday or a get together with friends. They take reservations and I highly recommend making one because it's been completely packed here both times I visited on a Tuesday. 

The place is nicely decorated and the servers are complete sweethearts. I haven't had a dish I didn't enjoy yet but here are some highlights:
Num tok rolls- delicious, but small
Papaya salad- always a fan favorite
Thai Street Green Curry Noodles- one of my favorite entrees here
Grilled River Prawns Pad Thai- Good, but not my favorite
Pad See You- yum
Pad Thai- I think it's a requirement as a thai place to not screw up pad thai
Red curry- good, but I'd opt for a noodle dish over a curry dish here

I'm not much of a dessert girl, but I absolutely fell in love with Farmhouse's dessert. I don't remember the name but it's a coconut filled with ice cream. If you order dessert, definitely say it's someone's birthday. ;)
author: Arezou A.

description: I always come here on my lunch. The chicken curry is very reasonable and filling. The service is great, food sometimes takes a long time but well worth the wait
author: AJ D.

description: Came here for a quick date night dinner. Of course I made reservations because I know the wait can be loooong. We enjoyed our meal and at the end we had a surprise ending trying fried worms!!!!!! The food is wonderful, the service is still outstanding. I will always dine in here! You MUST check this place out if you haven't!!!
author: Dorothy M.

description:
Had a fantastic time at Farmhouse. The fried chicken (Hat Yai Fried Chicken) was the highlight of the meal, as so many of the reviews indicate, is probably one of the only dishes I recommend as a must-get when stopping by. The only other dish I would recommend if you are into appetizers is the vegan fresh rolls (add shrimp if you are omnivorous). The chicken wings were frankly not worth the price. 

Lively, bustling environment, great decor, and great friendly service.
author: David Y.

description:
Service was great. Ambiance was festive. But the food didn't taste like Thai food at all. 

It was tasty Asian fusion food, but nothing amazing considering the Michelin Bib award they received. We ordered the Neua Num Tok Rolls and Panang Neua Dinner Special. I don't think it's worth the wait.
author: Cece Y.

description: Nice spot, great interior, good service. Underwhelmed by the food which ultimately is the key thing. Tried a bunch of different things. I see the other glowing reviews so I'm open to going back.
author: Ryan B.

description: What a funky place!  The name does not do it justice. From the drag queen host to the "kick boxing bowl" beverages...this place is unique!!!  Our favorites were the crab fried rice, the pad char shrimp and the neua num too rolls. The fried chicken was also super delicious. I would skip the fried calamari and the par dip fresh tuna next time. The tuna was "unpleasantly spicy", as my husband said.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
BEST THAI ON THIS EARTH! 
Visiting San Francisco from Maui, their yellow curry, sticky rice & Thai iced tea is the very BEST; Flavors are to absolute perfection! Since pictures can be worth much more than words... these images, make my mouth salivates for more. Counting the days until my next visit to Farmhouse. Addicted.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
My friend who lives in SF highly recommended this restaurant and it did not disappoint. I was lucky to get a reservation on a Thursday for a table of 2 for lunch on Saturday. I received a confirmation phone call about 5 mins prior to my reservation and we were seated right away when we got there. The decor of the restaurant is super cute and the food all looks very delicious. My husband and I ordered classic Thai iced tea, the neua num tok rolls, papaya salad, Hat Yai fried chicken, and Thai spicy seafood. Overall, everything was very delicious. It's in the top five of Thai food restaurants I've had (between restaurants in LA and SD). The papaya salad and seafood were a little too spicy for me (my husband thought they were fine), the the flavors were still very good. The fried chicken is a popular dish and I totally understand why it is popular. It's a perfectly fried chicken breast. The breading is super crispy, while the meat is super tender, juicy and flavorful. I was surprised at how moist the chicken breast was. The dish also comes with a roti and curry sauces. The roti is very buttery and flaky, and the curry sauce is very flavorful with a coconut mild base. Lastly, the rice that comes with the dish is a blue rice, dyed with a blue flower. The rice itself did not have too much taste but the blue color is definitely pretty in pictures. For my husband's seafood dish, this was not as impressive. The flavor of the dish is good, but not the best we've had. The amount of seafood in the dish is not that much but all are cooked to just the right texture. The two appetizers: Neua num tok rolls are also very good in flavor; I especially like how the mint sauce and cucumber perfectly balanced the fattiness of the beef. The beef itself is a little over cooked, kind of a waste since it's suppose to be Waygu. Finally, the papaya salad was refreshing, though kind of spicy for me. I was kind of supervised at the Romain lettuce and spring mix in the salad, but it doesn't taste weird, so I guess it's fine. 

Now that food review is over, I think their service is not as great. Our papaya salad was delivered to the next table, which also ordered one but ordered after us. Another waiter was bring another papaya salad to them and returned back to the kitchen after seeing that they already have one on their table. We eventually got the salad with the entree courses. We had to ask for water several times (since it was so spicy), last time before we asked for the check. The check came, but our water were never filled again. 

Overall, I would go back if I visit SF again. Definitely make a reservation if possible. The food is delicious and unique, but it would be better if the service can be just as good as the food!
author: Linda L.

description:
I think this place is very good.  It is really fun and the food itself is really tasty.  It is not going to wow you, but it is one of the stronger and tastier Thai places I went to.  Prices are a little above market but I'll trade that for better food.

Would have been 4* but for one thing.  The service is designed to rush you and turn over tables.  The wait staff continuously hover over your table and try and take your plates.  I literally had to tell the same server 5 times that I was still eating.  And I don't eat slowly! I had wads of food in my mouth each time I told him (sorry for the visual). 

My other guests all had their plates taken away the moment they dropped their guard, even if there was still a lot of food on the plate.  I mean is it so much to ask for that if you are paying for food that you get a chance to eat it? 

They just swooped it all away never asking if we needed a box or anything.  

Other than the very odd need to clear plates the service was friendly and fun. Too bad, because it is mostly a great place.
author: Tarek S.

description:
The Disney of Thai eateries. Not only was the atmosphere and entertainment on point but the food and drink also rose to the occasion. This place is too darned fun! I literally left wanting to book a flight to Thailand...because I'm sure its just like this ;) But, seriously, from the wardrobes of the staff to the birthday celebration songs with accompanying instruments, this eatery will be in my memory for months to come. In fact, I'd love to bring my team here during our next work trip to San Fran!

So, what did we eat and drink? 

Everything. Not quite but almost. The vegan soft spring rolls were incredibly tasty and served with eight small pieces (similar to sushi bite sizes). I appreciated that they used a thicker/different rice paper than you'll find at most other Thai eateries. I kicked my meal off with the Coco Lada with coconut cream and rum which was presented beautifully with a fruity garnish and umbrella. I was quickly taken back to beachy memories from our honeymoon in Vietnam. I could have guzzled several of these if not for knowing how fatty coconut cream can be. For my entrée I purchased the tofu veggie soup with rice noodles, pea pods, broccoli, tofu and a very refreshing and light broth. If I lived in San Fran, this would be my new go-to "sick soup". It was extremely light yet filling. Out of curiosity, I ordered a side of the ginger rice which also has garlic mixed in and I cannot recommend this dish enough. Great bonus add for whatever entrée you end up ordering! Finally for the finale: DESSERT! We rolled it all out with the bread pudding (which was some of the best bread pudding I've ever had - there is a reason the menu notes it as being a "house favorite") alongside the mango and sticky rice, coconut bowl filled with coconut granita (incredible!!) snd taro ice cream mixed with rice and red beans. All three were served on the dessert sampler. Perfect for a group!
author: Brittany S.

description: Thank you very much for amazing food!
author: Freda W.

description:
It's a great place for birthdays! Well maybe not so great for the embarrassed birthday girl/boy, but hilarious for everyone else. If you tell them you're there for a birthday when making the reservation, they have this whole birthday procession where 5-6 people slowly walk up to your table banging all sorts of percussion instruments and sing happy birthday not once but TWICE, all the while placing various accessories on the birthday person's body. (If you want to see a video of this, check out my video at https://www.instagram.com/p/BZ9KsMUjTIF/?taken-by=crazytensai in the second post). During the course of the 2 hours we were there, there were a total of 4 birthdays being celebrated, so this seems to be a popular spot for it!

Price-wise, it's definitely not your run of the mill Thai spot, so make sure you have the right expectations in mind when coming here. I was eyeing the crab fried rice, but felt like the $24 price point for it was a little high. Or $21 for their 24 hour beef noodle soup. I settled for the Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($19.50), which seems to be a popular dish according to Yelp reviews.

It was a much larger platter than I was imagining, as in addition to the fried chicken, you also get a serving of blue rice, yellow potato curry, and roti bread. It almost felt like two separate dishes, one with the fried chicken and the other with the curry / bread / rice combo. I definitely struggled to finish my dish and didn't end up eating most of my rice.

The fried chicken was a pretty large piece of breast, and while I was a little worried that it'd be dry (I'm personally not a huge fan of chicken breast), it actually turned out surprisingly moist and well flavored! I had no problem finished the chicken as that was my favorite part of the whole meal :) The curry was a little bit spicy for my tastes as I have very low spice tolerance, plus there was some cilantro in it which was a pain to pick out, but what I ate was tasty with the roti.

There were 7 of us, so we also opted to split a kick boxing bowl ($32 for 36 oz). I definitely recommend getting two for a group our size, as it was hard for all of us to reach the bowl and we had to constantly pass it around on the table and each person wasn't able to drink that much. It'd be good for 3-4 people, I think. It was a very sweet and fruity drink so I enjoyed it.

I'm sure it's bright inside during the day, but come dinnertime, they dim the lights way down and it becomes pretty hard to get a good shot. Apologies for the grainy shots!

Also, if you're all about that perfect 'gram shot, bring your phone with you when you go to the bathroom! I know that sounds weird, but the wall of the giant bathroom is painted with a gorgeous rainbow logo of Farmhouse Kitchen Thai. I was kicking myself for not bringing my phone to the bathroom when I saw it...lol
author: Dianna H.

description:
Whole Moley! The food, decor, service, and again.. the FOOD! By far one of the best (maybe the absolute best), dining experience I've ever had. 

 FOOD; we ordered the 24 hour beef noodle soup. amazing rich, hearty broth with an exotic sweet and sour Thai flavors! It came with Thin egg noddles that were perfectly al dente, a good amount of herbs, like lemongrass and slow simmered beef. It definitely appealed to my adventurous taste buds. 

But my favorite was actually the chefs special which had this garlic flavored rice, chicken, and of course various dipping sauces. 

Also their roti canal is amazing. Perfectly satisfying chewy and luscious carbs, while crispy on the outside... 
 
Some dishes that weren't my favorite (yet still enjoyable) : 
the friend chicken app. Too dry for my preference. Not much meat. Great flavor though 
 Blue rice: fun, tasted good, but overhyped and no where near tasty as the garlic rice.
author: Christina N.

description:
Came here for lunch on a weekday after an early yoga session, and I walked out feeling full and satisfied. We ordered two of their most popular dishes, the hat yai fried chicken and the papaya salad. The hat yai fried chicken was a little more on the pricier side, but it comes with so much more than just chicken. This dish included: curry with potatoes, roti, rice, and the fried chicken. Everything worked so well together! The chicken was crispy and not too oily. The papaya salad had a spicy kick to it, which I really enjoyed. 

The restaurant itself is decorated uniquely and kept very clean (big plus!!!) There is a long table in the middle which is perfect for a large party. Will be back soon to try the noodle soups and curries! Parking was difficult to find, even on a weekday. We found 2HR free parking a couple blocks away.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Amazing! Such a highlight of our trip. We were suggested to go here by someone we just so happened to be passing by. We had no reservations and they managed to get us a table at the bar once we arrived.

The service was incredible!! Everyone was so friendly and cheery that the atmosphere in the room was contagious and you couldn't help but also be happy and smiley. Our server took really good care of us at the bar. I ordered the beef soup which she recommended was very popular.

The soup was fantastic! The meat melted off the bone and the flavors were so good. I ordered medium spicy and it was a little spicier than I expected so just keep that in mind when ordering.

The night we dined there, they also seemed to be celebrating something and I actually won a free tshirt from the raffle they were having. Our server was also so kind to take a picture of my boyfriend and I, then have it printed out for us.

Dessert was unforgettable. I was already so stuffed from the soup but I couldn't pass up dessert it looked so good. We got the bread budding and it was delicious. I ate the entire thing even though I was already full.

This place is absolutely amazing! Such a great dining experience and will definitely be returning next time I visit San Francisco.
author: Hadeel A.

description: Great food, had street food dish Thai basil w choice of meat and fried egg w jasmine rice. Really good starters and specials too.
author: Tell It Like It Is ..

description:
Excellent decor, service with a smile, and delicious dishes! Our table of five experienced excellent service from a very happy and helpful server. We enjoyed several appetizer dishes including beef rolls and papaya salad. The main meals went very family-style-friendly, but we enjoyed scarfing them down nonetheless! (Our fault for not understanding the style of the service) I will certainly come back for a date night and order meals individually.  The wine list has plenty of variety and exotic cocktails and Asian beers are available to accompany the flavorful food. 

The meals are a bit pricey and fair warning: the dishes are spicy (duh! Thai food)
author: Andrea H.

description: Love this place a lot. After visiting tons of Thai places in San Francisco, I can say that FarmHouse Kitchen Thai is arguably the best Thai place in the city! Not just the authentic dishes, but the ambience, dessert, and places would easily win you over. Got some birthday? Brave enough for a spicy challenge? This place is absolutely for you to try!
author: Moorissa T.

description: Delicious authentic Thai. Surprised that there was a 45 min wait. We sat outside with heat lamps which were totally appreciated at night when it got chilly. The Thai iced tea is fun since it comes with a snow ball doused with condensed milk but there is a lot of ice so you do not end up with much iced tea. We loved the grilled shrimp pad Thai under the specials. The noodles were perfectly chewy and the sauce and tart and sweet. The braised beef special was melt off bone delicious. We also really loved the Fried chicken special that comes a with sweet curry and roti!!! We could not get enough of the roti and even ordered an extra order of it. The papaya salad was actually really spicy despite the "medium spicy" warning from the the server. We also got the drunken noodles which was not that spicy and lackluster compared to the special grilled shrimp pad Thai. Many dishes came with blue jasmine rice which apparently was cooked with a special blue flower. We got two desserts Thai vacation which is scraped coconut with vanilla ice cream which was ok but we hands down loved the famous Mango sticker rice - it was totally amazing!!!!
author: Vivian T.

description:
Came Saturday afternoon, customer service was prompt and answered all questions regarding menu items. Party of 8, we ordered appetizers, entrees, and desserts - photos attached. Total bill came out to almost 300 bucks, tips included. 

Customer service 3.5/5
Food taste 4/5
Price tag $$$

Overall, this is a good restaurant, but the items are on the more expensive end, ranging 20 and up per entree. Dessert platter was 30 bucks.  Good for small parties or first timers. Street parking only, tough neighborhood to find a space. No parking garages nearby.
author: Ed L.

description: A good place to dine in! It's always get crowded though,so be sure to manage your time or reserve it through Yelp before you get here. Service is nice. Food is good. The restaurant is well-decorated. A little bit finding parking spots though.
author: Ha D.

description:
Really good, really unique Thai food. Even the classic staple dishes are done really well. I really enjoyed the fried chicken, which comes with yellow curry. The flat bread goes so well with the rich curry, and the spicy honey sauce is great with the perfectly crisped chicken. Honestly there's so much food in this dish it could feed two people. I've also tried the green curry, which is a good level of spiciness with a lot of chicken. 

They also do a very fun and lively birthday cheer for you, complete with instruments. 

There's a bit of a wait, but the food is great.  I would definitely look forward to coming back here again.
author: Hali M.

description:
A few friends planned a get together at Farmhouse with Marley and her family. It was special to go with Marley as she reviewed the place on the Bay Area Show Check Please. So thankfully she did all the ordering and we just got to enjoy the food :) 

We arrived for lunch, and parking was pretty easy to find. We made reservations so we're seated immediately. It wasn't terribly crowded so I imagine those without reservations would be able to be seated pretty quickly as well. The interior was cutely decorated with a Halloween theme and the servers were also dressed in their fun Halloween costumes. 

Marley did all the ordering and we ended up getting Kobe beef jerky and par dip fresh tuna for appetizers. The kobe beef jerky was their house marinated wagyu beef with a delicious black dog chili sauce. The meat was very tender and marinated well :) the fresh tuna was a diced maguro tuna, which was also quite yummy.

For the main dishes we ordered the herbal rice salad, the hat yai fried chicken, the panang neua, the pad Thai, and the 24 hours beef noodle soup. Everything was delicious! The two dishes that stood out to me were the hat yai fried chicken and the panang Bria. The fried chicken was paired well with the yellow curry, and there was a sauce and honey on the side to dip the chicken in. The flavoring was so delicious! And the panang neua is amazing .. the meat literally melts in your mouth. I would go here everyday if I could :P apparently they do something amazing to their rice to make it such a pretty blue color :)

The servers recognized Marley from Check Please and were so kind to give us dessert on the house. The chocolate cake, apple pastry, and coconut ice cream were all amazing! Whenever I have guests in town I will definitely take them here :)
author: Jackie C.

description:
When people say "I am not a fan of..." they probably had some really bad first time experiences. I fell into that boat with Thai food -my previous experiences were so-so. There was something about the coconut-based curries that I did not like. 

That all changed with Farmhouse Kitchen Thai! Whoa! What an eye-opener! If all Thai restaurants served food of this caliber, there certainly would be more people loving Thai food. But, of course, that would mean everywhere would be good and the novelty lost. Thank heavens for bad Thai food and the mouth-wateringly good Farmhouse Kitchen!

Many of the entrees are served family style, enough for three or four people. If everyone ordered a different entree in a four-person party, the resulting meal would be more than satisfying!

If I were in the mood for their soup - temperature hot, with tender-but-crunchy vegetables, and a rich coconut curry soup base was sooo good, I must remember to order it the next time I come here (and I will return...). I didn't order it, but I tried someone else who had ordered it and wow! I immediately fell in love with this delicious soup!

The green curry had flavor bursting out the moment you tasted it, followed immediately by a good amount of spicy heat! Nice! 

The Pad Thai, with it's striking orange color, sticky noodles and a good amount of combo seafood, served over a bed of bean sprouts, made the saliva glands explode with tasty goodness!

The Pad See You with the flat noodles also had great flavor - with only a mild amount of spice

The Panang Neua (with a big marinated short rib) had meat that just fell off the bone, it was so tender! (My mouth is watering even as I type this!)

And finally, the Coconut bread pudding with a delicate soufflé with a caramel glazes on top, with a scoop of coconut ice cream and whipped cream with slices of strawberries - oh, so yummy!

There are so many other items on the menu I want to try. I cannot wait to come here again. Farmhouse Kitchen Thai, you have me sold in Thai food! Thank you!

Unfortunately, I must dock one star for the toilet. Unisex with one person occupancy, it smelled so heavily of urine that I had to step outside the restaurant to clear my palate as to enjoy the food. Great restaurants should pay more attention to their restrooms. . .
author: Vernon M.

description:
My friends and I came here for my birthday last year and I loved everything about this place. Group dining or date night, Farmhouse is the perfect place to enjoy some good food.

Inside is beautiful with dim lights and wooden tables. The dishes are detailed and thoughtful.

To start of with, we got some thai tender coconuts. They were refreshing as always. The herbal tea was average, I wouldn't get it again.
We also got some cocktails - the coconut pina coloda was sweet but good.

The vegan spring rolls are beautiful and good too. My boyfriend is a big fan of the tom yum soup and we always end up ordering it in thai restaurants. At farmhouse, it was good but had half-tomato sized chunks of tomato in it.

My friend said that the hat yai fried rice was delicious. I love the roti and curry that comes with it. They also had blue rice which sounded very interesting and is a good thing to try but honestly it didn't taste any different from regular white rice.

We also got the Pad Kee Mao and Green curry and they were all good
and were the right portion sizes.

We ended our meals on a high note, the restaurant employees gave me a Lei to wear, they sang me the happy birthday song and we got some thai coconut icecream to share. Such a fun night and a great place to hang out with a big group.
author: Preeti R.

description:
PROS
Great service 
Delish food and drinks 
Entertaining experience ( love their birthday song routine) 
Superb location 

CONS
Pricey Thai food
author: Eleanor F.

description:
If you have ADD, this place may not be for you.  It is LOUD and at times, sensory overload.  But I'll be damned if that short rib curry is not one of the delicious things I've consumed recently.

Also, if you hate restaurant birthdays, be forewarned.  It seems that everyone here is celebrating a birthday and they go all out with the cymbals, a bull horn, and lots of thai song.  In the 1.5 hours that I dined here they probably erupted in birthday song 7 times.
author: Clarissa P.

description: Food is bomb, and the interior is so much fun. Feels like a celebration. And they have such a fun way of singing happy birthday to their guests! I also loved seeing them in the Pride parade this past year.
author: Nic G.

description: Super cool place! Feels like a party inside. We had the punch bowl type drink and it was super tasty. Over all the food was great I would recommend it to anyone
author: Caitlan B.

description:
Our experience was absolutely terrible. 
We have continued to discourage our friends from going here. 
The food is overpriced, and they make Pad Thai with what looked, tasted and seemed like angel hair pasta. 
The food was subpar.
author: Lamia R.

description:
My parents were visiting from Germany, so I was looking for a nice restaurant that's a little different from what you can get back home, but not crazy expensive. I hadn't been before, but heard only praises for Farmhouse Kitchen, so this was an easy choice. And it delivered on everything! My parents loved it, so did I. 

We ordered the vegan fresh rolls and fried calamari as starters and then some of the Thai street food as the main course: Pad Kee Mow and Pad Black Pepper Garlic. Everything was delicious and flavorful, I especially loved the sauces that the starters came with. 

The atmosphere is casual, colorful, happy, welcoming - everything you want of a restaurant. With food, drinks, a shared dessert & tip for 3 people, we ended up at around $130. Not cheap, but still reasonable for the great experience we got. I'll be back!
author: Katja S.

description:
Fun place with tasty food!

Loud, colorful, energetic.  Expect a fun night.  The food was great too, only downside was the huge portion of food we each received.  Not really a bad thing, I hate wasting food so take-away containers will be in your future.

Will definitely return!
author: Rick G.

description: It's great for groups and is a fun place to celebrate one's birthday. Beware, if it is your birthday they will put a gigantic hat on your head, a lei necklace and the staff will come out singing and playing instruments and make the whole restaurant know it's your birthday. That's what happened to me. My face was red. This place is always busy, make sure you reserve in advance. They have the usual Thai staples like fried rice, noodles, soup, etc,.. and they have some more fancier dishes which is great to share within your group. They even have fried critters if you are daring to try, like the ones sold in the streets in Thailand. They also serve alcoholic drinks.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Nice quiet residential neighborhood. Great food with huge seating area and great Thai food from the old days with the traditional plates.
You must go here and you'll know why.
author: Mehran A.

description:
Yes - love this place! Although the name associates with something else, this place has some delicious Thai food on the menu! 
I came here with a friend on a Wednesday evening - and we were treated well, and had some great Thai food!! 
The papaya salad, in particular, was really good (and spicy!) :)
author: Nadia S.

description: Don't come here I'f you're picking up for Postmates. I ordered three things and they told me 15-20 minutes max. It's now been 35 minutes and counting. Their famous excuse to keep me on their line is that they're packing it now. Garbage customer service. Be straight up with me.never again.
author: Jake T.

description: We like their food.. good green curry , samosa & vegan rolls. The food was good but the place was loud. We were bunch of wine drinkers and they didn't have wines on the wine list which was a bummer.
author: Ankita J.

description:
It's going to be difficult for me to be constructive (read:negative) here, because I really did enjoy the food and experience at Farmhouse. However, their prices are out of control and doesn't match up with the portion size. I got the Panang Neua (short rib on the bone with blue rice and veges). The short rib was soft, flavorful and you could tell it was properly marinated, but it costs $30!!! They bump up their prices so much that their only menu can't even keep up (btw, why do they have blue text on a black background on their site...no one can read that -__-). 

I know it's SF, but my meal was not worth what it cost. There are way too many other Thai options in the area, for me to allow this to happen again..
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Came here with some friends for lunch while visiting San Francisco and was not disappointed! Knowing this place fills up pretty quickly, we actually got to the restaurant before it opened and we were one of the first people who got seated. 

We ordered a Tom Yom Soup to share and boy, this place does not mess around with their spice! We got medium spicy and I was sweating with each bite but the soup was delicious and loaded with stuff so it was a good burn. We also got this beef roll appetizer which was also really really good. I ordered the 24 Hour Beef Noodle Soup which was HUGE. The beef short rib practically fell from the bone the minute I touched it and was so tender. The broth was also really good albeit a little too sweet for my taste. My boyfriend got the Hat Yai Fried Chicken which was also huge and delicious. 

Overall, I had a great experience. The prices here are on the pricier side but the portions are pretty large. Had we known how large the portions were, we wouldn't have over-ordered.
author: Rachel Z.

description:
I came here on a Sunday evening, thinking it would be relatively easy to get a table. I was wrong. The wait was 40 minutes. I put my name down since I had to wait for my girlfriend to arrive as well, but the time went by pretty quickly. 

Once we were both seated, a waiter was promptly over asking if we wanted anything to drink and such. We just stuck with water but ordered the samosas for appetizers. The samosas came with this amazing sauce and were pretty sizeable. I think we had 1.5 samosas each. 

For our main meal we got the salmon wrapped in banana leaves, yellow curry, and pad thai. The salmon came first and we ate that extremely quickly. We barely had any room for the pad thai and yellow curry, but we got that to go.

The waiter actually packaged our stuff for us and we got the bill and were on our way. For how busy they were, I think we were out in 30-40 minutes. It was a quick dinner and we had yummy leftovers for days. I'll for sure return here!
author: James D.

description:
Eh. I ordered the wings and I got four small dinky wings that were not panko breaded and for almost $11 I want to roll my eyeballs out of their sockets. 

My fried rice was pretty bland. I had to ask for the spice tray. The crispy pork belly I asked to top it with was dry and hard which was a bummer. 

Friend enjoyed her panang chicken. 

The two desserts we ordered took longer than our meal to order AND eat. 

Taking it down a notch.
author: Walerz B.

description:
Checked out Farmhouse with a group of 12 due to the rave reviews of many fellow yelpers. It was definitely a fun experience and there were some amazing dishes in the mix, though we didn't love everything and the service wasn't perfect. 

I made a reservation weeks earlier but didn't get a phone confirmation the day before or day of, so I called them to make sure they'd have a spot for us when we showed up. They seemed a little confused on the phone but told us we were good to go. I heard that for past group dinners, my coworkers were greeted with a fresh coconut at each place setting, making for a memorable start to the meal. I requested the same and they said it would be no problem. 

When we arrived, the coconuts were missing and when I asked the server about them they seemed to have no idea what I was talking about, and offered to bring them out late. By that point people were already ordering cocktails and the effect was a bit lost, so I told them to forget it, but it was a little disappointing. 

The server was on top of it and was good about suggesting order amounts. I have to admit that I didn't believe her and ordered more than she suggested, and we ended up having leftover food. 

The highlights for me were the fried chicken dish and the short rib dish.  The group didn't like the prawn pad thai and many said the prawns were 'off.' I didn't take my chances so I didn't taste it myself. They did a great job accommodating our vegan members and I was really impressed with how they really didn't mess a single thing up on our order. 

The funniest part of the night was when we had a birthday song for someone in our party. An entire mini parade came out, clanging symbols, draping props on the birthday boy, and singing for what seemed like a really long time. I wonder if other diners in the place get annoyed when they have to be there for someone else's birthday... but in any case we thought it was hilarious! 

It's a big space, good for groups, and they make dining fun. Next time I'll make sure not to over order so I can take advantage of the small street style dishes passed around by servers holding big traditional looking baskets!
author: Christina P.

description:
Five Things To Know:

1. The beef salad is SPICY. But delicious. But SPICY.

2. If you scream out "SEND NOODS!" People will not think that you are asking the kitchen to send out your noodle dishes, which you have adorably abbreviated.

3. Farmhouse Thai offers the finest birthday celebration I have ever seen, replete with a screaming rubber chicken, a ridiculous hat and dollar bill necklace for the birthday boy, delicious dessert, and lots of loud and obnoxious singing. This makes up for the lack of attentive service, in my book.

4. The samosas, fried chicken, and the slow-braised shortribs with the blue rice were DOPE. Get all of these things. And that beef salad.

5. I was less enamored with the large bowl of cocktail that we felt obliged to get, the Ahi Cups, and the prawn pad thai. You can get all of these things if you want, but I personally wasn't into 'em.
author: Peter D.

description:
Wow a solid delicious thai spot in the SF, one of my favorites. This place is always busy and after trying the food I understand why. The food was delicious and the service was good. The place itself is a tiny spot so there might be a wait but they do take reservations and it seems like you can order takeout and delivery. 
Came here with a group of friends and we just ordered various things from the menu. Some of the items I thought were awesome were the samoas, calamari, 24hrs beef soup, pad sww ew, and their bread pudding. The other items we got (braised beed rib, bbq chicken, eggplant curry, thai wings were also good but it didn't wow me like the previous item i listed. The staff here are colorfully dressed and the vibe here is super chill. fyi it is loud but not unreasonable, also parking here can be a pain cause its right by residential property so if you can bike/uber/walk you should do that. They have a fairly extensive menu and I'll be glad to come back to try some of their other stuff.
author: Peter P.

description:
There is ALWAYS a wait, and we're talking more $$-$$$ for dinner per person, but my god, the *Hat Yai Fried Chicken* is so freaking good that I can't help but come back again and again to order it. On the one occasion I felt like venturing out and getting something different, their 24-hr Beef Noodle Soup was also great. I recommend starting off with the Neua Num Tok Rolls (4x wagyu beef rolls) for appetizers *DELICIOUS*. 

The ambiance is so fun here, definitely a popular place for birthdays and celebrations! They'll come out with drums and cymbals, with the waiters dressed festively. They also deck the place out for holidays like Halloween and Thai New Years. 

*PRO TIP* 
-- Make reservations in advance to avoid/minimize the wait. Every time I go there is always at least a 45 min-1hr wait for dinner. 
-- For parties of 2, ask to sit at the bar!  (You will often be seated faster)
author: Justine H.

description:
A great Thai restaurant in the mission! I really dig this place. Came on a Friday night to grab dinner with a friend and we were seated promptly (we opted for the bar). Inside the restaurant, it's dark, busy, and lively. Seriously tons of stuff going on! Hosts dressed up in colorful Thai outfits and cool decor everywhere. It's casual and upbeat and man, so much character. The staff is friendly and if it's your birthday, they sing to you. Very very loudly. Be warned! 

The food was delicious. There's a decent amount of items on the menu and a few vegetarian options. I ordered a noodle soup, can't remember what it was exactly but see the picture! DELICIOUS. Perfect portion size. Lots of stuff in the dish not just soup ya know. I asked for medium spicy but it wasn't that bad. It definitely builds up and sneaks up on you but they must have thought I couldn't handle real Thai level spice. (Somewhat true LOL). Prices were decent for SF dinner (12-30 per entree. My friend ordered some fried chicken dish and he loved it also.

Definitely need to come back and try other dishes at this place.
author: Amy T.

description:
Not all hope is lost!! I wanted to update my review because since my first review, they have since reached out to me to apologize for my experience and also reimbursed $30 for the meal.   Not so much about the money but more about how they handled my experience that made me change my mind. 

My experience as mentioned in my first review was great up until my insect encounter. I think that this place could deserve another shot and though I'm deathly afraid of most bugs, maybe some day I'll have the courage to try Farmhouse again.
author: Shelly W.

description: Perfect street style Thai food. We have been here 5 or 6 times and love it. Nice for groups as well. The drinks are fun and if you're adventurous there some interesting things on the menu (that I haven't tried)
author: Jay R.

description: Second time in a while here, but this time with my lovely wife and my dear princess daughter. If you come you have to order their Pad Thai, Thai Tea, blue rice any of the specials they offer. It's hard to go wrong with this guys. Great festive atmosphere
author: Juan D.

description:
Very very cool concept. Instead of trying to be westernized "modern chic", they totally embraced motifs found in countryside Thailand with tacky music and karaoke lighting. It's also quite a show when the staff gather to sing happy birthday for guests. 

Perhaps we ordered the wrong item, somehow the dishes felt too refined and westernized. I'd say the food itself is only 3-star but the overall vibe kicked it up to 4-star. Would go back again. Especially for birthdays!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Super attentive service and mouthwatering dishes.

This place is fun - seriously. The waiters are dressed in traditional, colorful, Thai clothes and they walk around with random dishes of food. Want to try fried grasshopper (and we did), you can do that here. Looking for a bucket of fried bananas? No issue, grab the server. I love spotting food and being able to say "I want that" and immediately getting a plate of it. 

The dishes themselves are phenomenal. I was dining with a huge group of 11, so that meant a lot of food. There were three dishes in particular that stood out to me. The Hat Yai Fried Chicken was amazing. It was perfectly seasoned and fried. That is a no brainer to get. The Pad Thai is also incredible. Those noodles rocked my socks off. The short rib (Panang Neua Dinner) was so incredibly tender that I was cutting it with a fork. There you go, I've given you your order.

Do not forget dessert. Although I've had better fried bananas at the Thai temple near my home, the dessert we ordered off the menu was all amazing. We had dessert sticky rice, chocolate cake, and a bread with rice inside that none of us could pronounce but we all declared the best dessert of the bunch. 

This place is a great choice for dinner. Just don't forget to make Yelp Reservations, because it does get packed!
author: Christina G.

description:
The food was great and the service was excellent. 
Highly recommend this place if anyone looking for a good thai food.
author: Inthira J.

description:
We made a reservation of 8 for early dinner. The décor of the restaurant was very unique. Same as the outdoor the restaurant staff. Restaurant was not full when we got there. 

-1 star 
It was unfortunate that we were giving a table which didn't allow us to sit comfortably because couple chairs happened to be placed in by the legs of the table. We couldn't really squeeze because of how the chairs were. Sitting partially side way was the only option. 

-1 star 
We brought our cake for the birthday ladies which the server noticed that it was a birthday dinner. We were then advised that there would be $1.5 per slice service charge. We didn't end up cutting the cake there since we were full by the end of the dinner. As we got the cake back, the cake cutter was missing.

-1 star
Dishes were not impressive overall, and overpriced. 

-1star
Service was not adequate. Nothing special. As they already know that it was a birthday dinner, there was nothing, not even a happy birthday to the ladies. 

As we left, there was a wait list. Not sure what was the hype about this restaurant. I have had better.
author: Lianna D.

description:
Amazing! I would totally come back.
The food was so good  I highly recommend the hat yai chicken and the jumbo grilled prawns!!
author: Hanna C.

description:
Yummy place my friends and I visited on a whim. I get the impression that it's always busy, and we waited 45 minutes to be seated. No big deal, they have outside seating and the weather was nice out! 
Decorations are really pretty, my friend loved all the flower arrangements as well as the head pieces worn by the staff. 
I was basic and had fried rice with crispy pork belly, my boyfriend had the wagyu beef, and my other two friends had pad see ew and pad Thai. Everyone enjoyed their meals, and I'm a sucker for crispy pork belly and they give you a good size as well (esp for being ~$5 extra). My boyfriends dish came with an interesting sauce, sweet, a little sour/spicy that he didn't like but I loveddd for my pork belly. I mopped it up!!! Made my dish. One of my friends asked for their spiciest sauce and they came out with a platter with four different ways to spice up your dish, one labeled "grandmas sauce" that's supposed to be the spiciest. Supposedly it still wasn't spicy enough for him, but if you have an average level of spice tolerance it should be pretty spicy for you. 
It's a bit pricey, but it's in SF and it's just one of those joints. It was loud and there's music going and the birthday song had drums, but it's all part of the fun. Good place!
author: Ronita S.

description:
I really wanted to like this place and even came a second time after having a subpar experience here to give it another shot. Farmhouse is just okay in my opinion, and I'm surprised to hear people raving about this place. I had a better experience this time around, but it still doesn't particularly impress me. It's not very authentic in my opinion and I'm not expert on Thai food but I've definitely had better experiences at other restaurants in SF. I would say this place is more an expensive hipster Asian fusion spot to eat at with lively decor and ambiance.

The first time I came we shared a lot of the typical dishes family style. None of it really stood out to me even though I don't remember what we had. Also don't really find the blue rice that impressive, since it's just regular rice that happens to be colored. There's a lot of potential for it, maybe could take some inspiration for how tasty and unique purple rice is at Korean joints. The presentation of the food comes on huge plates so I'd imagine that I'm getting a better deal for the entrees I'm paying for.. but I'm still not convinced. The food is generally pretty whitewashed.

I decided to try the most popular dish here to see what the hype was all about.

24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup - Slow cooked bone-in beef short rib, egg noodles, veal broth, broccolini, basil, bean sprouts, cilantro, green onion & pork fat garlic oil. Came pretty quickly in a huge bowl. The price on the menu is $23.95 but with tip and tax it could run you more than $30 which is ridiculous. It's good beef noodle soup and the broth was done pretty well, don't get me wrong but if I'm paying that much for an Asian dish it needs to exceed expectations.

I think a big part of why Farmhouse fell short for me was because of the scrappy service. Our waiter was hard to reach, and would often run off before we finished what we were asking for. We ended up having to flag a lot of other random waiters, some who ignored us. 

It's good but not great, and in my book this place is overrated.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen Thai is my favorite local Thai eatery (which I really like and frequent) making it with my second favorite local Thai eatery (which I also really like) and their offspring graduating from Thai eatery grad school. 

Get:

Pork Belly Pad Thai
Blue Rice
Everything
author: James G.

description:
Came here for my birthday dinner. :) 

I opted for more unique Thai dishes, so I got the Hat Yai fried chicken special dish. It was delicious, but at the same time not stand out enough to make this my top Thai place. The dish was certainly unique -- I've never had blue rice before (tastes the same, but the color just gives it that punch of novelty that I was intrigued by), and the plating was super cool. Another thing to note that compared to the menu images in Yelp, the actual pricing for some items have gone up (Hai Yat fried chicken was $22). 

Overall, a good experience, and I would recommend!
author: Sharon W.

description:
Group dining or date night, Farmhouse Thai is the perfect place for a food-focused night out. 

Inside is cuuuute the dishes are detailed and thoughtful and you can get delicious twists on both your Thai and American faves. 

I usually get anything with either crab or prawns - if I had to pick between the two, I'd say the prawn dishes are a better bang for your buck. 

For apps the Ahi scoops aren't super plentiful but they're sooo good. Maybe my fave. At least top 3 things here. 

The vegan spring rolls are beautiful and super good, too. 

Their Tom Yum soup is p good but there's like half-tomato sized chunks of tomato. It's hard to even get it on the spoon and it's the kind of thing where if you're getting a thing of soup you probably don't want 1/3 of your order to be single half tomato. 

Oh and the herbal rice salad is as beautiful as it is tasty. 

Oh and I heard that on some special Friday nights they have Thai street food baskets of fried bugs that sound so cool. Need to come back to try.
author: Candice G.

description:
Thanks to Yelp reservations my large party of 12+ people was able to get a table right away on a busy Thursday night. 

The restaurant and ambiance are beautiful - dim lights, wooden tables, Thai trinkets everywhere. You just know you're walking into a Thai restaurant the moment you walk in. We were sat in the middle of the restaurant at a long table. We were greeted by our server who took our drink orders right away. We started off by grabbing a bottle of white wine for each side of the table. 

Looking at the menu, they serve a wide variety of Thai dishes ranging from curries, soups, noodles, and "street food". We decided to two separate orders since we were such a large party and share with our respective side of the table. To start off, my side of the table ordered the kobe beef jerky, tom yam soup, mango salad, fresh rolls, and thai sausages. All of them were delicious. My favourite being the tom yam soup (perfectly spiced and flavourful) and the mango salad (surprisingly spicy, but perfect blend with the sweet mangoes). 

For our main dishes, I can't even remember everything we ordered, but there was a green and red curry, chicken pad thai, pad kee mow, and a few other dishes. All I remember from this meal is that I was one stuffffed lady! Everything I put into my mouth was tasty, spicy and flavourful. Everything you'd want for your Thai food - unless you're not big on spice. One thing that was really memorable was the servers walking around with bucket-like containers attached to a long pole that they balanced on their shoulders. They would come around offering smaller dishes such as crickets, shrimp, and smaller noodle dishes. Me and a few others tried the cricket, and after experiencing my first cricket, I can't say it was the worst thing I've ever eaten. The spice of it masked it's "cricket-ness" and all I remember is that it was really crunchy. Happy I could cross that off the bucket list! 

Overall, you can't go wrong with any of the dishes you order here. As Brett N said, all the dishes we tried ranged from good to great. Large groups, family dinners, date nights, you can have it all at the Farmhouse Kitchen. Definitely a must-try when you're in SF!
author: Issabelle F.

description:
One of my favorite Thai restaurant in SF.
So many yummy authentic food and very nice presentation. We did order many dishes and everything turned out nicely and very flavorful.
No wonder why this place is always busy.
We went there twice already within a month! 
This place is fun for the birthday celebration as well
The servers come up with the music instrument to sing a birthday song for you at the table!
Can't say enough, I would highly recommended if you want to try Thai food.
Definitely go back !
author: cathaleeya K.

description:
Wow, what a remarkable experience! I had high expectations after my manager said she booked reservations at Farmhouse Kitchen for a team dinner during a brief stay in SF. Of course I scanned their Yelp page, website, and menu before our arrival and I was so excited. I personally have a lot of dietary restrictions and I was pumped that this spot was able to work with my diet. The reviews on the page raved about how good the food was and the place looks absolutely beautiful. 

Our reservations were for 7PM and we got there about ten minutes early. I loved all the plants outside of the building and the colorful streamers. It really set the stage for dinner. We walked through the front doors and were instantly greeted by the host and were told it'd only be a few minutes before we would be taken to our table. Not only was the host decked out in vibrant Thai clothing but the staff was pretty decorative as well. I loved the bright colors, plants hanging from the ceiling and fun music playing lightly enough to not disrupt our table conversations. 

Once our table was ready we took our seats and dove right into the drink menu. Their drinks are somewhat tiki style but also a little classy. I ordered the flower spritzers and it was super light and refreshing. It included elderflower liquor, Thai rose bitters, sparkling wine, and rosemary. I loved that it came with a sprig of rosemary. Give me any drink with fresh herbs in it and I guarantee I'll love it! Next up were the appetizers. We ordered a few different ones for the table to share. We got the vegan fresh rolls, the "Mieng Kum Kung" also know as the crispy crusted prawns, and the Neua Num Tok Rolls. The vegan fresh rolls were awesome. They had some tofu, fresh herbs, bean sprouts, and noodles and came with a side of pickled vegetables. There was also a side of peanut sauce, which was awesome. Just how I like it! The prawns were honestly out of this world and I highly suggest you try them. They were fried and laid upon a piece of lettuce. It was almost like a little wrap. The third option we had I didn't try due to it being mainly beef but my teammates said it was delicious. After drinks and apps we placed our entrée order. I decided on the Mok Salmon, which came with a banana leaf wrapped piece of salmon, grilled asparagus, and blue rice. There was also a side of sauce, something with cilantro and lime. It was seriously amazing. I could drink this stuff. If they sold it, I would buy it and put it on everything. The salmon was cooked perfect, as was the asparagus, and the rice was the perfect texture. I did wonder how it was blue though...

Last but not least was dessert. We were celebrating a teammate and my manager snuck out to inform the staff. They went above and beyond to make her feel special. Not only did she receive an extravagant song and dance but a giant platter of desserts. There was ice cream, macaroons, brownies, flavored ice, etc. We all shared it, trying a few bites of each item. My favorite was the little macaroon. It was tiny but very tasty. 

If you're into this type of cuisine and find yourself in the area, do yourself a favor and come here. I do highly recommend you make a reservation ahead of time, as it was really busy. Like seriously, the place was poppin! Overall, you walk out of this place feeling like you just went on a mini vaca and let's be honest, who doesn't need that from time to time?
author: Jayme H.

description:
I expected much more from an authentic Thai restaurant. The portions were alright; however, the prices were too pricey for only mediocre food.

The only thing I really liked here was their thai tea and the Neua Nom Tok Rolls. Those were both made perfectly.
author: Lisa N.

description:
You step right into Thailand when you walk into the restaurant. The lively music and the costumed uniforms on all the servers add to building a great sense of fun. 

Tips:

Make reservations, on any day, they are always busy.

Parking is around the neighborhood only

Bar area also serves food.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Update: I'm still very unhappy with my experience, but I've increased the rating due to the fact that the restaurant let me know that they will contact Caviar to refund my order asap. 

--

I just barely choked down some of the fried rice I ordered via Caviar. The most important ingredient, the meat, was dry and stinky, so I left most of it (and I paid extra for beef! grrr!), and the overall dish didn't taste fresh. I thought the tomatoes were okay, but the dish contained only two pieces. 

This has to be the worst fried rice I've ever had. And overpriced. 

Are you going to contact Caviar to refund my order or shall I?
author: Paulina F.

description: Farmhouse is definitely one of the pricey Thai restaurant in San Francisco but in my opinion, it's kind of worth it to try it at least once! We got the chicken pad Thai and liked it. We also got an ice coffee I believe. The downside with the ice coffee was that it was 90% ice and 10% ice coffee, so you're kind of paying for the ice mainly.... the service was great. They made us felt very welcomed. I highly recommend you to book a reservation because the wait time can be very high. The atmosphere of this restaurant is so cute! The servers dressed in their traditional gown which makes it feel like you're on a tropical island!
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food is exquisitely prepared, so fresh and delicious the style is more family group eating vs individual entree...love it!
author: Gillian B.

description: Long lines but worth the wait! The short rib noodle soup is super fragrant and the beef was cooked so Tender it falls off the bones easily. The fried chicken is probably their most popular dish and it never disappoints
author: Weich Y.

description:
Came here with a friend and got to say, I'll for sure be coming back! I love how enthusiastic the staff members are and how lively it was in there. They really go all out for birthdays so if you want to embarrass your friends, bring them here! 

We started off with a drink and I got something with rosemary in it and it was pretty delicious, not too sweet! My friend got a sour beer that was really useful for cleansing the palate of how spicy the food was!

We got a papaya salad with fermented fish to share and WOOOO!! was it spicy! But in a good way, our lips were burning, but there was SO much flavor in it. It wasn't just pure spiciness. The fermented fish also added a nice kick of flavor to the dish that was delightful! I wish I could have more right now. I believe my friend got the mild tom yum noodle soup and I got the khao soi. The khao soi was a little sweet to my liking and I wish it was spicier, like the papaya salad, but it had a lot of flavor as well. Khao soi is traditionally chicken curry, but they made it with short ribs. 

I definitely will be back to get more papaya salad and to try their other drinks and food!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
My only regret from my trip to Farmhouse Kitchen, is that I couldn't try more things from the menu! I find this to be the case with so many places I eat in San Francisco because I know the likelihood of going to the same place twice is very slim. And with this meal with just my wife and I, you can't be a gluttonous fool and order the 10 things that sound good. But I digress.

I love unique and very local feeling places. And when we were dropped off in an off-the-beaten path neighborhood and then seated by a tiny asian man dressed in drag, I got the warm fuzzies that we were in for a treat.

After VERY much deliberation of what we wanted to get, we ultimately said we will split an appetizer and go on our own for the entree. Not the most ideal for trying multiple items. But with one shot at this, my wife and I decided selfish decisions had to made. To start, we got the Neua Num Tok Rolls. It was not at all like I expected. But the "rolls" were actually the extremely tender flavorful Wagyu beef. The savory flavors of the meat mixed so well with the cold, crunchy cucumber and mint. This was an incredibly, well designed dish that had such good complimenting flavors.

I decided to go with apparently what they are most famous for, the Hat Yai fried chicken. That was one decision I will never regret. It came with a yellow curry that was nearly as good as the chicken itself. But throw in some blue rice and get a nice forkful of curry and chicken... sheer bliss. It was absolutely amazing. I could not consider giving this place even the thought of anything less than 5 stars.
author: Will B.

description:
It was amazing, they have a special way to hooray for you birthday, the food is really good, especially the Thai Vacation, it is a desert. But the neighborhood is not so safe, so do not leave any thing to your car and make sure that you park you car as close to the restaurant as possible!!

IT is good for someone love spicy!!!
author: Jackson L.

description:
Really enjoyed Farmhouse.  

Ordered the Hat Yai Fried Chicken, Panang Neua, and green curry with pork belly - all were packed with flavors.   Also got the black sticky rice with ube ice-cream with dessert, which was delicious. :) 

It is a bit pricey, but the portions are huge for such heavy dishes.  Would come back!
author: Christine A.

description: Came here for lunch on a Friday at about 11:45 and there were plenty of seats. By the time we left, the restaurant was filled and had people waiting for seats.  I ordered the Pad See You $14.95 with beef for additional $1.50. The food was good, a bit on the salty side.  The noodles were cooked just right and they gave lots of beef and sauce.  The carrots were sliced really thin and it came with Chinese broccoli.   My friends orders the Pad Garlic Asparagus with chicken which came with the blue rice, and the Kai Yang Som Tum, which she said was very good.  All in all the food was really good and the restaurant was clean and the staff were friendly.
author: P G.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen is my favorite Thai food in the city. Prices are more than you'd typically expect for Thai food but portions here are MASSIVE and no matter what you order, you're going to get something delicious. One entree is easily shareable for two people, so if you can, try to come with a few people so you can order a few things and eat family style. 

I ordered the Tom Yum soup, and my friend ordered the fried chicken + curry plate. The batter of the fried chicken is a bit unusual since it looks like battered fish and chips, but it's simply one of the juiciest, crispiest chicken I've had in a long time. 10/10 would recommend. If you're ordering a curry, do yourself a favor and skip the rice (+$3), and instead, ask for more of their nann like bread (more like a Chinese cong you bing). The blue rice is definitely a novelty; however, it honestly doesn't taste any different than regular white rice. At first I was thinking it'd be something more like the purple rice you'd find at many Korean restaurants, but that's not the case here. 

Last but not least, the service here is top notch. If you're unfamiliar with anything on the menu or not quite sure what to get, don't be shy to ask the wait staff and they'll gladly explain things to you and provide recommendations.

Sorry for the disorganized brain dump of things I liked about Farmhouse, but do yourself a favor: stop reading and check it out for yourself :)
author: Austin W.

description:
Such a wonderful experience! This place deserves 5 stars because I would definitely come back. This isn't a one time thing. Who ever visits SF or I want to go on a fun date with or have a girls night with, I would take here. 

The ambiance is extremely lively. Place is filled with Thai decor and is bright colors. All the workers are in floral shirts, and all of them are extremely friendly just like Thai culture. 

My friend and I got the Hat Yai Fried Chicken with curry, naan, and blue rice. The plate was beautifully placed. The chicken was delicious. Super juicy and paired perfectly with the curry. And the blue rice just looks cool hahah. The workers also came around offering grasshoppers, which I've never had. It was good! Crispy. Nothing too crazy! 

Overall, great place :) Super fun!
author: Frances T.

description:
Ate here once so far and I'm a big fan. Its a super comfortable and bright ambiance, and I think it would be perfect for lunch time get togethers with old friends.

The ingredients were very fresh and felt clean. I would recommend asking for the spice levels if you're sensitive to spice since it does get a bit spicy. We ordered the 24 hour beef noodle soup, which was a unique dish and not too spicy. I'd definitely recommend doing family-style because dishes like the beef noodle soup isn't really ideal to eat as one person.
author: Angus L.

description: Actually a great place, the atmosphere is specifically live and food quality is also good although a bit pricy, go there if you have a birthday party, they will sing a great Thai song for ya
author: Jay G.

description:
A great place to have some fun on a Saturday night in the Mission. Pros: ambiance, flavors, portion-size; Cons: price, too much hype?

Food: We ordered the samosas to start and boy are they tasty. The dipping sauce is super addictive and helps cut through the warm flavors of the samosa itself. Pretty pricy at ~$10 for just 3 samosas. For mains we got green curry, fried chicken, pad see ew, and more green curry (with noodles). Everything was flavored really well with good portion sizes. The green curry was a little runnier than I'm used to, but nothing a little blue rice couldn't soak up. (By the way, it's literally just dyed jasmine rice. A little gimmicky since there's no taste difference... but I can't argue that it looks cool.) Pad see ew was delicious and I loved how fresh all the vegetables were. High quality food. We left clutching our sides and aching for a nap by the end. 

Atmosphere: What a unique spot -- decorated in a strange industrial/Thai style with staff dressed in island-like apparel. The birthday celebrations are INTENSE and COMMON. There is no way there were 5 birthdays going on in the hour I was there, but it's quite fun to play along if you're in the mood. That being said, might not be the best for a 'classy' first date.

Value: Prices are on the higher end, but portions are actually quite generous. Still, I consider this more of a 'treat' than a staple. 

Service: Despite the constant birthday celebrations, service was fine. Waters were refilled diligently. We did wait over an hour for our table though, so MAKE A RESERVATION. (If you don't, don't wait outside! Walk around the corner to Trick Dog for an awesome cocktail!)

Overall, a really fun place. It's food and entertainment in one and maybe a little over-hyped, but the food delivered, so that's alright with me.
author: Deena M.

description:
The food here is amazing! We ordered a few of their top sellers which is the hat yai fried chicken, panang neua, and 24 hr beef noodle soup. 

The portion sizes were huge so it's good for sharing.  The fried chicken was surprisingly tender and went well with the curry sauce.  The panang neua is braised short rib with a curry glaze on top.  The beef was fork tender and delicious.  The 24 hr beef noodle also have a large slow cooked beef short rib that of course was also tender.  The broth was very flavorful as well. 

We also ordered a pad thai dish but it was not too memorable.  Would definitely like to come here again the next time we're in town
author: Judy P.

description:
Came here for my birthday celebration with a few friends. We all ordered a variety of things. I had gotten the ginger tea, the lavender tea and their ribs with panang curry. Their panang curry is fantastic!  The ribs were fall off the bone good!  My friend ordered the seafood panang and it was also very good. Everything looked fantastic. We had a group of 8-9 people and it worked out with seating.  The ginger tea was excellent (which was surprising since I don't generally like strong ginger flavors).  I would not order the lavender tea again, just did not taste as good to me. 

Be aware that they won't seat you unless everyone arrives. The servers are very nice and attentive.  The food isn't 'authentic' Thai but it's pretty good Thai food you won't find in a traditional American Thai place. It also has a great atmosphere. 

Highly recommend.
author: Julia Y.

description: I stopped going to Thai restaurants in the Bay Area because I was kind of tired of the overly sweet food. I was delighted with the food here and the fun environment and attentive service. The food is on the edge of heat for me, my friend found some of the dishes too hot for him, but I would consider myself not very adventurous when it comes to eating super hot food, and I was able to enjoy with a bit of sweat. This is now my go to restaurant for Thai food.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
I and two coworkers took an Uber to this Mission area Thai Restaurant.  My buddy and his wife raved about the food here, especially the green curry and shrimp dishes.  After our meal, I'm inclined to say that its definitely one of the better Thai restaurants I've been in SF.  5 stars. IMHO its a step ahead of Osha Thai and Kin Khao. In fact, Kin Khao should give its 1-Michelin Star to Farmhouse.  I'll have to bookmark Marnie Thai on 23rd for next time.

The restaurant is in a somewhat remote area on Florida St, across from a residential area.  Outside, it looked nothing like a Thai Restaurant, but instead something rustic like you'd find in Napa.  We all ordered family style and pretty much enjoyed all the dishes:

1. Mieng Kum Kung: Appetizer of three perfectly fried prawns served on a green leaf with minced ginger, lime, coconut, tamarind, and yes peanuts.  Elevated coconut shrimp with some serious jacked-up flavors. (5 stars)

2. Green Curry with Mary's Chicken: Served with Thai eggplant.  Curry was excellent - not watered down and moderately spicy.  Chicken was moist.  They served this with blue flower rice! (5 stars)

3. Pad Kee Mao: Vegetarian version of spicy Drunken Noodles, and pretty good.  The color is lighter than I'm used to seeing, but the spicy kick is definitely there without the excess oiliness. (4 stars)

4. Pad Char Shrimp: Excellent sautéed shrimp in red curry, but the real winner is that amazing green cilantro-based dip that was similar to an Indian chutney, but with intense Thai kick.  Comes with more blue flower rice which was a hit (5 stars).
author: Daniel C.

description:
I have been to this place twice now, both times for lunch - because it happens to be open all day on weekends and it is convenient to get food if you were too busy to eat lunch until 3 or 4 pm. 

First off, there is a decent amount of street parking ! The menu had a lot of exciting options both for food and drinks. They have ample seating and unlike many places, the tables are not super tight (SF standards) so you don't have to listen to everything the people next table are talking about ;)  
We tried the papaya salad , yellow curry (comes with roti) and pad thai and all were great. The papaya salad was deliciously spicy which we love.
The young coconut is quite expensive (~$7)..IMO..

I wasn't a huge fan of the bread pudding (marked house fav on the menu) even though the vanilla ice cream was bomb (wish there was more ice cream and less bread pudding)

have to give a shout out to all the people who worked here - everyone seemed super dedicated into their job which is so sweet

This is a great place to celebrate birthdays as they go quite overboard singing and bringing the dessert (insta-worthy - shareable - $26) and definitely something to consider when planning a birthday dinner for friend or family  (they take reservations!_)
author: Anju J.

description: So because you have a Michelin star and blue rice that gives you the go to charge more? Michelin stars are a curse. You should give it back. You're food while good is not mind blowing. I gave an honest review. Thai food to me is one of the best cuisines in the world. But it is not exceptional. My review reflects what the ordinary guy goes through while eating in my town. Good luck with your eatery and i tell you it's good but the value is just not there.
author: Jorydude r.

description:
This place is definitely overrated & overpriced. The food is ok AT BEST. The portions are WAY too small for the price that they charge. We ordered the chicken pad Thai, a small tom kha soup and a papaya salad with one lager. The tofu in the pad Thai were dried and there were barely any noodles in it. The seafood soup was salty and filled with mostly cabbage. The papaya salad - nothing to write write home about. For the same amount of food elsewhere it would have cost us half the money we paid. 

Not only is the food overpriced, the ambience is noisy we couldn't even hear ourselves speak. This was on a Saturday afternoon around 2:30 pm. 

Save yourselves the money & disappointment and go elsewhere!
author: Lucy B.

description:
If you make it to Farmhouse you are in for a treat! This is really really really good Thai food that is fresh, well flavored and delicious. I felt like they put a lot of thought into the design of the restaurant and all the servers dressed colorfully which is parallels the dishes and the food that is served. 
We had a reservation and they were kind enough to push us by about 15 minutes which I appreciated. We were seated quickly when we arrived and it didn't take long for our server to stop by for drink orders. I ordered a hot tea and for appetizers we chose the chicken wings. The chicken wings had a nice sweetness to them and a little crunch although the portion size was only 4 wings. I was told that the recipe has changed so if you've had them before it's possible the recipe isn't the same. I thought they were good but I heard that the last recipe was amazing!
We ate dinner family style and ordered, crab fried rice, green curry with chicken and had a soup I can't remember the name of. The food came out quickly and everything was delicious. There is a healthy amount of crab in the fried rice. The green curry wasn't overly rich and had a nice balance of basil with a little heat. The soup was light and refreshing. 
Overall I had a great time at Farmhouse, it's one of the better Thai restaurants that I've been to and everything I tried was flavorful. Our server was attentive and quick with all the refill requests. The prices are a little higher but the quality of the food does match the price. Worth it if you're on the hunt for Thai!
author: Sean F.

description: Came here while visiting SF after reading some great reviews. We ordered fresh rolls, roasted chicken dish (forgot the name) and pad see ew. I would highly recommend the pad see ew - hands down one of the best I've ever had. Super yummy chewy noodles and yummy savory sauce. The chicken dish was good but didn't seem very Thai to me. It was like a roasted chicken and you were given a side of some spicy sauce. It had a side of sticky rice and green papaya salad. The papaya salad was amazing but very spicy. I had to take breaks to be able to eat it all. If I were to go again, I'd over the pad see ew, fresh rolls, and the papaya salad (less spicy). Overall good experience.
author: Jenni R.

description:
I went here today with a group of four for dinner! The place is definitely in a nice, cleaned up section of The Mission District. 

Vibe:
A few things of note - Chinese New Year is this week so the restaurant and staff were colorfully decorated with beautiful tokens of celebration!
