This place is family owned and when I raved about the chicken hat yai dish to our waitress, she told me that it was her grandmother's recipe which I love to hear! It's definitely on the pricier side as the hat yai comes around to 23 dollars for dinner but was big enough to share. Highly recommend this place and can't wait to try other dishes next time!
author: Lauren L.

description:
Maybe I need to try this place again, and if it's better, i'll update the review. However, my first time experience here was okay. I ordered chicken wing and tiger prawn from appetizer, and crab fried rice for main dish. Food came out REAL fast, but prob cuz there were few customers since we went pretty early to avoid the wait for lunch crowd. 

Tiger prawn was excellent. Very crispy and perfect amount of seasoning. 
Chicken wing was too salty. I had hard time finishing up even though it was only four small pieces. 
Crab fried rice was too bland. There was 2 different kinds of sauce available on the side, but I wish the fried rice itself had some seasoning on it.  

Considering how the price range is pretty up there for Thai food, I would give 3 stars for my experience. Place itself is really cute though.
author: Serena Y.

description:
Came here for lunch when visiting a friend. The atmosphere of the restaurant was nice. I liked the decorations and succulents at the restaurant and was excited to try to food as soon as we walked in. 

We got to the restaurants around 12:15pm and the restaurant was pretty empty. However, the lunch crowd started to trickle in after we sat down and got pretty busy by around 12:30 or so. 

My friend and I shared the samosas and pad Thai for lunch. Both were really good! The Samosas came in 3s and was deep fried. It was on the oily side but that was partly also what made it taste good. My only complaint about the samosa was that the crust was nice and hot but the inside was actually not very warm. It would've been nice if the temperature was more even. The pad Thai was good but a bit smaller portion than what I'm used to. Overall the food and service were good!
author: Nina W.

description:
I've been for dinner a few times.  SF isn't known for good Thai food and I think this is probably the second best in town and it's not very exciting,at that. The best is kin khao. 

The prices are pretty high, so I only go when I really have a Thai craving. The vibe inside is pretty cool though.  

Moderately vegetarian friendly.
author: Sarang B.

description: This is my second time visiting the Farmhouse. I paid a visit here last year, and I have to say, they totally deserve the Michelin star. The foods are delicious, ambiance was really nice, and the staffs are friendly. The prices are a bit higher, but totally worth it.
author: Nhi B.

description: I have a reservation at 7pm but they let me wait for 1 hour. Because of the strange rule, I have waiting for a hour. They said to me if I talk to the manager, he will put me in the end of the line.
author: Dan L.

description:
I'll be honest - I wasn't expecting to like Farmhouse Kitchen as much as I did! As someone who's originally from LA, I have pretty high standards when it comes to Thai cuisine. I'm also more of a "hole in the wall" diner, where I prefer the gritty, no-fuss mom-and-pop top establishments to the swankier ones that cost $$$ but don't produce very good food. That said, Farmhouse Kitchen completely took me by surprise - who knew you could have great Thai food AND great restaurant ambiance?

I had the Hat Yai Fried Chicken and my friend had the Pad Thai - the Pad Thai was meh (good flavor, but noodles were a bit overcooked), but the chicken was DELICIOUS! It's usually hard to go wrong with fried chicken, but I really loved the combination of the crispy batter (never had anything like it before) and the sweet/sour sauce. The curry and roti were the icing on top of the cake - the potato was cooked perfectly, and I'm a sucker for roti. I wasn't a fan of the blue rice (did they just add food coloring? weird...), but portions were so generous that I didn't feel the need to eat it anyway. Between me and my friend, we took home half of the pad thai.

Service was excellent. I was especially impressed at the end, when they asked if we wanted to split the check - I don't think I've ever had a restaurant ask me before! I know it's not convenient, so major bonus points in my book.

Random note - I love how they incorporated lots of small authentic touches in the decor. My friend's from Cambodia, which has a similar style. We noticed that the chicken was served on plates similar to those she has at her house and the background music was Thai. Small things I'm sure most people don't notice, but it made the experience feel like an elevated version of the mom-and-pop restaurants I love.

We'll definitely be back. It's totally worth the price, and I'm dying to try the beef noodle soup next.
author: Larissa M.

description:
I was very excited to eat at Farmhouse Kitchen after hearing so many great things about it. I really wish I liked it more, but I'm giving it 3.5 stars. 

Stand outs:
-The 24 beef noodle soup- my favorite dish. Incredible flavor and the meat was tender. Really reminded me of boat noodles. However, my boyfriend said he prefers the boat noodles at Zen Yai over this rendition. 
-The curry that came with the hat yai fried chicken. YUM. I could eat that sauce with anything. 

Okay: 
-The shrimp pad thai and red beef curry were alright. I've had around the same at other thai places. The beef in the curry was pretty hard. 
-I didn't think the hat yai chicken was anything special, despite all of the raving reviews. It was fried pretty well, but other than that, it was pretty small and wasn't extremely tender or anything. 

The not-so-great:
-The Thai sausage appetizer- okay flavor but kind of dry. Tiny portions.
-The service. None of the waiters were very welcoming. We felt rushed the entire time, as waiters tried to clear dishes before we even finished eating, without asking! Literally a second after putting down the fork, there would be someone at the table, trying to take away the dish, even if there was still food on it. This happened like 4 times.

Overall, pretty decent Thai food but nothing you can't get at other Thai restaurants.
author: Chloe Z.

description:
Have come here for dinner before and enjoyed some really great food. However, recently I ordered Take-Out for lunch and the Pad Black Pepper Garlic Chicken that I ordered was 1/2 empty and did not come with rice as advertised on the Lunch Menu. The dish was $16 and you could see the bottom of the container. It was as if they packaged it up before they finished preparing it.

Another tricky thing is that the Dinner Menu does not come with rice but is the same price, and you can only order the Dinner Menu Item from EAT24. Just something to take note of even if you are ordering Take-Out for Lunch.
author: Jim S.

description:
Something about this place just makes me want to come back. I think it's the whole dining experience. I've been here multiple times, for lunch and dinner. I recommend dinner over lunch because the ambiance is more unique at dinnertime.
 
AMBIANCE/DECOR
Loud Thai music/songs playing and staff dressed in Thai cultural clothing at dinner time vs no music and staff dressed in t-shirts during lunch time. The place is cute and interestingly decorated, from a wall of faucets to the antique sewing machine at the hostess/check-in station. Each table has a small succulent plant.
 
FOOD
Most memorable items I've had were the shrimp/prawn appetizer, fried calamari (it's not your usual calamari), short ribs (very tender and flavorful), Mary's chicken, and samosas (also like the curry sauce it comes with). They have specials that they print out on small cards.
 
SERVICE
Good service with each experience, still feel dinner service is a bit better. Food comes out fairly fast and they never took my order wrong. They take reservations for large parties in advance. Usually a wait for dinner, but usually no wait at lunch.
author: Iris H.

description: The best Thai place in SF and it is far better than the most Thai restaurants I have been in Thailand. Tom Yum with sea food is my favorite dish that I would definitely recommend if you are into spicy soups
author: Ilker D.

description:
What a crazy dining experience eating here at Farmhouse Kitchen is. Loud, brash, and wild enough to keep all 5 senses at full stimulation. You're pretty much guaranteed one of those unforgettable dining experiences here, so be sure to come in with an open mind.

The food is damn tasty. Huge portions, and you'll be thankful for them because you'll want to eat every last bit. Appetizers we had were the Chicken Wings and the Par Dip Tuna. The Chicken Wings were so delicious; incredibly crispy and the sauce it came with was fantastic. The Par Dip tuna was tasty as well. Kinda like a normal raw tuna dish but this one had a great texture and a pretty unique flavor to it. My main course was one of the chef's specials. It was the Massamun curry and although this dish was tasty, it got to be a bit overwhelming in flavor after awhile. The roti it came with was probably the best roti I've ever had though. So flaky and tasty. The blue rice was also a nice little touch, presentation-wise. Kinda weird eating blue rice though. Like eating smurf bits.

The experience itself is a trip though. If you wanna go in blind and not be spiled about the experience, stop reading here. It's so crazy in here. Some of the staff is dressed up in wild costumes and makeup. There'll be someone going around offering you cooked grasshoppers to eat which really isn't my thing at all, but my friends said it tasted like fried chicken skin. If it's someones birthday, there'll be lots of clanging and noise as basically all the staff will surround your table and sing to you with cymbals and drums ablaze. It's just a wild time and it all seems super chaotic but controlled at the same time. 

In all, it's a great dining experience and one I won't soon forget. Definitely on my list of places to go to again.
author: Sean H.

description:
Incredibly authentic and amazing! Thai vibes with awesome customer service. 

We ordered a lot of food, but I solely remembered my 24 hour beef bone! Must get here! Despite the price, I think it's worth trying this place. The servers are super friendly and they also do a special birthday celebration if you dine here for your birthday.
author: Miranda T.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen in the outskirts of the Mission District is undoubtedly one of the most beautifully and colorfully-decorated restaurants I've ever visited. Inside, there are colorful flags and art all over, as well as antiques that make you feel like you stepped back in time and into the opposite side of the world! Above all, however, the waiters were super friendly (and were all wearing water guns strapped to their shoulders--apparently in honor of a New Years festival/tradition that happens in Thailand) and the food absolutely amazing!

I came for lunch with a group of four, but the portion sizes are quite big, so we ordered three main dishes to share, and it was more than enough! The Kai Yang, Som Tum plate came with the most tender barbecue chicken I've ever had (marinated in turmeric and coconut), along with a bamboo steamer of chewy sticky rice, a dish of spicy, pungent papaya salad, and a vinegary spicy sauce for dipping. What an amazing, perfectly balanced combination! 

The Thai Street Green Curry Noodles were also amazing--the delicious, fragrant curry came with chunks of bone-in dark meat chicken and plenty of vegetables including eggplant, bell pepper, and bamboo. But the most amazing part of the curry was that you could taste the depth and variety of herbs that were used--so fresh, fragrant, and complex! The dish was served with rice noodles, bean sprouts, and pickled veggies on the side for a great combination.

However, the dish that impressed me the most in terms of flavor was actually one of the most simple--the Mok Salmon, which consisted of grilled wild salmon wrapped in a banana leaf with oyster mushroom, and served with grilled asparagus, blue rice, and a spicy cilantro lime sauce. The best part of the dish was definitely the salmon. Like the other dishes we had, you could really taste all of the pungent herbs and spices that were cooked with the salmon--the depth and level of the flavors were unbelievable, yet the salmon wasn't overpowered at all! The blue rice was also particularly fragrant (though I have no idea how they make this!), and the spicy cilantro sauce went perfectly with every component of this dish.

Farmhouse Kitchen deserves 5+ stars for the finesse of their dishes--not only is the plating absolutely beautiful, but the execution is unparalleled, and every single dish I tried was perfectly seasoned, and the components were perfectly well-balanced. I'll be back!!
author: David K.

description: This is probably one of the best Thai in SF! The food is great and very refined. The place is very warm and the service was very nice. I would definitely recommend!
author: Ouiam C.

description:
Given how close it is to my place, this has become a no brainer for me to get delicious take out or just simply show up and get fed. (I know I'm lucky :D)

Must try: fried chicken, crab fried rice, green curry noodles.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
Fried chicken house special with the blue rice was delicious!
Came here for a birthday celebration - let the waitstaff know and order a desert,they bring out out candles and sing!
author: Prash A.

description: Such an amazing restaurant!!! So authentic, they have specialties too! The Pad Se Ew is to die for!! The mango see you race is delish. Coconut ice cream deserts are outrageous OMG. Best Thai food ever!!!!!!!!
author: Asher B.

description: Amazing and fresh Thai food that won't give you a tummy ache. Love their red curry with chicken and pad Thai. Can't wait to try more. Such a hidden gem in the deep mission!
author: Emily F.

description: No complaints you cant go wrong.  Make sure to make a reservation and wear something comfortable to relax and enjoy your meal. Staff is amazing very attentive.
author: Ralique J.

description:
Even with a reservation, we had to wait pretty long. 

This place was fun. Very unique and exciting. Tell them it's a birthday and they'll make sure the entire restaurant knows. On top of a traditional way of ordering with your server, they also walk around the restaurant with basket of appetizers for you to add to your table. This gives you a very culture feeling to the restaurant. Got to try my very first fried cricket. Not bad but I can't eat the head. I just can't eat it while it's looking at me. 

The food was ehhh. It wasn't outstanding. The food wasn't something that I would say, "yes! I want to go back because it was soooo delicious." 

I might go back because it's fun. So maybe for another birthday celebration.
author: Lillian r.

description: Went with a friend for lunch mid-week. A lot of people here! The blue rice was eye-catching, but nothing to order again. The curry was good, and the appetizer must not have been since I can't even remember what we ordered! Disappointed. Especially for the prices; at lunchtime!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Wow, I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet- it's definitely one of my neighborhood go-to spots. Great thai food and great service- it's a bit pricier than your normal thai joint but you can tell that they take great care to try to make the food as good as possible.

Whatever you do, DO NOT bypass the short rib on your trip here. It's fall off the bone goodness paired with blue rice that you don't want to miss. The fried chicken is one of their famous dishes and it doesn't disappoint either. I'm not sure what's better honestly- the chicken, or the roti and dipping sauce that comes with the dish. I've asked for the sauce by itself a few times with no shame because it's that good.

For starters, skip the vegan fresh rolls- the wrapper is weirdly thick and not tasty. However, an order of the Neua Num Tok Rolls and Mieng Kum Kung prawns are well worth your time. The Tok Rolls are grilled and marinated flank steak wrapped up with cilantro and a cilantro lime dressing- really fresh and refreshing. The prawns are coconut battered and fried and also amazing.

I've had some of their curries here as well, which have always been good- but watch out if you don't want bones in to make sure you order the right curry!

BYO is $20 a bottle if you choose to go that route. There isn't a full bar, but they do have beer and wine!
author: Elliott W.

description: I love this place.  The food is very good and the prices are fair.  Their food presentation is always an A+.   My mind says that the food tastes better because of this.
author: Bob H.

description:
MAKE RESERVATIONS. 

I got the pad sew ew and I loved the noodles! They were soft and chewy. I could eat them all day everyday. I do wish the portions were bigger though. 
My husband got the fancy version of pad thai with giant prawns. He really liked it. He said the prawns added a nice extra flavor. 
I was hesitant on ordering the tom yum soup because there was an extra 4-5 different sea food additions. I usually just like the soup and noodles together.... My friend did order the whole sha bang and she loved it. 

I got the peach jelly drink because it sounded really unique and I love jelly. I definitely wanted to order 10 more of those. It was sweet with a touch of alcohol. 
The vibe was very lively. They would sing happy birthday with cymbals and sirens. There are a lot of flashing lights, discos lights and a projector. It reminded me of a typical asian restaurant that had a lot of flashy decorations. I liked that there was a lot of plants hanging! I don't get why there was a wall of faucets. But art is art.
author: Elaine W.

description: This place is so fun! My friends surprised me here for my birthday. Their HBD song is over the top, loud, and super entertaining. The Thai food is amazing, and they have shared cocktail bowls with the extra long straws.
author: Kelsey C.

description:
Sadly, I have to downgrade my rating for Farmhouse. My visit in August was just not as great as the experience I had at my first visit back in the July '15. Our large group went for a team dinner and, once again, our group leader called in advance to ask for fresh coconuts at the table. Unfortunately, the coconuts were not there when we arrived and we never received them. 

The restaurant was very busy, and service was spread thin. It took a really long time to get drinks. An annoyingly long time. 

Our group shared a bunch of apps, and almost everything was on the extremely spicy side. This actually made it difficult to enjoy the food, because everyone just felt like their mouths were on fire the whole time. (And again, drinks were sparse.) Still, everything was tasty.  

We also shared our entrees, and we ordered a little bit of everything. My favorite dish by far was the fried chicken, which was absolutely incredible. The least favorite dish of the night was the pad thai with shrimp. More than one person at the table said the shrimp tasted off. 

Saving this review from descending into two star territory is the incredible birthday celebration the staff performed for one of our friends. Huge dessert plates were presented at this time and I have to say they have a killer array. I couldn't get enough of the frozen coconut cream dessert, in particular.

Would I go back to Farmhouse Kitchen in the future? That is unclear. With so many great restaurants in San Francisco, I probably wouldn't go for a dinner but might be inclined to return for lunch.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Fairly legit Thai food in the Mission with a reasonable price and nice ambiance. I've gone for group lunches here and the lunch menu is a tasty food and generous portion size at good price. I like the balanced flavor profile and fresh spices of the food - doesn't rely on sugar or oil as poor Thai food does.

During lunchtime, the service is fairly efficient and attentive. They've never gotten my order wrong and the worst wait hasn't been that bad even when the place is at capacity. The ambiance and presentation are semi-bougie - bright colors, nostalgic surf rock music, a single table with plastic lawn chairs and tablecloth. Side note, the bathroom is clean and pleasant.

Tom Kha with Chicken - Sour, bright and citrusy kaffir lime flavor, coconut milk is savory but not too much or heavy. The consistency was still watery and not super rich or thick like curry, a good thing.
Beef Salad - Slightly sweet and sour marinade, acidic dressing, fresh fibrous greens. Texture was like a chewy soft like bak kwa pork jerky.
Green Curry Chicken - A good sized portion for lunch. Only mildly spicy and a fairly thin, not soupy curry which I like. Very fragrant with bamboo shoots, basil. Had it with Jasmine rice.
author: Truc N.

description:
My first time here yesterday and I must say this place is worth a try! It's very different and unique! Lots of selection for all kinds of food- noodles, soup, rice, meats, seafood, and drinks! Decent pricing- more on the high side to be honest. Proportions- shareable-ish. Tons of drink selections but none looked appealing to me as far as alcoholic beverages. 

I came with my friend and ordered:

-paid Thai with seafood combo: $15.50+6
-neua yang steak-27.95, oh it had a mini scoop of rice 
-seafood plate (don't know what it had exactly or what it's really called, but it had salmon and it was super HOT/SPICY and price was like more than $21) with blue rice 
-a bbq stick w I think squid or octopus: $3
-farm house wings: $11.50 , good but not worth only 4 pieces

With tax and tip it was $115 for 3 entree's no drink  1 appetizer of 4 pieces, and a mini stick. Now that I think of it it's pretty expensive 

I wanted to try more things but I wasn't sure of proportions and taste. I would probably come back but for a light snack and maybe drinks.
author: Rob V.

description: This place has amazing Thai food in the city and it's adorned with colorful decor. My girlfriend ordered the Thai ice tea and that was a presentation in itself! The Thai tea concentrate is served in a metal cup with a dome of shave ice drizzled with cream. A memorable entree for us was the 24 hour beef noodle soup. It's served with a large beef short rib, egg noodles, cilantro, and bean sprouts. The flavors are hearty and at the end of the dish (if you can finish it all) doesn't weigh you down one bit. Customer service here is great, but the one annoyance is if it's a popular birthday day. The happy birthday song is loud and it's fun to clap along to, but it gets tiring after the 3rd birthday. I'll definitely be coming here again to enjoy the food and Thai ice tea.
author: Aimee I.

description:
***MORE LIKE A 3.5*** 

My sister and brother in law put it on hella thick that this spot was going to be good and it was the "best" Thai spot they've been to out in the Bay so I had to try it! They also said everything they had was HELLA good. With that said, I ordered a variety of things off the menu and I can't say I had the same experience. 

First impression, I liked their little hidden location. I thought the place itself was hella cute and decorated fun. I wanted to take that flower pot/center piece home lol but I took a picture of it instead. The service was like other people have said it was so-so. I didn't think they were hella friendly and they weren't hella rude BUT I did feel rushed towards the end when hella people started lining up outside the doors. Luckily, because it was planned I set up reservations around 6 PM this past Sunday so it wasn't hella busy when we first came in. Also, I don't know if I was just distracted but I was surprised at how fast everything came out. 

As for the food, I listed what we ordered and my personal opinion: 

STARTERS 
- Ahi scoops: hella cute to look at & tasted just as good too, the fish was fresh, the flavor had a little kick to it, know that they only come with 4 servings though 
- Thai fish cakes: this wasn't anything extraordinary but it wasn't bad, I think this came with 6 cakes and crispies underneath 
- Kobe beef jerky: I know it's supposed to be jerky but I thought it was a little too dry LOL, either that or it really didn't have any flavor it was more something to chew on but it is good with the lime-y sauce 
- Mieng Kum Kung: unfortunately didn't get to try this because it's my sisters favorite thing from this spot lol and everyone ate it all, there wasn't enough to serve our table so order appropriately lol 

SPECIAL 
- Mok salmon: I like how they wrapped it with the fresh dill on top added a LITTLE flavor, and they didn't overcook the salmon, it is better with the green sauce which I am assuming is something cilantro-lime-y 
- Panang neua: the best thing here according to my sister and brother in law, I agree there is a lot of flavor, sweeter than I am used to but still hella good! The meat falls right off the bone 
- Hat Yai fried chicken: the "other" best thing, again I lucked out trying this one but I did try the dipping sauce and again, lots of flavor and if you like your curry sweet it's good. 

THAI STREET FOOD 
- Pad See You: My family ordered this last minute so I was too stuffed to try it. My brother said it was the best he had because he could tell the noodles were fresh and prepared there 

SOUP
- Tom yum: one of the main reasons I had to knock them down some, this arrived fast but HELLA cold like nobody wants cold soup (well at my table anyway) and on top of that the spoon they gave me was hella too big to scoop stuff out, there wasn't enough broth to serve to everyone at my table, the flavor was good extra tangy and spicy which I liked but don't expect more than 6 prawns, I prefer more of a seafood combination option 

SALAD 
- Yum Moo Krob: I thought "garden vegetables" was going to be more like a typical salad but it was just pork belly on top of hard cabbage with a sauce similar to what they put on the larb. I was disappointed this didn't taste as good as I hoped. To be honest, there was no crunch to the pork belly it was either prepared with too much moisture or it was sitting out for a while. It hurt my teeth to eat this lol. You know it's not crispy enough when the skin is like sticking to your teeth. My brother in law can cook a mean piece of lechon though, which I think most prefer crispy. 

SIDES 
- Side of asparagus: I liked this, not overcooked, still crispy, and who doesn't like garlic? 
- Side of bone broth: I don't know why I expected more from this lol but it was simple, not bad, kind of what you would get if you ordered broth at a pho restaurant 

DESSERT 
Platter: Enough to feed our table lol, variety of things to choose from & again cute 

Overall, I didn't hate it but I think my sister made me set high expectations. I think it would have been different if we didn't feel rushed and the soup was actually hot. I would come back and try the things I missed! Everything is definitely overpriced tho!
author: Roxanne A.

description:
Delicious Thai food with modern artistic interior design and excellent service. What a pleasant surprise once you enter the unassuming space from the outside. The space is very spacious, airy and beautifully decorated. The food is out of this world. Fresh, yummy and beautifully presented. This place is a must try, go to if you love Thai food. Try it, it will not let you down. 
-Thai iced tea 
-Tom kha gai 
-wagyu beef wrapped cucumber and mint
-grilled tiger prawn pad Thai 
All excellent! Yum, yum, yum!
author: Audgal G.

description: My favorite Thai place in the whole city! The fried chicken with roti and curry is absolute perfection. So is their red curry. I also love that they serve blue jasmine rice - looks cool and tastes delicious! Their cocktails are also delicious. Definitely make a reservation cause wait times can be super long - but if it's your birthday they put on quite a show!
author: Sam M.

description:
This place is filled up very quickly after 12:00. It has a very substantial variety of improvised Thai menu. What I liked about this place is its food decoration. It is quite expensive, but the quality is worth. However, If you search for Authentic Thai food, you might feel a bit disappointed.
My choice
1) Fried curry chicken
2) Tom Yum
3) Chili Cabbage.
4) Thai Tea / Tarmarind

The portion is quite big, so you might consider when you order.
author: Kev W.

description:
Celebrated my best friend's birthday here last Sunday. I have been wanting to try this place specifically for 2 things. One, because of how they greet the birthday celebrant before serving dessert and two, to try their bomb Hat Yai chicken. We started with some appetizers; Ahi tuna scoops, crispy tiger prawns, and calamari. (All freakin delicious) For entrees; most of us got yellow curry and Hat Yai Friend Chicken. (I definitely recommend trying the Hat Yai) Highlight of this dining experience: Pad See You dinner with crispy pork belly (we ordered 1 to share). TO DIE FOR. If I had to choose 1 dish from the menu, I'd definitely pick that. 

I am only giving them 4 stars because although the service was pretty fast, they messed up our order, had us cut our own cake and gave us insufficient utensils and plate.
author: Gwen M.

description:
This was my first time at this place and it was subpar at best. I went here for a friend's bday brunch with a group of about 8. After waiting for a few minutes indoors, we were seated in what I saw was the only outdoor table; being that it was a sunny Sunday our entire group was delighted. Before our orders were taken, I walked back inside to use the restroom. Not seeing any directional signs, I asked one of the servers were the restroom was located. The server looked me up and down and without hesitation told me that the restrooms were for customers only. I quickly replied that I was with the group outside and the server rolled his eyes at me and pointed almost with his head where the restroom was. Not the best first impression of the staff. 

When it came to the food, I ordered pad Thai. The dish was nothing out of the ordinary; neither good nor bad, almost bland. None of my friends were floored with their food either. I did not have a drink, however my friends did enjoy a few of their colorful cocktails. More than likely not coming back to this place.
author: Ranferi C.

description: Great food, friendly staff, and gluten free menus.  Spicy food galore if that is your flavor.
author: Christopher M.

description: Always entertaining and delicious. Have been several times and it never disappoints. The menu is so full. Love their pad Thai and other noodle dishes. Good for dining in and take out. They also sell something unique and off the menu, and I once ate deep fried crickets here!
author: Stephanie C.

description: The service was spotty at the host stand, bar and table. The sound system is bad, so sit outside if possible. My bill was incorrect. The veg curry dish was good and the samosas great.
author: Vicki L.

description: I've eaten all over the world and that's true, this is in my top five meals of all time. When here with my wife and kids and the overall experience is five stars. From the wait staff, to the food, to the drinks, to the atmosphere. Highly recommended please do not miss this killer restaurant.
author: Townie M.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The Good:

I love that the food comes out quick and they come around with 'street snacks' like fried grasshopper (i didn't try it - but it was interesting).  

Food itself was tasty.  Ordered the pad kee mao with chicken and also the fried chicken dish that came with roti, curry and purple rice.  Also got the tom yum soup.  

Service was great considering it's a super busy restaurant and the servers were all dressed up in traditional wear.  If it's your birthday, they come out and perform and sing, too.  

The Not-So-Good:

I've never paid so much for Thai food before.  Ever.  For the 3 items, split with my friend, we paid $30+ per person....How is 3 items $60+?!  Considering I can get the exact same meal for probably $30 total, it felt a little bit like a rip off. 

Also, purple rice is a hype.  It tastes exactly like regular jasmine rice with food coloring.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Excellent food and drinks, the spicy shrimp Curry is the yum yum yum :) !
Parking in the area is not hard to find and the restaurant is beautifully decorated
author: Vish E.

description:
Came here with a party of 6 on a Sunday night with reservations. It was a packed house! Even with reservations, we waited for about 15-20 min after. 

3 of us ordered the fried chicken dish, 1 ordered the pad kee mao with fried pork belly, 1 ordered the pad see ew with chicken and another person ordered the short rib. 

The fried chicken dish is definitely worth the hype! Huge portion and really flavorful chicken. Loved the dipping sauce and the platha that came with it. I tried some of the pad see ew and thought it was tasty as well. 

Everyone seemed to really enjoy their dishes!

Service was attentive. But inside was extremely loud. It was a little hard to talk because we could barely hear each other, so just be aware of that. 

A bit on the pricey side, but portions were large!

Note: if you're planning to split the bill, tell them in advance when you order.
author: Noelle H.

description:
We came here after being turned away from Aina and Plow for long wait times/full reservation lists. I am so glad that we were able to end up eating here :)

Initially I felt good vibes; the asthetic is open and modern with lots of colorful, interesting decor. 
Service was super fast and attentive, giving worthwhile recs that we were glad to have as first timers. 

Ahi Poke Scoops were excellent small bites. Super presentation and fresh taste. Love the crunch of the cucumber with the poke. 

****Hat Yai Fried Chicken was excellent as many would agree! Seems to be a favorite here. Full fried chicken breast meat with a side of awesome blue rice. They also give you an amazing curry to dip little roti breads in. So delicious and fun to eat. 

Lastly, we got the 24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup. Not for the faint of heart. They give you a beef bone with meat that falls right off. The broth is so flavorful, and the noodles are cooked well. Perfect for our cold SF Sunday lunch.

Hope to be back someday, Farmhouse Kitchen :)
author: Emily J.

description:
First off, the hostess was dressed in beautiful traditional Thai attire and provided immediate acknowledgement when we entered. The restaurant I'd say, is not huge but not tiny either. 

We made a reservation at 5:30 and I'm so glad we did because the place was packed by 6:10. I  wish I had taken more than just the photo of my own dish but I spent my efforts stuffing my face and I forget to take pictures of the environment and my husband's and kids' plates. My husband selected a mango salad that he thouroughly enjoyed (advance notice that it smells a bit like stinky feet, which scared him at first). Our eldest enjoyed the red curry plate and was actually full despite the initial feeling that it would perhaps not be enough. Our 11 and 7 year olds shared a chicken noodle soup. They were like revenous beasts they enjoyed it so!

Overall a very pleasant experience of  delicious  and  fresh food, excellent hospitality and a great atmosphere.
author: Nydia S.

description:
Heard amazing things about this place, so decided to check it out! We made an appointment for 7:15 on a Thursday night and once we arrived, we were immediately greeted by the host and taken to our seats towards the back near the kitchen. 

We loved the ambiance and vibe of the restaurant. Everyone seemed cheerful, music wasn't too loud and we had enough space between tables so we didn't feel like we were in someone else's convo. 

Service was great overall. Our waiter was attentive and very friendley. 

Food: 
- Samosas: These things were so freaking delicious we ended up ordering another one after finishing the first. It reminded me of a potato empanada and was served with a coconut curry sauce. Super crispy and flaky outer layer that's filled with potato and spices. 5/5
- Tom Kha: I'm normally not really a soup person, but this was another amazing dish that had so much flavor. We ordered the larger size and it was MASSIVE for two people, lots of vegetables (carrots, cabbage, broccoli) and the coconut base/broth was delicious. 5/5
- Grilled River Prawns Pad Thai: By the time this dish came out, we were getting pretty full, but it was still so tasty! They serve some of the shrimp butterflied, but it was also chopped up in the noodles as well. This was a big dish with lots of noodles, bean sprouts, and other vegetables. 5/5
author: Sierra G.

description: Amazing Thai cuisine. Order everything seriously. The green papaya salad is extremely hot so tread with caution.
author: T B.

description:
Whoa, fancy Thai food?

At least it feels like it.  The ambiance of the restaurant seems a lot more upscale than any other Thai restaurant I've been to.  The food is solid, I had the beef rolls, fried chicken, and some kind of curry with a huge slab of meat in it (short rib curry?).  The fried chicken was definitely my favorite, I love that it came with curry, rice, and roti - the portions are huge!  The roti seemed a bit bland for my tastes, but the rest of the dish was delicious!  Flavors are great and not too heavy.  I had a date here that actually went terribly, but the food was so good I didn't care!

There are also servers going around with tiny bites, I got to try cricket for the first time and it was actually pretty good!  Tasted kind of like a soft shell crab.  

Tips and Tricks
-Prices are definitely more than your typical Thai restaurant, but you get what you pay for
-Can get pretty crowded, I would get a reservation for dinner
-Try some cricket!
author: Jessica L.

description:
My neighborhood spot, I order take-out from here at least once a month. I finally had the opportunity to come here to eat in with a group of 5 friends. Hands down, 5 star restaurant. As you walk in, the staff are dressed in colorful shirts or dresses, and we were greeted by friendly smiles all around.

Every dish we ordered was flavorful and come in a timely manner. Everything was well presented, and casual ambiance sparked an evening filled with light-hearted conversation.

Most dishes are at least a mild level of spicy, with some very spicy dishes. Their menu is really good at calling out which ones are the really spicy dishes, so definitely recommend to keep at eye out for that. We loved that they have people bringing their daily specials around to your table, reminiscent of authentic street food hawkers.

We'll definitely be back soon!
author: Nat E.

description: They recommended the beef noodle soup, the gai yang & som tum, and the crispy pork salad. Sooooo delicious!
author: Charissa S.

description:
I love this place! It's a lively and fun spot with some bomb food. 

I had a Friday night reservation for 4 people and we were seated immediately. My group shared a few different things, but everything we had was delicious. I can't really remember exactly which dishes we had but I believe we ordered the short rib and the meat was falling off the bone. 

Although I can't remember the main dishes we tried, I do remember the most important part of any meal: DESSERT! We only tried the Thai Vacation - coconut with vanilla ice cream and taro ice cream served in a coconut. The dessert was honestly so good I would go back just to get it again (and probably all the other desserts too)

All in all, I definitely recommend checking out Farmhouse Kitchen!
author: Estelle C.

description:
TYPICAL TASTING THAI FOOD
(3.5 stars)

Just so you know... on yelp RSVP it said no opening until 5pm. However, at 3pm I was able to walk-in and get a table for 3. 

I wanted to like this place but I need to expect more than average tasting food. I guess restaurants in SF are doing new things to be "creative" to stand out in the crowd. Well, I'll be real with you - typical tasting thai food, nice presentation, but nothing to over bend the wallet. I don't get the concept of "farmhouse" and "thai food". The ambiance was cute and clean but walking in didn't feel like I was a Thai restaurant. For example, you can uproot the thai restaurant and put an American(New) restaurant and the owner wouldn't have to change the decor. 

1. Servers were thai, food was authentic 
2. Service was good
3. Menu had a decent selection 
4. Food was good
5. Price wasn't worth it
6. Try not to sit near the back wall. Why? Because it's near the one toilet unisex bathroom. And someone took a dump and the staff cracked the door and it smelt like shit. That's so gross, luckily we were done eating but that's just disgusting. 

NEUN NAM TOK ROLLS - it's basically cucumber, cilantro, and mint rolled up in meat. It was tasty but a little overrated. Average. And average shouldn't be expensive. The meat wasn't as tender as I'd expect it for the price you pay. 

GREEN CURRY - with pork belly. Pork belly for the choice of meat was the best choice. They were bite size and crispy. But it would have been nice if they warned you this was spicy. Not just spicy but 'thai' spicy. I could only handle one bite but that one bite was good. for those with sensitive stomach... be ware, it made my stomach lightly twist throughout 24hrs. RECOMMEND if you like spicy curry.

GRILLED RIVER PRAWNS PAD THAI - this is from the special menu and not the regular pad Thai listed on the back of the menu. This special pad Thai is $8 difference. And honestly, nothing is special about it. Same Pad Thai with fried wontons and ONE big prawn cut in half (not plural prawnS) on top as garnish. No choice of meat, by default tofu is mixed in. It was good/decent/typical tasting Pad Thai but if you don't care for those garnishes save yourself $8 and get the regular pad Thai. RECOMMEND if you want to pricy Pad thai. 

PAD FRESH GINGER SAUCE - with chicken, shiitake mushrooms, white onion, green onion, and fresh ginger. LOL the name is ridiculous. Obviously they are Americanizing their menu but they should keep it authentic with the names, this is basically Gai Pad King. This was very good, but again typical tasting. RECOMMEND.

SLATE BLUE/GRAY RICE - nothing special. Don't be fooled. It's just presentation. They cook rice with butterfly pea flower but it didn't change the the taste of the rice JUST THE COLOR. 

BUTTERFLY PEA FLOWER DRINK - not listed on their menu. But when the server mentioned how they prepared the rice, I recall having A butterfly pea flower drink in a different thai restaurant. Thy prepared it on my request and it wasn't as great as I had it before. It was like a sweet/sour lightly carbonated lemonade. Def not how I've had it before and was kind of disappointed.

Nice ambiance, good food, but not a rush to come back. 

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
This place has authentic thai food....eating here brought back so many food memories from when I was in thailand!!!! This is definitely on my list of one of favorite restaurants in sf!!!!

The thai iced tea was delcious. The food here is fantastic...so full of flavors. Yes, it is spicy but it's bearable...Definitely tell them to go easy on the spice level. The tofu soup was so good, did not expect this at all since i like meat in my soup. Our main entree was the hat Yai fried chicken...so crispy and yummy.

The food and aroma and everything is perfect here! Make reservations! This place is packed and I cannot wait to come back
author: Caitlin P.

description: This is definitely my to go to for Thai food.  It is worth the wait if you don't have a reservation.  It is not the place if you are looking for something quiet. I always order the yellow curry, comes with these potato sliced on top! Very good.  The staff is always friendly and I always do take out with them.
author: E A.

description:
This place has a pretty legit Thai food. I think the food is pretty authentic and yet it feels a bit modern at the same time. I love the open kitchen and the restaurant space.

Like many other Thai restaurants, the menu is pretty big. Everything that I have tried so far is pretty good and tasty. My favorites from the appetizers were the Thai fish cake and the Neua num tok rolls. The fish cake was very fragrant with the fresh kaffir lime leaves, and the rolls were so delicious... it's basically rolled grilled flank steak with mint, cilantro and cucumber which came with a tangy dipping sauce... yum!

For the main course, I had enjoyed the BBQ chicken served with papaya salad; the hat yai fried chicken served with potato yellow curry; and the short rib panang neua. All dishes were cooked nicely, and the portion was pretty big and ideal for sharing. The seasoning and spice level were spot on, and the ingredients tasted fresh.
author: Sam M.

description:
Came to Farmhouse Kitchen Thai and left very content. My friends and I tried a variety of dishes and really enjoyed the bold, SPICY, flavors used in their dishes.

We started off the meal with the Par Dip Fresh Tuna which features fresh Maguro tuna tossed in a mix of green onions, cilantro, dill, coriander, and dehydrated chili. The flavors were aromatic and delicious, but that chili was definitely a kicker. It was bold and took us by surprise on just how spicy it was. Take caution.

Their complementary tap is good though and enough to temper the heat if you don't want to go the extra mile to order a fresh coconut. Their tap was infused with mint and limes too!

As for the Yum Moo Krob, the pork belly pieces were delicious. Mint and shallots gave it a sweet, yet refreshing undertone on an otherwise rich and meaty cube of pork belly. However, to call it a salad was a little excessive. It was literally a wedge of cabbage that you had to saw apart. It wasn't really conducive to tossing like a traditional salad.

For main entrees, we shared Thai Street Green Curry Noodles, Spicy Eggplant, and Khao Mun Gai. I thought the curry was absolutely delicious. I loved the addition of figs to give it a nice sweet surprise. Some of the other garnishes were just okay in my opinion - I always love the addition of bamboo shoots and bell peppers because they tend to withstand the cooking process and stay crisp. However, the green beans were almost mushy. In regards to protein, it wasn't a lot for the price point, but the dish itself will be more than enough to fill you up. As for the Spicy Eggplant, I thought it was done very well. It wasn't too oily and the pieces were very substantial. Lastly, the hainan chicken rice. I thought the chicken was a little dry, but when paired with the broth and variety of sauces, had really good flavor. That said, my favorite part of this dish was the broth. It was so light and the daikon inside provided a lovely sweet flavor. The rice lacked some flavor compared to other versions I've had prior.

Additionally, the bowls of rice provided were...blue...it was odd. It's not purple rice...just blue.

Overall, I enjoyed our meal. It's definitely an elevated style of Thai cooking. Flavors were phenomenal, presentation was beautiful, but it's definitely a pricey choice in my opinion for ingredients that weren't otherworldly unique.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
1/15/17

Arrive and stand face to face with the sentinel of choice.  Before the entrance door you can either step back or forward, but if you have the imagination you have the key to unlock this door.  Beyond it is another dimension - a dimension of sound and sight, a dimension of flesh, a dimension of mind. You're moving into a land of both shadow and substance, of the once-living and earthly life, of things and ideas. You've just crossed over into the kitchen zone, where cooking is not bringing fire to flesh, but where life is to be recreated into dreams to be consumed.

Here we are the aliens; the foreigners to a land where men still till the olden ways, oxen strapped forward.  Yet, there is no passport, no visa, no need of any kind to prove the right of passage.

There is only one booklet with which to concern yourself, the one given to you, not taken the one taken.  Read the menu well, because it is your ticket.  And the train only leaves once.

5/5

#thai #sanfrancisco #star
author: Dean C.

description:
For our office lunch on Friday, January 27th, I decided to try Farmhouse Kitchen. Our order arrived via Forkable around 12 noon.

Green Curry ($13): Grilled eggplant, bell pepper, bamboo, basil with your choice of protein, Served with house Jasmine rice
*Sub white rice with: Brown Rice (+$2)
*Protein for Curry: Organic Chicken
*Notes: Extra spicy

I was really looking forward to the curry since I haven't had Thai curry in a while, but my curry arrived broken. There was a huge layer of oil floating on top. I tried mixing the curry, but there was no way I could put it back into the creamy curry I was craving. It just tasted like super oily meat and veggies on rice. Not good. It was a shame too as the curry had a good spice.

I'm not sure if it was Forkable's fault in transit or if they were given the curry broken from Farmhouse, but if you're craving good Thai curry, I'd pass on this place.

Note regarding the comment left by Farmhouse Thai Kitchen Cuisine: I guess the curry was meant to be super oily. In the end, this just wasn't up my alley. It just ended up being an oil slick on my plate.
author: Elena N.

description: Ok, I love Thai food, and this place was super good.  My best friend and I went there for girls night out and the food was amazing.  The owner told us she is opening a location in Jack London Square and we will definitely be there with the husbands.  The presentation of each dish was so beautiful, we actually felt like we were in Thailand.
author: Theresa R.

description: Genuine Thai... from the food to the costume to the atmosphere. Fun if you have a big group cause then you can try many dishes, most are recommend by the wait person, all very tasty.  I definitely need to come back again for other menu items.
author: Gary Y.

description:
amazing thai cuisine
again and again the craving for thai surges
Farmhouse qwells that hunger with supremely seasoned dishes and sensational authenticity
after eating here, it begs the question:
can one be truly satisfied if they are always wanting more?

arroy mak mak!!!
author: Wendell A.

description:
There is only one word to describe this place: Character.

The décor was oozing Valentines with red and white balloons stamped with the words "I LOVE YOU", menus with printed cupids, a projector displaying a shower of raining hearts, special cocktail drinks that'll make you blush, and lastly, a free polaroid session at the end of dinner to cherish the moment on this SAD day.

The staff was dressed in what looked like authentic Thai attire and drawn on half rubbed off curly mustache.  They were very attentive and provided good service.

The food was exceptional.  This is not your everyday Thai cuisine.  If there is one thing all the dishes have in common, its good flavor.  From the salad to the fried grasshoppers, everything was executed beautifully and deliciously.
author: Linda N.

description: Found this spot totally accident!!! I had a meeting in ZSpace and ended up parking near by - good luck with the parking. Tried yellow curry and it's was damn amazing. I will be back toy try several other items.
author: The Food L.

description: Super fun place for a birthday dinner.  My sister in law made reservations for my brother's birthday dinner here.  I've never heard of the place and didn't know what to expect.  It's nice, casual and the food is good.  But if you go on weekend nights, when they're busy and tons are celebrating birthdays, just know that this is a place that can be loud!  I felt like I needed a megaphone to talk to my brother, who was sitting right next to me.  The food was good!  Although, I didn't know how I felt about the blue rice - it was still good but I've just never had blue rice in my life so it was something different.  Definitely a fun place to celebrate a birthday. Great for groups.
author: Christine P.

description:
The Thai food here is amazing! Not only do I order online delivery from this spot, but going to the restaurant has such a "home environment" it has a family feel!  The Pad Thai is AMAZING, and the rice here is BLUE! BLUE RICE!!!!! (Why I do not know... I'm sure someone else knows the history behind this...) The rice is so good! Curry is good! 
The servers are also so nice and respectful! 
Highly recommend this spot!
author: Justin S.

description: 60 minutes waiting to get a table. We arrived with day light and didn't get in until dark. Clanging loud music. The food is over seasoned and too spicy, entrees are expensive. You'll leave wondering why you spent so much.
author: Tiare L.

description: Expensive for Thai food but an experience unlike most Thai restaurants. Festive fun environment. Typical dishes done slightly differently. Authentic flavors. I loved the rice salad--flavors of coconut, lemongrass, ginger, and sesame. They also have durian for dessert!!
author: Alias A.

description:
Reservations on the weekends are a must! Multiple friends had to give up eating here previously, since they tried to walk in and it was over an hour wait. Luckily for me, my friend had her birthday dinner here and we were able to get reservations for a large group on a Saturday night. They packed in 12 to one table, and a few of us had to sit in an uncomfortable corner spot; however, it was worth it for the food! The ambiance here is very eclectic and lively- some of the male staff have makeup on, wear dresses, and are hilariously sassy. This was perfect for a group birthday dinner, and we tried:

Drinks:
-Sparking Peach Jelly (Pink Moscato, Sparkling Peach Jello, $12, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=h6NXWQjiF1EQYAlT-Wq5fg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum, this was a very unique drink with actual jello pieces in it. It was very light and refreshing, and not too sweet- recommended!
-Kick Boxing Bowl (Brut, "Sato" Unfiltered Rice Wine, Passion Fruit, Lychee, Umami Chili Salt, Served in Ratchaburi Bowl, 36oz/$32, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=XaDAdwbj0x3TbCz87Z0bvQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): You can't taste the alcohol in here much, or the fruit flavors. This was a very light drink, and difficult to share since the straws are super tall. I probably wouldn't get it again.

Food:
-Neua Num Tok Rolls (Wagyu Beef Wrapped w/Mint, Cilantro, Cucumber, Served w/Cilantro Lime Vinagrette, 4/$14.50, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=__xSIWPwtDhRVqHvCy4Dag&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Delicious! The beef had a great sear, and the flavors worked really well together- recommended!
-Ahi Scoops (Pan-Seared Sesame Crusted Ahi Tuna, Cucumber, Seaweed Salad, Crispy Yam, Dill, Lemongrass, Chili Lime, $13.50, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=WVrgd4hhfeKuszxEkbOyrw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): A little too spicy, which I rarely say. I loved the spice, but it overpowered the subtle taste of the tuna. There also weren't enough scoops- skip!
-Mieng Kum Kung (Crispy Prawns on Lettuce, Wrapped w/a Zesty Mixture of Lime, Ginger, Onion, Roasted Coconut, Peanuts, Tamarind Sauce, 3/$13, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cmgVmnXZoWiVOtZHbmwfbg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- this was my favorite out of the appetizers. The crispy prawns were large, and cooked perfectly, and the tamarind sauce was delicious- recommended!
-Kai Yang, Som Tum (Half BBQ Chicken Marinated in Turmeric & Coconut Milk, Papaya Salad, Sticky Rice, Roasted Rice Sauce, $21.50, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SePPjJ1mt4D4LS_JhkQdXA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- the chicken was flavorful and cooked really well, and the presentation was amazing. They also give you a giant portion- reocmmended!
-Hat Yai Fried Chicken (Chicken Breast, Turmeric, Herbs, Fried Shallots, Roti Bread, Potato Yellow Curry, Blue Rice, $19.50): Super crispy exterior, and they give you a giant portion! However, I don't like chicken breast, and it was a little dry inside, so I wouldn't get this dish again.
-Penang Neua (Slow Braised Bone-in Short Rib in Penang Curry, Grilled Broccolini, Bell Pepper, Onion, Fried Basil, Served w/Blue Rice, $25.50, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=jyYfXyc7_f6cEChP9GF_CA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The flavors were great, but I wished they gave you more penang curry (it seemed like the short rib was just dunked it in quickly). I also wished the short rib had a bit more fat to it. The majority of the meat was tender, but there were a few spots were it was dry. I probably wouldn't get this again just because there are so many other more delicious dishes!
-Tom Yum Noodle Soup (Salmon, Calamari, Shrimp, Scallops, Egg Noodles in Spicy & Sour Broth, Spinach, Broccolini, Bean Sprouts, $17.50): The tom yum soup was really good, and had complex flavors. They also didn't skimp on the seafood. However, I'm not a big noodle soup person, so wouldn't get this again.
-Pad Thai ($15, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=OvAAaaa-_umtvVHRV6S_Fw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg&utm_campaign=www_photo_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)): Yum- this was a really good version of pad thai, if you like your noodles on the sweeter side. I loved how all the flavors worked together- recommended!
-Thai Vacation (Half Fresh Coconut Filled w/Black Sticky Rice, Vanilla Ice Cream, Coconut Cream, Peanuts, Black Sesame, $9.50): Super unique and delicious! I loved the slices of fresh coconut in there, and the coconut cream was really good. 
-Croissant Bread Pudding (Vanilla Ice Cream, Caramel Sauce, $10): This was an interesting take on bread pudding, and it was good, but not as fluffy/chewy as I was expecting for a bread pudding. This is worth trying once, but I'd order the Thai Vacation again over this.

Overall, this was a really fun dinner, and a few of the dishes were also unique. Service was solid, and but parking can be difficult.
author: Amy D.

description:
Good service and good food just for the first time.
I didn't eat bad but I won't comeback.
Different Menu but nothing of so special
author: Gabri G.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because this is such a great place to go sharsies style.

   ---   ---   ---

Much like most dinners with co-workers go, this was a collection of a lot of dishes that we all liberally shared with each other. I definitely did not have anything that I disliked - it all ranged from good to great! One thing I will never forget is that I tried a cricket for the first time here - it didn't taste like much of anything, it was just crunchy. 

There were a couple of things that were a little too spicy for my liking, but Thai Tea helped numb that heat, as it always does. 

Looking back at my pictures (that I didn't upload because I'm a bad Yelper) I really had some amazing food at this dinner. The thing that makes this review difficult to write, is that I wasn't in charge of ordering, so I don't even know what half the dishes were called. While my review might not be that helpful in terms of specific things to order, what I can tell you is that I sampled so many different plates, and really enjoyed all of it. 

I can confidently say that you can't go wrong with just about anything on the menu - just make sure it's not too spicy for ya!
author: Brett N.

description: We've been coming to Farmhouse since they opened and the food has been consistently great. Quirky atmosphere and good service.  Yesterday, my buddy Owen convinced me to take their "Thai Spicy Challenge" which means we both had 15 minutes to finish a large plate of incredibly spicy noodles.  They presented us with chili pepper hats and paraded the food out in a loud procession as to call as much attention to our foolishness as possible.  Did I mention the plates were lit on fire like some kind of diabolical birthday cake? Well, we succeeded, painfully choked down our two plates, and won our meals plus a bucket of beer!  Spent the rest of the evening paying for it in other ways.  Thanks for fun experience Farmhouse!  I'll never do that again but will come back to Farmhouse for a normal meal next time.
author: Russell G.

description: It's very hard to find GOOD authentic papaya salad place. This place does an amazing job at making authentic papaya salad.
author: Pa H.

description:
I called before to add my name to the waitlist and they kindly added us, telling me the wait would be 30min on a busy Friday night. When we arrive our table was ready, which was awesome.

Between two people, we shared the herbal rice salad, king prawn pad Thai, and the Thai vacation and croissant bread pudding.
The herbal rice salad was awesome, super fresh, tasty, sweet, crunchy. So many textures and flavors pairing perfectly.
The king prawn pad Thai was good, but really expensive for what that is. I understand the price of prawns but we only had two in the plate, and next time we'll just have the normal pad Thai. 

Make sure to keep room for desserts because they have a great selection!
I was disappointed by the Thai vacation. It looked great but there was so little rice, this dish is just a big scoop of ice cream in a coconut, not worth the price.
The croissant bread pudding was delicious, might not be authentic Thai food but it was glorious. 

Staff was really nice, they accommodated our ask not to have cilantro and were quick to serve us.

The place is really fun, ideal for nights with friends, not so much for a date night as it's quite loud. I'll go back to try more dishes!
author: Coralie S.

description:
I actually really wanted to like this place. But alas, I was completely underwhelmed given the hype, and most of our food came out lukewarm. The one saving grace: atmosphere is nice, and it seems like a fun place for dinner with friends. 

Green curry chicken with vermicelli - curry was lukewarm and after you add the vermicelli, raw bean sprouts, etc, it downright was cold. Chicken was tender, but bland. 

Chicken wings were pretty good. The skin had a nice crunch to it. The sauce that you dip it in is a mixture of that sweet thai sauce from a bottle and they chopped in fresh chile and garlic. I think for a restaurant of this caliber and price point, they should make their own sauce or at least not use the most basic thai sweet sauce on the market. 

Crab friend rice - the crab was dry and tasteless. The fried rice was almost cold. The bone broth that came with it wasn't very flavorful and yet again, it was lukewarm.
author: Patricia L.

description:
I've come here a couple of times now! Once with a big group of friends for someone's birthday (definitely come here for someone's birthday -- the serving staff are so extra and adorable with their celebration, that it's amazing) and a couple of times in a pair.

In terms of FOOD: I've never made a wrong choice here. The curry, the noodles -- everything is amazing. I did get the short rib once and thought it was a little too salty for my personal taste, but the meat was tender, and no one thought it was over-salted besides me, so that might just be me being sensitive!

I will say though that I've never had good service the past couple of times I've been here. I've always felt as though the staff were a little rude to me (would sass me occasionally, or would never refill my water until I asked like two or three times for it) but it was never too bad and the food more than made up for it.
author: Jessie Y.

description:
Recommend reservation! Fun atmosphere, good food, great drinks, reasonably priced. Relaxed atmosphere makes it an easy place to hangout with a group from work. Also a great place for date night. Be willing to step out of your comfort zone! Check their website for special events like the Festival of Lights.

Their coconut soup is wonderful and the presentation is super cool! Definitely worth trying. We got the bowl and shared it and loved it.

Many of the appetizers were meh so I'd suggest seeing if there's anything there that really excites you but otherwise skipping. 

Great blue rice!
author: Cole E.

description: Absolutely terrible customer service! We made a reservation over the phone for lunch and they somehow lost our reservation. We had a baby and a 40wk pregnant friend with us and would not honor our the reservation I made even when I had phone confirmation. This is what happens when good neighborhood restaurants become successful and snooty. Never going back here again!
author: Mary J.

description: Hat Yai Fried Chicken, end of story. Okay fine, so here's the story... The crust on this fried chicken is kind of like a spicy crème brûlée biscuit from heaven. Then, add some of the accompanying sweet and sour sauce and it becomes one of the best bites of food you'll ever take. It truly checks all of the boxes: sweet, spicy, crunchy, salty, tender, it's a flavor bomb. Now, add in a few complimentary bites of blue rice, curry, and whatever that insane baklava like bread substance that comes with it all, and you've got yourself a very special meal. I've said it before and I'll say it again. San Francisco is a secret fried chicken oasis and Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Cuisine is one of the elites, now go eat!
author: Ryan M.

description: My fiancé's friend have mentioned this restaurant to us a few months back as we were driving the area. This past weekend, I had a friend visiting from Netherlands and I was looking for a good spot near where she was staying. (She was staying at the Mission) So as I was browsing Yelp (of course, where else. Duh?) Lolinda and Farmhouse came up as the top 5. I've been to Lolinda and yeah, it's a cool spot because of the rooftop and all but it's been cold and I also feel that Tapas don't typically fill me up so I always end up with a big check since I order all of the items on the menu. Lol. So I made her choose which menu she liked and thankfully, she liked Farmhouse so I made a reservation the day before we were going to go. We got there at 6:35pm or so on a Monday (good thinks I found parking quickly) and we got seated right away. The place looks really festive! They've got banners and all the festive decor that are Thai inspired. We got served right away which is always a plus to me. We ordered a few things to share: The Vegan Spring Rolls. I love these. I ate most of it! There's nothing really special about them but they're always a good starter to share. We also had the Ahi Scoops - pan seared sesame tuna served on a cucumber seaweed salad thing. The tuna was fresh and the presentation was amazing! We had the Neau Num Tok Rolls - Wagyu Beef wrapped with cilantro and cucumber.. another greatly presented dish and the beef was soooooo tasty. Ah! I can eat probably like 5 orders of them. We shared the Seafood Pad Thai - this was ok. Nothing special about it but there were big scallops, shrimps and squid on the plate so at least they weren't stingy on the ingredients. We also had some wine. I had the Pinot while my girlfriend had the Rose. They were.. Meh. Well, maybe we had higher expectations so we were a bit disappointed but we still drank them obviously. Why waste them right? Overall, giving them a solid 4 because as busy as they were - we got their attention with refilling our water, checking in if we're good or need more food, etc. They were busy on a Monday, celebrating a few birthdays and singing to them so I'd suggest you come during the week so it's less crazy. I'll definite come back here again and next time, with my fiancé so I can have some dessert and he can pay for the check!
author: Anna Y.

description:
My friends both Ordered tom yum noodle soup and one came out with very little noodles. We point that out and our waiter went in them back to ask. The waiter said the back kitchen pre measure their noodles ??? I'm just speechless, are they implying that the customers is lying ? They don't care about customer services. The fact that we compared both noodles soup and one bowl has decent noodles and the other has very little.  Beside that, The soup was too spicy, salty and sour too Never coming here again

The funny part was the owner would respond back and said if your not satisfied please notifies our waiter? We DID.!!$&& HELLo??? Did you even read my review? We were dissatisfied that's why we called our waiter. It's a common sense for the waiter to offer us something to make our experiences better. Truly your restaurant don't have any customers services skills.
author: Aniko N.

description:
What a wonderful dinner. My kids loved drinking from a coconut and eating blue rice. I loved the Fried Chicken dish (though the potato was undercooked). The Pad See Ew was good. 

Will return for sure.
author: Kaanon M.

description:
Food:

24 hour beef rib noodle soup - though it's not bad in flavor, the beef was a bit dry and the noodle portion is pretty small unfortunately.  Not to mention it's a bit on the pricy side especially for lunch.  

Service: great waitstaff and very attentive.

Ambiance: a cool neighborhood joint tho it's probably more geared towards the hipsters.

Overall: maybe once in a great while I'd come back but it's not on the top of my list.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Oh  man I love the food for this place. I ordered the fried chicken and it was absolutely delicious. The plate comes with blue rice (similar texture to basmati), a really large piece of chicken (with a sort of sweet and sour sauce) plus naan and curry. Everything on the plate compliments the other sections. It's $22 but well worth and easily split into two meals (which is what i did). DEFINITELY REC THIS DISH.

Boyfriend ordered the fried rice and that was also delicious for $15. Ingredients were fresh and great, but I think I'm more willing to pay for lesser quality at a lower price.
author: Mimi T.

description: I had high expectations for this place, but it fell short. Went there early on a Sunday night. Place barely filled when we got there, but within ten minutes of sitting down and ordering it was packed. Positives: the popcorn green tea was delicious as was the Herbal Rice Salad. Not so positives: the service- food wasn't presented well on dish and upon delivery literally dropped or shoved on to table. The Hat Yai fried chicken was over cooked, roti bread dripping with oil and the Pad Thai cold.  For the prices, I expected more.
author: Beth J.

description:
This fun and inviting Thai spot is definitely one of the most unique dining experiences that I have ever had. Upon entering you are greeted by a vibrant space with tons of character and Thai music bumping. Luckily, there were 2 seats at the bar area, so we went ahead and skipped the hour wait for a table. 
As for the dining experience, we ended up getting the Thai milk teas, which were honestly some of the best milk tea that I have ever had! I love how they serve the tea with a snowball of crushed ice, definitely IG post worthy. As for the food, we ended up getting the samosas for our appetizer and the crab fried rice and pad thai noodles for our main dishes. Everything was so flavorful, fresh and delicious! We even decided to splurge and treat ourselves to their infamous bread pudding. Overall, if you are seeking the ultimate Thai food experience in SF, then definitely make this your spot to go to.
author: Cristal C.

description:
Came in with a group of friends on a Friday night and the place was LIT! Lively and engaging staff. The star of the show is the food. Flavors are full and rich, spices were just right for both spice fans and the milder at heart. Will be back again and again for more feasts.
Highly recommended to  make reservations ahead of time as this place is very popular.
author: Dee D.

description:
False advertising. I saw Farmhouse Kitchen on Check Please Bay Area. I was so excited to go I waited and waited for week. On the show the waiters and waitresses look so happy walking around the tables and enjoying interaction with the customers they were bringing treats around that you can buy and the atmosphere was light and hearty. 
This is not the experience that we had. The waiters hardly smiled they rushed us through our dinner constantly asking are we done are we done and we were still eating.  They had fun between each other joking with each other and smiling at each other but I did not see one table where the waiter or waitress was having a good time with their own costumers. They were promoting the Thai style and I have been to Thailand and I've been to many Thai restaurants this restaurant did not I repeat did not have the Thai feel as far as the friendliness.I will say the food was ok (main course) appetizers we bad! 
The table sitting next to Us the waiter just dump the food on the table and left.  They had no idea that the food was sitting next to them 
It was also way overpriced for what you can't. I'm so sad.
author: Lj G.

description: The place is very hipster. We had pad thai and curry. I would recommend the beef appetizer. It was both fresh and mouthful at the same time.
author: Vincent L.

description: Good food. Bit noisy but fun and lively place. Interesting new chic part of Mission. Would go back. I don't recall what we ordered but not all dishes were as good as others.
author: Michael G.

description:
Got to try a bite of 6 things on the menu. Perks of going with fam and friends. We all voted our favorite dish as the specialty dish with chicken, rice, and curry. Hands down best curry I've tasted in my life! The pad thai was also spectacular. I did not know pad thai could taste that good. My stomach's eyes were opened that day. 

Mind me as I switch over to the dark side for a moment. The crab friend rice, braised beef, and salad were very underwealming. Surprising because the first two are one of the most expensive ones on the menu. Expect to wait a bit in line but the waiting area is nice.
 
Finishing off with the best part. If it's your friend's birthday and you want to embarrass them, take them here and tell the staff it's their birthday. You're in for a treat!
author: Daniel K.

description: Their food is really good. 24 hour short rib soup pho Item is delicious but expensive. Everything I've ordered there has been yum. Worth trying.
author: Jamila G.

description: First time there and the food was delicious. Literally 3 blocks from where I live and never knew it existed. Will go back again.
author: Barry K.

description:
LOVE this place. The ambiance is fun and inviting, a great place to take a date or someone on their birthday (the staff does an elaborate birthday song). 

The food comes out quickly, is flavorful and portioned well for sharing. Highly recommend either of the dishes served with blue rice.
author: Marisa R.

description: This place is worth the wait! Food is so savory and well presented. I do not think you can go wrong with any choice on the menu. I can't wait to come back again.
author: Dominique A.

description:
We came here for our first meal after landing in San Francisco. One of my friends highly recommended it. It is located in the Mission area of SF. We walked in during lunch hour and it was packed.

AMBIENCE: The ambience was amazing. The restaurant is filled with an array of inviting colors, patterns, and textures. The music was fun and soothing. They did a good job in depicting some of the Thai culture in their design. Everyone seemed to be in good spirits and enjoying themselves.

FOOD: We dined as a group of (3) and did family style in order to try as much as we can. We got the Kobe Beef Jerky, Chicken Wing (4 wings), Mok Salmon, Thai Street Green Curry Noodles, Kai Yang Som Tum, Iced Coffee Thai Way, and Honey Milk Lavender. The food was spot on! The portions are fairly large, so be mindful about that. The presentation of each dish was beautiful and creative. There was so much flavor packed in each bite but was not too overpowering. I liked how they put the sauces on the side - that way you had control over how spicy you wanted each bite to be. Overall, I would say the food was pretty authentic to traditional Thai style cuisine. 

SERVICE: The staff was busting their butts and moving quickly. We were seated fairly quickly but it took 10-15 minutes before anyone approached our table. Other than the initial long wait for our order to be placed, the experience after that was nothing short of fantastic. The staff was very friendly and attentive. I would definitely recommend trying this place out. We look forward to returning again!
author: Julie N.

description:
Excellent chicken noodle soup loaded with veggies.

When I went there were many groups celebrating birthdays. The entire staff comes out singing, some with drums and cymbals. Its fun, lively and loud in evenings. I'm gonna say it's my birthday the next time I'm there ;)
author: Amy M.

description:
I'm sure others will make their way over to Farmhouse Kitchen after seeing them profiled on Check Please Bay Area.  My friends and I were looking for something new and different for dinner and found this Thai restaurant.  Farmhouse Kitchen is a really fun way to experience Thai food with your family and friends.   A look at their website will tell you what you need to know.

I had arrived early and walked in to check in with the host.  That host was a site to behold, truly a Snapchat picture come to life with floral headband and beautifully done makeup!  We could not be seated until all members of our party arrived so we decided to wait outside on one of available seats.  I saw one thing I really liked, which was that many people were getting food to go.  Either this is the only place in the area to eat (it's not) or the food is really good (it was).  Reservations are needed or a long wait could ensue.

When all members of our party were present, we were promptly seated.  We asked our server for recommendations for beverage and food selections.  We started with the Neua Num Tok Rolls, then ordered the Herbal Rice Salad, Hat Yai Fried Chicken and the Panang Neua.  We chose to eat our dishes family style but each entree could definitely be eaten on its own.  

The Neua Num Tok Rolls, were wagyu beef rolls wrapped with herbs and cucumbers in a tangy vinaigrette.  The beef was tender, succulent and beautifully seasoned.  This was my favorite dish of the night!  The Herbal Rice Salad was a fantastic mix of textures and sweet, salty, sour and spicy flavors.  I could have eaten a heaping bowl of this dish.  

The fried chicken dish is highly recommended but note that they prepare the chicken with a very light and delicate batter, likely using rice flour or cornstarch in their mix.  It comes with pieces of roti and a yellow curry sauce.  I love fried chicken and found this version well seasoned, tender and juicy.  If I recall, this also comes with a side dish of honey.  I was happy to have shared this dish as it might have been too rich for me on its own.

Panang Neua is a short rib on bone that was cooked until fall apart tender.  It came with a nice curry sauce that cut into the richness of the meat and came with their blue rice and broccolini.  This dish is definitely good for meat lovers!

To accompany this meal I ordered the Thai Chelada.  Most of their cocktails are on the sweet side so I selected this beverage on advice of our waitress.  It's similar to a Michelada.
