While the beverage itself was fine the spice mix was a bit on the salty side.  Luckily, they have a wide variety of alcoholic and non-alcoholic options.  

The staff were helpful and really friendly.  They have a great way of celebrating birthdays here.  Farmhouse Kitchen could easily have been one of those places that known for cocktails, flash and overpriced menus.  However, it's not and the food is really one of the reasons to try this restaurant.  The food is presented in a beautiful manner and tastes great too!

Parking is not easy but it was doable.  I found a spot one block away on a Friday evening and a couple of spots opened up right in front of the restaurant while I was waiting for my friends.  This is one spot where it's probably a good candidate for an Uber/Lift ride.

We saw small and large groups here made up of young families, friends and couples of all ages.  It's a fun spot and will definitely put you in a great mood upon arrival
author: Melissa L.

description:
First off I'm not big one Thai food (don't @ me), but this place is beyond yummy.

Right off the jump they have a chill set up.

You don't come here for the servers, but one of em can get it. 

The food was awesssssooome. Chicken and pork belly is a must. The wings and calamari was just right and yummy. The Roti was bomb.

Did I mention one of em can get it? 

I'd definitely come back here. Super good for groups.

Tip: The green sauce is LIFE
author: Joaquin A.

description: Came for lunch on a Saturday and didn't have to wait at all. Was seated right away and service was consistently good throughout the meal as they checked in a couple of times. We ordered the pad Thai, pad see ew, Thai fried rice, and a curry from the special (with slow roasted beef? Can't remember what it is called, sorry!) and Thai iced teas. I would recommend the pad Thai and Thai fried rice, but all of the meat in our dishes was a bit dry. The Thai iced tea wasn't really worth the $5 price point as well and it was quite sweet. The serving sizes were on the smaller size. Service wise, they are great! Food wise, they are okay.
author: Jacqueline H.

description: This place is what dreams are made of, they have great kids menu options and it's located in a quieter area of the Mission-- so you can actually hold down a conversation without an overwhelmed toddler throwing a tantrum. I went with the vegetarian red curry and let me tell yaaaaaa they actually use a variety of fresh vegetables + tofu! My son loved the egg and broccoli noddles and the bae loves his tofu soup. Great service, fantastic food and an extremely clean environment. Will be definitely returning!
author: Cindy G.

description: Late post... last night dinner... service is great earn a full star there. this place is actually really good. The squid speciality is really good in flavor but pretty salty. Cutting down on salt would make it so good. The steak roll is the bomb. Tuna not all that, crab fried rice is ok but the fried chicken with blue rice is yummy. The giant mix drink with flashing light looks tempting to get but don't do it. Not good. But pretty so get it for fun than it's fine. Overall 4 star
author: Christy V.

description: For dinner, this place gets LOUD. They blast music, additionally the staff's performance for birthday celebration are a party but gets to be a bit much after the 4th time. We decided to walk-in at 8pm (which for SF restaurants in Mission District isn't the smartest) we put our name on the waitlist and was given a wait-time of 1.5 hours. So we walked back to our friends spot on Mission and 19th and bought a $4 bacon-wrapped hotdog as an appetizer. They called us back at 9:30, walked back but they had given our seats away. However, they were able to seat us quickly after. The food was good, not the most amazing but still pretty good. The drinks were delicious (I don't like to taste the alc) I got the elderflower spritzer, and also tasted the coconut creme drink as well. They also had $36 bowl drinks which look fun but would be a bit much for a party of two.
author: Jan Kirby Z.

description:
To be fair we only tried one of the things they recommended (think there are 4ish main ones they highlight?).  The rest traditional.  Maybe they excel at the fancy stuff.... ?  eh.....

C -- 24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup (they recommended): "Slow cooked bone-in Beef Short Rib" 
Sounds amazing, yah???  Welllll, nope.  I've had great bone based soups, this wasn't one of them.  Kinda tasted like... Maybe at some point in time it was awesome but they didn't make enough and kept adding water to it....  The meat was tough.....  Taste was not offensive but a little odd.     

C -- Pad Thai: Meh.  Too sweet, smallish portions, no noodles only bits  @$15 a pop.... MEH.  

C -- Pad see you: Better than the Pad Thai.  No noodles only bits, smallish portion and $15  Tasted good but was average.  Not worth the cost.  

A -- Raw shrimp sample: They were passing out these little raw shrimp samples with a pretty tower of sauce on top.  It was so, so good.  God, if the other stuff followed suit.  

Ambience/Service:  They were attentive when we went.  Very honest, told me the fried rice was bland, LOL.  The decor is beautiful - traditional thai, colorful and they dressed the part to boot.  Woot! Some of the plating was beautiful.  It's really pretty - good date place?
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description: Bewilderingly expensive, quite tasty, nice aesthetic, super brisk service--turned the table in 30m leaving us feeling well attended but shooed out. There's plenty of better value Thai experiences in this city!
author: Stella S.

description: Amazing service. When I asked for no eggs with my Pad See Ew, the waitress asked me if oyster sauce was ok before I even had to think about it because I'm vegan. Very attentive, friendly customer service and delicious food. I highly recommend the vegan rolls and Pad See Ew. Definitely coming back!
author: Regina C.

description: Holy smokes! Talk about everything is delicious! We had the masaman curry, fried chicken & steak meals, plus the papaya salad (ps. Super spicy). We even had three desserts. Bread pudding, chocolate cake and coconut shaved ice. Would definitely go back!
author: Pauline G.

description:
This place reminds me of Kin Khao in Parc 5 hotel. It's got the taste, the price, though not the Michelin Star. We ordered the Hat Yai Fried Chicken (a bit too much breading), Panang Neua Short Rib (really good), Pork Belly Salad (must try!), and Thai Sausage (so-so). We didn't have to wait at 12.30pm on a Sunday. It's a little pricey so can't and won't make this our regular go-to Thai restaurant. 

Still searching for quality Thai food in South Bay...
author: Ken L.

description:
Good food, good atmosphere& decoration ,okay service.

I enjoy everything that we had so I really have nothing to complain about food at all.

They have a reasonable lunch menu but it's quite a pricey dinner menu.
author: Dom G.

description:
We came on a Saturday night to a busy restaurant with party vibes from a first glimpse. When we were dropped off, we were surprised to see that Farmhouse was the restaurant on the street with loud music, bold colors, and workers wearing elaborate costumes; this is definitely not your typical Thai food spot or Thai food take out restaurant. 

I had made a reservation at 6:30, but they were kind enough to extend my reservation to 6:40, since we were running late. When at the door, we were instantly greeted by a hostess who was dressed in a Thai-themed costume; he really added to the theme and festivities of the restaurant. 

After being seated, we were served pickled cabbages and carrots, which I actually really enjoyed since they were refreshing. For an appetizer, we decided on the samosa. The order came with three samosas and a yellow curry dipping sauce. The samosas were super flaky on the outside and moist from the potatoes on the inside. The curry sauce was also one the best I have yet to have! It was super aromatic and lightly sweetened. For our entrees, we ordered the river prawn pad thai and the curried shrimp dish that came with blue rice. The dishes came on large and beautiful plates, but I was honestly not super impressed by the food. The pad thai was good, but definitely not the best I have had. For my personal preference, I wish they used more tamarind sauce or sauce in general, since the noodles came out pretty pale in color, even though they should be well coated in sauce. Also, the pad thai was $23, which I thought was a bit ridiculous for a dish that should be super inexpensive. The pad prawns were good and juicy, but super greasy; the whole dish was swimming in oil. However, I did really enjoy the blue rice. We decided to try a dessert so we went for the Thai vacation, which I enjoyed as well! It was a coconut ice cream and sticky rice combination that paired well.

The ambiance at the restaurant was amazing! It was super festive and the decorations were so colorful. Also, halfway through the dinner, waitresses were walking around with food on shoulder baskets to give an even more authentic Thai feeling. 

I do wish the restaurant wasn't as loud as it was, however. The blasting music made conversations somewhat difficult. Also, the prices are honestly really steep for this place; each entree was about $20-23, and though good, I think it's a bit excessive to spend that much for Thai food that isn't even that amazing. 

Overall, the food was a 3.5/5, but since the ambiance was so amazing, I am rounding it to a 4. I would come back again for the experience and the ambiance, but I am sure there are better Thai restaurants.
author: Sandra S.

description:
3.5 stars for the food.

We came here for lunch on a Saturday. We ordered several items for sharing: Mieng Kum Kung (leave wrapped crispy prawns), Green Curry w/ House Crispy Pork Belly, Tom Yum Noodle Soup, and Hat Yai Fried Chicken.

Of those dishes, the prawns and the fried chicken were the standouts. The meaty and crispy prawns were wrapped in a leaf, along with a flavorful mixture of peanuts, coconut and onion. The fried chicken was the most memorable--moist and crispy and filled with flavor. (Though the batter was on the greasy side.) The accompanying yellow curry was flavorful as well. While the blue rice made for a dramatic presentation, it tasted like, rice...

The Tom Yum was a bit of let down. Although it came with a generous portion of seafood, the soup was missing the expected flavors (lemongrass, galangal, etc.). 

I found the service to be quirky. We were asked to place our orders so many times, that I stopped counting after the fourth or fifth time. It was inexplicable, because the restaurant wasn't busy--the dining room was only a third filled. And they seemed just as anxious to clear our table. Several times they attempted to remove dishes while we were still eating. One staff member did notice our growing annoyance, and did jokingly ask before removing the remaining dishes.

Overall the food seemed solid. But for me, only the fried chicken dish was memorable. (Oh, and the rushed service.)
author: David W.

description: Love love this food. Really have to be in the mood for the atmosphere though. It was Friday night and boy was this place poppin. They had 3 birthday song requests while we were there and I wasn't sure I could handle a 4th! It was fun the first two but then it was pretty intense for the 3rd. The most important part was the food was amazing, we had a table of 6 and we ordered 5 dishes! All were so good and I thought for sure I would feel bad after but with such high quality food I was totally fine. With the volume of the place I couldn't really hear what we ordered but I am sure everything on the menu is fantastic. Give this place a try but be ready for a wait and for it to be loud.
author: Linette S.

description:
Came here for my mom's birthday with my boyfriend, my sister, and my mom's friend. We started off with BOMB samosas (3 pcs.). For entrees, I got the Pad Thai with chicken, my bf got some black pepper beef with pork belly, my mom's friend got the braised ribs, mom got Kai Yang (I'm not sure how to spell it), and finally my sister got Hatyai Chicken. Everything was really good! Pad thai and black pepper dish were smaller but we got really full. Other dishes were a little bigger. Their Thai Iced tea is also really good. My boyfriend isn't usually a fan of sweet drinks, but he really liked this one! 

Service was super nice and quick. Austin was our server and he was the sweetest person ever! He was also really knowledgeable about the menu and had great suggestions. 

Overall a really good experience. Definitely coming back. :)
author: Justine Leigh S.

description: Thai Food lover and this place was great.  Food, staff and venue were nice.  Could have done without the banging and clanging of pans for the happy birthday - to loud for the size of the restaurant.
author: Leahcim S.

description: This is definitely my favorite Thai spot in town. The food is flavorful and delicious, with a wide variety of dishes. The atmosphere is super festive. The staff all super friendly and helpful. It's almost always busy so definitely recommend getting a table. It can get quite loud with the crowds but that's just part of the fun!
author: Nana L.

description: Amazing Thai food. One of the best meals I had in SF was the hat yai chicken. The other items that it's served with created a wonderful medley of flavors and textures that all complemented each other. Frankly just a fun dish to eat. The atmosphere was nice too; however the wait is long! (With good reason though.)
author: Tyler H.

description:
I have mixed feelings for this restaurant - my coworkers and I used to frequent this place for lunch whenever we wanted to have a "treat yourself" day (about 3-4 times a month). The food is excellent, but when I went a few months ago they had raised prices of (their already expensive) dishes by $1-$2. It doesn't look like the price increase has been reflected in the lunch menu on yelp (you've been warned). Although the food is very good my coworkers and I now go only once every few months which is a shame since we're only a few blocks away. Average per person after tax, tip and health fee is around $22-$27. Too pricey for lunch out in this area.

For those who do want to treat themselves, make sure to check out some of my favorite dishes:
* 24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup - a favorite when it's cold out, I ask for it with no spice - the meat is tender and falls off the bone
* Pad See You - delicious when you add pork belly
* Hat Yai Fried Chicken: Big enough to share - I love that it includes naan and curry
* Bone Broth: Portion size is small, but the flavors are delicious - some of the best broth I have ever had
author: Christine L.

description:
EVENT: Ya know, it's a get together with a few friends during the holidays. Needed some Thai Food Fix.

**Reservations recommended**

PARKING: I live a few minutes away from here... didn't walk cause it was too cold, didn't drive cause I'm bad luck with parking spots, and I took uber like an SF pro!

SERVICE: homeboy was very nice and fast service! Filled my water every time he went by! I was never thirsty! 

FOOD:
(1) Ahi Scoop, $12 - came in four little scoops... so adorable!
(2) Papaya salad, $13.50 - one of my favorite dishes here! Get it with the salted crab!
(3) Thai street green curry noodles, $17
(4) Hat yai fried chicken,$ 19
(5) Panange neua, $24
(6) Tom yum noodle soup, $16.75
(7) 24 hours beef noodle soup, $18.75

DRINKS:
(1) Kick Boxing Bowl. $32 - came in a massive bowl and long straws... for sharing! Lychee flavored... so delish!
(2) Zinfandel, $11
(3) Pinot Noir, $13
(4) Chardonnay, $12

**MUST GET: Papaya salad with salted crab and Kick Boxing Bowl! 5 stars!
author: Mindy Y.

description: This is the perfect restaurant to make a reservation to celebrate a family or friend's birthday. It does get really busy so I do recommend making reservations.  The food tastes authentic and the atmosphere is what puts this place above others. If you let them know you are celebrating a special occasion, the employees will come to your table to sing and play music for the guest of honor. It is extremely festive and a fun dining experience.
author: Yin W.

description: So glad I tried this place on my trip here. Some of the best Thai food I've had in this city. The space itself is beautiful, modern and edgy but their food is what I'll go back for. Rich flavors, lots of interesting dishes you don't see in most Thai restaurants and while it's not cheap, it's worth every penny. We loved the beef red curry, the Hat Yai fried chicken, the Thai Street Green Curry noodles and the crab fried rice. They went easy on the spice level and I wish I had asked for them to make my food spicier. But every dish we ordered was pretty amazing.
author: Trips R.

description:
Ummmm... this place is pretty amazing! Food is delicious, especially the fried chicken and the beef noodle soup. So tasty. Bread pudding is also surprisingly good here. 

Staff is nice and accommodating, but the place is small and noisy.
author: Samantha C.

description: Its such a cozy and warm ambiance yet very spacious. I reserved table for 16 via Yelp reservations for a team outing lunch and hassle free it was. Highly recommend it for team lunches or in general lunches. Their service is swift and the waiters are well studied on their menu for giving good recommendation. I'd highly recommend reserving table well in advance as the place is quite crowded.
author: Kalyani R.

description:
If you are in search of a fancy Thai restaurant to take your date, this is the place for you. Farmhouse Kitchen is not your typical pad thai pad see ew thai joint in your local neighborhood. They have very good service and the interior is clean and nicely decorated. Their dishes here can also go up to $18 - $25 per person, but I have to say they have some of the best eye-catching beautiful plating of thai food I have ever seen. Also, BLUE RICE. They serve that here. Have you ever had blue rice before? I never had, until I came upon this place. 

The dishes I have had here:
Vegan Fresh Rolls ($9) - about 6 pieces of chopped up viet spring rolls with tofu inside. Definitely not worth the $9, but the taste is good. 
Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($16) - this is the dish with blue rice! The fried chicken is tasty and goes well with the vinegar sauce. The yellow curry also can act as a dipping sauce for the fried chicken! The portion size is big! 
Thai Street Green Curry Noodles ($16) - super good green curry! It can be spicier, but it was very creamy and fragrant. The curry had chicken or pork blood jelly which can be a new thing to try for some. The eggplants in this one were sooo sweet and creamy. 
Neua Yang Steak ($20) - wagyu beef steak can be served rare to well done. My coworker got the medium rare and it came nicely sliced. The waiter also lit it up using 151 rum on the table! It was literally ON FIRE. :) 

If you are craving thai food in the mission district, I would recommend trying Farmhouse Thai out. Be prepare for the higher prices, but it's worth the additional money. I wouldn't go for the appetizers though.
author: Hoyan L.

description: Easily the best Thai in the city! But what do I know, I've only been to Thailand 5 times.
author: Dong L.

description:
Four stars. Solid!
Love the colorful uniforms. Spacious and place smells great. It's a little far coming from downtown but totally worth it. Close to the former club Whisper. Place was packed and everyone looks happy, from eating yummy food. Great service. I really dig the sticky rice wrapped in leave presentation. The huge braised short rib, Super tasty!! The two noodle soup bowls were slurpy! Tuna poke salad a bit too spicy but thats just personal preference. Fried chicken yummy too. Great way to end a Thursday evening (clapping!)
author: Vee V.

description:
Made reservations at Farmhouse for 7:45pm.  They told us the table would be ready in 10 mins.  Service was really slow, we waited at the bar and had to ask for cocktail menu's after being ignored.  Finally after we ordered our drinks and waited for about 30 mins our table was ready.  

The hostess apologized and offered free dessert.  

I guess this was acceptable?!  I mean I wasn't in a hurry but a little communication would have sufficed. 

Had to go with the 2 most recommended dishes the papaya salad and the fried chicken.

The waiter asked us how spicy and we said medium...but damn that spice was strong!  

The flavor of the curry on the fried chicken was on point.  I loved the "blue" rice and the little pancakes served with it too.  

There was a birthday in the restaurant which was fun because the staff came out singing, banging drums and made the atmosphere a bit more lively! 

We also tried thai vacation dessert - super yum!

I'd definitely recommend this spot, very unique and traditional, lovely meal but slow slow slow to get seated.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to the city today for the Museum of Ice Cream and wanted to find something to eat afterwards. I searched nearby restaurants and I was in the mood for some Thai food, came across this restaurant and decided to try it out. 

Let me tell you, this place did not disappoint. When we arrived there was no line so we got seated really quickly. We ordered the fresh rolls with shrimp, papaya salad, Tom yum soup with chicken and beef pad see ew. The food came out surprisingly quick. If you love spicy, I would highly recommend the Tom Yum soup and Papaya Salad. The soup was my absolute favorite!   The Chicken Pad See Ew was very flavorful and the chicken wasn't dry like other places. Oh and their Thai tea is BOMB! 

The environment of the place was also very nice and the pace of how the food came out was perfect. Right after we finished our appetizers, the entree came out. Such perfect timing. Overall we had a wonderful experience. We will definitely come back in the future.
author: Joanne A.

description:
I was expecting a lot more from this place, since I had heard great things, but it didn't reach those expectations.

Only 1 out of 3 main dishes was delicious (it was the yellow curry). Everything else was just OK.

Generally, I found it to be overpriced for what it offered (I think every main dish-- from noodles to curries, was about $15 without meat, $19 with meat).
author: J. A.

description:
Celebrated Father's Day here yesterday with a dinner reservation for seven. It was easy to find parking since there seemed to be more availability with the ninety degree parking around the area. It was also a pretty hot day for SF and even though we were seated right by the open doorway, it was really really hot inside the restaurant. I couldn't imagine how I would've felt like sitting further into the restaurant.. there was absolutely no breeze coming inside. That was probably one of my main issues with this restaurant - the lack of ventilation and fresh air! 

Here are some of the things my family and I ordered. For appetizers, we started off with their samosas, calamari, and mieng kum kung (crispy tiger prawns). I didn't have a chance to try the samosas. The calamari was good, but I wasn't expecting the batter to be so thick/deep fried. It looked like onion rings you'd get out of the fair.. The pickled vegetables they served at the beginning of our meal were so good!

Most of our dishes had blue rice which was pretty unique. My mom ordered the mok salmon which was wrapped in a banana leaf. I took a bite of this and I wasn't too big of a fan of the taste. It definitely had the taste of the banana leaf.. but it was a huge piece of salmon! My boyfriend and I got their hat yai fried chicken. If you're looking for a comparison with what it tasted like, I'd say the fried chicken plate at King of Thai! But this dish comes with roti bread and yellow curry for dipping! My dad got their tiger prawn pad thai. Pad thai is always good, but my dad said the tiger prawns didn't have much meat. My brother got chicken yellow curry which tasted pretty standard. My sister's boyfriend had the kang kua prawns which seemed to be a very small portion. My sister got one of their seafood specials and I'm not sure if it was the phi pi platter.. but it wasn't good. It came with an assortment of seafood like mussels, tiger prawns, octopus, some sea shell.. lol. The vermicelli noodles served in the middle of the dish were difficult to separate and had absolutely no flavor. Her dish actually took forever to come out and sadly it was not worth the wait.

Another issue I had with this place was the fact that they kept waiting on us to pick up our plates at almost every opportunity. Yes, I get it, you wanna clear up the table, but I felt like it made our dinner feel a little rushed. At several points during our dinner, when we'd just be sitting there, I'd notice the waiters/waitresses just standing there like "Are you done?" 

A little on the pricier side of Thai cuisine, but I'd say it's worth a try. They gotta do something with the ventilation though..
author: Sydney C.

description:
I should preface this review by saying that I'm not a big fan of Thai food. Farmhouse Kitchen is definitely an exception though! I've had both lunch and dinner here and enjoyed everything. The food and decor is pretty unique so at the very least you'll get to experience something you probably haven't by coming here (is blue rice a thing??). The food itself is tasty and fresh and the portions are satisfying. Overall a great place to bring friends although it can get quite loud during dinner.

Just don't tell anyone it's your birthday for the sake of the other diners--by the 4th drum accompanied birthday recital I was pretty jaded.
author: Dennis C.

description: Delicious food! Quick service. Very good experience overall. I've been to thailand before and had some very authentic Thai food. My food here tasted just like it did on my travels. Roomate loved it too.
author: Bailey N.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Cuisine is one of those fun places that is a bit different than your traditional Thai restaurant, which has deemed its Michelin Guide recommended status. I came here with a friend after running an errand in South San Francisco and thought if we had already crossed the Bay, we might as well go somewhere in the city for an early dinner at 5:30 on a Friday. 

FOOD: Hat Yai Fried Chicken. The famous fried chicken of this place and it's definitely worth ordering. The potato curry was very full body and the three pieces of potato were cooked to perfection. With the roti on the side, you can dip it in the shallow bowl of curry and enjoy the crunchiness of the roti with the saltiness and spices in the curry. Moving onto the chicken, this fried chicken ain't a joke. It's fried to perfection with a light batter that is fried at a very high temperature creating a nice thin, but very crisp texture on the outside. The chicken is very tender and not dried out and pairs well with the dipping sauce on the side. The blue rice, although does not taste very different from regular white rice, is visually appealing and adds a filling aspect to the dish. 

SERVICE: Average, although I did find myself a little rushed towards the end of the meal service. Although I wasn't done eating, my plate was almost taken away, but I got to enjoy my last few bites of the delicious fried chicken. 

Although pricier than your typical Thai joint, this place has a twist on your standard Pad Thai plate. My only complaint with my dish that it was not as hot (temperature wise, not spiciness) when it came from the kitchen. I may have a temperature After we left at around 6:45, there was a line/wait, so I would highly recommend doing a reservation if you are looking at dining at a normal time on a weekend and want to get seated immediately.
author: Albert H.

description: Really good food. A bit salty, but all in all very good. They had a good selection on classic Thai dishes and some good new Thai dishes you don't get everywhere. I had he Braised rib and it was fantastic!
author: Nori W.

description:
Fun and relaxing atmosphere here. Perfect place for a casual date night or dinner with friends. Servers are dressed in colorful tropical shirts. Succulent plants everywhere from the tables to the outside of the restaurant. Walked in on a Wednesday night with no reservations and was lucky enough to get seated in five minutes. We got served some pickled vegetables as a free starter.

PAPAYA SALAD $12.50
A good light option to combat the fried chicken that followed after. The medium spicy wasn't really spicy at all. I probably won't get this next time and would opt to try the mango salad or herbed rice salad next time. 

HAT YAI FRIED CHICKEN $18.95
Stellar! Fried chicken is perfectly crispy and it just flakes off easily. Biting into it, the crispy part reminds me of funnel cake. Chicken breast is nice and juicy and it pairs well with either the sweet and sour sauce that comes on the side or you can dip it in the curry. The dish also comes with roti, curry dip with potatoes, blue rice, and some pickled side veggies all on one big tray.

After we finished eating, they cleared our dishes and then someone came and set out new plates in front of us and that was confusing since we hadn't even received our check yet. I thought more food was coming or something (that we didn't order) since they gave us new plates but I guess they were just setting it up early?
author: Diana C.

description:
Average at best. After spending a few hours at the Carnival in the Mission I brought my butt here because it was the closest restaurant to where my brother and I parked our car. I got a Pad Thai and he order a salad. His salad wasn't bad although he said he would not order it again. There was nothing special about it, indeed, I do not see any difference between the one we got there and the one he could have bought at Trader Joe's. Well, maybe the difference is that we paid nearly $20 for this one when Trader Joe's costs probably a fourth of that. My Pad Thai was the most boring Pad Thai I could have asked for. Plain, boring, non-spicy and bland. I had to eat it because I could not find the waiter after my first bite; although I wanted to send the meal back and order something else that option did not seem to be on the table.

I have not see a restaurant that is worth when the food this bad and when there is no service. Not to mention that we paid fine dinning prices and ended up getting a "Sizzler's" or "Fresh Choice" experience. Not coming back.
author: Alicia J.

description: Sorry to say but the food was a little bland. Nothing made it special from any other Thai place. Kinda disappointed. I had fried chicken and it was greasy. The samosa was a little mushy. The only dish that I thought was good was the tuna appetizer.
author: raimundo t.

description: Excellent everything omg sooooo yummy I can't wait to come back! The fried chicken and the short rib were incredible and the staff was all incredibly helpful and professional!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Thai food is authentic but also modern! The food is always fresh, from the 5ish times I've visited and it's a solid local place for the area. I would recommend for others that love Thai food but I would also advise that it's a little bit more expensive then I think Thai food in that area should be.
author: Ayanna A.

description:
Very vibrant Thai restaurant with great customer service and good food. 

The experience is great. The staff is full of personality and very flamboyant which made ordering fun. 

The food was good. Every dish was well flavored and well worth the hype. 

We had the yellow curry, Fried chicken, and the Pad See Ew ( with pork belly ). All were delicious. 

However, if I had a complaint, it would be the size of the dishes as they were quite small compared to other Thai restaurants, especially at the prices. 

Overall it was a great atmosphere for a social purpose and the food was overall good. The experience itself is what makes it stand out compared to the other Thai restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Alberto P.

description:
Hallelujah! I have found a Thai restaurant that I absolutely love in SF. I thought all hopes were down the drain but Farmhouse has been an absolute blessing. 

Their dishes are so flavorful (I'm hoping they don't use MSG) and authentically Thai. They have really unique dishes that you cannot find anywhere else. 

I recommend to get the crab fried rice and the yellow curry. It was to die for! Even though we asked for mild, I was crying by the end of my Tom Yum soup and Papaya salad, a hard thing to do with someone growing up eating Thai food. I definitely will be back and will take all my friends from out of town here - although I'll be sure to make reservations first since getting in can be quite tricky!
author: M T.

description:
Ok, came back here for their Thanksgiving Day special and was BLOWN away at the great job they did. The night was full of a mix of restaurant, street cart foods, carnival games, and dancing! We got to try fried grasshoppers for the first time ever (quite nutty and delicious as long as you don't stare into those eyes). I managed to score a nice pilsner glass from throwing darts on the wall to blow up a balloon. 

Overall, the food was excellent and the atmosphere was super lively and exciting! We brought in our own wines and paid their corkage fee. We may just have to make a tradition of coming here for Thanksgiving every year!
author: Sam L.

description:
Decided to come here for dinner and made reservations online. It gets super packed here so it's better with a rvsp or you'll wait for an hour. Even with rvsp we had to wait 20 min, ugh. 

Once we sat down, service was pretty fast. 
We ordered: 
Ahi Tuna Spoons: Delicious and refreshing. They had these crunchy flakes in the bottom that were super good and topped with a spicy sauce.
Hat Yat Fried Chicken: YUM! High recommend! The chicken was crispy and juicy, cooked very well. Comes with curry, blue rice and bread. 
Green Curry Noodles: OK, I would say pass. Too much coconut milk in the curry. It's not bad but not authentic. 
House Soda: Interesting, made with lime, sugar and blue flower. It does go well with the spices but it's not for everyone. It's not sweet at all, kind of sour and bitter. 
Thai Ice Tea: Pretty good, had more ice than than tea though. 

Overall, a very fun environment and great place for birthdays! They come out and bang on drums and sing happy bday to you!  I would come again to try their other doses someday!
author: Natalie L.

description: Fun lively and delicious! We came here to celebrate my husband's birthday and it was awesome! Our table was ready when we arrived. Drinks, food, and dessert was all fantastic plus the special small plates that come around table to table was very delicious and for the adventurous there are crickets. Gratuity was included as expected on our bill since we were a large party. Super fun, great hospitality and tasty food and drinks. Everything you need with fabulous company for a fantastic evening out.
author: Sinee H.

description: OMG i could go back again and again and never get tired of this place. We had the Hat Yai Fried chicken (huge portion, great for sharing), absolutely amazing, plus a bunch of other things to share like tom kha soup. Cute place! Will be back!
author: Paalika B.

description:
This place is definitely on the high end scale in terms of prices, good thing the quality is GREAT.

We've tried:
Pad see you- the noodles portion is GREAT, but way too much veggies compared to the noodles
Pad Thai-Decent, once you had the best, all the other pad thai are mediocre. 
Green Curry noodles- SO SPICY
Chicken with papaya salad and sticky rice- chicken is good, but the papaya salad is the spiciest thing ever. 
Thai tea
Chai Coconut latte- so sweet but so good. 
and a Young coconut drink ( this was so damn good)

There are so many dishes I've never seen at any other thai places, so I'll definitely come back to try others.
author: Josie H.

description:
My daughter made reservations on Sunday afternoon at 2 pm at Farmhouse Kitchen Thai. When we arrived the place was filled but our tiny table for four was ready. The table itself was very small and narrow and could only hold three dishes at one time. So when we ordered a bunch of dishes we knew we would have to eat and finish the dishes to make room for the additional food coming. We ordered the following :

Boat Noodles 4 stars the noodle soup comes in a large platter with the toppings on the side.

Fried fish cakes 4 stars the fish cakes cone on skewers and was flavorful. 

Green Papaya Salad 3 stars small portions and was very spicy way over the medium spicy we ordered

Beef rolls 5 stars excellent tender beef rolls

Beef short rib 4 stars was tender fall off the bone flavorful beef. 

All of the food was good. The service was lacking. Our server was nice and always smiling but I think they only have one POS system terminal at the bar which was all the way across the other end if the restaurant.  Our server was constantly in front of that POS terminal and we waited to clear the used dishes to make room for all the food. Minus star for the service.
Street parking only but not hard to find on a Sunday afternoon.  Note they only have one unisex restroom but it has to be the largest single restroom in the Bay Area. Overall the food is good but very expensive for Thai Cuisine.
author: George F.

description:
Such a fun spot! 

Came here to celebrate a friends birthday, which is probably one of the best reasons to dine here. I made reservations about three weeks in advance, and we were seated right away. Right when we got to our table, we were greeted by a server who gave us a mini fried shrimp sample to taste. We thought we would be charged for it, but guess it was on the house! I noticed that not every table got this special treatment so I'm not sure if it was because they knew we were celebrating a birthday, but regardless it was a nice touch and great welcome.

The food- just phenomenal. The portions are HUGE!! Our favorite was the Fried Chicken, which is probably the best fried chicken I've ever had in my life. It comes with blue rice, yellow curry, roti, and other herbs on the side. The fusion of flavors was off the charts. 

For every birthday, they come to your table singing super obnoxiously complete with one of those loud bullhorns. The staff is dressed in authentic outfits, which adds to the feel of the restaurant. The experience was so much fun and definitely a night that we will remember.
author: Sonia D.

description:
I hardly ever come to this part of the Mission, meaning east of Harrison because my perception was that it gets very quiet and warehousey around there. Unless I drive over there, it's a bit of a schlep especially if you're counting on the 12 to pick you up sometime in your lifetime. However, my friend Maggie took the advice of a colleague of hers and invited Jamie W. and me to dinner at this spot of which I was completely unaware. Trick Dog and Central Kitchen are just around the corner, but I didn't know this happening Thai eatery was attracting the young and hip all on its own.

It looked expansive when I first entered the empty restaurant, but it crowded quickly before we knew it. I got there first and ordered a $4.50 Classic Thai Tea just because I needed something refreshing (photo: http://bit.ly/2fBnKd3). Once we sat at the table, I moved onto the even more refreshing $6.50 Whole Young Coconut, which is exactly what it was like I was on an episode of Gilligan's Island with the Howells. It even had a pink straw and matching umbrella (photo:  http://bit.ly/2fP2jCW). Maggie decided to get something with more of a kick and landed on a $9.50 Thai Cooler which mixed a lager with fresh pineapple juice, lime, and cane sugar (photo: http://bit.ly/2gfssLK).

We decided to share our plates and started with the $12 Ahi Scoops, a quartet of appetizer servings combining pan-seared Ahi tuna covered in black sesame seeds, cucumber, seaweed salad, crispy yam, dill, lemongrass, and chili lime (photo: http://bit.ly/2gwcZYe). Tasty bites with a nice contrast in textures, they were like maki rolls without the rice. We moved on to a $12 tureen of the popular Tom Kha, a luxuriant coconut soup with mushroom, tomato, galangal, kaffir lime, lemongrass, long coriander, and for $4 extra, fresh prawns (photo: http://bit.ly/2gJf06m). It was a lovely tropical broth that tasted creamy without having any cream in it.

Our entrees came next with the recommended $18 Hat Yai Fried Chicken arriving first. It's a Southern Thai specialty that fries up a large chicken breast and adds fried shallots, turmeric, and other herbs in the coating. It came with a bowl of potato yellow curry, roti bread for dipping, and a scoop of intensely blue rice made from dok un sun (butterfly peas) (photo: http://bit.ly/2g2gAiz). The poultry was quite tender on its own, but the curry, rice and roti bread made it a more complete meal. The finale was the $22 Panang Neua, a large slow-braised, bone-in short rib with a Panang curry ladled over it.

It came with grilled broccolini, peppers, onion, fried basil, and more of that blue rice (photo: http://bit.ly/2gfzHmW). That was definitely a high point with the meat falling off the bone with ease with the curry providing extra punch. For dessert, an indulgence I know after all that food, we decided to splurge and get the $26 Ruk Na Platter, a somewhat overpriced potpourri of most of their specialty desserts - taro sticky rice, coconut creme brulee, choco cake, a caramel macaron, and a wedge of fresh seedless watermelon (photo: http://bit.ly/2fP7F0L). It was such a fanciful meal like we were in Koh Samui lounging next to the beach....only it's the Mission and I don't need sun block.

FOOD - 4 stars...creatively executed Thai dishes mostly flavorful, some a bit overdone
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...cavernous space feels casual like a beach club
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...polite but not overly informative
TOTAL - 4 stars...Thai food for an eclectic palate, no pad thai allowed
author: Ed U.

description:
Yummmmmmmmmmy!!!!!!! Probably my favorite Thai restaurant in the city now!
I came for lunch on Sunday, and three of us shared the 24hr beef noodle soup, hat yai fried chicken, and pad see ew with pork belly. Those three dishes are ~$20 each which is more than what I'm used to paying for Thai food, but the serving sizes are generous and food is deliciousssssssss and full of flavor. We got the 24hr beef noodle soup medium spicy, and it definitely has a kick. The hat yai fried chicken was greaaaaat (crunchy outside, blue rice o.o, love the sauce) and the pad see ew with pork belly was delicious (the pork belly really sticks to your teeth though). I'll be coming back!!!
author: Annie S.

description:
Delicious food - we tried the soup, short rib and green curry... and Thai ice teas. The iced teams come with a ball on crushed ice on top - definitely going for the IG crowd, ha ha. 

Food was really food. Entrees around $25 is expensive for Thai but quality and type of offerings very different than an average Thai takeout restaurant. Massive portions too - enough for two servings.

However, very loud - hard to carry on a conversation.
author: Raj S.

description: Farmhouse is incredible food, love the Green and Penang Curry. Be prepared to wait... a long time, but I will say if you have the time its 100% worth it.
author: Scott G.

description: Hands down the best Thai I've ever had - and I've had them all. Yellow curry with shrimp- superb. Fried chicken- delectable. Tom Yum - yum. Yeah I'm fat, so what...
author: Jason S.

description:
Farmhouse Thai Cuisine is my new favorite Thai place in the city! The food is delicious, and it's relatively easy to get a reservation in advance. They also have tasty cocktails and are a great place for a group dinner/hangout!

My favorite by far is probably the Hat Yai Fried Chicken, and this entree comes with SO MUCH FOOD. In addition to a super crispy and delicious fried chicken, you get some curry and rice to pair it with. The Ahi Tuna scoops are also a great appetizer, but spicier than I expected! If it's your birthday, come here to celebrate and the staff will come to your table to sing (with props).

The service is pretty fast so turnover is good if you're coming here for a bite with no reservation!
author: Grace C.

description: Expect a long wait sundays mornings! But worth the wait! Cute farm-y design with wooden tables! The food is on the pricier side, but yummy :)
author: Mako U.

description:
Low key last minute dinner. I was in the area and found this place.

Love the warm ambiance, especially during the cold winter of December.

I was seated immediately at the bar.

I ordered the hat Yai. The fried chicken platter. It came with Roti, a BLUE jasmine rice, and probably one of the best potato curry sauces I have ever tasted in a long time.

The presentation was beautiful. The portions; The plate was huge and I had to take my leftovers home. 

The chicken was crispy. My highlight of this dish was the potato curry. It went well with everything; to dipping my fried chicken and Roti in it and pouring it over my blue jasmine rice. I could probably drink the sauce with a straw if they served it as a cocktail.
author: A Z Flor H.

description: I love this place! The food is amazing and service is great, one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Everything on the menu is good! Always recommending this place to friends and family.
author: Jessica J.

description: Super delicious and flavorful food, fun atmosphere. Get a reservation or you'll likely have to wait a bit!
author: Alli S.

description: Amazing food. Amazing service. Great place to have a birthday dinner or for large groups. Food came out fast, parking wasn't too hard, and it's super clean. Overall a really good experience. I would definitely come back again! I recommend the their Thai-Cheladas and fried chicken with the blue rice.
author: Penélope C.

description: Yum.  The chef secret menu is the yellow curry noodle with egg noodle.  I enjoy their yellow curry. We had the short rub.  Good thing they had blue color rice to go with the sauce.  The fish cake had 4 pieces but i love the sweet and slightly spicy peanut sauce.  Skip the shrimp.  Was very full when we left.
author: Helen L.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco: unpretentious, delicious fresh food in dishes that dont all taste the same, and the service and decor are actually quite eccentric and fun. You can tell the people who are in charge know how to run a great restaurant and kitchen. The added bonus of the dim sum carts circling are great between courses or even get that extra indulgence just bring this up a level
author: Daniel S.

description: They have a different special everyday and the food is delicious. I'm a bit hesitant to rave about it is already crowded but the food is worth it.
author: MJ C.

description:
I was SO disappointed with my meal here. We are gluten free and they do have a lot of options.

The Bad:
We had the Tuna scoop and it was okay, kind of on the spicier side and I asked for little spice.
Then we got the pork belly appetizer. I tasted old, the meat was super dry, like they reheated it. Not fresh. Not good at all. Also confusing how to eat it as it came with a slender wedge of cabbage.
The salmon entree was not good, it was way overcooked.
We had the Thailand vacation dessert-half coconut with shaved coconut, ice cream, peanuts and rice. Super weird and super hard to eat. I love rice dishes for dessert. This was just weird.

The Good
The spring rolls are the bomb. Not like any other spring rolls I have tried. The wrap is thick and chewy. Their peanut sauce is wonderful.
The crab fried rice was pretty good. 
The service was great. I was there for a birthday and that was a fantastic experience. Very friendly staff.

I don't think I would eat here again though. Which bums me out. I wish the food was better. I really was looking forward to it and thought I would like it more.
author: Lucia M.

description: Our recent visit was a hoot. Their food has more variety than your typical Thai restaurant and the lively, party atmosphere made our date night an evening to remember.
author: Scott O.

description:
I loved the atmosphere/decor of the restaurant! Service was great and staff were extremely attentive. Now on the important part....the food!

Fresh rolls: delicious and perfect sized appetizer, served with an amazing peanut sauce
Tofu Pad Thai: loved the consistency of the noodles and tasted great. perfect amount of sweet and tangy + savory 
Chicken Thai Fried Rice: delicious and not oily at all, generous amount of meat

I docked a star because the portions are definitely on the smaller side..one appetizer and two entrees later, we were still hungry! 

Overall though, a great place for some great Thai food in the Mission.
author: Winnie T.

description:
In a world where Thai restaurants are plentiful in major cities, Farmhouse Kitchen is a standout. We shared the herbal rice salad as a starter, and I had the pad kee mow with prawns, while my friend had the kai yang som tum. The pad kee mow is fantastic, properly spicy, with a large amount of prawns, and the portion size is reasonable but not enormous. It's probably the best pad kee mow that I've tried. The kai yang, som tum has a lot of different components to it, and the portion size is massive. The herbal rice salad is a flavour explosion, and I am so here for that toasted coconut.

The drinks here are on the sweeter side, so not so much to my taste, but the non-alcoholic options (especially the teas) are plentiful and worth trying.

I've been pretty lucky with getting in here, but the waits can get a bit crazy.
author: Jillian K.

description:
+ Fun ambiance; they will play music and sing for people's birthdays; waiters are dressed up
+ Very good food thai food
+ Fresh coconuts are always win
+ Random - will come around with fried grasshoppers; a bit pricey - I think it was $3 / grasshopper
author: Margaret R.

description:
I like this place very much. It's trendy, hippy and serving the most unique Thai food in SF with affordable price. I just visited the newly rated one star Michelin Thai restaurant in downtown SF. Food was probably equally good, but considering price and convenience, Farmhouse definitely is a better choice! 
I have been to Farmhouse more than three times and I cannot wait to go there again! This is so far the best Thai restaurant in SF!
author: Pink M.

description: Holy shit, this was better than a lot of the Thai food I had in Thailand. GET THE FRIED CHICKEN. It is a lot more food than you are expecting. You get the chicken and the blue rice, but then you also get a small small side of curry and flat bread to eat! Went here on a whim with friends and it was an amazing surprise. The wait was really a lot longer than I thought it would be.
author: Alex B.

description:
It's been awhile since I've gotten out for dinner during the week.  When my girlfriends and I were deciding on where to celebrate our friend's birthday, I threw this recommendation out! Farmhouse had been on my radar for awhile, and got excited when a co-worker of mine raved about here.

Farmhouse Kitchen doesn't seem like a Thai restaurant, but I assure you, they know what they're doing. Our group of 5 sat at one of the tables, and ordered family style.  We came hungry and ready to eat EVERYTHING!

We decided on the Neua Num Tok Rolls (grilled flank Steak wrapped with mint, cilantro, cucumber served with cilantro lime vinaigrette) and Fried Chicken Wings to start. Followed on with the popular and always delicious pork Pad See Ew.  We tried out a few of their house specialties with the Panang Neua (slow braised short rib in a Panang curry) and Kai Yang, Som Tum (BBQ chicken marinated in turmeric and coconut milk).  And of course, there was the Hat Yai Fried Chicken.  Fried chicken is always a good idea, but an even better at Farmhouse Kitchen.

The night ended with their Croissant Bread Budding that we all shared, and enjoyed the birthday celebration my friend got from all of the wait staff.  Everything we had was fabulous and service was friendly! I definitely would love to come back here with a big group! If you're in the Mission, definitely check this place out!
author: Lisa I.

description: This is a bit overdue, but I've been coming back to this place for many times now, with many different group of friends and have been very happy with everything: Service is very friendly and professional, food is always excellent, the place itself is so nice and clean and awesome.
author: Joanna L.

description: The curry is to DIE for--I had bowl after bowl. I would recommend the fried chicken. The portions are a bit huge, however.
author: Edson M.

description: This is the first time I tried boat noodles and my taste bud could not adjust to the taste at the first bowl. However, it became quite tasty after eating subsequent bowls of it. The pork and beef are good. The noodles in pink broth has a little weird taste
author: Macleod R.

description: Just went back last week and had an amazing meal. Sat only a few minutes after our reservation. We split the papaya salad (ordered spicy and I loved it). I had Tom Yum soup which I ordered spicy, and it was really spicy, but I loved that too. My partner got some kind of stew that wasn't even on the menu which he was so happy they had and he loved. We were craving soup but I just want to add that the people around us were getting amazing looking beef and other meat dishes...including a bread pudding that looks like heaven.
author: Dana H.

description:
Yumm!!! My new favorite Thai in SF! Too many decors everywhere, even the workers! It's worth the wait!! 

FOOD

-TOM YUM, this soup got our asses burning for days. So spicy and at the same time we LOVE IT! 
-HAT YAT FRIED CHICKEN, holy glory... love this place! The presentation is like 10/10 with BLUE RICE?? WHAT? Wtheck is that? But it tastes good like it mixes with vinegar and sugar.. something like that with shredded carrots! Comes with delicious fried chicken with Thai roti... yummm. and the curry! OMG BOMB.COM! 
-LARP, comes with sticky rice inside the a mini enclosure that's like made out of bamboo! So tropical.. presentation is on point again (probably why the prices are higher) that comes with chicharrones (pig pork skin) and some battered fried veggies! With the soup broth

Service is great! Everyone looks busy and at the same time know how to keep up with their customers! Will definitely come back!
author: Jan P.

description:
I've been to Farmhouse Kitchen twice now, and both visits have been awesome, memorable experiences... I am sure there will be many more in the future.

Not only does this gem of a restaurant offer a casual and fun atmosphere, but the service is attentive and friendly, prices are moderate, and food is fabulous!

Farmhouse Kitchen is great for groups, and it's super easy to make a reservation using Yelp Reservations.  On my recent visit earlier this week, the restaurant was decorated for Halloween and had candy bowls scattered throughout...  My party of 10 was seated promptly upon arrival.  We were offered water and drinks (we went with the Wonderwall Pinot Noir) within minutes, but given plenty of time to enjoy without feeling pressure to order food right away.  When we were ready to order, our server, Tonk, was super helpful... I was torn between several dishes and he helped me decide what to order (the green curry chicken).  This was in addition to some shared appetizers and sides (Vegan Fresh Rolls, Ahi Scoops, Spicy Eggplant and Asparagus).  

This place is known for their Hat Yai Fried Chicken, which I tried on my first visit, and it is delicious.  That being said, I don't know that you can go wrong with your order here... everyone I dined with loved their meals.  If you go and you're torn on what to order, go family style and share... or ask Tonk for a recommendation!

If you find yourself anywhere remotely close to Farmhouse with a craving for Thai food, this is your place!
author: Gabi M.

description:
Nice place, clean. Waitress are slow at bringing your condiments and checking back with you.  Short braised ribs are delish. But the green curry were very disappointing:( 

The Portland location is better...
author: Maile h.

description: This is my new go-to Thai restaurant. The food quality is amazing and the vibe is rockin. I got my food to go so I was only in the restaurant for a few minutes, but the food was cooked pretty fast from when I called it in to when I arrived to pick it up in 15 minutes.
author: Philip D.

description:
One of the best Thai restaurants in San Francisco for sure. First of all, the place is cute af. Decorations are a nice touch, and the ambience makes you feel like you are in the East Village of NYC. 

You cannot go wrong with anything on the menu. Fried chicken is dope. 

The wait is worth it. Come hungry.
author: Anthony G.

description: I love love love Thai food, and this is becoming one of my favorite Thai restaurants, both dine in and for delivery. Festive place, great location, and creative dishes. Also love the fun tropical bev options. The special bbq chicken was amazing, as were the more traditional street food options. Good amount of spice. All ingredients seem fresh. I'll be returning!
author: Nancy P.

description: This place was awesome and authentic. Cute restaurant in mission district.  Parking was a bit hard. The green chicken curry was sooo good.  Only thing I was sad aboit was no sticky rice and mango for dessert l.
author: Lindsey O.

description: Love the weird funny video of the staff that plays at the entrance. Service sometimes is a little lacking, but they have good energy and are friendly. LOVE the food. Highly recommend. One of my favorite places in the SF.
author: Amber L.

description:
SUMMARY: I would go back to try other dishes but not sure I would recommend to friends quite yet for the food or service - would recommend for cute and unique interior
ORDERED: Tofu pad thai + spicy chai tea + steak roll appetizer + fried chicken plate

-----------------------

FOOD: Tofu pad thai was ok - lots of veggies which I typically love but the veggie to noodle ratio was a little too veggie heavy. Steak roll appetizer was DELICIOUS but too large to eat in one bite. The fried chicken plate I wouldn't get again. It's more of a fish and chips style fried chicken (not a big fan) with a delicious yellow curry but not much to dip in the curry.

DRINK: Spicy chai was not spicy nor chai-y. Wouldn't get again. Other drinks may be good.

ATMOSPHERE: Beautiful - I walked by this place a while before I actually went to eat here and thought it was very cute. Interior is simple but romantic. Quiet enough to talk. 

SERVICE: Slow and nothing to write home about, but not bad either.
author: Christina K.

description:
I had dinner here last night. I found the restaurant randomly on Yelp. I was so impressed by everything. First off the service was so on point. We got attention from multiple people that were checking in to make sure we had everything we needed and were happy. The waiters made a point of walking around the establishment looking around at people's tables in intervals. I haven't seen that kind of dedication in a long time at a SF restaurant. 

Secondly the food was delicious. We ordered:

Par Dip Fresh Tuna 
Pretty spicy. Actually a great pairing with the Tom Kha soup since it helped with the spice level. Really tasty. 

Crab Fried Rice 
They dished out a lot of crab in this dish which I appreciated. The dish came with some sort of beef broth which I think were suppose to use for more flavoring? The crab fried rice was excellent on it's own. 

Large Tom Kha 
LOVED this. Best Tom Kha I have ever had. Amazing base broth. We ask them to add shrimp in it. Highly recommend you do the same. Definitely order the large if you are sharing this with two people. You will probably need to get two larges if you are sharing with more than two people. 

Glass of the Waterwall Pino-yum 

Presentation was on point for all three dishes.

The whole vibe of the place is happy. Also this is a great place to take groups. They had some huge farmhouse style table set ups that could of accommodated a group of 10 or more. 

I'll be back.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Although not authentic Thai and more fusion, the food was amazing. Organic ingredients that you can taste the difference. We had the steak that was set with a flame for aesthetics. The curry was delicious as well and the atmosphere and service fantastic.
author: Doron K.

description: Great Thai dining in a residential area (almost obscure).  But a packed house was a great indicator that we made a good choice for dining.  Food was excellent and clean, maybe on the "smaller" scale if you're with a large group and trying to share (aka family style).   Some of the spicier dishes tasted great....but the spice kept lingering in my mouth (i don't do spicy very well).  Definite must try when in SF
author: Brian C.

description: Food was great! I would highly recommend this place. Very authentic Thai food with a twist. Loved the drink menu too!
author: L F.

description:
FOOD is awesome!
the atmosphere is so great. 
portion are generous, the hostess was very nice with us, so were the barman!
Only bad side is that they push you to finish your diner very quickly.
they take the order after 5 minutes sitting, and you better not have a lot of question as they answer so fast that it makes you understand you better not have too many... the tables have to be cleared quickly!
Food is out on the table within 5 min.
they buss your table at the second you are done with it and the check is ready while you havent finished.
I will come back and will try to take more my time as we were in and out within 45 min.
definitely a place to check out!
author: Mariette H.

description: Fancy Tai food that's good combine with Tai and US fusion. My friend visits me out of the town and I decided to show him some foods that can present the SF culture. Farm Kitchen is excellent in both food and surrounding. Happy to be there. But could be better if they have a menu with pictures in the future.
author: 恒生

description:
A lil closer to 3.5 stars. There are some hits and some misses, overall it was alright. It was my first time here and I've been wanting to try them for a while now. The pricing is wild, pretty expensive for Thai food, but I guess it's more Thai fusion.

We ordered the punch bowl, calamari, fried chicken, curry and roti, the crab fried rice, and the Thai street green curry noodles. Each dish cost roughly $19-26. The best thing was the fried chicken and curry, but the roti was basically rock hard, it was the worst roti I've ever had. When I think roti, I think airy, soft, thin. This was flattened and tough. Next thing would be the crab fried rice, that was pretty good. I enjoyed the two bites I had. My only thing is I wish they had mixed the crab in instead of putting it directly on top, but it makes sense from a presentation stand point. The calamari was okay, I've had better, but the sauce it came with was good on its own, a little sour and salty, but I don't think it complemented the dish. And the green curry noodles were not good. They were cold and because of that the flavor was not there for me. All I could really get was the spice, not much else. My friends and I agreed, that we could definitely skip this. We also got talked into trying their bread with pandan dip, which was alright, it was just bread dipped with a sweetened condensed milk flavored with pandan. The pandan flavoring could have definitely been stronger. I would skip this as well. If I do come here next time, I would probably go for the basic curries or more authentic Thai cuisine, because from what I could tell from the fried chicken dish, the curry was good. And the entrees/fusion dishes we ordered this time didn't really fulfill my Thai craving.

Service is good, a little pushy, but they're all super nice and sweet. They kept coming around and asking us if and when we were going to order when we had already ordered a drink, an appetizer, three main dishes, and their pandan item.
author: Eva C.

description: The food is completely delicious and definitely my favorite Thai in SF. The main negatives are that they are so popular it can be hard to get seating and they are quite pricey, but I guess you can charge more when your food is that good. Love the blue rice!
author: Erin W.

description:
Came here for my friend's birthday a few months ago and was super impressed! She chose the place and made reservations, so the wait wasn't long at all.

The ambiance is super cool, very trendy, with the waiters/waitresses all wearing brightly colored Hawaiian shirts. It's pretty loud in the dinner room, so maybe not the best choice if you're trying to have a quiet intimate conversation.

I got the Thai Style Fried Chicken, which came with rice, yellow curry, and roti. I was impressed with how big the portion was, and also thankful because I was so hungry! The dish was super flavorful, and I loved having the warm curry to dip everything in. I didn't get to try anyone else's dishes, but honestly I was so impressed with mine I will totally come back just for that. 

Only thing I wasn't a huge fan of were the prices, $10-15 for an appetizer and $20-25 for a main dish was kind of steep, so this isn't somewhere I would want to put up the cash to frequent. However for a special occasion it's a fun dining experience and somewhere I'd recommend everyone trying at least once!
author: Tracy C.

description: This place is super clean and cute and the staff is friendly!!! The menu is straight to the point and it's literally the best Pad Thai I've everrrrr had. When I was younger I thought I just didn't like Thai food but I believe I wasn't going to places that did the amazing food justice. The food here tastes fresh and does a fresh take on things which I appreciate so much. Definitely not a "hole in the wall," it's more like a hidden gem! Please please give this place business-even though from my last visit it looks like they're doing just fine!
author: Yasmeen S.

description: We had Penang Curry and Hat Yai Fried Chicken. OMG SOOOO GOODDDD. Highly recommended everyone to book the reservation otherwise it will be a long wait. The Fried Chicken melted in my mouth. So soft but really tasty. They have the God Mother Chili Sauce for whom loves spicy food. That sauce is a killer but really good tho. Must try!
author: Chloe N.

description: I love this place. Good for groups that are sharing food family style. Birthday parties here are a blast. :)
author: Becky H.

description: I was so excited to try this restaurant out. Unfortunately, the MOK SALMON was rubbery and over cooked. We mentioned this to the manager and his response was that's how we (Thai) cook the salmon. He had no desire to satisfy the customer. Most likely not coming back here.
author: Sharon J.

description:
I found out about this place on Instagram, not sure how it got on my feed but the food looked good and I'm always down to try something new. We made on reservation for 5 pm on a Saturday. When we got there it was pretty empty but probably 20 minutes later it started to get packed.

The food was excited! I had pad see you, one of my favorite Thai dishes, and it was excellent. My husband had the crab fried rice, delicious, I will be getting that for myself next time. Only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because once they got packed are service was not very good. Our waiter did not check in with us to see if we need refills or something else. 

I would still recommend this place.
author: S R.

description:
Holy smokes this place is delicious. We had a party of 6 that got seated within 10 minutes on a Monday night, but any other night you'd probably need reservations for a party of that size. This place is popular. Service was super quick. We were in and out in about an hour. 

We got the samosas, fish cakes, tom kha, papaya salad (medium is way spicier than other places), crab fried rice, pad thai, and red curry. The portions are not terribly large, so we tried tried a lot of different things. The flavors are bold and beautiful. Great homey vibe too.
author: Lauren J.

description: I always brings friends visiting from out of town here. I'm not usually a fan of Thai fusion, but this place does it right. I absolutely love the Hat Yai fried chicken, it's incredibly moist and flavourful. My go-to every time.
author: Heather N.

description:
New favorite Thai restaurant!! I'm not usually a huge fan of Thai - I'll eat it but I never crave it. But this place was so good, and that's saying something for expensive thai food.. 

The 24 hour beef soup is pretty strong, so if you're not a fan of super strong broths and flavors, I'd stay away. It's super flavorful. The pad see yew with pork belly was also deliciousss and the pork belly is perfectly soft and crispy. Just crispy enough to add some texture to the chewy noodles! But by far, the best is the hat yai fried chicken. Seriously, I cannot rave about this chicken enough. What everyone is saying is true - it's so crispy and juicy and tender, and the blue rice + curry are perfect with it. I got the thai iced tea (which I also don't normally like) for dessert which was pretty good! I'm not a thai tea expert, but I really appreciated that they could make it with soy milk (yay for non-dairy options).

I will be CRAVING this thai food now.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Our latest lunch at Farmhouse was rather disappointing, especially considering how fantastic our first experience was. 

THE CONS.
- Incredibly high pricing model
- Overly sweetened dishes
- Rather small portions considering how much you're paying

The main kicker was that both my fiancé and I had some negative reactions in our stomachs from our lunch here. So that added insult to injury. Sadly, we won't be dining here again.
author: Claire S.

description: We got cold food after waiting an hour for a table. We sent it back and they came back still with the same cold food :(
author: Jenny D.

description:
({Vegan Friendly}) 

The food was good, but not out of this world for its price. The decor of the restaurant was nice and the staff were attentive despite being so busy.

Based on my whole experience I felt like this place is a little overrated. I would definitely get a reservation because the wait was one hour long even though we were told 40 minutes. Don't get me wrong I don't mind wait for an hour for really delicious food. 

I ordered samosa  ($9), antofu Panang Curry ($15) with Jasmine rice ($3). 

For $15 the proportion size of the Panang curry was not that big. The flavor was there but I wasn't satisfied. Other thai restaurants I like to go to have huge portions, same flavor, and their plates  are few dollars less.  Samosas were okay, they weren't big. For $9 you get three wonton- size samosas and a curry dipping sauce. Yeah, I wouldn't pay $3 for a mediocre samosas.  Rice was $3, maybe because it was blue??? They have blue Jasmine rice . Didn't do anything for me different taste wise.
author: Maggie M.

description: Hands down the best Thai food in San Francisco, we get delivery and take out regularly and the restaurant is super fun. If you don't like spicy food this might not be the place for you!
author: Cherie C.

description:
Thanks for the note. I just wanted to add that service was practically nonexistent and our waitress never even asked if the food was ok. Only as we were ready to leave did another woman ask if everything was good. At that point we were already done. :(

Terrible. Salmon was so overcooked to the point of being white. Menu claims that the fish is "wild caught" salmon yet I was served an enormous piece of farmed fish that tasted worse than something you would pick up at the Whole Foods hot bar. Chicken wings were nothing special. Ahi cups were nothing special, just spicy. Beef noodle soup was outrageously priced at $23. Prices are astronomical for the lousy quality of food. I was incorrectly misled by the glowing Yelp reviews and would never recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Poker B.

description: We ate short rib panang Curry - super delicious and meat is as soft as it can be. Best food we've eaten in San Francisco and possibly best Thai food.
author: Andrea T.

description: Huge fan! Easy parking right outside in a cute residential neighborhood, spacious interior, great service, robust menu, top-notch Pad Thai (and I am a lover of Pad Thai, so I compare every Pad Thai I try to all the many other Pad Thais I have tried), tasty and unique juices and drinks. AMAZING beef soup - so mouthwatering, and I usually don't like beef soups.
author: Jan Z.

description:
They're spamming me. Someone used my phone number to reserve a table yesterday, apparently? And so the restaurant called last night, and I told them they have the wrong number. 
Now today, I'm on the list and I'm getting texts saying that I'm on a waitlist? What?
author: Phil B.

description: One of the best Thai restaurants in the city. Atmosphere a bit quirky with lady boys and communal tables, but food is authentic. Probably 1 -2 levels less spicy than what I had in Thailand, but very flavorful. The drunken noodles were the best.
author: Pramod G.

description: Loved the fried chicken, yellow curry to dip the small naan triangles, and blue rice! Will have to go back and try their other specialties very soon.  Parking can be challenging but it's well worth it.
author: Doris L.

description: great pad thai and service was excellent.  get here early in the day as I was shocked to see they were almost a full house 20 minutes after they opened. We will return for sure :)
author: Bryan H.

description:
I will probably, from hence forth, refer to this as one of the great Yelp-affirming experiences of my life. It's no secret that I'm a fan of the site. I live it, I breathe it, I say the word every day, and I preach it from the tops of the mountains. But sometimes when you're so far into the trees, you have a hard time seeing the forest. It's experiences like this one that help me remember that big, beautiful forest that is Yelp, and how it's completely changed my life for the better. 

Enter Farmhouse Kitchen. It was a Wednesday night and I had some free time. I had a lot of work to do, and found myself taking too long at the hotel doing it, panicking, and abruptly grabbing my phone and wallet from the hotel to rush to the party supply store. I took a Lyft (thanks!), arrived in enough time to get what I needed, but by the time I could catch a breath I found myself back out on the curb, in a strange part of town, in the dark, hungry and ready for dinner.

Ten years ago, I wouldn't have really known what to do. Go back to the hotel? Ask the guy at the party store? Sometimes I wonder what we did... did we just wander? There's a certain adventure and sense of discovery that comes from that and I've found some gems that way, but instinctively I reached for the Yelp app and punched up nearby locations. With a few quick swipes and taps, I locked in Farmhouse. With another tap and rotate, I mapped the walk. And just like that, I was headed to a highly rated Thai spot. 

This review isn't all about Yelp, however, so let's get down to the restaurant itself. When I was a block away I got that tingle. You know the one, don't you, my fellow food lover? The one that starts with the faint scent of coconut milk, lemongrass, and fish sauce. Then it intensifies when stoked by the chatter and laughter that only a full restaurant house can produce. Then the tingling reaches maximum strength when windows reveal rows of happy diners, determined servers, lights reflecting off of clanking silverware and half-drunk wine glasses glistening under the warm yellow lights of a well-appointed interior.

Yes, the bar will be just fine. I passed the communal seating and plopped down. The tingling had become a warm, low burn when I checked the menu to find that sai ua (aka Chiang Mai sausage) was available, and they presented an adorable little card marking Khao Soi as the day's special. These are my two favorite Thai dishes of all time, and I rarely find one of them, let alone both, in the same place. Again, I checked Yelp to see what people were ordering. Hat Yai was the clear consensus and when the server approached I closed my eyes and half-ordered, half-wished that they would all be as good as I hoped and as other Yelpers described them. Two entrees and an appetizer. I regret nothing.

By the time the sausage arrived I was drunk on the smells and kind service. The couple next to me was feeding each other, going on with each other and the staff in Thai. I tried the first piece of sai ua and the rest is a blur. I ate it. Fast. Then the khao soi. Perfectly pickles greens, crispy noodles (not everyone gives you this many to mix in, but the textural element it adds is invaluable) and thin noodles. I had the first piece of chicken and was almost disappointed it didn't have bones. But sure enough, the second bite did--as did most bites--and that deep, rich flavor from bone-in chicken filled me up. Then the Hat Yai. The blue rice. The curry dipping sauce. Whatever magical vinegar honey sauce that was served with. I ate nearly everything and only stopped because I promised a friend a few tastes.

It was a Yelp-affirming night. In no other world would I have confidently walked right to an incredible Thai place like Farmhouse. I wouldn't have found it otherwise. The personable servers made me feel at home as a solo diner. It felt like that restaurant, in this city, at that bar, eating those dishes was exactly the place I should be that night. No where else would have done.

These people understand flavors. Maybe you won't have the same experience. That's ok. It's subjective, after all, and I don't want to leave the hype that this is a magical place that transports you to an alternate food universe. It's food, after all. But it was MY magical place. Go find yours. I know just the app.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Found Farmhouse Kitchen from other Yelpers recommendation, so i decided to give it try. From my experience of having actual legitimate Thai food in Thailand, this place is authentic in both taste and favor. 

We ordered the Hat Yai fried chicken and Green Curry. Both dishes were amazingly flavorful and delicious. The green curry is the perfect amount of spiciness as it suppose to be for spicy food lovers. The Hat Yai fried chicken was amazing in its own category of deliciousness with sweet curry and naan combined with the fried chickens. The portion are huge and very worth sharing with friends and family by doing a family style among one another.

Overall, definitely check this place out and you'll never regret it! ;)
author: Steven C.

description: Good food but the experience was marred by watching the staff -- none of them were smiling or really looked like they wanted to be there.
author: M T.

description: Booked a table 1 week in advance. Got there at 8:15 still didn't have a table ready. Went again last week, still didn't have my table ready for a reservation made five days in advance. Their restaurant management sucks, food might be good but try not to eat, there do a take out
author: Kartikeya Mohan S.

description:
Love this place.
