Wait is never too long and always worth it.
Typically order a whole lot of stuff - have yet to be disappointed.
author: Charles M.

description:
Went here for my birthday dinner! 
Food, definitely was amongst the best Thai I've ever had.
 
Starters- We ordered the samosas which came with a curry- the pastry was flaky and the filling was just the right quantity and the curry was nice as well. 

In the main course we ordered the (guess what) hat yai fried chicken which was the undisputed winner on the table. The chicken was well cooked, the curry was coconutty in a good way and was the best thing on the plate. The roti was soft and flaky and the chutney paired perfectly with the chicken. Next was the pad char shrimps which again were very flavorful served with mint chutney and blue rice. We asked for medium spicy and the dish delivered on the spiciness, something that you don't find at other places. Overall it was infused with flavors which were beautifully balanced. 
Drinks- Not a fan. Ordered the limeade house soda, which was too much ice and very little soda. My husband ordered Thai iced coffee which came in a small cup and was too less a quantity. We didn't find any cocktail to be appealing so settled with our non alcoholic drinks. 
Ambiance - Nice chilled out place, loved the colorful clothes on the servers. The place was a tad bit small for the number of tables they have, making it quiet noisy, so no real personal space. 
Service- The service was quick but both of us didn't quiet appreciate the servers attitude. That's what led to the four stars.
author: Isha R.

description: Super fun Thai restaurant! Immediately you're greeted to the hostess who's wearing traditional Thai clothing. They paid a lot of attention to the interior design of the restaurant! Since I was a first timer, I asked the waiter what their most popular dish was and he highly recommended me their Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($21). So we ordered that and had to order the Thai street food classic Pad Thai ($16). Hat Yai Fried Chicken was delicious! Very crispy flat fried chicken with yellow curry, roti and blue (!!) sticky rice. The Pad Thai was decent - a bit too sweet for my taste (ketchup?). Overall, it was a fun and exciting experience. I was seated immediately at the bar on a Sunday night at 7pm but there were lots of people waiting for a table. My final thoughts are great food, perfect date night place but a bit pricey.
author: Katie Y.

description:
Definitely a fun place to check out while in the Bay area. Our group was on a trip there and we had a birthday girl so despite of the location (quite far from downtown), we came here for a birthday dinner. I would suggest making a reservation if you have a large group cause it gets pretty crowded. 

Okay first impression, the vibe of this place screams "overpriced hippie joint" (plot twist: it's not). The staff dressed in tropical clothing with flower necklace and crown(?). Around the tables were vintage decoration such as old fashioned sewing machine, old food cans, and old toys. As we were navigating through the big as* menu with Thai titles and English description, a waitress kept coming back and forth every 20 seconds to ask if we're ready to order, which was kinda annoying. She also seemed uninterested and impatient when my friends had some questions about the menu. 

Anyway, setting that aside, we ordered some appetizers, Neua Num Tok (steak roll with cucumber), Yum Moo Krob (house grilled pork belly salad) and a Tom Yum pot for sharing. The steak roll was high quality and the pork belly salad was really well seasoned. Tom Yum was just okay, not the best I've tried. We each ordered a special set ourselves so we got to try as many dishes as possible lol. I had the Crab Fried Rice my self and it was perfect. The fried rice smelled really good and there was a lot of crabmeat as well. It also came with a bowl of light and hearty veggie soup and some dipping sauce. A lot of people came here for the Hat Yai Chicken so we tried it as well. I wasn't impressed with the fried chicken itself (c'mon, it was chicken breast) but the yellow potato curry including in the set was on fire! I'm normally not a fan of curry at all but it was so good you feel like there's an explosion of flavors in your mouth. I would also recommend the Panang Neua, which is braised short rib and veggies in panang curry (but more like panang flavored soup). It's definitely not a typical Thai dish you can get anywhere. I would not recommend the Mok Salmon (too dry) and Kai Yang, Som Tum (nothing special) tho. 

If you have a birthday person in your group, you can order the Dessert Platter and when they bring it out for you the whole staff will play gong (yes, the metal round thingy) and sing for him/her. I think it's a nice service of them. But if it's not the celebration then never mind cause it was basically some scoops of ice cream, watermelon and some irrelevant sweets. 

Overall, the price is more pricey than an average Thai place but you totally get what you paid for. The food is unique and delicious and you will have a fun time as well.
author: Hannah V.

description:
I don't know what's happened to Farmhouse Thai but it's not what it used to be. When it first opened, both the food and service was outstanding. My last two visits before visiting tonight were mediocre with servers who didn't seem to care at all, and food that wasn't prepared with the same quality as when the restaurant first opened. 

Tonight I ordered take out and the experience was terrible. There was a huge line of around 20 people trying to get attention at the front desk but it was taking forever for the server to process each person. To make matters worse, each person in the line had to fill out a form on an iPad which took a long time. I waited around 10 minutes in this line for the chance to pick up my pre-paid take out order. 

When I finally got to the front of the line to get a chance to pick up my food, I found that it had been stored on the floor. I find this to be disgusting and shows lack of respect for the food and the guests. Who puts food on the floor? 

It's also a violation of Part 7 of the CA Health and Safety code (CALIFORNIA RETAIL FOOD CODE) which specifies that all food must be stored at least 6 inches above the floor to prevent contamination by splashes, dust, vermin, or other forms of contamination (Article 5 114047 (b). 

Nevermind that it's a health code violation to put food on the floor. I think basic common sense thinking about hygiene should cause a reasonable person to put dinner on a table, not the floor in the middle of a high traffic commercial environment. I didn't have the energy to complain about this because I'd just landed from a cross country flight and 12 hour journey and after driving across town to pick up this food that I'd been so looking forward to, I didn't have energy to argue, so I took it home, then threw most of it away.

Interesting to note they had a DPH inspection just last month and got hit with multiple food safety violations and got a food safety score of 83/100 which is not great. As I suspected, the attitude that would allow employees to put dinner on the floor is not isolated but seems to be consistent with an overall culture that disregards commonsense principles of food safety. And this seems consistent with my observation that things have changed a lot since it first opened.
author: Eater S.
Miko B.

description:
Wow! Authentic Thai food flavors.

You step into Thailand, enjoy the Thai experience & flavorful food as you step into the farmhouse kitchen.
author: Binita P.

description: Service was great, I must say this is one of the best Thai food I tried. Must tried there beef noodle soup
author: Tom T.

description: My cousin recommended this place and it did not disappoint. Had their samosas, which were not like the usual crispy samosas i'm used to. Rather, these samosas were buttery and flaky such as you would find on a pot pie. All in all i would go again to eat their samosas and chicken wings from the appetizer menu & hat thai fried chicken dinner (which is so filling and comes with roti, yummy delicious slurp-worthy curry, blue rice, and fried chicken), and to celebrate my bday (the staff sings to you and you get to wear what looks like a Thai farmer's hat). I highly recommend if you have a hankering for some Asian comfort food.
author: P C.

description: Thank you to all those Farmhouse Thai staff who took the effort of singing Happy Birthday for my sister. It made our day so special. You were also kind enough to allow us to take us pictures of you while you did your lovely birthday song performance. There are lots of places in the Bay Area which serve good Thai Food but when it comes to hospitality - Farmhouse Thai crossed all boundaries.
author: Shruti B.

description:
I liked the taste of the food.  The service was a bit inattentive but I got what I needed once I waved someone down.

Hat Yai Fried Chicken
This was my favorite dish because of the yellow curry.  I was dipping everything in it and could have just drank it.  The fried chicken was crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  By itself, it was lacking flavor but after dipping it in honey and then the curry, it was delicious.  Make sure you get this dish if you go here. 

Panang Neua
The short rib is fall off the bone but the Panang sauce was too salty for my taste.  I thought the meat was flavored enough to where I didn't need the sauce.

Neua Num Tok Rolls
This was a very nice appetizer.  I highly recommend it.

Pad Kee Mow
This was good too but we had too much food so we didn't eat it all.

The only disappointment of the dinner was the dessert platter.  For $27 I expected some interesting Thai desserts.  Instead there was one Thai dessert, big slice of watermelon, and the rest was American stuff.  The American desserts were too sweet (like stuff you find at Safeway).  The watermelon wasn't ripe enough, plus I don't think I should get simple fruit for that cost.  At least give me nice berries.

I will definitely go back but will skip the dessert.
author: Lily L.

description:
A friend recommended this restaurant & it's been on my bookmarks for awhile so we decided to come for dinner! We made a reservation for 3 and got there about 5 minutes late, but was seated right away!

We ordered the Hat Yai Chicken (per yelp reviews), Papaya Salad, Tom Yum Noodle Soup Lunch, and the Kickboxing Bowl to split!

My favorite would definitely be the Hat Yai Chicken. The fried chicken was juicy and the blue rice added a nice punch of color. Papaya salad was good, a bit spicy but tasty, and finally, the Tom yum noodle soup was HELLLLLA spicy. I have a pretty good spice tolerance, but this was kind of crazy. I tried to take a small sip of the soup just for the taste, and ended up choking because it was THAT spicy - BEWARE. 

The kickboxing bowl was delicious! We didn't really taste much alcohol in there.. but it was really good... with really really really long straws... not sure why they have it that long LOL

Overall, I'd like to come back and try other dishes, but not anytime soon. The food was good, but service was terrible. We asked for water 3 times with 2 different waiters before we got a small cup.
author: Carrie L.

description: Farmhouse is just amazing all around! It's kind of under the radar for SF, yet it's always full with locals. Food is amazing! I've been twice now and everything is incredible- favorites are crab fried rice, green curry, all noodle dishes. Service is super fast and efficient. Decor and ambiance are really fun!
author: Sarah H.

description: The food is really good but be warned that the vibe and the interior isn't your typical Thai restaurant! It sometimes feels like a club on weekend nights which is good if I'm filling up my stomach before going out but isn't where I would eat if I were just looking for a quiet / chill place to enjoy food.  I live a block away and almost end up doing takeout for this reason and even with takeout the food is still delicious!
author: Hyan P.

description: The best vegetarian friendly Thai food place in San Francisco. Their panang curry is amazing and so is the rest of the menu. Highly recommend trying out this place if you are in the mood of getting Thai food in the city. Be careful, other people know it as well. It gets busy quickly.
author: Darshil V.

description: Great food and great service! My wife took me here for Fathers Day & I am so glad she did! We had the Hat Yai, Panang Neua, Pad Thai, Rice salad & I had the Shaved ice Thai Tea. The flavors were just awesome. Better to experience it yourself than read my take on these delicious dishes. I can honestly say this is one of my top restaurants in the city. I can't wait to go back and try other things and of course get the Hat Yai again!
author: Rad V.

description: Our lunch here was a-okay but none of us were overly thrilled with the meal or experience... Traditional food & fusion with SF price tag!
author: Coco J.

description:
While in the area, my friend and I stumbled upon this place around 8PM on a Friday.

The place was packed at this time but we managed to snag a seat at the bar upon entering (SCOREEEE). Our very adorable host guided us to the bar seats and we were ready to order.

I ordered the Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($19.50)

The order came out fairly fast and I was surprised about the portion. The fried chicken had a thin layer of crispiness and the chicken meat was extremely juicy. The curry sauce you dip the chicken in was extremely flavorful. It also came on a bed of fried shredded sweet potatoes and  slices of roti to dip into the curry. 

Even though I stopped by this place to just eat, I would highly recommend this place if you plan on having a fun birthday dinner or just have a fun dinner close to the mission.
author: Anna H.

description: Good food, good atmosphere, very busy place and the parking sucks. Crab fried rice is delicious!!
author: Nicole V.

description:
Love this lively spot! Farmhouse is bright in every way--from their decor to their menu, everything was vibrant and delicious. 

I tried this spot with a group of ten and they were great about accommodating a larger group. We got started with the vegan fresh rolls (love the peanut sauce!) and the ahi scoops (yasssss!!). For my main meal, I grabbed my Thai go-tos: a huge papaya salad (medium spicy) and a Tom Kha with prawns. All I gotta say: SO GOOD! Both dishes were perfectly spiced and crazy delicious. I wish I could have this delivered in Denver! 

Make sure to make a reservation, as this place is popular (with good reason!). Prices are a little on the high side, but totally worth it. Try this spot!
author: Megan R.

description: First time trying this place and it was amazing. I came here for a dinner gathering with my family. The atmosphere was great and the servers were kind and sweet. We ordered the Thai chicken wings for our appetizers. As for our entrees, we ordered the Hat Yai Fried Chicken which was amazingly fried and tasty, Panang Neua short ribs which was tasty and tender, Chicken Pad Thai, and lastly the Tom Kha soup. Overall a wonderful experience and restaurant that I will absolutely visit again.
author: Maggie L.

description:
First time here and I am so amazed by the creative and delicious entrees!  I have to commend them as the presentation is on point.  I usually like to fall in love with my food before I devour it. 

Started off with the Wagyu Flank Steak appetizer rolls and every bite was amazing!  The steak was juicy, tender & paired well with the mint, cilantro, cucumber & dressing.  Everyone on Yelp raved about the Hat Yai Fried Chicken- Mary's Organic Chicken Breast with roti bread, yellow curry & rice.   They were not wrong.  It was an incredible fusion of flavor to dip the chicken in the curry.  That curry...YUMM!  However, the Panang Neua- slow braised bone in Short Rib in a Panang Curry stole the show for me...  *Sigh*  I'm still dreaming about how that tasty succulent meat falls off the bone and into my mouth.  

The service was great and the atmosphere was very lively and festive.  Will I be back?  It's not a matter of "If" but "When..." =)
author: Melanie N.

description:
Let's start off by saying this place is awesome! 

We made a reservation for lunch on a Saturday and got there a little after they opened (also our reservation time) and I was a little surprised to see that only a few people were there. I half expected there to be a line and a wait before they opened. However, soon after we got seated (may be 15 mins in) we saw that all of the tables got filled and there were a few parties waiting. I guess if you don't plan on coming right when they open and don't want to wait, a reservation would probably not be a bad idea.

On to the food...

Hat Yai Fried Chicken - this was really REALLY good. This pretty much blew me away. The yellow curry was just the right amount of sweet The fried chicken was crispy and juicy.  The blue rice just tied everything together. It was visually beautiful and appetizing and it tasted delicious. Definitely recommends this to everyone to try at least once. 

Beef Penang curry - this was yummy too! The flavor was great but on the spicier side (I'm not great with spicy food). My bf loved it tho.

Thai Iced Coffee - the cup is small and there is a lot of ice. My bf was sleepy so he ordered this but he didn't get any less sleepy after drinking it. I would may be go for their Thai ice tea next time...

The price is on the higher side but for the quality and atmosphere, it's worth it in my eyes.

10/10 would come here again.
author: Renee W.

description:
Totally love this place! My boyfriend and I came in on a Saturday at about 1pm. We were seated right away. We ordered the tom yum noodles and garlic chicken with sticky rice on the side and Thai tea. We got the bread pudding for dessert. IT WAS ALL DELICIOUS!!!! 

The one bad thing was I had to remind the waiter about my thai tea. 

There were other things on the menu I wanted to try but me and my BF couldn't have eaten it all. 

I can't wait to go back!!!!
author: Aileen V.

description: Super food, nice service.  They did a great job with a big group.  The only problem was parking: most of the parking places around the restaurant were blocked off for some reason, so we had a hike.  With any luck that's a temporary problem.
author: Libby W.

description: Nice presentation, ambience and friendly staff. You have to make a reservation prior. We went on New Years Day and we had a reservation at 1:15pm. Took less than 5 mins to wait for our table. Ordered the kogi beef and green curry noodles. Both were very delicious. Good size. Got Thai iced tea was well and it was good until I saw there was hair on the drink. They comped is the Thai tea. Overall, if that didn't happen I would've rated this place a 5. Witnessed a birthday and they sing to the celebrant and give em a lei with money and hat!  Would definitely come back here again to try their other food!
author: Roxanne A.

description: Good food, great presentation, awesome ambiance and excellent service. The fried chicken was a little bland but everything else was great. Beware of the small portions. Definitely would go back.
author: Tyler N.

description: was a bit overpriced in my opinion, my friends and i eat alot we usually order an additional 1 or 2 dishes and i've gotta say the portions were small and parking sucks.
author: Nancy W.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMMM. Delicious and affordable Thai food, presented bountifully and beautifully in a spacious, modern, industrial space in the Mission area. RESERVATIONS RECOMMENDED.
Think it came out to $45 per person for 2 of us after tax and tip with a beer each and we were STUUFFFFFFFED.
The service is extremely active, fast, and friendly. You can tell they definitely work as a well-oiled machine.
This area is still up and coming.. there are some nice restaurants scattered here, but you'll likely pass by some homeless encampments as well. Oh, SF.

I walked in on a Friday evening at 5:30 and one of the hostesses told the lady in front of me (that was trying to get a walk-in) that they were already pretty booked for the night and couldn't seat her early until her whole party was there. ZANG YO. I didn't expect a wait at this place, so early in the night, away form the hustle and bustle of the main strip of Mission... so I already knew I was in for some good food.

Based on the Yelp reviews, we opted for:

NEUA NUM TOK ROLLS - 5 STARS. The only thing that could make this better is if they portioned it out smalller. The piece of meat was a bit too big and I would have savored it more if it came in a smaller bite, maybe halved. But it was SO TENDER AND DELICIOUS and went perfectly went the fresh cucumber and mint. Comes with 4 'rolls' and is a pretty big appetizer for 2 people. Perfect for 4 though.

HERBAL RICE SALAD - 4 STARS. People said that if you like the tea leaf salad, you'd probably like this.. well, the flavor isn't really the same but you'd probably like this if you like coconut and peanuts! I like coconut and peanuts, soo.. yeah. 

HAI YAT CHICKEN - 4.5 STARS. YUMM. Two thin pieces of juicy fried chicken served with roti, rice and curry. The only thing that would make this better is MORE POTATOES IN THE CURRY (but I'm a potato fiend and I'm really asking for too much - haha). The presentation is awesome with the knife thru the roti and the chicken, along with the blue rice. I think they just dye the rice blue as it doesn't taste any different.


Would love to return as a group to try more things as well as the big alcoholic drink in a bowl!! AGAIN - make reservations, definitely come and try this place!
author: Emily C.

description:
Mediocre food, nothing special. My neighborhood Thai restaurant is much better. I really don't understand what the hype is about.

And the service? Oh my god - the waitress almost smashed the plates at the table. No smile, no nothing. Terrible!

Go spend your money elsewhere and enjoy!
author: Sharon P.

description: I like this place, but it is a little on the sweet Thai side rather than spicy.
author: Jill H.

description: Quality and unique flavors with good presentation. Solid service. It's in our lunch rotation with our department. They're able to accommodate our group, usually 6-12 of us, with no problem as long as we get there early. Some of my favorites: tom yum, pad thai, green curry and papaya salad.
author: D C.

description: This Thai street food restaurant impressed me in many ways! Food is extremely yummy and unconventional, and the environment is fun and interesting.
author: Yawen H.

description: Papaya salad! Drool! Very friendly staff and the food is amazing! Just stop by and enjoy and you will see. Cheers!
author: Punkster S.

description: This is definitely the best Thai place in the city! That Hat Yai fried chicken is amazing and the steak rolls. Don't leave without getting the bread pudding dessert.
author: William D.

description:
Hot Thai this place was such an amazing find!! Forget your regular pad thai, tom kha soup and curry choices. This place offers so much more that you normally don't see at other Thai restaurants. 

For appetizers, the beef rolls-- so tender and juicy. Don't forget to dress it with the "green" sauce it's sitting in. 

Entree- the Hat yai chicken--delicious, crunchy with a honey based dipping sauce. 
Green curry- plentiful but for some reason it wasn't resonating that great with me. You can expect the unexpected in this curry dish. They put things in there that aren't normally added by other normal thai dishes. But that's not a bad thing! 

My favorite drink from the place was the Ginger Milk tea. Came out warm and delicious and comforting as hell!! 

The space and people bring me right back to Thailand, the land of smiles.  

During Loy Krathong (in November) they have specials dishes, prizes and street food. Would highly recommend coming during this time.
author: Sarah N.

description:
Delicious food, fun restaurant, so-so service.

Another trendy restaurant in SF (surprise, surprise). The restaurant is pretty cool that it re-purposed an old school and add some fun, modern decorations inside. Beware that the food is pricier than your average thai restaurant... I almost had a heart attack when I saw that one of their pad thai's was $22.50. $22.50!! double the price of any ol pad thai...

Anywho, my number one tip is to MAKE RESERVATIONS! There's a nonstop line of people waiting to get seated. And because of this, we felt like we were rushed to get through our dinner by our server. The menu is pretty extensive and it was a little annoying the server kept asking us if we're ready to order. We wondered if there were choices of spiciness level, because the server for sure did not ask us... we joked she disliked us and just chose the spiciest setting for the mango salad (described below). 

And onto the food... we ended up ordering the mango salad, fried chicken with yellow curry, extra roti, and pad thai. Yes, we are super whitewashed... the mango salad was spicy HOT! Just one bite and you can feel the burn. It was still good and flavorful though.
Fried chicken was amazing, juicy and paired well w/ the curry. Roti was a little greasy, but also went well w/ the curry dip.
pad thai was also solid. Pork was dry though.

We were full, but not bloated.. just ordered the right amount food. Amongst the 3 of us, it was only $20, which is amazing for SF. Woohoo!
author: Janet H.

description:
Aw man, I'm torn. This place is between a 3 star and 4 star for me. But overall I felt that the flavor profile and price point weighed it down to a 3 star. We ordered the boat noodle special, which was $20 for a not-so-big portion and a salad for like $14. I don't know how some reviewers spent $20 for a meal and a beer per person :( What did you order?! The table next to us spent $75 between two girls with no drinks and they were kind of surprised too. Overall, I felt underwhelmed especially because the boat noodle special wasn't flavored boldly. Instead, it was a nice hot soup that didn't warrant 5 stars. 

The atmosphere was excellent, as was the service. Maybe I'll be back again to try more of the foods, but I'm not so enthusiastic about it.
author: Maggie G.

description:
First time coming here didn't recognize the restaurant is so popular, all table already full. Only bar table left. So remember to make reservation in advance. 

We order three dishes:
1. Neua Num Tok Rolls (beef Rolls with cucumber and mint) : at first I was surprised that $15.5 only 4 small Rolls .. but after tasting it, I know why it's expensive. The quality of the beef is good, and it is tendon and juicy.  

2. Hat yai fried (organic) chicken: actually I am not a fan of fried chicken breast because it's always dry. But this one, its soft and moist inside. Taste really good! 

3. 24 hrs beef noodle soup: I like the homemade beef broth and the 24 hrs braised short rib is amazing. Can't stop eating it after the first bite.
author: Elsie L.

description: This place is SO fricken good I should be ashamed of myself for not trying it out earlier. I'm a simple gal with simple taste so I just got their yellow curry/fried chicken entree. GUYS. Their food is on another level. I've had thai food all over the states and Farmhouse comes in at the top 1%. Tbh drooling just thinking about their curry and roti right now.
author: Miss M.

description: Food is so authentic and delicious!!! My favorite is the sticky rice and papaya entree
author: Nikki T.

description: The food was delicious. It's definitely one of those places that keeps you coming back for more. Had a chance to try the silkworm and it was pretty awesome. If you hadn't called previously for reservations, it's highly recommended. But bar seating is open,and usually no wait.
author: Amber L.

description:
This place is a bit of a gimmick. Gentrified thai food at its finest. Food came out warm. Waiters are dressed ridiculously and there's terrible disco lights all over the place.

Focus on the food and not on the atmosphere
author: Penelope C.

description:
My favorite place to eat that's all organic and with gluten free options.
Great presentations and delicious food.
author: Pedram H.

description:
This is the most hipster Thai restaurant I've ever seen.  In this city, usually, the combination of hipster + anything equates to overinflated prices and mediocre food.  Farmhouse Kitchen Thai is a rare exception.  Ridiculously hipster yet still authentically delicious.  Yes, it is a bit on the expensive side but the quality is worth the somewhat inflated prices.

AMBIANCE & SERVICE
Weird.  A wall of a hundred faucet taps (which I assume are useless) all lined up.  Unattached faucet taps just lying around.  A strange iPad to greet you with what looks like a fake music video that was filmed at the restaurant playing on repeat. Somewhat cool is that they periodically come around with traditional carts with "specialties" almost dim sum style.  Total throw back to being in Thailand and an extremely smart marketing ploy.  Who could say no to $3 fried grasshoppers that you know someone at your table will just HAVE to try?

Service, once seated, was excellent.  However, they were super behind on seating reservations.  We made a reservation for 7 PM and we weren't seated until 7:30 PM.  We saw other tables being seated before us and asked why and they said it was because they had a 6:45 PM reservation.  However, to apologize for making us wait, they did comp us an appetizer of delicious spring rolls.

FOOD
We ordered the Hai Yat Fried Chicken (duh!), Green Curry Noodles, Crab Fried Rice, and Drunken Noodles with Crispy Pork Belly.  Each dish was exquisitely presented, colorful, well-balanced, and generously portioned. The rice is even blue!  I thought this was a gimmick...but apparently it's a real thing!  It's dyed with a special blue flower.  

The standout, not surprisingly, was the Hai Yat Fried Chicken.  Love the roti and the curry that the chicken is served with.  In fact, we ordered an extra bowl of rice and kept refusing them to take the dish away because we wanted to slurp up and sop up every last bit of the yellow curry it is served with.  Definitely a must-order! 

The green curry noodles were also really flavorful, but definitely much more on the spicier end.  Plentiful with curry and lots of garnishes (bean sprouts, cucumbers, basil leaves, pickled vegetables, other unnameable herbs, etc.) but a little light on the amount of noodles given.  The crispy pork belly in the drunken noodles was also great!  But, what's not to love about drunken noodles?

Each dish is around $20 so this is definitely not somewhere I could eat on the regular but it's a nice treat!  And, I will definitely be back!
author: Jess Y.

description:
This is quite possibly the best Thai restaurant I've been to. I am not saying it's the best Thai food cause it might not be, but I loved everything we ordered.
Surprisingly there wasn't any waiting to get seated. Staff was dressed in some colourful shirts which looked more Hawaiian than Thai, but I've never been to either places so I'm probably wrong. Service is fast and friendly: they're always there when you need something and don't bug you every few minutes.
I ordered the special which was some sort of curry noodles with chicken. There was A LOT of chicken in that dish. The meal wasn't too spicy(I probably wish it was). We also got green curry with sticky rice. The rice came in a cute wicker sort of bowl. 
For appetizers we got some beef wraps. I can't even express how soft and tasty the beef was! 
It probably shouldn't matter much but the food was made to look appealing. Wasn't just something done quickly to fill you up.
With that being said this is one of the first places I'd visit once I go back to SF.
author: Stanimir C.

description: This is hands down my favorite Thai place I've been. My first time I went here I came with friends in the afternoon after an event the evening before. For appetizer we had the calamari and it was so good. The breading was crispy and the cilantro lime sauce it was paired with was delicious. I had the Pad Char shrimps for my main course and let me tell you, it was delicious. I craved that dish ever since then. Just yesterday I finally had a chance to go back and get dinner. I live a little less than 2 hours away but it was well worth the return. Grabbed chicken wings for the appetizer they were spot on. The chili plum sauce was good. I got the Neu Yang Steak and it was excellent. Cooked to perfection and the green beans that came with it were seasoned and cooked perfectly. Well worth the hour wait we had. I definitely will return whenever I have time.
author: Marlena M.

description: Absolutely loved the vibe of this place.  From the bright colors to the colorful waiters and waitresses, this was a blast of a restaurant.  I ordered the crab fried rice (north of $20) and while it was tasty, it seemed a little plain to me for the price tag (it did come with 3 side sauces, but I wish the flavor had been incorporated into the rice).  My friend and I shared a dessert and I absolutely can't remember the name, but it was served in a coconut with vanilla ice cream on top.  Delicious, but hard to eat-probably recommend keeping this desert to yourself ;)
author: Sophia B.

description:
HIGHLY RECOMMEND. This place is the perfect combination of tradition and modern in terms of food, service, and decor. 

Service was AMAZING. Fun and energetic group of people, especially for birthdays (drums, big hats, singing)!  They also walk around selling cooked up bugs with the traditional baskets - So cute and different. My water cup never went empty. Dishes were picked up quickly (we ordered ALOT of diff dishes). Their cleanliness is on point. Servers wear gloves when picking up, kitchen staff masks and hairnets in the back.  

Food was so delicious! Something I had not never heard of before and really enjoyed was the herbal rice salad. But really.. Everything we tried was yummy. 

Just be careful because some of the foods are very spicy!!! 

ALSO MAKE RESERVATIONS ON THE WEEKEND. We waited 1.5 hours on a Sunday. It was worth it though.
author: Ashley N.

description: We tried this place three times. On two occasions we were unimpressed. On the third occasion, it was okay. They dishes are too spicy and lack a certain substances we find in other Thai restaurants. Also, the wait staff can be surly and rude as often as they are nice.
author: Harry P.

description:
This is a going to be a very mixed review.  First the good stuff.  The food was excellent. The highlight for me was the Hat Yai Fried Chicken.  It was super juicy. Surprisingly the grasshopper was very good as well.  It reminded me of deep fried shrimp.

Where Farmhouse went downhill was the service. First, they cancelled my reservation a couple hours before the time which I wasn't aware of so when we got there there was confusion checking in. We were going for a family birthday celebration and there were 2 kids. We mentioned up front that the kids could not handle spicy food but many of the items recommended ended up being very spicy. We were annoyed that the waiter recommended yellow curry without telling us that the fried chicken included the very same yellow curry we just ordered when it was clear we were trying to sample different things off the menu.  Also, it was very busy but they kept trying to clear our plates while there was still food on it and we were still eating. This happened at least 4 times.

Overall, the food was a 4, but the service was a 2 - thus the 3 rating.
author: Chris T.

description: I strongly recommend to try this place. It was an unique and exciting experience. The food was fantastic. You should definitely save space for coconut dessert. I enjoyed it a lot.
author: Eva Y.

description:
Just didn't think the food was particularly flavorful or well prepared. Give me Lers Ros any day! We had fish cakes, they were lacking in flavor. Also had Tom Kha soup. Full of veggies but unfortunately that included huge chunks of hard green tomatoes....flavor was ok on the soup base. Our main of Mok Salmon gave us a nice big piece of fish, plenty for two to share. A bit overcooked but not too bad. 

Next time we're in the hood for a show at Z Space we'll give Tartine Manufactory a try.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I was nervous about coming here after seeing so many reviews mention the lack of vegan/vegetarian options; what assuaged my fears, though, was the business owner responses saying they were more than willing to make substitutions in order to accommodate dietary needs. So:
1) Kudos to them for doing that!; it feels like more and more restaurants are refusing to swap out ingredients for whatever reasons (it's too much work, they "know best" how the dish should taste, etc). Bend don't break, chefs, because we're all paying attention.
2) Proof to business owners that responding to reviews makes a HUGE difference to your potential customer base!

I came with a large group and there seemed to be some hiccups regarding initial service (I think, for example, we were supposed to have those individual coconut drinks waiting for all of us, but that never played out), but it mostly smoothed out over the course of the evening.

I shared a bottle of wine because the cocktails all seemed to have beer; I was really expecting there to be a bigger, more interesting drink list. Folks I was dining with got the Kick Boxing Bowl (brut, rice wine, passion fruit, lychee, and chili salt), and I was immediately jealous. Expensive, but worth it from the looks of it/them towards the end of it! 

The food, for me at least, was much more awesome than I was expecting. The Vegan Fresh Rolls (with tofu, mixed greens, bean sprouts, and a chili peanut sauce) were delicious. The rice paper roll was thicker, stickier, and gooier (for lack of a better word) then any other fresh roll I've had, but that made them interesting and different. If you're coming here with friends who aren't plant-based eaters, I'd suggest getting an order just for yourself! For my main I had the Yellow Curry with Tofu (sans fish sauce). It was very, very tasty. There are times when I'm glad I don't have to share with my omnivore friends, and this was one of them. The bowl of food contained a hearty portion of potato, tofu, and sauce with several wedges of perfectly made roti bread. I also got a side of sticky rice to ladle it on top of (pro tip, right there). Ate until I was beyond full, and don't regret it (reason number #433 why I wear yoga pants all the time: their stretchiness).

The atmosphere is colorful, vibrant, and definitely different from anything in Maine. And, yes, the bathrooms are the size of studio apartments and worth checking out!
author: Steff D.

description: Came here with my girlfriend on a Friday night and we shared the fried chicken with yellow curry, pad see ew, and the pork belly salad (yum moo krob). First off the food was great and I think the yum moo krob and the pad see ew (medium spicy is spicy if you can't handle heat well) were our favorite of the three. The fried chicken was great too but I wish I would have gotten the bbq chicken and papaya salad. The staff was really friendly and they fill the ambiance of the room with high energy and happiness. They move and dance and take rounds around the restaurant singing happy birthday with symbols and a loud speaker in very colorful clothing. Very unique experience and a great place to go for a birthday party or celebration. Definitely will be coming back and trying out the rest of the menu. Thank you for a great experience.
author: Jo M.

description: You want Authentic Thai food? Come here! The food was excellent. We never had tried a place like this and it surpassed our expectations. The prices were a little high but you get what you pay for. The quality of the food was outstanding.
author: Liz Y.

description:
Came here for a joint bday party. I was told that the owners of the restaurant also own Kitchen Story but Farmhouse Kitchen was more Thai VS Kitchen Story being more fusion.

The restaurant is located in a pretty secluded area in the mission. It was mostly warehouses when we drove by at night. It's pretty easy to spot since majority of the area is pretty dead at night, we saw a bunch of people outside and figured that was the spot. Parking is pretty limited, but we managed to snag a spot across the street as someone was leaving.

The vibe is definitely more Asian than Kitchen Story and so was the menu. We ordered a bunch of appetizers, drinks, and everyone had an entre to themselves. For a party of 7 the bill came about to $450 after tip. They included a 20% gratuity for parties larger than 6. 

The food wasn't bad, but not the greatest Thai food I've ever had. For the price it's a bit high for what I'm used to, but it's SF and it is a popular spot so I get it. 

Most likely won't be back unless it's with a group of friends... but all and all not a bad spot.
author: Milton F.

description:
We had the pad thai and panag chicken! Yum! It was amazing! If you come to SF come here! It is amazing! Thank you! 

Next time I hope to try their Tom Kha soup!
author: Adrienne D.

description:
By far some of the best Thai food I've had outside of Thailand. The service is always above and beyond what you get anyplace else. The ambiance (space, wait staff outfits, birthday singing/performance, drinks) is spectacular for a special celebration.

The food is priced higher than most Thai restaurants but in my opinion you get so much more when you dine in. I usually bring friends here from out of town.

Everything is delicious. Get the Fried Chicken, Panang Curry, Tom Yum Soup, Pork Belly... Yum!
author: Kathy J.

description: This is my favorite Thai food in San Francisco! Every detail is contemplated here, from the savory broths, the colors of the ingredients, flavor complexity to even the decor of the restaurant walls. It's bold and not subtle. Great for a birthday dinner. Tom Kha soup and Panang Chicken are my favorites. Please try this wonderful place out for yourself!
author: Carey L.

description:
Positives:
--they do the best restaurant rendition of happy birthday I've heard, with drums and cymbals and a megaphone
--you get free fried grasshoppers and they're pretty tasty (took some major mind-over-matter to get one into my mouth)
--curry dishes were bomb, with high quality ingredients.  spicy food was nice and spicy

Negatives:
--our table was so dark we could barely see our food
--rice was served in an impractical woven cup (rice gets stuck inside)
--big boxer bowl drink tasted funky and bad, needs a reimagining. It's also mostly ice--just get individual cocktails
author: Maxim M.

description:
Dinner was delicious and the atmosphere fun and vibrant. Some of the portions were a bit scant (ie. $9 for 1 sausage?!) but everything was delicious. They have a very large menu and it was hard to pick. We ordered the Pork Belly Salad which was crisp and delicious. I really loved the platter with roti and curry. 

Everyone was friendly and the food was flavorful and interesting. Not just your typical Pad Thai and chicken curry spot.
author: Nicha K.

description:
We were lucky to get a table outside - inside was EXTREMELY noisy. I subtracted one star for that - I'm very finicky about noise levels at restaurants. 

the staff was awesome and the food was amazing. Very flavorful food (I forget what we had - dumplings and then Pad Thai). I've had a lot of Thai food (including in Thailand) and Farmhouse Kitchen rises high above the standard-issue, Americanized bland Thai you usually get.
author: Maggy S.

description:
Initially walking in, I thought the decor was cute but immediately noticed the loud music which infringed on a relaxed environment. However they lowered the volume when I asked. 

Their food heavily relied on sodium and what tasted like msg to flavor the dishes. Dishes came in small portions and were overpriced even by SF standards. 

The service was fine but overall the experience was just mediocre and there was nothing that special so I won't be back. xx
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Wow, I love Farmhouse. I randomly went for a late lunch early dinner a couple of months ago, and immediately fell in love with the ambiance. The delicious food and drinks quickly followed. I went to Thailand for my honeymoon, and we decided to come back to Farmhouse last week. We decided to order different dishes this time around, and were equally impressed. I will be coming back to celebrate my birthday next  month, and I can't wait to for my friends to try it. Yelp Reservations makes it easy to book a table, and parking in the area is fairly easy. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Came here for my mom's birthday after seeing photos of the place and loved how festive the place looked. First off, I have to say they provide you with the best customer service. It was pretty busy for a Monday night, but we still received great customer service. We were taken care of immediately (a reservation through Yelp definitely helped though). After ordering, I think our food came about 10 minutes later (maybe less?). However long it was, it's the fastest I've ever gotten my food at a nicer, sit-down restaurant. And don't think the speed compensated how good the food was because IT DID NOT.

Food: Besides the blue rice, which I thought was alright and tasted like regular jasmine rice, everything was pretty delicious. I got the Hat Yai Fried Chicken--chicken is fried and crispy, and it came with the blue rice, roti, and a sweet curry dipping sauce. I think this sauce also comes with the samosas, which I highly recommend as well. The exterior had a crust similar to an empanada which I'd never seen before in a samosa. My mom got the Mok Salmon, which came wrapped in banana leaves, leaving the entire thing super juicy. It comes with a spicy cilantro lime sauce that was a little too spicy for my mom and I, but I'm sure others would love. If you aren't fond of spicy food, I wouldn't recommend this though. Without the sauce, the salmon would be a bit boring. My dad and boyfriend got a Pad Thai with beef and Yum Moo Krob, a pork belly salad which were also pretty good.

Dessert: We got the croissant bread pudding which was perfectly baked and sweetened with caramel on top. If we weren't so stuffed, we'd have finished the whole thing. Comes with vanilla ice cream, strawberries and whipped cream. My parents got the Yim-Yim with everything coconut. I don't usually like coconut, but this was great. The server poured the cashews and coconut cream for us at our table with great enthusiasm--it was awesome.

Will definitely be coming back again!
author: Kristine N.

description: It is a secret place around the neighbor but it is popular and busy. I mean it is hard to spot a Thai restaurant on the corner where it is at.  The services are very friendly, and the staffs are always dressed up which add more ambiance for the restaurant. Everything I ordered were tasty but I have to mention the slow braised short rib, perhaps it's one of the best braised beef I've eaten.
author: Jason L.

description: Love this place, ambiance, the outfits, service was great, staff is super friendly and they smile a lot. I do recommend reservations cause it's that good. Food is so tasty I would definitely come back to try all the other dishes.
author: Rey D.

description:
Very decent Thai restaurant located in the Mission district of SF. I came here with a group of friends for a weekend lunch for a birthday celebration. One of my friends mentioned this was one of the best (if not the best) Thai restaurants in the city so I was pretty hyped to try it! It did not disappoint.

We ordered a few sides and entrees to share. The most memorable for me was the Hat Yai Fried chicken -- the chicken meat was so tender and the slightly crisp outside provided a wonderful texture to go with the flavors of the chicken. The green curry noodles were also very good -- even though I felt the curry was a bit light, it soaked the noodles and other vegetables very well. We also ordered some sides of blue rice which was very unique.

Prices were a little on the high end but well worth the quality of the food.
Service is very friendly and the food came very quickly.
author: Alvin W.

description: There food is really good, this review is about their customer service - rather the lack of it. I ordered soup and green curry from them yesterday when I was sick - the food came quickly and it was hot. I had asked for mild since I had an irritated throat and both dishes were quite chilly - I've eaten there before so I know it was not close to mild.  I was not well enough to deal with it and when I called them today they refused to do anything about it. So I followed up with Eat24. The rep was quite good and called the restaurant which again refused to fix anything and only offered a 20% discount. Very insensitive behavior considering I'm a regular customer and the cost of losing a customer for a small inedible order was clearly not worth it. They need better management
author: Sarah M.

description:
I been wanting to come here for awhile. You need to come with 3 or more people to try a lot of things. Portions are pretty big and make a reservation. This place gets packed all the time. Staff is pretty friendly except for one girl that is super rude, doesn't smile, and is so snappy. The place was not busy yet, but I had more than half my party here. I asked if we can sit and order first. She straight up said NOOOOO. Geezzzzzz ok...was just asking. The check in process is so slow because they are so busy. People with reservations, walk in, caiver and eat 24 trying to pick up orders....they need a better system. When my whole party was here, I asked the same mean lady we are all here. She looked at me and went ok and straight up walked away.....WTF!!!! Then this nicer pretty lady comes and helps me......

Thai Fish Cakes White fish, fresh kaffir lime, red curry paste, sliced long bean, cucumber
peanut relish-I love Thai fishcakes. Presentation was nice and yummy. 

Herbal Rice Salad Bangkok style. Toasted coconut, peanuts, shredded green mango,
crispy shallots, lemongrass, sliced long beans, chili, kaffir lime, dried shrimp with Tamarind dressing. Mix and enjoy-This was bad. No texture and way toooooooo much ginger. 

24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup Slow cooked bone-in Beef Short Rib, Egg noodles, veal broth,
broccolini, basil, bean sprouts, cilantro, green onion, pork rind garlic oil-this reminds me of Taiwanese beef noodle soup, but a bit better. This had so much flavor and the beef short rib is huge and very tender. 

Hat Yai Fried Chicken Thai Southern style. Mary's Organic Chicken breast, turmeric & herbs,
Fried shallots, roti bread, potato yellow curry for dipping. Blue rice-my friends and Yelpers said this place was a must. So good. It's like a little sampler. The fried chicken is crispy and tender, the curry is perfect, the roti is a nice touch, and the rice blends everything together. 

Crab Fried Rice Dungeness crab meat, cage free egg, onion, tomato, cilantro wrapped
twice cooked rice in lotus leave. Served with bone broth-a lot of crab meat and great flavors.

I want to come back to try other stuff, but hope I don't have to deal with a rude person again.
author: Karen H.

description:
Thai food in America can sometimes be really American-ized. The food does not have sharp, pungent flavors. Pad Thai can be a hint of peanut and that's about it. Not so at Farmhouse Thai! Slices of pungent, sharp ginger and all kinds of strong flavors can be found in all our dishes. The tom yum soup and Pad Ped...wow. The vanilla ice cream in coconut shell with fresh shavings of coconut--delicious.

The noise level, and number of people having birthdays wish accompanied singing, is the one factor that would lead me to not take people like my parents there--just too loud to have a good conversation. I like the kitsch factor, it feels like a tiki bar in Key West, but the noise could be taken down a notch.
author: Adam B.

description: Amazing food! Everything we got tasted delicious, especially the papaya salad. Must try!
author: Leila L.

description:
I have always had this place bookmarked for the longest time and I am so happy I finally tried it! Hidden in a less busy part of the mission, Farmhouse Thai Kitchen might be hard to find, but I promise they offer a memorable experience. For starters, Farmhouse Thai Kitchen has a nice interior and set up. And they also take reservations in advance. 

Favorite Dishes (If you are going to get something, I highly suggest getting these two) : 
-24 hour beef noodle soup - so flavorful and good enough for 3-4 people! The beef is so succulent and the noodles aren't too overcooked. Might be a little on the salty side for some people, but it was my favorite dish hands down. 
-Hat Yai Fried Chicken: Blue rice. Thai spiced Fried chicken. And a flavorful curry. Hell yea!!! 

The pad thai and fish cakes taste like your regular Thai dishes, but they are very flavorful and are great for starters. Also, the fish cakes portion is small, but it is darn beautiful. I had a great experience, despite the waiter commenting on my parents and I only ordering a couple dishes. We even had leftovers and the waiter seemed annoyed at us. Other than this, I would definitely venture out to Farmhouse Thai if I am in the area again!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: Great taste and service. Only problem with this restaurant is getting a table. Make a reservation a coupe days ahead!
author: Albert L.

description: I heard so many good things about this place but was so dissapointed. The waitress was rude and kept rushing us. Food was not bad though and interiors were nice.
author: J L.

description:
Came here wanting to explore comfort thai food at a place we haven't tried, and to our surprise, food and experience were better than we imagined. We wanted to sample everything but settled for a few dishes that all turned out delicious!! 

Love the traditional thai ambiance with the ornate clothing, thai music and eclectic thai decorations. 

Will definitely return!
author: Liz C.

description: Cool place! I get Thai food fairly often, and this is SOME of the best I've had. The place was absolutely slammed, so reservations were clutch. Service was pretty quick, it has to be do they can free up tables. Compared to my usual places, the prices were a few bucks over the norm. Good, but not great, but I guess the buzz justifies the cost. Hip place to check out once or twice, but couldn't see myself becoming a regular.
author: Andre P.

description:
3.5 STARS

Remember that nightclub, Whisper? Yah, those were THE days...you can hear the ratchetness and smell the camel toes from a mile away.

Enter the hipsters and tech bros: Whisper is gone and the just as pseudo fancy Circolo (just as ghetto as Whisper when it was a club) across the street is gone.

Although this part of the Mission is still gentrifying, it's come a long way from what it was 6-7 years ago. Super cute restaurants like Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Kitchen have taken residence along with multi-million dollar lofts that I will never be able to afford. But, that's gentrification for ya right?

At first glance, the prices at Farmhouse Kitchen may seem high for Thai food but they're justifiable. They use local and organic ingredients, and the portions are generous (enough for another meal). Plus, the presentation of every dish is instagrammable worthy - beautifully plated with vibrant colors that pop. 

After an offsite work meeting, I stopped by Farmhouse Kitchen for lunch. No need to peruse the menu as I knew what I wanted to order, the much raved about Hat Yai Chicken: Southern style fried chicken, yellow potato curry, roti, blue jasmine rice ($16): http://bit.ly/1VCfJUJ. The fried chicken breast had a satisfying crunch and was nicely tender. I immersed each piece into the curry sauce and wrapped the flaky roti around it to make a mini kati roll. The blue rice was just dyed rice. I had plenty of leftovers for dinner. When I ate the different components separately at dinner, I noticed that the chicken was sour (too much citrus in marinade?) and the curry dipping sauce was too sweet. This went unnoticed at the restaurant as curry sauce balanced out the sourness of the chicken. 

Also, ordered their House Soda ($3.50) which was refreshing but a little too concentrated for my liking. Needed to be diluted a bit more. 

Props for the lightning fast service (received my order in 5 minutes) since I had to go back to the office but one of the servers had a bit of a diva attitude - an unspoken sass with his body language. 

Me: "Hi!"
Him: "Ready to order?"

Me: "Yes, I like to order the...thank you!"
Him: *flips hair*

*Server places check on the table*

Me: "Thank you!"
Him: *flips hair and quickly turns away*

He didn't actually *flip his hair* (it's an idiom) but he gave off the "whatever, girlfriend" vibe. Not a deal breaker but the lack of mannerisms and response was off-putting. The other taller male server with the side swept bangs was really nice though. He read my mind when I wanted a glass of water and nicely packed my leftovers into different compartments. 

Usually the ambiance and décor at Asian restaurants are an afterthought. This is definitely a restaurant for the millennials, it's hip, trendy, and great for groups. Too bad, there's no full bar.

Parking is VERY difficult during the weekdays. Since there's no meters or time limitations on parking (other than street cleaning), people that work and live in the area park all day in the area. I got lucky. As I was driving down the street, someone pulled out of their space. Parking on the weekend should be much easier. 

Kin Khao and Lers Ros (original TL location) are still my top picks for Thai food but Farmhouse Kitchen is great for a hot date and chic group together. Please work on that *hair flip* though!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I wish I had discovered Farmhouse Kitchen earlier. This place is amazing! Not only is the food delicious, the decor and atmosphere makes you feel like you're on a vacation in Thailand.

We got the fried chicken plate, 24 hour beef noodle soup, and Thai Vacation for dessert. Everything blew my mind away. I could taste authenticity, real ingredients, and lots of flavor in all their dishes. Highly recommend.
author: Vivian W.

description: I was kind of disappointed considering how excited I was to try this place. I definitely think the food isn't worth the price here. Some classic thai noodle dishes including the pad thai are a lot more expensive than other thai restaurants. I also didn't think the food was as good as I had hoped.
author: Hanna K.

description: Legit Thai food at San Francisco prices. Very creative and fun decor and outfits. Usually pretty busy for dinner, so make a reservation. Save room for dessert.
author: Marcello B.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen Thai 

I was expecting an awesome experience based on the hundreds of excellent reviews. However, I was a disappointed. I ordered based on the recommendations of the server. 

RESTAURANT: 
Good vibe, open space and busy even for an early dinner. 

You don't have just one server when you order. There are multiple servers checking in on you so it's hard to know who to flag when something is needed. Some were more friendly than others. 

FOOD: 
Spring Rolls - 4 stars, fresh light clean taste. Definitely recommend if you want something light. The sesame seeds in the peanut sauce were really yum! 

Crispy Prawns - 4 stars, the only thing missing was a sauce or diced mango for extra flavoring. 

Papaya Salad - 2.5 stars, giving this a lower rating as the level spiciness cannot be chosen and is pre-made. It's disappointing as most Thai restaurants, especially ones that charge $20 for most main dishes, should allow you to alter your spice preference on a papaya salad and prepared well in advance of service. 

Pad Thai - 3 stars, greasy. The noodles were stuck together and very limited amount of vegetables for a veggie pad Thai. There were also 3 large inedible green vegetables almost as big as a finer in the plate.
author: Marisela E.

description: Lovely decor, nice atmosphere.  Disappointed with my pad Thai, it had a sweet sauce.  I expect pad Thai to be a savory dish, but it was almost dessert sweet.  Service was indifferent, the server almost frisbeed the dishes randomly on the table, but he probably assumed the 4 of us were eating family-style.
author: Sandi S.

description:
This place is amazing! As of today, it has been open for over a year and a half ...and i am sure it's not going anywhere!! 

This is a northern style restaurant and it is reminiscent of Andy Ricker's Pok Pok, but maybe even more enjoyable! It is currently Michelin recommended! 

The appetizer line up has flavors that are bright, balanced and have sweet and sour notes, in a majorly good way. My absolute favorite appetizer was the Mien Kum Kung which are crispy crusted tiger prawns, served with  leafy green veggie (not sure what the leaf was, raw collard greens, perhaps) with a zesty mixture of lime, ginger, onion, roasted coconut and peanuts with tamarind sauce. This effin appetizer is so effin good, i would not be mad if that was one of my last bites i ever ate! That little mixture under the prawn is surely to contain particles of crack, cuz it is addictive!  You must get this remarkable dish folks!

We also tried the Neua Num Tok Rolls which are snake river farm wagyu flank steak wrapped with mint, cilantro, cucumber served with cilantro lime vinaigrette. The steak was very tender and the combination of the other ingredients make it a well balanced bite, it is served four  per order.

The Crispy Calamari are curry battered monterey squid in spicy pepper served with a cilantro lime sauce. This is very good especially if you are one of those people like me that if calamari is on the menu, u will get it....so get it. The only thing thats it's missing is tentacles, no tentacles! All calamari lovers love tentacles! 

Now to the main dishes...

This is the house that Hat Yai Fried Chicken Dinner built!! This dish keeps coming out that kitchen all day long yo...and for a reason, it is fire!!! This is a Southern style dish with Mary 's chicken breast, turmeric and herbs, fried shallots, roti bread, potato yellow curry for dipping and purpleish rice....the big colorful plate has all these tiny bits too, well the fried shallots...and cucumber and a little dish of sweet and sour sauce. My party all agreed that this was the best dish. The chicken is outstandingly tender and fresh and the batter is so crispy and puffy. The roti and the curry are super good together. The curry sauce is very sweet and light. 

The other dish we had was the Kai Yang Som Tum Dinner which consists of half a Mary's organic BBQ chicken marinated in turmeric and coconut milk, papaya salad, sticky rice (the menu says you get black sticky rice but we got white) and roasted rice sauce. The chicken was very tender, but it could've used some grill marks or char points, in my op. The papaya salad us easily the best i've ever had because of the shocking balance of flavors! The rice was HELLA sticky, like so sticky, the rice particles did not want to part ways with each other...that was the only sucky part if the entire meal. The chicken too, I mean it takes effort to eat chicken on bone especially if you share, so i may skip this another time, due to laziness...

I'm ghetto, so i brought my own coke zero, cuz no places have coke zero (well some) but the waitress said she would get in trouble if she brought me a glass full if ice... So...I put my zero away...my mom insisted that I should get a Thai Iced Tea, but i didnt want to, because i didnt need more calories. She said it was the best one shes ever had and she orders it at every thai place in SF...she said something about the texture of the ice (looked like cruahed ice) makes it extra special...

The decor is super cute and the music is groovy, like not sure if it was English or Thai...or maybe i cant remember...parking can be difficult! 

One more thing that was dope about this establishment is that in SF terms, it is huge! Lots of tables and space....it kinda says "we knew we were gonna be successful and need a big ass place in SF standards" It looks like they have performances of Thai dancing at times, maybe just not during lunch. Another cool point is that they seem to value diversity and hire a diverse staff!! 

All in all, great place that pays attention to tiny details in all aspects! Service was attentive and friendly as well. Come early, it gets crackin'
author: Yva D.

description:
When your teammates invite you for a dinner and tell you that we're going to an amazing Thai place, the expectations are set pretty high. Fortunately, Farmhouse didn't disappoint and I've had the best Thai food experience. Granted, I haven't been to Thailand, but this seems to be pretty close to the real deal. 

As the long and hip name suggests, this is not your typical Thai place that you've grown up with. You won't find green curry fried rice nor Thai ice tea on the menu. My colleague, who'd been here already several times, highly recommended the fried chicken and so I went with that: a-mazing!

While I love the food, I found the service a bit nonchalant...let's put it this way: I can't recall any interaction with anyone from the service team. Sorry, Farmhouse, but you're losing a star here :-( Nevertheless, I'll be back for another fried chicken!
author: Uli B.

description:
This is my favorite thai spot in SF. First I thought the dishes were pretty over-priced, but the food is amazing (you also have to get the right dishes). I came here several times with large groups because there's lots of tables and waiting is max 15-20 min (hard to find such places in SF). The restaurant has a fun, clean vibe. 

Here are my reviews in order of my favorite dishes.
1. Hat Yai Fried Chicken - 100% will not regret ordering this. The serving can feed almost 2 people. The chicken is so juicy and crispy. So perfect with the sweet and sour sauce. The curry dip comes with yuka (first I thought they were potatoes) and slices of naan? platha? This part of the dish tastes very similar to Burma Love's platha dip which is my go-to appetizer. 

2. Grilled River Prawns Pad Thai - Is $20 pad thai really worth it? yes. The prawns are HUGE and so fresh. I love their pad thai although it can be a bit sweet for some people. Treat yoself to some expensive and darn good pad thai. 

3. Green curry with crispy pork belly - At first I totally judged this combination, but you need to try their crispy pork belly. I couldn't stop eating them. I like how their curry has a lot of vegetables. 

Dishes I didn't like:
- Papaya salad was way too spicy and too saucy 
- Tom Yum was also super spicy
- Pad Kee Mao's noodles were too overdone

I like their thai iced tea and honey milk lavender!
author: Christine C.

description: Love love this place so much fun all staffs very friendly. Food was so delicious. If you looking for place to celebrate your birthday or any occasion this is the one.
author: Kanjana N.

description: What an interesting experience. Make sure to get a reservation, otherwise place your name on the list and walk to Trickdog to kill time. After our official wait time, we had to go back and check-in and waited some more. There was an interesting smell throughout the restaurant, but maybe that's just SF street life seeping in. The food was fine, but not worth the long wait. The one positive thing, you never have to ask for water refills, they are always there.
author: Laurisha C.

description: Really enjoyed the food here.  Ordered the pad Thai, papaya salad, chicken noodle soup (non spicy) for kids, and the secret menu dish of the day. All dishes were tasty. Definitely coming back to try more from their menu.
author: eddy p.

description: This is probably the most authentic Thai spot in the bay area...I haven't found anything else that comes close to the more diversified dishes that this spot is able to represent (green seafood sauce! you can't find that anywhere here! I legit bring back bottles every time I come back).  I love going back to Thailand since it's a foodie's paradise...and the sad thing about it is that it's so hard to find even half of what's out there...here.  And even in the varieties you find here, there's a lack of depth in some of those flavors.  Farmhouse gets pretty close.  But, not as close as my Thai coworker that makes her curries homemade.
author: starrynight c.

description:
Inedible 

Ordered a to go meal for 2. Papaya salad (so hot my mouth was numb and had tons or chewy stale prawns).  Panang curry that didn't taste anything of peanuts and a mediocre yellow curry.  The rice is all extra - $17 for a curry that doesn't come with rice. Very expensive and not worth it.  Next time I'll go to Bang Sai Thai.
author: Rus M.

description:
Great for groups! A rare gem in the packed city of San Francisco. 

I've been to Farmhouse Kitchen Thai twice with a party of 5 or more and both times, it's been a solid experience. Call ahead or make a reservation on Yelp and it's smooth sailing.

One of the many things I like about this particular restaurant is their location: 20th Street Corridor. Within a short walk you've got quite a few Mission border gems like Trick Dog, The Tradesman, Atlas Cafe and Flour + Water. Totally underrated in terms of neighborhood street cred.

What to order? I hate when people say this at a restaurant, but you really can't go wrong with most everything on the menu. Here's what our seven top chowed down on a few weeks ago:

+ Fresh Rolls (with shrimp)
+ Ahi scoops
+ Crispy Calamari

And for an entree, I should've split the Hat Yai fried chicken, but damnit, I didn't want to share. Half of the table ordered the same main dish and none of us were willing to go halfsies. And you know what? It really was everything promised: tender, flavorful, and just the right amount of spice. My tastebuds were tickled in oh, so many good ways.

Price per person (with automatic 20% tip with large parties) came to about $35 per person. That included apps, mains, and drinks. That's a huge win in San Francisco... finding a table to fit your people and then being able to afford the experience.

If you like Thai food and you like visiting the Mission, go here now. What are you waiting for?
author: Abby S.

description:
FOOD: superb! Pad Thai has pleasantly bold flavors that fade into sweetness without the grease that plagues so many Thai restaurants. Pad kee mao is a heartier pick with tolerable but awakening spice. Steer clear of the mango salad unless you are SERIOUSLY ready for the spice. My tongue was stinging so much that I had to order the lavender steamed milk, which has the perfect ratio of milk to foam to flavor.
I've heard the samosas and coconut soup are outstanding, but I love my go tos far too much.  Skip the shrimp fritters unless you understand (and like) them mini sized. 

SERVICE: so friendly. Their energy and attitude is especially impressive given how busy it is (even at 10:45pm, the last seating I saw :)). Water glass was never wanting and waiter check frequency was great. 

AMBIANCE: steampunk meets rainbow explosion. I love it!!
author: Helen W.

description:
Pros: The atmosphere is excellent. It's clear that a lot of thought went into the physical aspects of the restaurant, and the staff are well trained; quick, very friendly, and very attentive.

The food itself was good seemed authentic (who am I to know?), but people considering the restaurant should keep in mind that what they've had before probably won't match up to what'll be served here. Adjusting takes a little bit of time, but it's worth it. The flavors you are used to aren't as strong as they usually are, and there are new flavors and spices to try.

Give it a go!


Cons: This place almost got 5 stars. 

What knocked it down were the insects (grasshoppers? crickets?). They offer very authentic cuisine, and part of that cuisine are the insects they offer to you as a treat while you wait. Unfortunately, they don't really ask if you want it, they just serve them as if they were serving a bowl of peanuts. 

While this isn't necessarily a bad thing, where they missed the mark on customer service was the fact that the bowl followed us from the waiting area to the dining table. The fact that the bowl sat far away from the waiting party and no one so much as touched them should have been a sign.

Staff should probably take 30 seconds to explain what the treat being served is, and if the party is interested in them. As it was, a few people at our table lost their appetite in spite of the quality of the food.
author: Carlos G.

description: I love this place! My husband and I tried their Hat Yai Fried Chicken and Penang Neua. We came at 1:30 pm and it was crowded, good thing we made a reservation. I think the restaurant has great local authentic Thailand ambience. Overall, it's a good place with good foods! I'd love to come back.
author: Irma P.

description:
I've been to many Thai restaurants in my lifetime, two during this trip to SF alone, but this place SLAYS. 

The attention to detail in the restaurant is remarkable. They have a wall of water spouts, gorgeous floral arrangements that play with sizing and scale, and they serve their bottled beer out of chalices. Everything is expertly curated, it's truly a beautiful space. 

The food is incredible, too. The menu is extensive for the size of the place and includes everything from Fried Chicken, to Pad Thai. I had a Garlic Chicken dish with Rice that was delish. They brought out spices and salsas to add to your meal that allowed you to choose your spice level. That was an awesome benefit, because even though I like a good amount of spice, I really wanted to taste the flavors of my food last night. 

The one thing that was really spicy was the Papaya Salad. The menu mentions that it's spicy, but we glossed over that.. I mean how spicy could it be? Spoiler alert: HOT HOT HOT! 

Overall this was a great choice for a mid-week meal, make reservations though! The location is small.
author: Luci H.

description:
Good environment, nice bathroom, a little hard to find parking. 

I have had three of their dishes: the Tom Yum Noodle Soup, the Flaming Steak, and the Hat Yai Fried Chicken. 


Tom Yum Soup: 8/10 soup was really good but a bit spicy so if you're not into that then probably pass on this

Flaming Steak: 4/10 it looks so cool but it just tastes burnt :( the green beans that came with it were good tho

Hat Yai Fried Chicken: 9/10 so so good omg, the chicken was wonderful and crunchy
author: Emily G.

description: Absolutely the most flavorful Thai food in the city.   The owner upholds his customer commitments and delivers on Spice and Flavor.   And he uses fresh ingredients.    Unusual Environment.  Highly Recommend.
author: Holly H.

description: To say this lunch was amazing would be an understatement. I came in with mediocre expectations but they were very quickly surpassed. Miu, my server, was very kind and attentive. He made some amazing suggestions and really knew how to pick a good meal. The atmosphere was also fun. It was clean, tables were appropriately spaced apart, and it has a great energy. Definitely coming back!
author: Nicholas L.

description:
I came here on a Friday night for my boyfriend's early birthday dinner; we had reservations so we got seated when we arrived. The tables were really close to one another so I felt like I was practically eating with the two tables on each side hah. They also have this unique faucet decoration on the table that is movable, but never seen it before so it was cute. My boyfriend and I ordered a few too many dishes for us to share, but since it was our first time, we had to go for it! We were given a complimentary pickled dish ata the beginning of our meal, it was decent, but I like Vietnamese pickled cabbage better. 

- Tom Kha: this coconut soup was delicious! We ordered a small to share and it was enough knowing the many dishes that were on its way. Generous on the chicken, the onions were soft and sweet, and the coconut flavor was prominent and delicious.
- Chicken Wings: not dry on the inside, but super crispy and tasty on the outside. Decently made, but if I had to rank my dishes from my favorite to least, this one didn't stand out to me like the rest.
- Neua Num Tok Rolls: deliciously flavored beef rolled up for an easy bite. Comes with 4 pieces - definitely recommend trying.
- Hat Yai Fried Chicken: came here just for this dish and it was not disappointing. The dish setup was beautiful, the blue rice was unique and yummy, and the curry had a kick of spice but still super yum! A bit pricey, but totally would order again.
- Thai vacation: this has got to be my favorite dish - or maybe I'm just a huge coconut fan. This is eaten out of a coconut, where you can actually scrape off in the inside. The mixture of black sticky rice, vanilla ice cream, coconut cream, peanuts, and black sesame came together so nicely that I forced myself to finish it even though I was so full. Recommend to order!

While waiting for our dinner, all of the sudden I notice a line of the waiters and waitresses come out with a gong walking towards my table. I then realized it was just how they presented the Thai Vacation for the birthday boy! They sang and gave him an awesome hat and neck decoration to wear until we left. Too bad we didn't get to keep the hat and lei, but definitely unexpected and funny to see my boyfriend so embarrassed of the attention from the whole room.

I had a good experience here. Good & fun service, fun decor & attire, and delicious food  - what's not to like? I would definitely return even though they are a little more pricey than most Thai spots.

+UPDATE: came back with girlfriends and had the crab fried rice with their hot sauce - it is delicious! The short ribs with the blue rice was a bit more bland that I'd like so stick with the chicken and rice :) mango sticky rice is also always a great choice.
author: Amanda C.

description:
BEST MEAL EVER!   We spent 6 days in SF and this was by far the best meal I've had in months.  

My husband and I took a Lyft from fishermans wharf for $13 and I'd spend 3x's that much just to get here again.  Reservations are a must because it gets packed until the doors close at 10pm.  

The night started off with drinks and samosas for the appetizer.  They were light, crispy and fried and served with a curry dipping sauce that we poured all over the samosas vs dipping because it was that good.  

Dinner was the Hat Yai which was two chicken breasts fried and served with rice, Asian pickled cucumbers, roti bread and a big dish of curry sauce with potatoes in it.  All was served on a big plate which had a little side dish of a honey sauce that paired nicely with the spice of the curry.  

Next was the Neua Yang Steak entree which was wagyu served medium with a side of long green beans tossed in a nice spicy sauce and had a giant scoop of jasmine rice on the side.  It also had a side dish with a spicy, vinegar based sauce that had a huge kick but so worth the heartburn.
