If that wasn't enough, we got coffee to go.  I ordered the coconut cream latte which was the best cup of coffee I had during my stay in SF and the hubby had an iced latte with simple syrup which was fantastic as well.  

Spread the word, tell your friends and check this place out.  It'll be worth your time to fill your bellies with this deliciousness.
author: Tammie W.

description:
Very very interesting...randomly picked this spot because a friend wanted thai and the mission is close by. I completely forgot it's chinese new year and when we walked in the restaurant was decorated, playing chinese music, and they had a performance going on. Surprisingly our wait was only 30 minutes on a Friday night. Not what I was expecting at all but it was so really cool. Service was great - prompt and very friendly.
Food - 
24 hr beef noodle soup - Full of flavor, the short rib was sooo tender and fell right off the bone. I did ask for medium spicy and it felt a little mild to me. Maybe it's just my taste buds but I could've had a little more heat. 
Thai Iced Tea - Presentation was beautiful and unique with a ball of crushed ice on top. It's hard to find an authentic thai iced tea in the US but this one was really really close. 
Hubby had a steak entree that was lit on fire. Really cool, sauce was yummy but pretty sweet.

Overall - Good food. Great atmosphere. Super nice staff.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Yes!!!!  This place was amazing. I want to start with the flavor of the food as that is what is strongest with me now a week later from when I dined but, I am doing  them an injustice as the service was spot on from the word go!  From booking the reservation, to being seated, to the attention throughout the meal.  A really great experience...this is really the reason we dine. Hunger schmunger, we dine out to have an experience and that it what we had, me and my sisters. The eggplant appetizer came first and was SOOOO good. They both agreed. I can't remember now what they had but my panang curry was the bomb. Simply...just go. You WILL NOT be disappointed!!!

Flavor, flavor, flavor...incredible service with some more flavor!!!
author: Derrick Y.

description:
Farmhouse definitely has ambiance, but not the type of ambiance that's for everyone. My family and I came here after a long day of hiking since my brother was in the mood for Thai. I checked online for open reservations around 6:15p, and seeing none until 8p, I didn't see the point when we were going to get there around 6:30p anyways. No way a party of 4 would have to wait for 1.5 hours, right? 

Walking off the quiet streets of this part of the Mission into Farmhouse was something like stepping out of a chimney after using Floo Powder. It's dimly light, colorful, and festive inside - an assault on pretty much all your senses. We put our name down, were told about a 40 minute wait, and settled on some of the colorful plastic stools in front of the reception desk. A cheesy parody music video was being projected on the screen facing us, and loud Thai music made it difficult to converse so we tried looking at the menu instead. 

Unfortunately, it was holiday season and my presumption that Farmhouse managed their floor service like most other restaurants and held at least 1/3 of the seating for walk-ins did not hold. Ordering takeout would have been more efficient. This would not have been too much of a problem had the front house staff been more upfront about their seating system and wait time (every "10 more minutes" turned into 30), and had a brush-up on PR skills. The bathrooms were at least a nice refuge, the far back one being a spacious vault with one toilet and two sinks. And a sign-up list for their top secret club. 

As we were superseded by group after group of people, each seemingly larger than the last, I had the fleeting thought that maybe reservations superseded any semblance of a waitlist for walk-ins. The only entertaining moment during the waiting game was when a server went around with fried crickets to the diners (not us, part of the Crowd Behind the Desk) to offer his wares. Over an hour later, I was regretting not just making an Open Table reservation for 8p because I wasn't even sure we would get in at that time. Several other groups around us, even with reservations, were getting antsy and two groups decided to leave. 

Just before 8p we were seated at the draftiest table, being closest to the door. A vegetable salad was dropped on the table before us, and my sulking mother was determined to find everything else wrong with the restaurant. Unfortunately, they got her order wrong (she ordered the Chicken Noodle Soup and was given the Vegetable version) and I ended up switching my Tom Kha Soup w/ Chicken with her as mollification. These items were just average, but my brother was quite happy with his super-tender Panang Neua (short rib) and ended up eating half of my dad's Hat Yai Fried Chicken, so at least there was one happy stomach at the end of the meal. The portion sizes seemed about right for dinner pricing - the noodle soups particularly so. The dishes were unlike other Thai places I've been to - and I've never been to Thailand - so I can't speak to how authentic they actually were, but it definitely appeals to the SF crowd. 

During the meal, the waitstaff was pretty attentive and kept the water glasses full. But about halfway through the meal, it became obvious they were rushing to turn over tables and nearly took away my brother and my dad's plate three times. Calm. Down. What irritation had dulled now rose again to the surface, and I'm sorry to say that we all left with a sour aftertaste. I recognize that my experience was affected by the timing of the visit, but I don't think I'll be coming back to re-experience the poor service and average food.
author: Helen S.

description: Nice ambiance and quite trendy. When it comes to food, nothing impressive nor authentic. I had the red chicken curry. The chicken tasted like it was boiled and dumped into the pre-made a day old curry sauce. I also ordered vegan spring roll that was $9.95. Outrageously pricey since all it had was bunch of iceberg lettuce with one or two basil leaf with a small piece of tofu. Tasted very bland. Thank God for the peanut sauce for improvement. I also ordered Penang neau and pad Thai to go for my daughter. Didn't try any. Parking here is very limited. It can get pretty busy esp on weekends. If you want authentic Thai food, go to Marnee Thai on 9th and Irving. Very busy and parking is just as limited, but worth it.
author: Mariah O. C.

description:
Love this place!! Definitely the best and most unique Thai place I've been to in SF

Highly recommend these dishes:
(1) the calamari - really crunchy, reminded me of an onion ring
(2) the 24 hour beef noodle soup - so flavorful!
(3) the fried chicken with blue rice - my friends and I LOVED this one. favorite dish forsure. the chicken was crunchy and juicy and dipping it into the curry sauce with the roti was bomb mmmmm
author: Sophia L.

description: Ordered the hat yai fried chicken and the Thai street green curry noodles. Both were delicious. The menu was a bit pricier than usual but considering how large the portions were, worth it. The hat yai fried chicken seemed to be the most popular dish here and I can see why. Everything from the roti bread to the chicken and curry were good. The fried chicken was super crispy and juicy. The green curry was also fantastic. It came with some garnishes and noodles on the side. Also loved the little kick of spiciness in the curry. All around great meal.
author: Annie H.

description:
Fun vibe, huge portions, not-your-average Thai flavors! Farmhouse is off the beaten path, but a worthwhile venture for something slightly exotic and VERY filling. It does get pricey, if you start with appetizers. Word to the wise: save space and go straight to the main dishes!

The menu is super long and tempting, so I suggest using Yelp photos to choose what you want. The Thai Fried Chicken was popular with our group, a huge portion of chicken with a side of curry & purple rice. Share-able! The 24-hour beef noodle soup was another winner, the broth so unctuous and rich. 

I wanted something saucy & noodley, and ordered the Thai street green curry noodles. This was more like curry with a side of noodles. Still good, but definitely ask the staff questions if you're craving something specific. 

Note: the tom yum kai soup is a BIG portion to start with, with tons of chicken, light on the broth. Not the best if you just want something to savory sip on before your meal, but great as a filler-upper. 

Ambiance is vast, like a Farmhouse, great for a group dinner of 6-8 people (or less, of course). Service was very fast and attentive to special requests. Overall, a delicious, decadent meal that was extra fun to share with fellow adventurous eaters.
author: Nique F.

description:
Great place. Lively, fun, and good food. Came here on a Sunday to celebrate my birthday and was pleasantly surprised with how busy it was at 7pm. House was packed and many others were also celebrating their birthdays. We had calamari, fried chicken with blue rice, snake river steak with ginger rice, this sauteed pork belly with onions, papaya salad. Food came out quickly, beautifully plated, and large portions. 

For dessert we had Thai Vacation and bread pudding. So yummy! 
My friends who had never been really enjoyed it too. We will be back!
author: Zara H.

description: Blue rice and undercooked Salmon = bummer.  This is the Cheesecake Factory of Thai Restaurants.  Not a fan of PDX kitsch invading San Francisco. The staff noticed the undercooked Salmon without me saying a word and removed it from my bill.  Bonus points.
author: Riley O.

description:
We had a rocky start.  

We walked in on a Saturday after 8pm and the place was packed save for a long communal table that appeared reserved.  Put our names down for 2 and were told that they would call in 30-45mins when our table was ready.  So we took off and came back 45-mins later expecting to be seated soon.  The host told us (could have been a language communication issue) that he still had no table for us and moreover, his 9pm reservations were going to arrive soon and we as walk-ins would be bumped yet again for them.

What kind of hospitality is this?
 
Considering we just came back from a different establishment and dropped $30 on cocktails waiting for our table.  [Note to owner: don't let those $30 go to another place next time because we didn't order ANY drinks with dinner.  Not the wisest business decision on your most profitable product- alcohol]

Before we could fume however, we saw a few people get up from the bar seating and pointed the empty seats to the host and asked to be seated at the bar instead of waiting another hour.  The host obliged.

Now with that experience behind us, we moved on.

FOOD: authentic, delicious, and came out QUICK.  We ordered (for 2):

-Crab fried rice: a MUST.  The rice was soft and perfectly cooked, and CHUNKS of crab were visible.  Came with a bowl of delicious chicken bone broth.  Very satisfying.

-Papaya salad: refreshing and savory.  We ordered "spicy" and were warned that it was going to be SPICY.  It wasn't.  Just the right amount of spicy and I can handle some, so it was perfectly fine.

-Beef rolls: they were AMAZING!!  Grilled Steak wrapped around cucumber and served up with a sweet and savory sauce.  The roll was a bit too large to stuff in our mouths in one bite so I would recommend cutting it up.  Hopefully the chef can just make more smaller rolls to enjoy so you don't have a mouthful of food and chewing it for a solid 5 minutes to get any kind of room in your mouth to even speak or breathe.

-Tom Yum: if I could re-order, I would NOT have ordered this.  It was just fine, and we were warned yet again that this was super duper spicy.  It was a tad spicy but again not that bad.  Let's just say I wasn't dunking my mouth in my water cup at any point of the meal.

We left incredibly full and satisfied.  No room for dessert.  Everyone was much nicer on our way out and we'll probably be back.  Hopefully they work out a better system to seat customers in a more efficient manner and improve on the hospitality.  As a walk-in, I would expect to be welcomed and not treated as a nuisance.  Once the hype dies down, there will ONLY be walk-ins!
author: Cin P.

description: This is a diamond in the rough for sure! I was absolutely blown away with this amazing food! We got panang curry, tom kha soup, pad Thai and a fresh tuna appetizer and we loved it all! The only downside... you can't ask for it any spicier than it comes. You add your own spice but all you can add is jalapeños, chili powder and chili paste (I think that's what it was). Other than that, I was incredibly impressed! I will seek this place out next time I am in town!
author: Erin B.

description: Chicken on the pad Thai was very dry, and the portion was ridiculously small for 15.5$ (half of the tiny plate was just sprouts). The pork in the yellow curry had the consistency of a car tire or an eraser, and was also very dry. Also, the spice on the yellow curry was very mild which was disappointing. The curry that came with the fried chicken was also way too salty; it tasted pretty bad. This is also one of those shady restaurants that suggests tip amounts after automatically applying gratuity.
author: George K.

description:
If you're looking for scrumptious thai food with a relaxed spacious ambiance and great non-alcoholic drinks this is the place for you!

We went as a group of 6 for lunch on a Saturday and truly enjoyed it. It's always nice to go with more people to Asian restaurants so we could get many dishes and do family style. The place was had a quirky but fun decor. It had a casual relaxing vibe but not too loud. Great place for groups (if you can get a reservation). 

The food overall was really good! I wouldn't say it's the most authentic or best thai place I've been to in my life but it's definitely up there in the SF thai restaurant list. 

We all loved the hat yai fried chicken entree. Must get that one! Also the neua num tok rolls appetizer was amazing. Wish we got more of those since each order only has 4 pieces. It was the perfect mixture of refreshing cucumber and grilled wagyu beef and bright flavors. 

The crab fried rice was quite yummy also. The most underwhelming dish was probably the pad see yew with pork belly. Will be back again to try more dishes!!! 

Don't forget to order the whole coconut and thai iced coffee :)
author: Rohenne L.

description: Fantastic Thai style food.  Not quite traditional Thai but more like Thai meets California cuisine.  Seems like lots of veggies/meats are sourced from local areas and the menu caters to it.
author: Yoichi N.

description:
Most thai places area look something like the following: hole in the wall that produces predictable, greasy, cheap, yet tasty dishes. Farmhouse is leading the way in reversing that stereotype. This place puts fanciful twists on traditional classics and introduces some new ones all in a beautifully decorated environment.

THE FOOD
The papaya salad, Neua num tok rolls, Kai Yang som tum chicken, and Panang Neua braised short rib are all incredible. Great flavors, strong spices, but nothing too overpowering. Everything comes in generous serving portions, and the coconut rice and blue rice are an especially nice touch. They've also got a great dessert menu. I've only tried the Yim-Yim, a dish of coconut ice cream, shaved almonds, coconut meat. Not usually a big fan of coconut, but this was delicious.

THE AMBIENCE
Fun thai music playing in the background. The servers are dressed in colorful garb and are incredibly friendly. Awesome place for dinner and great for group dinners/gatherings. So happy  that a place like this is turning traditional perceptions of Thai restaurants on its head.
author: Tim X.

description: Get the Pad Thai. Its a safe bet. Maybe too safe so I didn't get the band out of my experience.
author: Captain M.

description: Wow, such good food.   Loved the coconut soup.   A wonderful vegan curry and vegan pad thai.  There was a really good beef rib dish.  Wonderful sticky rice tea.  The staff all had Halloween make up and the dining room was decked out with flying creatures.   I also lined the permanent succulent displays.    All nicely done.
author: Carla D.

description:
I arrived at 5 PM Sunday evening and got right in.  During my meal the room slowly filled so the Farmhouse is popular.  Service was polite but rushed: even before I finished my appetizer the main course was placed table side.  But at least they didn't grab me by the neck and throw me out the door; maybe that's reserved for next time.

The spicy Papaya Salad is highly recommended on Yelp, so that was course number one.  It was moderately spicy but not egregiously so.  However, the dressing was sufficiently assertive so that I couldn't taste the papaya, and that was the whole point of the salad.  A dressing should complement, not mask, a salad.  This wasn't bad but it could have been a salad of almost anything.

Hat Yai Fried Chicken Breast with roti bread, potato in a yellow curry and blue rice was plated to give the impression that there was more on the plate than was actually the case.  The potato and yellow curry was in a large bowl that occupied most of the plate and the roti bread sat atop the chicken breast making it appear as though there was more protein than was actually present.   But the chicken breast was perfectly fried and when dipped into a bit of the proffered honey was very nice.  In fact everything on the plate was very nice but be aware you are really carb loading high glycemic food with this plate: a large portion of blue rice; roti bread; and white potato.  Nevertheless I consumed everything and then put in a bit of extra exercise to drive down my blood sugar.  

This is a nice place with good food at a good price.
author: David D.

description:
You would think with the 2:1 staff to customer ratio here they would be able to facilitate a to go order at 5:30pm. Left me sitting at the bar for 20 minutes only to discover my food is ready and has just been... sitting there. 

@ $16 for basic pad Thai that is half bean sprouts you could at least tell me it's ready. 

I even tipped in advance :( regret regret regret

Edit : upped a star because the owner reached out, which is nice. I'll give it another try... maybe it was an off night :)
author: Sabrina M.

description:
In a word? Delicious. 

The title "Farmhouse Kitchen Thai Cuisine" perfectly describes what you'll get when you sit down for a meal here: modern twists on authentic Thai meals made with fresh, farm-to-table ingredients. As far as Thai food is concerned, this was one of the better meals I've ever eaten. 

As soon as my work group sat down and saw the menu choices, we didn't hold back. Thai Fish Cakes? A selection of curries? Hat Yai Fried Chicken? Whatever we saw, we ordered. My personal favorite appetizer was the Neua Num Tok Rolls, a succulent combination of Wagyu flank steak wrapped with mint,
cilantro and cucumber and served with a cilantro lime vinaigrette. I was equally happy with my main course: 24 Hours beef noodle soup. This addictive elixir includes slow cooked bone-in beef short rib, egg noodles, veal broth,
broccolini, basil, bean sprouts, cilantro, green onion and pork rind garlic oil. If that sounds delicious to you then believe me it was. 

Our server was quick and attentive and the atmosphere is pleasant if not a little noisy. I could easily return here on my frequent trips to the city, and I know it will be a recommendation to other traveling friends as well.
author: Alex L.

description: Delicious yet super small portions. I ordered for a group, $80, and everyone still very hungry.
author: Nat Y.

description: I absolutely love this place. The food is amazonly outstanding and the serevers and wait staff very knowledgeable. I have been for bruch, dinner and Mother day. Have not been disappointed at all!!!!
author: Arica G.

description: The only big negative to this restaurant was the lack of truly vegetarian friendly items. Typically at most Thai restaurants I have been to, I have been able to order salad(papaya) and curries(red,yellow, panang). However, at this restaurant they said they cannot modify any of their recipes to take out oyster sauce or shrimp paste. Hence we had a really limited menu to choose from. That being said, we really enjoyed the spring rolls, spicy eggplant, and fried rice. The noodles were so-so.
author: Sara V.

description:
Fresh for sure - You can tell the ingredients are fresh - The flavor overall is good but on some dishes can use a little turning up a notch.
I like that they have a variety of GF options which is awesome and appreciated for those of us that have this "issue"
I've tried quite a few dishes as after coming in I ordered for catering an event for work. Everyone really enjoyed the food and commented on the level of freshness overall, even the picky person who is never happy with the food liked it and asked where it was from so this was a WIN lol
author: Kelly M.

description:
Have been here several times now, and this place is a solid 4-4.5.  The decor, atmosphere, and presentation of the food is really great, and we've found some standout dishes as well, especially:
- Ahi tuna scoops
- 24 hour beef noodle soup - a brontosaurus-sized bone-in beef short rib, slow cooked to soft, fatty perfection and seasoned expertly, over noodles and tasty broth.
- Kha moo - a big ol' braised pork shank packed with thick, gelatinous skin - just the textures you're looking for.  Served with rice, pickles, and vegetables.

Farmhouse is definitely moving closer and closer to the top spot in our list of favorite Thai restaurants.
author: Simon L.

description:
When I think of "Farmhouse Kitchen," Thai food isn't usually what I"m expecting.  When I first heard of Farmhouse, I was expecting some iteration of the whole tired "farm-to-table" schtick, instead I walk into a bright and eclectic restaurant filled with off-kilter, tongue-in-cheek elements like the wall lined with faucets to a soundtrack of Thai Elvis jams.  

Usually come here for lunch on the weekdays and it's usually packed.  I've had the following:

Tom Kha -coconut soup with veggies.  I found the soup to be a lot on the sweet side.  Make sure for the soups you get the small since the next size up is HUGE and enough for four people. 

Tom Yum Kai - spicy and sour soup.  usually my go-to thai soup.  Flavors are good, but not mind blowing.  Best I ever had was in Paris of all places!

Tofu Noodle Soup - served with pho noodles and has a flavor profile similar to chicken pho, but a little more garlicky and flavors more subtle. Great for a cold day. 

Neua Yang  Steak - one of the rare misses on the menu.  Grilled slices of wagyu beef and green beans.  Arrived flambe style with the steak in flames; however, once the flames died, most of the alcohol didn't - not the most pleasant experience.  Major let down - the steak had a barnyard-y unpleasant aftertaste - not appetizing at all.  

Fresh Leaf Tea - mint and a whole lotta parsley.  Order only if you like parsley.
author: Hieu H.

description:
My first experience at this restaurant was already 5 star. Then I just devoured my yellow curry take out for lunch at work and wish I could throw in another star. So. Dang. Good. And I can only imagine how much better it would be fresh. Came w roti which is a nice touch. 
My sit down experience was also great. The tiger prawn appetizer was perhaps my favorite thing. It's on the spendy side for three pieces of food, but it's nicely prepared dish w fantastic flavor. Samosas were flaky and fresh w an amazing yellow curry dip  I shared the braised beef plate w my roommate. MORE than enough food. We almost ordered a second main dish but thank goodness we didn't, although I'm sure it would've been delicious. All the food around us also looked and smelled amazing. I will note the prices are a bit on the high side for the plates mainly. A curry w rice is fairly reasonable, especially for the quality, ~$18. This place has definitely made it into my regular food rotation. So far my favorite Thai spot in sf!
author: Joana Z.

description:
Went here last night (2/17) with a group of friends and was big time impressed with the food, service, and atmosphere. First off, the layout of the space was amazing and go figure, it looked like a farmhouse. :) A+ for interior design work. 

The food was fantastic! I don't eat a ton of Thai food in SF (not for any particular reason), but I'd put this at the top of my list. It's non traditional in a Thai sense from what most of you are probably used to, but man is it good. 

We started with the Ahi Tuna Scoops (see picture), Herbed Rice Salad (prob my favorite of the bunch), and the Neua Num Tok Rolls with a Thai chimichurri dipping sauce. All were amazingly different from each other and I would highly recommend them all. My main course was the Hat Yai Friend Chicken. Yes, I'm a sucker for friend chicken if you couldn't tell from other posts. If it's on the menu, I get it. Seriously, this was one of the best fried chickens I've had in SF and was an enormous plate of food. It comes with a bowl of curry and rice too. I opted to let the chicken sit in the curry and soak up the amazing flavors. Seriously, heaven. 

I'll surely be back with a large group of friends who are sure to be impressed. Boo ya.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
So full.

This was one of those times that the boyfriend had visited before me and then couldn't stop talking about it. I had to try. We were starving (as usual) and ordered three main dishes... The server politely asked if we would like to switch a main to a starter. Nahh we'll keep all three main dishes.

Hat Yai Fried Chicken (duh) $18 - I've had my fair share of fried chicken, but I've never had it "Thai-style" before. And I've been missing out! You have too if you haven't tried it! The herbs really make the difference, and even though the curry was for the roti bread and rice, I dipped the chicken in there too. Oops. A very delicious oops.

24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup $18 - The meat that came with this dish, man, it was so so good. Literally falling off the bone, the meat was soft and juicy and everything I want my beef to be. Great flavors! Again, different from your "usual" beef noodle soups (Taiwanese or American). Honestly, I loved this more than I loved the chicken (boyfriend was aghast - nothing beats fried chicken).

Specials $18 - That I forgot the name of :( It was a broth of pork and blood jelly, with condiments, cilantro/sprouts, and vermicelli on the side. This was a really interesting dish, and while it wasn't bad, the blood jelly overwhelmed the broth. (it also had that sticky rice taste, but there was no sticky rice in sight). Overall, interesting combination but I wouldn't try it again. I have nothing against blood jelly! Definitely props to the kitchen for being adventurous with something that's rare in even Asian American kitchens.

Loved the vibe and service. Super fun and delicious place that I can't wait to visit again! And yes, we were stuffed from three dishes... but no complaints :)
author: Lucy Z.

description: I'd never had Thai food until my boyfriend's cousin too is here and thank god he did! I've been hooked on Thai food ever since, only unfortunate part is that it's in the city and I live in San Jose! Amazing service, incredible food & will definitely be coming back in the near future!
author: Claire B.

description: One of the better this places in the city. We always get the pad see ew and it had a lot of vegetables. But because this is one of the better this places, it is expensive. It's worth coming every once in a while when we get the craving for Thai food.
author: Jeremy Anne C.

description: Great food as per everyone else's reviews, except the staff could be friendlier. Also, the annoying thing is they don't let you in unless the whole party is present at the restaurant. Most of our table had arrived and our friends were on their way but the restaurant wouldn't let us sit down at our table to wait. I don't understand this policy, as we could've started ordering first and they were losing revenue on potential orders. Also, the waiters could have been more friendly and explained the policy to us as they just made us wait at the front for a long time without an explanation. They also strangely kept trying to take our high chairs to store away, even though no one else needed it.
author: Zaza Y.

description:
Ordered chicken pad thai and chicken panang curry to go. Came out to around $35. The food was ready for pick up within 10-15 minutes. The lime for the pad thai was very sad but otherwise the noodles were good. The panang curry was spicy!

Overall, I enjoyed the food but it wasn't worth the SF prices of $15 dollars an entree
author: Amanda W.

description: This place is really amazing!  Food is fantastic every time, and we've been here a few times already.  My only "complaint" is that portion sizes are pretty small so we end up ordering more to get full.  But it's not bad, you get to try more dishes :).  Overall, amazing place!
author: Pavel P.

description:
I had the fried chicken for lunch.  
Overall it was great and very filling.  A good assortment of goodies on the plate.
But the curry was literally cold.  I should have sent it back but that's not me.  And it seemed to have no spice, something I'm definitely not used to from eating Thai in the South Bay.
The chicken was very good and very hot.  So hot that at the end of the meal I couldn't hold it in my hands.
I ordered the ginger rice, but I couldn't taste any difference from standard jasmine.  Won't do that again.
Lots of food, too.  Too much for one person, really.
Cost:  $19 plus $2 extra for the ginger rice
author: RandyCP U.

description: Nice ambience, good service, decent price. No long wait times as it's really roomy inside. The Thai ice tea is very good. Good for big groups as they have tables for big group as well.
author: Mrityunjay K.

description: Salad was so incredibly spicy we literally were unable to eat it. I can handle spicy but this was borderline insanity. Yikes.
author: Captain B.

description:
Different than any other Thai restaurant I've ever eaten at! A couple of my friends and I had the Ahi tuna scoops and lemongrass flavored soup for appetizers and they were good. The tuna was a little fishy but overall good. For our entrees we had the fried chicken with yellow curry, pappaya salad (way tooo spicy) and BBQ chicken. Thai ice tea was great! Overall good, cool Thai comfort food and trendy joint to go with friends.

Went for a second time, had the beef ribs, chicken wings and Thai vacation dessert! All three were a hit!!
author: Noor S.

description:
Found my new favorite thai place! Farmhouse offers delicious food that I find quite unique from other Thai restaurants that I've tried. 

I ordered the Hat Yai ($16) fried chicken breast with blue rice, roti, curry dip, and some pickled cucumbers/veggies on the side. I was worried the chicken breast would taste dry but boy was I wrong. It was juicy, perfectly fried, and flavorful. You could dip it in the curry or the sweet and sour sauce. I liked how there was so much going on with this dish, as I could dip my roti with the curry or out the curry on the rice, etc- it was an experience. Would definitely recommend this dish. I ordered it because it was so popular on yelp and I could see why. The bf was definitely having entree envy. 

The bf ordered Panang Neua ($20) braised short rib with blue rice. Flavorful and tender but we both enjoyed the fried chicken above more.

Overall, we think we've found our favorite Thai restaurant in the city! The prices are a bit pricy but typical for SF and the portions are big at least. Delicious food, large portions, and friendly service. We came on a rainy day so there was not that much people, but I can imagine it getting crowded during peak hours.
author: Kathleen Y.

description: Celebrated my friend's birthday here. Got an easy same day reservation by calling the restaurant after seeing that Yelp and Opentable said they were full. The waiter was cute! Haha but also very receptive to our needs. The food came out fast. We ordered pad see yew, pad Thai, squid special, Panang curry, Thai sausage, chicken wings, and tom kha gai soup. Everything  was very tasty and authentic. My Thai friend who came with us was very impressed with the flavors. The wine was good but a bit overpriced. I love the ambience of the place, from the friendly Thai staff to the decor to the loud Thai music. It reminded me of being back in Bangkok. Overall with good and 2 bottles of wine our total was about $300 for 6 people. Not too shabby. Will def come here again. Oh and birthday boy got serenaded by the staff. So funny!
author: Thai L.

description: This is my favorite fancy Thai restaurant on this side of the Bay Area. Lots of great vegetarian options, and rich sauces.
author: Ari M.

description: I've eaten here twice, and twice the food blew my socks off.   It's creative and incredibly delicious.   Highly recommended.
author: David A.

description: Enjoyed the fried chicken dish and pad Thai the most. Would recommend no more than 1 bowl of rice per three persons.
author: Vincent P.

description:
One of the best hidden gems of the Mission.

I brought a friend who loves Thai food and she was blown away!

The vibe is really cool and the food is stellar.

Surprisingly my favorite part was dessert! Bread pudding ftw!

We got chicken wings, pad see ew (my favorite), a special that night with noodles and meat in a clay pot and so much more.

If you are going out to eat Thai food go here. It's romantic and cool. Great for groups or just you and your hunny :)
author: Taylor S.

description: Excelent food tanks nice place for sure we came again tanks tank great great great we highly recommended
author: Mejia Nery P.

description: AMAZING SERVICE. The staff was very friendly. It was a very fun atmosphere that was unexpected. There were colorful lights, loud music, and the waiters were in fun outfits. Our food came quickly (before our drinks) and was very good.
author: Erica H.

description:
I loved the cute, hipster farmhouse interior, and I loved my lunch here even more.

- Thai Fish Cakes ($9): Really enjoyed this, especially with the cucumbers, and the addicting sweet chili sauce. I don't think it's for everyone though due to the texture, which is very similar to Japanese kamaboko (that pink stuff that you get in a bowl of udon) or the fish balls you put in hot pot
- Tom Yum Noodle Soup ($15): Good amount of seafood inside, and the broth was spicy and super flavorful. Loved that the egg noodles were cooked well, not soggy at all. The crispy wontons(?) on the side were a nice touch too.
- Hat Yai Fried Chicken ($16): HIGHLIGHT of the meal! The fried chicken's breading was so so amazingly crispy on the outside. And the yellow curry was the most flavorful yellow curry I've ever had. So naturally, I smothered the fried chicken, the roti, AND the blue rice with it as I was eating.

On top of the taste of the food, service was attentive and friendly, and the dishes had really colorful and playful presentation (aka good food Instagram material). 

Definitely the most unique Thai meal I've ever had, and one of the tastiest!
author: Sara L.

description:
Okay WTAF.. 

"Thai fusion?" I scoff..

"Yeah" replied our host.

It takes me a grand total of 30 minutes to (gladly) eat my words.

This place was beyond epic during our visit.  Every single tastebud got lost in an experience that hit me on so many levels.

Not "gentle nice experience" either..

I'm taking OMGWTFBBQ "I won't ever forget this meal" type experience.

And yes, I couldn't resist..

Had to have the fried chicken.  

Dear god.  Such a delicate flash-fried almost tempura batter.  Easily the most moist chicken I've had in my life.  And with that curry and roti?  Are you kidding me? 

If I die fat and happy, it's because of this dish.
author: Chad L.

description: Wild and crazy restaurant!!!  Fun and the food is great!!!  Definitely one of the more hip places in SF!!!  It is a must!!!
author: Jan D.

description: I ordered take out here and I would like to come  back and actually eat here. The place was bumpin'! A very loud, fun atmosphere. They have a  birthday conga line which was entertaining (I got to see it while I was waiting  for my food). As for the food, I enjoyed the garlic chicken with rice. The coconut soup was good, a little on the sweet side, but I realize a lot of places make it that way. I want to go back with more people and try more of the menu!
author: Zoey M.

description: Outstanding flavors in an outrageous atmosphere. Sign me up. One of the best Thai incarnations I've had outside of Thailand.  Everything we tried was dynamite--yellow curry, pad se ew, crab fried rice.  Sooooo flavorful!
author: Aryn B.

description:
Farmhouse has quickly become a staple for my boyfriend and I, and therefore, it is hands down my favorite Thai spot in SF. Go if you like flavorful, TASTY, delicious Thai food with a bit of spice. 

The hefty portions are affordable in comparison to other "hip" Thai/Asian Fusion restaurants in SF), and the best part is that the food is TASTY (did I already say that?). If I could dream of what authentic Thai food tastes like, Farmhouse is pretty much close to what I would expect the real deal to be. As someone who personally loves salty, flavorful foods, Farmhouse nails the Hat Yai Fried chicken with curry, naan, and blue rice. The batter on the chicken has the perfect crunch and isn't dried like many other Thai fried chicken dishes that I've tried. My favorite part about this dish is the curry that's included - it simply makes everything all the more creamier and tastier! My boyfriend typically orders the Panang Neua, which is a slow braised bone in short rib in a panang curry with grilled broccolini, bell pepper, and blue rice. This is literally to die for. Again, I'll highlight the curry, which makes this dish as it adds creaminess, flavor and spice to the beef. 

Bonus points for a fun, well decorated atmosphere! For a second, you might almost forget that you're in SF. 

*Caveat: although I deemed Farmhouse 5 stars, I must mention that the service can be off sometimes (the staff has forgotten to put an order in, mixed up an order, etc). But, the food and atmosphere is so worth it that I couldn't not give it 5 stars.
author: Jazzica D.

description:
Wow.  Just wow. We ordered the fish cakes and samosas for appetizers.  Both were super good.  

Ordered green curry with pork and the river prawn pad thai.  Along with blue rice.  Again super good. 

Service was really attentive.

The homemade video at the front was pretty entertaining.
author: Herb L.

description:
Some of the most delicious samosas I've ever had! I ordered the yellow Tofu curry as my main entree. With the side roti, blue rice and the big bowl of curry, the entree was A LOT of food. I could hardly eat it all, and almost wish I had known how big the portions would be so I could split it. 

Not the most vegeterain-friendly Thai though. Originally I had planned on ordering the Papaya salad, something a little less hearty and rich than curry, but was told the dressing used wasn't vegetarian and that there was no way to alter this dish to make it vegetarian. Kind of a disappointment and slightly annoying since Papaya salads are normally a veggie go-to (and how hard is it to just not add dressing to a salad?)

The ambiance of the restaurant is dressy, lively, not too noisy, low-lighting, hipster-Thai fusion fun. I went here for my birthday and would recommend this place for special occasions!
author: Jackie K.

description: This restaurant is more about the experience. Presentation is great and the fun ambiance makes it great for groups. (Make a reservation). Had the fried chicken and the panang curry, which were both good but slightly too sugary. Minus one star for charging extra for the rice that comes w the curry.
author: Christine K.

description: Food was light, tasty, cooked to absolute perfection! It was quite obvious that care went into the preparation
author: LT B.

description: This place is very yummy but the prices are sorry high. $11 for spring rolls? $17+ for an entree?? Sheesh!!  The food is really yummy and when I want to splurge then definitely a good place to go.  Just a heads up lunch time is a lot quieter then dinner. Dinner time this spot turns into what they think a Thai night market is like
author: M S.

description:
Score! This place met every expectation I anticipated for! I found it on yelp, made a reservation through yelp and could not wait to dine here, I really was very excited to try it out! 
Friday night we walked over from the office (1.6 mi. from Hayes Valley). BEWARE: Florida st and Treat is crackheads ghetto - Yikes! But it's ok, me and my gal pal made it through alive! SUGGESTION: Uber it. 

Once we walked in, it felt like we left San Francisco and entered Thailand! The host/waiters were in costume or I should say, traditional Thai attire, and they all spoke with thick Thai accents; quite authentic. (Our jaws dropped). They asked if we had a reservation and I said, yes, so they immediately seated us. The decor on the other hand was so cool, very trendy with a modern twist. There was a wall display of water faucets with red handles.. hundreds of them, visually a pretty cool concept. The decor didn't seem to have any authentic Thai theme/motif, but it suited the place and I loved every inch of it. The overhead lamps looked nautical, I'm not sure if there is an intentional "water" theme of some sort, but whatever it was, it looked great! 

Where do I begin with the food.. Ugh.. There's so much to say.. As I expected everything to be delicious.. It was! We ordered all the waiters suggestions:
Ahi Tuna appetizer - BEEE-U-TIFUL presentation and excellent tasting. 
Phai Char Shrimp - came with veggies and blue rice - Yum!
Beef plate (not the beef noodle soup) - meat was so flavorful and tender it fell off the bone. Came with veggies and blue rice - perfection!

THEN.. came a little Thai man, in his Thai attire, carrying a pretty Thai display of Thai food. (Where has he been my whole life?!) Optional for $7 he offered a spicy red curry chicken bowl with veggies. The combination of fresh veggies was presented in a bowl made out of banana leaves to mix in with the red curry chicken).  Uhhhh.. Yes please! 
We gobbled that right up! 

If there weren't people around giving me dirty looks, I would have licked all the dishes clean.. ! 

We washed everything down with a nice cold Belgium beer; much needed to cool the spice! 

Finally, dessert.. The chocolate thingy. (I forgot the name). It's the only chocolate item on the menu, served warm, you can't miss it.. It's so good, included vanilla ice cream! 

We ordered a lot, bill came to $88 for 2 people including tip. I have to add, the service was exceptional, everyone was so kind and respectful, and humble I may add. 

There,  that's it, I got it off my chest.. I absolutely loved this place! Location kinda sucks, border lining the crackheads ghetto. (Further down on Florida St at the corner of Treat.)   however, the restaurant is located in a residential area, looks as though it's a new development (not sure), but street parking is available. 

Yes, I'll be back again and again and again..
author: Anie L.

description:
The food here is delicious with awesome service to match.

We ordered a bunch of items from the menu, but the Beef Wrap Rolls were absolutely the most flavorful and mouth watering.

I came here with my girlfriend and another couple we were double dating with. Our experience here was incredible. Definitely will be back to try more dishes.
author: Josh L.

description:
One of my fave places to grab dinner. I've been here a number of times with family and with friends and kiddo in tow. The staff here is very friendly and accommodating. I suggest going with a group and sharing so you can taste a variety :)

Some of my fave dishes to order:

24hr beef noodle soup (4/5) - Slow cooked bone-in Beef Short Rib with egg noodles. SO GOOD. Very flavorful and leaves you wanting more with each bite.

Crab Fried Rice (4/5) - Great dish to share with a group. Chunks of sweet crab. Served with a side of chicken broth.

Grilled River Prawns Pad Thai (4/5)- I'm a sucker for pad thai and pad see ew. But this pad thai has such a great balance of the sweetness and slight sourness. 

Hat Yai Fried Chicken (5/5) - My fave dish here. It's like fried chicken and roti and rice. How could I say no? So tasty! The chicken is always moist and fried perfectly.
author: Tiffany L.

description: This place is every bit as amazing as the reviews say, even with high expectations going in they still managed to surprise and excede them! The food is amazing, that's a given- we had the hat yai fried chicken, the neua yang steak, fried prawn appetizer (mieng kum kung) and then had dessert (pung) which was a sweet bread, black sticky rice, coconut ice cream and some green sauce. All delicious. The restaurant itself is so much fun- the atmosphere is so festive and it really feels like a celebration. I will definitely be back here.
author: Debra D.

description:
Seriously such a wonderful dining experience with some delicious dishes.  I love Thai food and I loved the flavors in all of the dishes we ordered (please see pic!).  The service was also great!! 

I've been raving about it to friends and families -- Can't wait to come back!
author: Siv L.

description: Authentic thai...great atmosphere.
author: Amey K.

description: Two words: Curry, Pad Thai!! very delicious, will be coming back with my family very soon! maybe for Mother's Day!
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Love this thai place. 

Food - quality and quantity are great! The food tastes amazing!

Location - great location and has lots of parking around the block. Easy to get to as well.

Staff - the people that work here are super friendly. They really care for you and try to seat you asap.

Service -  the service is fast even when they are super busy. The staff always checks up on you and makes sure your wants and needs are met.

Overall i would highly recommend this restaurant to all thai food lovers or if you want to try it.
author: Mark M.

description: It was mad lit tbh that chicken was crispy as a mf and I don't think that one can truly understand chicken until they eat the fried chicken here. Is that a good idea?? Maybe but maybe not because now I see fried chicken in a whole new light. Please try it. I implore you yelp friends!!!!
author: Yoona C.

description: Love the ambience of the place however, food was standard if not overpriced.  We had a group of 12 and had so much left over.  Staff and service was great though.
author: Emily H.

description: This place instantly became one of my favorite restaurants in the city (not just Thai). The food is phenomenal and atmosphere equally on point. Fun and energetic.
author: Andrew M.

description: My friends and I came to Farmhouse for the first time after looking at so many positive reviews, but we were seriously disappointed. The service was average, and the pad see eew and pad thais were ordered were unremarkable at best. In fact, the latter tasted pretty odd. Our portions were also pretty small, considering each dish was 15 dollars. The one perk was the Thai tea with shaved ice, which was very sweet but still delicious. Overall: we won't be coming back here.
author: Natasha A.

description:
Very fun twist on traditional Thai, which usually has delicious food and terrible ambiance. This place is between Mission and Dogpatch and has a combination of interesting entrees, Thai street food dishes, and awesome curries. 

Seems like a good place to celebrate a birthday with friends - you pretty much get a full band singing happy birthday to you. Can't wait to go back!
author: E F.

description: So I used to love this place. Have been going here for some time, also order from here often. I have been rooting for farmhouse for so long and have spread the word to everyone how great it is. Now, I don't normally write reviews, this is actually my first ever review. Today, I was so beyond disappointed I felt compelled to write my first review. I had a reservation at 9:30pm. Which I understand is late. I came in and they sat us down very quickly. Then we received a very rushed server with attitude asking us if we knew what we wanted. Understanding that it's late and last call was in 15 min, we quickly responded since we've been here many times and know the menu inside and out. I could easily wave the rushed order, that's understandable, But that's not what disappointed me. So our order comes out, our usual, 2 chicken noodle soup dishes but it comes completely plain, no spice, although it says on the menu (SPICY!!). We order this almost every time we come here so we know how this dish is, and what we're signing up for since it normally comes out pretty red. Again, the plain soup was very understandable. Maybe miscommunication. So when we had a look of disappointment, they asked what's wrong and we let them know we're sorry but we usually order it spicy, and that it's okay we can keep them as they are. They took it back quickly without saying anything and come out rushing with new dishes and slammed it on our table. We would understand if it was busy at the time, but the Resteraunt was half-full. They were just trying to get people out fast. The dishes were un-editable spicy. I mean dangerous. I have never received this dish so outrageously, vengefully spicy. I had 2 bites before I had to quit. I saw copious amounts of large red chili flakes I have never seen in the dish before the other times I have ordered this. It's the kind that hit your throat and make you cough. They weren't supposed to be in there. I am so disappointed they would rather hurt their customers to prove a point, or try to fulfill a request so haphazardly that they added a sick abnormal made-up amount of spice to a dish. The next day, we were both sick to our stomachs, whether it was from the spice or food poisoning, I don't know. I have never been so disappointed with a Resteraunt. Eat here in the evening/night with caution. The service will be terrible.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Seven words for you: 24 hour beef noodle soup uggggggggggghhhhhhhhhhh yeeeeeessssssssss

I have dreams about this soup. Try it.
author: Savanah T.

description: I just wish they had more vegetarian options (ie vegetarian Som Tum). But my girlfriend who's family is from Thai couldn't get over how authentic and good their food was. Reminded us of Essan. Also this place has a very fun atmosphere and ambiance so it was perfect for our date night.
author: Peter B.

description: Great service, great food, amazing cocktails and a lively atmosphere. The pork belly in the yum moo krab salad was unlike anything I've ever had before. So unbelievably crispy, yet chewy and a lot of it. Also had a cocktail with elderflower, cava and rose bitters that was so super tasty. Will definitely be back.
author: Shelby S.

description: The atmosphere was fun but the food fell pretty flat, it wasn't bad, just meh. I would try it again if someone suggested it but I could easily forget about it.
author: Kristen B.

description: Went with a part of around six and everyone really enjoyed their meal. I got the pad kee mao and it was delicious. Only critique is that the dish said "spicy!!" next to it, but was 100% mild. I realize there's a lot of people that don't do spicy foods, but if it says spicy next to the item, it should have SOME spicyness to it.
author: Ryan J.

description: The food was inventive and delicious.  The restaurant is well decorated also.   I like the menu, and hope to go back soon.
author: Michael E.

description: I love the food here! Probably the best in SF but the service can feel a little rude. As much as I loved the food and designed, feeling rushed by servers is never fun!
author: Rasela L.

description: This was billed to us as best Thai restaurant in San Francisco. Was good ambience and vibe, but food was a disappointment. Salmon was over cooked and flavorless. Steak salad had mediocre pieces of meat, too much chili oil and not enough greens. Fried rice was dull. Best dish was pad Thai--which was solid but nothing to write home about. Maybe we just had an off meal, but won't be back to find out.
author: Itai D.

description: I love this place! If you eat the specials, it can be a really high end, delicious meal. If you go for the most popular stuff (fried chicken) it is still pretty good. This place is really delicious, high end fusion Thai.
author: Ryan E.

description: I don't have a sophisticated review of each dish I tried here. I just came here to say that this is the best food I've ever eaten at a restaurant! The service was fast even though the place was packed. The host and the servers were very accommodating. You can tell they are a good team! I love the yellow curry here sooo sooo much. I try to eat here every time I'm in SF. Plenty of vegetarian options! Can we also just appreciate how they respond to Yelp reviews with such consideration? I see you! ;) :)
author: Elliott Y.

description: Hands down one of my favorite Thai places. Can you has a lot of depth and most items are done very well. There's way more to this place than the typical thai fare. I highly recommend any yellow curry dishes with roti. I like the fried chicken a lot as well. The ahi tuna appetizers were also very nice.
author: Anant P.

description: Good Thai place. Went here for a birthday. Big group. Good service and food. I would eat here again.
author: Karl K.

description: Khin Kao and this place are the my two favorite Thai places in sf. Dinner here is like attending a Thai rave. Lunch is more peaceful for you old fatties like me. Sucks to get old.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Cute exterior, interior, and servers ;) 

This place seemed a mix of hipster, artsy, and formal all at the same time. My sister and I went on a random Wednesday evening and there was parking right outside. We didn't have a reservation so they were going to place us in the middle of the room, but we said we preferred to be against a wall. Although we pointed at the booths, she took us to an awkwardly small table that was right next to the bathroom. Um.

But let me get to the important part - FOOD:
- complimentary salad (watch out, it has a kick!)
- hat yai - chicken was crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside. roti nicely chewy. curry consistency very watery; would be better to be less sweet to offset all the oil/fried stuff on the plate
- panang neau - blue rice was cool. just rice though? no special flavoring along with it. short rib was fall off the bone mmmm
- drinks: sparking peach jelly, coco lada - sister had both of these drinks lol. She was surprised at the jelly bits inside the 1st cuz you can't see it. Said she couldn't taste the alcohol. 2nd one, she liked better cuz it was lighter. This one seemed bottomless! She kept drinking but the level would barely go down lol 
- fried crickets - didn't try, but it was cool how there was a server going around asking if people wanted to purchase some to try it!

All of these had AMAZING visuals - large portions, great color themes on the plates. I honestly want to say that the taste of all of these didn't blow me away, but they were very filling and we loved the different textures and flavors that they included. Service was great in the beginning, but as it got busier into the night (nice diverse crowd, btw), they got slightly negligent. About $85 with tip for all this. So yes, on the pricey side, but considering SF and everything, very worth it. Happy bellies = happy experiences. 

*** TL:DR - Cute and instagram-worthy + good food experience. I would come here again (b).
author: Joan Y.

description: Mixed. The menu and ambiance were exciting, and the tom kha ga soup was AWESOME. Red curry was so-so and the service was RUSHY RUSHY - like over the top - we got PUSHED OUT. Uncool.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I was pretty excited to see that there was a Thai place with good reviews very close to me.  We went in for an early lunch and first impressions were really good.  The place was decorated very well and very modern.  There were still traces of new year decorations so it made the place really colorful and bright.  On one accent wall there was a art display of water hose faucets.  It was really cool and grabbed my attention instantly. 

Now for the food we ordered chicken wings to start and the waiter offered some egg rolls that weren't on the menu to try.  The wings were extra crispy and really good.  The eggrolls lacked some flavor and meat.  I didn't realize it was veg.  It came with the sweet dipping sauce but that didn't help much. 

Main course was pad ka pow with chicken.  It didn't come with rice, which I find to be a bit odd.  The waiter bought me some and to my surprise it was blue! Really cool as I've never had blue rice anymore.  The waiter assured me it is only food coloring and no flavoring is added.  The chicken was a bit over cooked.  As I bit into it, it tasted really dry and not tender at all.  However all the spices in the dish were really good.  Just a shame the chicken wasn't cooked right. 

My bf had the chicken curry which was served with eggplant and bamboo.  Again a bit of a let down.  There was something off about the curry.  I can't really describe it but it didn't taste like how I expected it to taste.  Kind of a sharp unappealing taste.  It really is a shame since this is so close and it looks so chic inside!

I may give it one more try since we live so close.
author: Nyla K.

description: Beautiful sweet people here, wild yumi food & just delightful! Celebrate your Birthday here
author: Rani N.

description: Worst place ever. Vegetables were old and browning. Food was slightly cold. Several orders were incorrect. Horrible customer service once informed of the mess up with the orders. Do not recommend this place for takeout.
author: Parabh J.

description:
Farmhouse is near the top with Kin Khao for posh, Thai food, and apparently everyone in the Mission agrees because both times I've been there have been a wait - make a reservation! In order to have a positive experience, I think it's essential you order the right dishes. 

Order These:
* Chai Latte - 4 stars: Creamy, rich, flavorful. So good.
* Herbal Rice Salad - 3.5 stars: If you like Burmese tea leaf salad you would love their take which includes purple, herbal rice. It was a little too sweet for me, but a must-order for first timers.
* Panang Neua (short rib) - 4 stars: Fall off the bone tender, and great flavor. Note: The beef still has some structure, but I enjoyed it still.
* Beef Noodle Soup (short rib soup) - 4 stars: Soup version of panang neua (so choose one or the other).
* Coconut dessert - 5 stars: Fresh coconut served with sticky rice. MY GOD. So fresh and so good, and I don't even like fresh coconut much. 

Pretty Good:
* Bacon wrapped Scallop - 3.5 stars: Good, juicy, and bigger than other places. A little pricey though at about $3/pop. 
* Thai Crispy Rolls - 3.5 Stars: Clear noodles in egg roll format. Good, but could be more flavorful. Would get again.
* Spicy Eggplant Side 3.5 stars: Good, but standard. 

Pass on These:
* Chicken Satay - 2 stars: Dry, served with sauce that tastes straight up like peanut butter. Liked the roti.
* Kai Yang (BBQ chicken) - 2 stars: Pros: smokey, comes with papaya salad and sticky rice. Cons: Sticky rice seemed under-cooked. Chicken was dry and mushy at once, didn't like the flavor. $18!
* Tom Yum - 3 stars: Pretty average flavor. Prefer the 24-hour beef noodle soup.
* Green curry noodles: A little bland, especially when paired with the noodles.
author: Jess C.

description:
Love this place! 
very colorful, inviting place, always a good time! 
The menu is just the right size, many traditional and some not so traditional items on there. 
Beer and wine only, but they do have some interesting cocktails with the unfiltered rice wine. 

I've eaten there several times and never had a bad dish, and everyone at the table was happy. Price is right, very fair. 

It can be a little loud on the weekends, but that kinda adds to the vibe. 

I am eating the leftovers today for lunch and it still tastes so good ! 

We will be back time and time again.
author: Adrian M.

description: Such a great restaurant! Friendly service, quick turnaround on orders, delicious food and an amazing ambiance. We will certainly be coming here again when we're back in SF!
author: JackieAaron B.

description: Amazing atmosphere! I love the authenticity to their cuisine. Take your white friends, they won't know how to act LOL.
author: Malalay S.

description: Overpriced and gimmicky. I actually liked it the first time I came here, but $25-$28 for a short rib is really steep. It was tasty but I would not pay that much for it again. The second time I came back with some friends, and it was super busy. In fact, it was so busy they had three birthday rituals when we were there. It's a ritual where the workers bang on tin and sing really loudly - distracting when you want to just sit and enjoy food. In fact, the entire restaurant is dark and loud which made it really hard to talk to friends. This time we all ordered the fried chicken, which was really thin chicken breast that wasn't very spectacular. I wouldn't spend the money to go through this again.
author: Ashley T.

description: Be warned, this is the place for birthday groups to come meaning lots of noise and singing. The place is over the top, but the food is great and its a fun atmosphere. The red curry is my favorite!
author: David S.

description:
The food at Farmhouse is SOOOOO GOOODDDD!!! 

Ambiance: Its like being at a resort in Thailand. Everyone is dressed up to look the part.
Food: Reminds me of Thailand
Price: Expensive 

This is not your everyday Thai restaurant but when you feel like treating yourself...I would give this place a try.
author: Amber D.

description: We had reservations for brunch so we were seated relatively quickly but the restaurant wasn't too busy. I ordered the Mok Salmon and that came out relatively quickly. The salmon was good and was filling enough but it started out a little dry and was juicy as I got towards the middle and end of it. The asparagus was cooked just right, not too soggy. The ambiance is nice and bright. They were playing traditional music mixed in with more modern tracks which added to the dining experience.
author: Gerard Y.

description: We have been in the restaurant 4-5 times since December and still love it. One comment about the service: we often feel as if the staff wants us to leave as soon as we are done with our food. We understand that the place is often busy, and many people are waiting, but we don't go to any restaurant just to eat. There is some sort of hectic atmosphere in this place. For example, I take the last piece of food from one of my pates and put my fork down; Momentarily one of the staff members​ grabs the empty​ place from the table. Just chill a little. Do it so that it does not look like you want me to leave.
author: Sophie N.

description:
Eh this place was overrated. Good thing I made a reservation through Yelp because it was very crowded on a Friday night! Cute, modern decor and food comes out quite fast.
We ordered the fried chicken and the beef shank. Huge portions! I liked the curry that came with the fried chicken but the beef shank was quite salty. Both dishes came with a scoop of pretty bluish purple rice. I tried the house soda as well and wasn't a fan. It reminded me of plum juice.
For dessert we ordered the Thai vacation which was vanilla ice cream served in a coconut with coconut meat and sticky rice, and requested to leave off the peanuts.
Service was kind of stifling. While you ate, they were nonexistent but as soon as you look full they seemed in a rush to make you leave. While we were waiting for the bathroom and check, a waitress bluntly said to me "A bunch of people are waiting for you to finish". I've never experienced something that blatant in a restaurant! I get it's busy but people should be able to enjoy their dinner before leaving. Not something I would try by myself again.
author: Sarina J.

description:
Food: I guess somehow it had one of the most expensive bowl of noodles I've ever had. 24 hr beef noodle soup. The noodles were decent but very small amount. Egg noodle. I'd be happy paying 15 to 16 bucks. But wow 23? It is a giant bone in short rib. Maybe that's why it's so pricey. But when all is said and done out the door with tip is 29 dollars for a lunch for 1 person. Hmmm. It's not so so so good that I think a bowl of noodle soup is worth that. 

I don't think I'd come back. It was busy though tons of people. The rest of the food seemed to be priced more normally. It's pretty trendy. Want to seem like street stall except you are paying hell of a lot more for it. Didn't really feel like a place I'd come back to. Like just a little too much for me.
author: P L.

description: Stopped by here for lunch: ordered Pad Shrimps and crab fried rice. The food was absolutely delicious. Authentic flavors, beautiful presentation.
author: Justin G.

description:
Please help me understand the hype? Maybe because I grew up in Berkeley I've been spoiled with amazing Thai food, but I really wasn't amazed by the food here. 

I tried the fried chicken dish as recommended and for me, the batter was a bit too soft. I would have liked it to have more crunch and carb as opposed to just melting in my mouth. The chicken, however, was very tender which I appreciated.

I also ordered the pad Thai. Again, I wasn't impressed and actually it was a bit too sweet for me. I ordered it with prawns, and to my delight, the prawns were nicely sized and cooked well.

For dessert, I ordered the sticky mango rice. Ok- this dish is was amazing and I most definitely may come back here just for this dish alone. The rice was a blue/purple color and it was super chewy and sweet. I also appreciated the way they sliced the mango to be extra thin and artful. Small details like that get me excited.

Overall experience: 7/10? Parking was also not easy.
author: Christine L.

description:
Solid place. The food is hearty and flavorful. The decor is very cute (I'm very amused by their wall of faucets. 

I highly recommend the 24 hour beef noodle soup, especially if it's cold outside! 
I also tried the Hat Yai fried chicken and Panang Neus, both are also good options. 

There may be a wait if you come during peak dining hours. Parking on the street. But staff is very friendly!
author: Cindy N.

description:
Unique, mouthwateringly-delicious Thai food, beautiful insta-worthy presentation/plating, and amazingly-cute decor and great laid-back vibes! 

I've been here four times in the past two months already (once with a party of 10! Great for groups, easy to make a reservation), and I would find any excuse to come here again in a heartbeat! Tonight, maybe? Highly likely. Great every time.

If it's your first time, I recommend sharing for two: Herbal Rice Salad to start (maybe an order of Thai crispy rolls or samosas too, both yum), definitely the Hat Yai Fried Chicken to share, and the mango sticky rice for dessert (mmm). Get a Thai iced coffee / tea or Whole Young Coconut too!

More detail:
**Hat Yai Fried Chicken 5/5 - Must-order. The crispiest, juiciest fried chicken ever. Not too heavy, and comes with a little bit of everything delicious: cucumber salad, yellow potato curry, roti, and blue saffron rice! Pretty large portion, so it can easily be shared between two if you order an app or two as well.
**Herbal Rice Salad 4/5 - Highly recommend trying this if you like Burmese tea leaf salads. This is almost like a Thai version of that. Great mix of textures and flavors! Love the crunch.
**24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup 4/5 - Delicious, flavorful broth, and the short rib meat falls off the bone
**Starters: Crispy Thai rolls 3/5, Samosa 3/5
author: Ashley S.

description: We were visiting SF and our friends recommended this place for dinner. Unarguably the best thai food I  had ever! Their thai fried rice and par dip tuna that we tried were awesome and am sure other dishes too will be equally good. The staff is very friendly and courteous. Service is quick and decent size portions. This place though gets very crowded even on weekdays, so make sure you reserve in advance and get their in time. Wish they had a presence in NJ or NY too.
author: Mil K.

description:
Amazing. Got braised short ribs which were perfect and crab fried rice. Appetizer beef roll.

Flavors exquisite.
author: Jenny B.

description: My friend brought me here a few days ago and I am obsessed. Will definitely be bringing some of my friends here to share the deliciousness!
author: Danielle S.

description:
We were hungry after rock climbing as we walk past this place and decided to give it a try.  It was about 2 pm, past the lunch rush and there were only a few people still dining.  Service was definitely not up to par... slow and inattentive.  We sat down and was basically forgotten.  
So.. we waved someone multiple times and got the "hold on" sign... 

Finally, ordered: 
-ahi scoop: piece of tataki ahi tuna over cucumber and bed of fried sweet potatoes.. it was spicy!! But a good bite! 
-mango salad with added salted crab: spicy and on the sweeter side.  Pieces of crab in the shell you gotta crab open and suck out the raw salty goodness.  
-beef curry with sticky rice: fall off the bone tender beef in a nice mellow sauce.  Sticky rice was chewy and the correct texture. 
-pad garlic ginger shrimp: portion was small but shrimp was nicely cooked.

Ginger milk tea was served in a cute cup, sweet and a tad spicy.  It was a great way to tone down the spice. 

Overall food was actually good, spicy though but I like that! 
Service definitely needs help! It was actually quite annoying.. but maybe we were just hangry..
author: Linda T.

description: OMG - The pad Thai was so hot it was not even edible.  We like spicy food but this burned the taste buds off my tongue.   And we had to wait over an hour and a half for the food - No Bueno!
author: Todd H.

description:
Very cute ambiance and wasn't too crowded! 

We ordered the following:
1. Crab fried rice
2. Pad see ew 
3. Chicken wings - MUST TRY, super crispy with delicious sweet dipping sauce! Save the sauce!!!*
4. Sweet and sour soup - I personally wasn't a huge fan of it
author: Grace L.

description:
We came with a group of 8 and every dish was delicious!  The restaurant is clean, spacious and the decor is very cute.
It's hard to find restaurants that will seat more than four people comfortably, so we were glad to not only find this place, but that we were able to reserve beforehand.

My ONLY complain was that the papaya salad was EXTREMELY spicy, no one in our table could take more than one bite.  I do spicy, but this was WAAAY crazy! I asked the waiter if they could change it, but they said that I could have asked for the sauce on the side, wait what? on the side? A papaya salad COME WITH the dressing, never on the side.  They should clearly indicate the level of spice.

Other than that, every dish is very flavorful and we were all happy :)
author: Rosa G.

description:
I work upstairs the restaurant, so let's say it's my cafeteria :) 
The 24 hours beef noodle with his amazing broth is  must try. I love the atmosphere and decoration.  The best Thai place I tried in SF so far (and I tried a LOT ).
author: Morgane M.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go for a celebration with a small to medium sized group. The atmosphere is fun and festive and the food is amazing. Everything I have tried I have loved and my friends have always walked away happy as well. They take reservations which is a huge plus in SF. The service is great and they do some fun stuff for birthdays :)
author: Sarah S.

description:
Food was delicious, service was excellent, and food was delicious (and made quickly!)
I also rather appreciated the lewk served by the host. Gave a very quirky San Francisco Mission vibe.
author: Kyle P.

description:
We started with fresh vegan spring rolls. They were so fresh with a spicy peanut sauce. The samosas were crispy with a delicious curry sauce. 
We had a delicious Thai tea and an even better  ginger milk tea. Perfect and not too sweet.
The food is absolutely spectacular. We had a very good Pad See Ew, chicken dish was very good, red curry was so amazing as was the Thai fried chicken. The presentation was beautiful and the service is friendly and efficient.
Unfortunately, the place is very loud, but there is a very festive atmosphere. They make a big deal for birthdays. There are a lot of families with kids. The music is loud and is Thai music.
Certainly the best Thai food I have ever had. We will go back next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Eveline H.

description:
Get the chicken and Thai vacation dessert

Starters
Neua num tok rolls- wagyu beef wrapped with mint cilantro cucumber 

Entres
Panang neua- slow braised bone in short rib
24 hour beef noodle soup- beef short rib egg noodle with veal broth with basil
Grilled river prawns pad Thai 
Hat Yai Fried Chicken Dinner -Thai southern style, mary's chicken breast, turmeric and herbs, fried shallots roti bread, potato yellow curry for dipping and rice.


Desserts
Thai vacation - vanilla ice cream with black sesame rice with sliced coconut meat and jizz like coconut milk with a sprinkle of nuts in your mouth was to die for
author: Andrew H.

description: The best Thai place you can find in the Bay Area. Love the 24 hours beef noodle soup.
author: SK W.

description:
The atmosphere was on and poppn on a Saturday night. Our hostess was rude though, glad she wasn't handling our food. 
The wait was an hour, which apparently is normal for a weekend. Had the pad Thai, asked for it spicy and it was. Very small portioned but delicious. The Thai tea was good , taste like Thai tea anywhere else. 
I was pleased.
author: Shakei D.

description:
Phenomenal food! 

Although a bit overpriced considering their portion sizes, Farmhouse is a great (vegetarian friendly) Thai restaurant. My friend is a vegetarian, so sometimes it's hard for us to eat out together, but Farmhouse made it very easy. From the delicious chicken wings to tofu stir fry, I could eat their food all day! 

I would come here regularly if it wasn't as expensive. I went to dinner with three girlfriends and it cost $35 for me without a drink. My girlfriends who got drinks paid about $50 each -- probably normal for San Francisco, but definitely not an every-week kind of thing. 

Also, for birthdays they don't give free dessert, but they will put a candle on a dessert you purchase and sing a really cool birthday song with lots of noisemakers included.
author: Joanna S.

description:
this place is super fun and great for birthdays! beautiful colors inside, very bustlin and great for groups. lots of exotic and delicious dishes on the menu. (nothing WOW'd me, but definitely well made)

- neua num tok rolls: delicious flank steak. even though it's called "rolls" its really just meat wrapped around veggies. super yummy (comes with 4 pieces), small portions but very delicious. 
+ yum moo krob: i'm a fan of pork belly, it was very crunchy. their vegetable:meat ratio was very off though. for something under the "salad" portion, there was hardly any salad to it. i enjoyed this dish, but for those looking for some veggies-- this is not it! also forewarned: its pretty spicy!
+ tom yum noodle soup: used egg noodles (wish they used white flat noodles instead womp womp) but still great, with lots of variety of seafood!
+ panang neua: my favorite dish! slow braised bone with blue rice (yummm)

overall, this place had amazing atmosphere, with good food! will be coming back here with large group of people!
author: Cathy Y.

description: Farmhouse is quickly becoming one of my favorite Thai lunch spots. Though pretty filled with techies on their lunch, they can usually easily slip in 2 of us if we arrive just after the rush. I love the Tom yum soup, the Thai fried rice, cucumber salad, and fried chicken. It's a little pricier than I'd normally spend (hence the 1 star loss) but the food presentation is gorgeous, authentic tasting, and service professional and attentive.
author: Tessa M.

description:
we really liked the creativity and hip vibe. and loved the kickboxing bowl drink and the fried grasshoppers lol.  Fish cakes come with the best cucumber salad I have ever had.   its def an interesting and lit experience to eat here.

however, pad thai is a huge disappointment to us -- not much spice, way too sweet, not even lime juice to make it fresh and authentic.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
The first time we came was for lunch and we're delighted that it wasn't crowded and excessively loud. I think it was 3:30 on a wet Saturday. They left such a good impression with food and service we made it a point to come back ASAP! 

We came back for a birthday and at night this restaurant is busy and bustling with a very loud and fun atmosphere. I usually stay away from loud places because I like to talk but here is an exception. Coming here is a blast! At one point there was a guy with a cart going around to all the tables with Flank Steak appatisers. This was great because we needed a snack. 

Have your birthday here on Saturday night; it's a party! Raise your voice a little and really laugh out loud.

Spicey Fish Cakes - great!
Green Curry with Chicken - loved it.
24HR Beef Noodle Soup - wonderful.
Herbal rice salad - on point.

Later on some street vendor looking dude balancing a funny bamboo contraption on his shoulders was serving bite size desert things. Very cool. If you're looking for a place to impress your friends and family from Iowa bring them here.

The value here is exceptional. This is not cheap but the food is a home run. The pictures helped a lot; you can see the quality.

We will be back.
author: Justin S.

description:
Such a cute place for lunch! 

The service is wonderful, they're polite and quick to check on you if you need anything! 

We ordered the Thai crispy rolls for the appetizer, which we surprisingly really enjoyed! We had the pad thai and pad kee mao for lunch, which were very delicious. 

This is one of the better Thai places I've been to, everything is fresh and they put cucumbers in the water- a nice touch :)

I would definitely recommend this place if you're in the area!
author: Letty H.

description: Best Thai in SF. This place is always packed for a reason so you better have a reservation. The yellow curry is a personal favorite, but everything on the menu is solid. Great service every time as well. Love it!
author: Scott C.

description: I can't dance for shit but the silly upbeat music that blared through the speakers made me want to boogie at the dinner table. It looked like some of the guests who were waiting to be seated felt the same as they bobbed their heads uncontrollably to the tempo. In the meantime, one of the servers snaked through the restaurant while balancing baskets of snacks on his shoulders. I was delighted and stimulated by these funny gimmicks.
