- pad see you with ground pork - this was great!! - strong delicious flavors and good ratio of protein to noodles (actually could probably use more noodles).  

- dessert platter - loooooved this.  The bread pudding was phenomenal as was the warm chocolate cake (decadent yet not overly sweet, my fav).  

Love the ambiance in here as well - nice combination of feeling like your in Thailand but also at a hipster Mission place (if you can imagine that)
author: Olivia T.

description: The food was soulful, full of flavor. Every bite had that balance of taste, flavor and aroma of great cooking. Ambience was cool - bit loud for the great food but okay. I would have given a 5 star for great food, service and ambience but I do that once I have tried at least 3 times and find it consistent. PS - toilet was also clean which is a good measure for a great restaurant.
author: Sachin P.

description:
Farmhouse Kitchen is a surprisingly authentic and delicious Thai restaurant in the less-traversed part of the Mission. I gathered a bunch of friends here for dinner Saturday night.

First of all, the plates are YUGE. Good luck finishing one yourself unless you have a big appetite. Most of my friends ended up splitting two dishes, which ended up being the smart thing to do. We also split some appetizers: Thai fish cakes and calamari with cilantro lime sauce. Enjoyed these, but nothing too special. I'd recommend skipping the appetizers since the entrees are so filling.

The Hat Yai ($18) seems to be the most popular dish here, and it did not disappoint. The chicken was so flavorful and roti bread was perfect for dipping into the curry. The blue rice was a bit novel but didn't actually taste too different than white rice. While I loved the 24-hour beef noodle soup ($18) with slow cooked bone-in beef short rib and veal broth, I do wish there were more egg noodles. The short rib was unbelievable. Both entrees were really solid!

The restaurant itself is trendy as hell and roomy enough for large groups. In fact, there was a table of 20+ people sitting behind us! However, it's very popular on weekends, so get here early or make a reservation.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Since the first time I came to Farmhouse Kitchen it became my favorite Thai spot in San Francisco. I first came here on a date night, and it was super fun since they had part of the staff performing and dancing. I also loved their street food offerings. My favorite dishes on the menu are:

- Panang Curry
- Samosas
- Herbal Salad
- Ahi scoops

Definitely try to get reservations every time you plan to eat here; otherwise expect to wait long, especially during the weekends. I've been many times and even have ordered delivery in the past. I simply can't get enough. It is my favorite neighborhood restaurant.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: The 24 hour slow cooked beef and noodles was to die for .. it's definitely a must try.. the short rib was full of meat..the broth was tasty.. the atmosphere was very trendy, nice and clean.. service was great! I will defintiely be back..
author: Rochell S.

description:
Because the reservation was full at the dinner section, we went there earlier, about 3:30 PM on Saturday. And there were only about 10~12 customers dining. No need to wait. Wow, how lucky we were! The weather was good, the environment was bright, and people there were all with the great smile. Such a relaxed atmosphere that I would recommend people who like to take dinner earlier just come here.  

We had 2 special: Neua Yang Steak & Panang Neua, and 1 classical Thai tea. The steak in medium rare tasted good, and the sauce was worthy to try for people who love to explore new flavors--the combination could give you some new inspiration. And, I really like the ginger rice with the steak. It was not too hard nor too soft, just right.  
As to the Panan Neua, I love it! Although it was really a big size for me that I could only finish about half of it, I still couldn't stop. When those multi vegetables went with the super delicious curry sauce and the hashed sweet potato, not only the flavor but also the texture became a nice balance as a whole. In spite that the blue rice looked good but not a too surprising taste, I was still conquered by this entrée. 
By the way, their Thai tea smells good. It seems like certain distinctive herbal added. However, it is still too sweet for me. But, after all, a really nice experience to dine here. Recommend!

慕名而來，我們沒訂到晚上的位子，於是提前下午來試試。大約三點半抵達，客人不多，完全不用等待，用餐感覺也格外清爽、悠閒，非常推薦想在下午用餐的人此時前來！

我們點了Neua Yang Steak和Panang Neua(short rib)兩個主餐，牛排醬料確實帶有泰式香料獨特的風味，搭配起來頗感新鮮，牛排附的薑飯口感微硬，烹煮得剛剛好。short rib份量相當大！但搭配的咖哩醬非常美味，加上底下鋪墊著洋蔥、甜椒、青花菜等豐富的蔬菜，以及地瓜小炸塊增添口感，好吃得讓人幾乎停不下來！雖則藍色的飯，嚐起來不如視覺上來得驚喜；他們家的泰式奶茶，對我來說，也還是太太太太甜了...不過，整體而言，還是非常推薦唷！
author: Anne C.

description:
This neighborhood was packed when I came here last Friday around 8pm. There was absolutely no parking for blocks in radius and we were JUST about to give up and go somewhere else when a car pulled out right in front of the restaurant and we were able to snag the spot! Inside is bigger than it looked on the outside, with nice decor and a shiny stone wall on one side where the bar is. The place was fairly packed and parties waiting by the door to get their seats. Luckily we made an advanced reservation and waited only 10 minutes. This place is very loud, casual dressing, mostly white collar people wanting to relax after a long week. 
I ordered the panang curry with seafood combo, with the famous blue jasmine rice plus extra roti bread, that was crispy and fresh pan fried. Reminds me of a green onion pancake without the green onions. The flavor of the curry was strong, sweet and spicy, embedded with calamari, shrimp, pieces of tender fish fillet (tilapia?), chopped red peppers and fresh basil leaves. I drank it up. The rice tastes normal, just blue, so no hesitation needed if you got it and didn't know what to expect.
The boyfriend ordered a tom yum noodle soup with seafood as well. Same types of seafood as mine, flavorful broth and he ate all the noodles! So I think he liked it. :)
Oh yeah they also gave us pickled radish and carrots, sweet and sour, like Vietnamese style.
There was also a man carrying two dishes on a stuck on his back, offering free samples of something but we were too full at the end of our meal to try. It's a fun plus to have though.
Overall, I enjoyed the experience. It truly reminds me of Kitchen Story, with the menu it offered, but just a way bigger and louder crowd. If the parking wasn't so bad, I'd be inclined to come back, but I have to stick with Kitchen Story since it's much closer and more intimate.
author: Alice S.

description: We drove through Nob Hill into Mission to get to this place. Great location because there are parking spots right out front of the restaurant. Great staff and fun atmosphere. They were completely booked with reservations from 6:30 pm to 9 pm but they got our party seated without a reservation within six minutes (very accommodating). The food is divine. Get the steak cucumber rolls for an appetizer (full of flavor). Green curry is super spicy--I love it! Others got Pad See Wey (devoured the entire plate) and red tofu curry. Big portions. We really enjoyed this restaurant.
author: Allison C.

description: Waited 30 minutes and nobody seated me. Some servers were busy but other just stay by the bar and talk. They're friendly to big groups but not two people since they don't make much money from two I guess. They treated the big groups better and gave them more attention. Our waiter didn't check up on us at all. Terrible service and staffing. The food is decent but the service doesn't make me want to come back here.
author: Lexie H.

description:
I used to think all Thai restaurants were pretty much the same. But that all changed when I dined at Farmhouse Kitchen last night.

Sure, this restaurant offers the usual Thai suspects (curries, noodles, Tom Kah, papaya salad, etc.). However, what makes Farmhouse Kitchen stand out is their unusual menu offerings. I'm talking about dishes like Ahi Tuna Scoops, the Neua Num Tok Rolls (Grilled snake river farm wagyu flank steak wrapped with mint, cilantro, cucumber served with cilantro lime vinaigrette), and the Herbal Rice Salad (made with toasted coconut, peanuts, shredded green mango, crispy shallots, lemongrass, cilantro, sliced long beans, chili, kaffir lime, dried shrimp with tamarind dressing). And those are just the starters!

For my main course, I ordered the much-Yelped-about Hat Yai Fried Chicken (crispy chicken breast seasoned with turmeric and herbs, and served with fried shallots roti bread, and potato yellow curry for dipping. This dish more than lived up to its hype in both presentation and taste. My dining companions feasted on the Panang Curry Chicken, the 24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup (slow cooked bone-in beef short rib, egg noodles, veal broth, broccolini, basil, bean sprouts, cilantro, green onion and house pork fat garlic oil), and the Mekong Fish Cakes (White fish, fresh kaffir lime, red curry paste, sliced long bean served with cucumber peanut relish). Everything was beautifully plated and fan-freakin-tastic. Although I'm not much of a beer drinker, a bottle of Singha was the perfect way to balance the Thai spices.

Service was friendly and attentive. Given how busy the restaurant was, I was surprised by how quick the food came out. This kitchen is a smooth running culinary assembly line. They clearly know what they're doing.

Although we sampled a variety of dishes, we barely scratched the surface. I can't wait to come back and explore more of this eclectic menu.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I had a wonderful dinner at Farmhouse Kitchen with some great friends.  I was pleasantly surprised at the modern yet farmhouse ambiance paired with such interesting Thai cuisine.  Every item that we ordered was plated with such care and detail.  The flavors in the food were authentic and highly enjoyable.  Between the four of us, we had the pleasure of trying several dishes.

Two of my favorite dishes of the night were the Hat Yai Fried Chicken & the 24 hr Beef Noodle Soup.  The fried chicken was perfect in every way.  It wasn't too greasy, the chicken was moist on the inside and had wonderful flavor.  The beef noodle soup was superb, if you ask me.  The meat fell of the bone and the noodles were tender.  The flavor of the soup was absolutely comforting.  

I would definitely come back again for the food.  The wait staff was OK.  I didn't feel like customer service was all there.  They were prompt to take our order and also clearing the table was quick....but I felt customer service during the night was lacking a little.  Perhaps it was just an off night.
author: Vindy C.

description:
3.5 stars

Farmhouse is a quirky/hip Thai restaurant in the Mission. The food was pretty good, but service was not so great - we waited at least 10 minutes before anyone acknowledged us. When someone finally did, we ordered the Panang Neua (bone in short rib curry) and the Hat Yai (fried chicken with roti and potato curry dipping sauce and some sort of sweet sauce). Both were also served with blue rice, which made the dishes look really interesting, but it just tasted like normal rice. Not sure why it's blue.

My bf thought the short rib was OK; the meat was tough and the sauce was heavy, but the broccolini was a nice touch. I thought the Hat Yai was better; the boneless fried chicken was tender and had just enough breading and the dipping sauces were flavorful. I love roti, but this roti wasn't as soft as others I've had. We also ordered the "Thai Vacation" for dessert, which was vanilla ice cream, sesame, peanuts, coconut cream, and real shaved coconut served in an empty coconut shell.  It had a nice presentation and was delicious, but I would have preferred a more tropical ice cream flavor. All in all, a cool Thai restaurant, but I think you'd be paying more for the ambience than the food.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Not only is this the best Thai food hands down in the city, but also one of the best meals I've had. A true hidden gem on the outskirts of the Mission, this place is worth the trip. The Panang Neua will change your life and leave you licking the plate. Staff was friendly, prompt, and very cognizant of my dairy allergy. I have a feeling this will be the first place in SF I will become a regular at.
author: Sarah U.

description:
It was a good thing we made reservation in advance because when we got there around 7 there was a crowd of people waiting for tables by the door. 

The décor of the place was kind of hipster meets Thai land. Only saying that because of the wall of faucets.

Food was delicious, i think this is the best curry if my life!! The blue color rice was cool. 

Best service by far! Never needed to ask them for a refill, all the servers were knowledgeable, patience and attentive. Even thought there were a lot of people waiting, I did not feel rushed at all.
author: Fran C.

description:
Fantastic food and a fun atmosphere. It was packed on a Thursday at 8:30pm!
I had the fried chicken dish that was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. My dining partner ordered the vegetarian pad see yew and also enjoyed it. Next time we'll order the 24 hour beef soup - it looked amazing!
author: Zahra G.

description:
This place was so awesome! 

Some of the best Thai food I have had in the city. It was very authentic and I loved the ambiance. I recommend making a reservation if you plan on going on a weekend evening, as they get pretty crowded. 

We were here an evening where they had live music. Also, they had certain dishes that they would bring table side, but I'm not sure this is an every night thing. 

I highly recommend this place if you're looking for authentic Thai cuisine.
author: Jack J.

description:
Extremely overrated and overpriced. You are paying for expensive SF overheads and a hip scene. I get it, everyone is impressed by the fried chicken dish, but come on folks let's try to move beyond that novelty and look at the entirety of the menu . Would not eat here again. Here's a breakdown of the pros and cons:

Pros: 
-Fresh herbs, traditional pungent flavors
-Flavor profile of most dishes close to what you would get in Thailand versus Americanized Thai Cuisine (sweet and not herbal or complex)

Cons:
- pricing is ridiculously high for small portions. Many dishes run between $20- $28 for factory farm beef/pork.
- some dishes such as the rice salad ($14) are syrupy-sweet.
- green curry noodles ($20) are very disappointing. Simply a bowl of green curry with a small side of mushy overcooked vermicelli rice noodles. Again, not sure what justifies the price. Chicken was full of tiny very sharp bones. 
- dishes are small and not meant for Asian style sharing. When I asked for more rice noodles because there wasn't enough to share among the four of us, our waiter told us portions are meant to be for "one person only" we were then charged $5 for an additional tiny side of mushy vermicelli  noodles. Would one person really want to eat an entire bowl of green curry and nothing else? 
- fish cake was rubbery with no detectable kaffir lime. 
- despite use fresh herbs many of the dishes were not layered or complex. I love spicey but  every dish was overwhelming even thoughwe ordered medium. This place was so one-dimensional couldn't taste any of the other flavors. This is a typical trick of some new Thai places to make people believe they're eating authentic Thai food by simply cranking up the heat.
- the tarot and rice dessert is unimaginative--simply mashed Taro on top of a bed of rice with sugar and some coconut milk.
- at least four or five times the waiter tried to take away dishes that still had plenty of food on them. We found ourselves fighting him off for the majority of the meal. It eventually became so comical that at least it brought some good laughs.

The people running this restaurant are very smart and savvy, they've tapped into a very young "hip" consumer base in San Francisco that doesn't care about paying twice the price for something with no justification.

For those Thai food aficionados interested in an  authentic experience checkout the plethora of Thai restaurants on San Pablo Avenue in Albany which are less than half the price of Farmhouse.
author: Earls C.

description:
Um, this place is the freaking best. 

Service is lightning fast, still don't understand how 24 hour beef noodle soup can come out within 5 minutes (it seems like an oxymoron, no?). 

Anyway, per Eddie Huang's "Fresh Off the Boat", every cuisine has its own take on the beef noodle soup and the one at Farmhouse is comparable to anything you would taste in the Thai motherland. 

I can tell it's that good because my favored eating companion who is a bona fide BNS snob spoiled by Taiwan legitimately ignored me for 15 minutes because he was so preoccupied with eating. 

Also adding this to the short list of go-to chill places to eat with anyone if you want a solid sit down dinner.
author: Susan L.

description: Great Food, and a bunch of fun stuff to experiment: Fried intestines, Grasshoppers etc! The masaman lamb shank is awesome!!
author: Zaina H.

description:
This restaurant is a little gem in the outskirts of the Mission. Its been open for around a year but still a very hustlin' and bustlin' restaurant. The funniest part about this dining experience was the semi-erotic video they play by the front desk. 

Food wise I would recommend the Hat Yai dish which is a friend chicken dish with a side of yellow curry (w/ potatoes) and roti. Amazing flavors with the very unique jibe of yellow curry spices with the roti and friend chicken. These two dishes compliment each other's flavors.

To top it off most dishes come with BLUE RICEEE!! First time trying it and it was delicious.

BE AWARE the spicy meter is very hot here my buddy had got the green curry medium and he could only eat 2-3 bites (his tolerance for spice is above average).
author: Kunal T.

description: Found this place as I was searching for a ramen restarting in SF and I found this gem! It's as good as all the reviews claim. I had the Tom Yum Noodle soup and it was delicious! I had initially ordered the Shrimp Pai Thai and Austin changed my order without any problems. For desert I had the Thai vacation and it was also as good as expected. Can't wait to come back again when I'm in town!
author: Paola V.

description: Best Thai food I've had. Short rib, chicken wings, panang curry, spicy eggplant side dish and a few grasshoppers. Really neat kitschy atmosphere with the music, Hawaiian shirts and drum line bday celebrations. On the pricey side, but definitely worth it
author: Jeff M.

description:
Love this place. The food is way exceed my expectation. However, i wish the price w
could be cuter.
author: Alan J.

description: We love this place! The menu is interesting and the food is very well done. The atmosphere is kitschy and fun. Service is awesome. One of our favorite items is the short rib in curry.. but you really can't go wrong with the main dishes.
author: Urban S.

description: One of the better Thai restaurants I've been to. Very authentic flavors and very fresh. Decor is great as well. Highly recommended.
author: Michael P.

description: Best Thai food I've ever had. Hands down. I've been to a lot. Flavorful and good atmosphere.
author: Omar M.

description: Great food, service, and ambiance. Loved my salmon and the ahi tuna appetizers. Great portion and price. Very authentic feel and taste. I would recommend coming here for celebrations. Awesome vibe and song for celebrating birthdays!
author: Thu N.

description: Bomb Thai is all I gotta say.  Cute farmhouse modern decor and staff is super friendly.  I've had the basil chicken and pork and it's so good I have a hard time ordering anything else.  My friend had the Pad-See U (not spelled right) and it was good too.  I'd definitely recommend going before noon to beat the business lunch crowds.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Let's start with ambiance it is really adorable, modern meets old Thailand .

SERVICE: went on Yelp saw the great reviews made reservations for 2 . Walked in was seated in less then 5 mins greeted immediately by a waiter with water and menus .  Took our drinks back in less then 5 mins placed our order pretty much in at 8pm and out by 9 pm stuffed and satisfied .

FOOD: 
Appetizers -
Flank skewers 4 delicious flavored steak rolls. 
Pad Thai ( from the street food side ) yummy a little sour for my taste .

Main - 
Fried chicken - yes it's what everyone raves about and it was true . That dipping sauce OMG  had me duping everything in it  (rice , potatoes , flat bread) 

24 hour beef soup- that meat just fell right off and broth had every tastebud wondering what spice it was !!! There is an occasional spicy kick too it. So if you don't like spicy stick to the fried chicken . 

Drink -
Porter
author: S R.

description:
Tonight was my first experience at FarmHouse and while the food was fine I don't think I'd dine there again.  Our reservation was for 8:15 and we weren't seated until almost 8:30.  The restaurant is in a former pop-up space, and while the renovation is very pretty they didn't make much of an effort to improve the acoustics.  We were basically shouting the entire time we were there.  It's incredibly loud.

The waiters were very busy and rushed.  The service was attentive but not friendly. 

Overall the food was fine, but not special or delicious.  Our mango salad with crab was mostly crab shells and cabbage garnish; I'm not sure there was any crab meat in it at all. The portions were quite small, so not good for sharing.  Nothing really impressed us, especially for the price.  We had green curry, pad se ew, and the mango crab salad. 

The other frustrating thing is that for a fairly large restaurant there was only one bathroom.  There were lines the entire time we were there, but the interior of the bathroom was ENORMOUS.  They should really consider breaking it up into tow or three smaller bathrooms to help with the lines.
author: leah w.

description: The Panang Bone-in short rib is otherworldly. Juicy, tender, bursting with flavor. Loved our meal here. Really can't fault this place.
author: Joe L.

description:
3.5 stars

Stopped by for a weekday lunch and were able to be seated immediately. Service was good. Food was just good, presentation was beautiful.

We started with the papaya salad and I got the grilled salmon as my entree. The salmon was wrapped in bamboo leaves atop a bed of blue rice with a side of asparagus. The salmon was not too flavorful but it did come with a side of green sauce that I did not use.
author: Yin H.

description: The hat yai fried chicken is great but it HAS to come with the set which includes scallion pancake (meh, and cold) and curry. The chicken is very very good tho. Worth it. This places gets packed but they accept reservations. Last time we went the staff was in a hurry to get us out. They kept trying to take our food away and shoving the bill in our face. They asked my friend if they could take her food away the second she put down her fork to take a break. It was still FULL of food. Ridic
author: Wesley T.

description:
The place looked nice and we were excited to be here.  When the food and drinks came out, good presentations.  Though my friend think the ginger milk tea was a bit on the sweet side, the Mango salad was favorable.

As we were enjoying our lunch today with a varieties of dishes,  I chewed on a small piece of ROCK that was mixed in the Mango salad.  It almost broke my tooth!

Even though they didn't charged us for the salad but it made me wondered the standards of their kitchen practices and overall cleanliness of the food been prepared for the customers.  Not to mention my lunch was kind of ruined and I was wonder how rest of our dishes were prepared.  What other foreign objects might be masked in our dishes?  

It really makes me wonder should I bring my mouth guard next time or just move on.
author: Tkd K.

description: Dropped in to place a to-go order about 30 minutes ago. I didn't see anyone at the check-in desk so I proceeded to the bar. I sat there for a few minutes as 3, 4 workers walked passed me. After 5 minutes, I asked the man working behind the bar if I could place an order, he said I would have to go back to the check-in desk to place a to-go order so I did. The lady standing behind the check-in desk looked up and asked had I been helped, I said no and she continued entering another order. I figured once she was done, she would help me, nope! After entering the order she was working on, she walked over to the bar. I figured well maybe she had to go grab something from behind the bar but instead she proceeded to talk to her coworker and do other tasks. I waited another two to three minutes to be serviced then left. I don't want to make it a race issue but I will say their customer service is HORRIBLE. Will not be returning!!!!
author: Jamesha T.

description: Very good Thai food!  Also good service.  Also a comfortable albeit unusual eclectic dining hall.
author: Flint W.

description:
This place is bumping at night. It's definitely that hipster vibe for the millennials.

The food was A - OK. I thought that for the price you are paying, the dishes are actually quite small. The cool part - that blue rice. I got the penang curry and to me, it definitely tasted like a red curry. It wasn't bad, just not the best I have had.

Would I give this place a second shot? Definitely! If you're in the area and are looking for some thai cuisine, check it out.

They also have tons of dishes for vegetarians - another plus!
author: Laura C.

description: Some of the most incredible Thai food I've ever had! My friend brought me here when I was visiting from New York and the atmosphere, food, and everything was amazing! We shared a tom yum noodle soup and the fried chicken. Both were great - but beware the tom yum is SPICY!!! The chicken is great because it also comes with curry and bread and this cool blue rice so if you're looking to sample a couple different things, this is a great dish. Overall would absolutely come again!!
author: Karen X.

description:
one thing I love about being a parent: ordering more than we should eat and pretending "it's for the three year old." yeah, we already ordered the fried chicken with rice off the kids menu but blamed it on the preschooler for all the extra fluffs the hubby and I ordered.

get the samosas. tastes more like an empanada which was amazing with their curry dipping sauce. 

get the crust crusted tiger prawns "mieng kum kung".  

get the slow braised short rib "panang neua". the highlight of my night. it was so damn good and this is me saying this after being so damn full from the appetizers and drinks we had. husband was so jealous and somewhat looked like he was pouting with regret as he ate his "hat yai" fried chicken. don't get me wrong, "hat yai" is good if you want an all-in-one thai dish, olive garden type of tour of italy entree...it comes with your chicken, your roti, your curry which you can't go wrong with...until you get the panang neua. 

get the thai tea. strongly flavored and sweet.

get the thai vacation dessert. pass on the mango sticky rice.

get the coconut latte.

get more food from the servers coming around with street snacks.  

get reservations.

get your kids to come with you (they have a kids menu!) so you can claim a larger table like we did and order practically everything off their menu....then blame it on the kids.
author: Herissa C.

description: The food was really good and the service was fast! Evertime i finished my water, i didnt have to ask for refills. The wprkers were on top of it  I also ordered the bbq chicken with a side of papaya salad. The chicken was moist and well bbq'd. It was not dry. The chicken was also flavorful with whatever spices they used. The papaya salad was light, but it was more than just a taste of lime.Typically Thai papaya salad is lighter than laos style, but Farmhouse killed it ;) I will definitely be back!
author: Jade B.

description:
Can't say enough great things about Farmhouse Kitchen! 

Just to make your life easier, they allow reservations via Yelp, and they actually have your table ready at the time of reservation. 

Waiter always comes by and fill your drink as needed, and always checks in on you. 

Would not recommend the Kick Boxing drink bowl. Concept looked cool, but it just does not execute. 

Hat Yai Fried Chicken - Fried Chicken served with Rice and Roti with potato yellow curry
Papaya Salad  - Actually has some heat to it! 
Panang Neua - Pricey but still great!
author: Gaurav B.

description: Very great food and an impressive ambience. The vegetable dishes that I ordered were all delicious.
author: Anthony B.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in the city! The atmosphere and food are amazing. My favorite dish is the Hat Yai Fried Chicken - it comes with yellow curry, roti and blue rice.. soo bomb! My second favorite dish is the 24 hour beef noodle soup.. the broth is very flavorful and the beef is tender. All the desserts are great too! The service is always excellent. I always recommend this place to friends.
author: Rachel N.

description: Everything about this place and the experience was 5+ stars! From the customer service, the menu choices, the food and flavor. Will definitely making a trip back here soon.
author: April H.

description:
This is a really fun spot. Menu is diverse with a mix of thai classics and some interesting specials. Decor is very cool and somewhat eclectic, definitely feel the farmhouse idea. On Fridays, they pass around traditional thai street foods. I had fried grasshopper and my friends shared bbq pork skewers. 

Recommend: Pad See Ew and yellow curry! 

PS: Make reservations because this place is popular (and rightly so)
author: Eman A.

description: When I first walked into Farmhouse Kitchen Thai, I was pretty confused on the juxtaposition of traditional thai and farm like decor. It definitely added to the experience of eating there though! The two times that I have eaten here/gotten it catered was through my work place so warning... I didn't pay for either of my meals. I did however skim through the pricers and noted that this place is on the pricier side of thai food - but you're paying for the great atmosphere and flavorful, adventurous thai foods. The 2 appetizers that I have tried were really good - it was the vegetarian spring rolls (which surprisingly tasted good but it's because of the yummy peanut sauce it's served with) and the thai sausages (which were super flavorful and sweet...). I also was able to try the Pad See Ew, the Red Chicken Curry, and the Yellow Tofu Curry. All of these were very very tasty and full of flavor. I thought the portion sizes were kinda small as I could finish it on my own (which i usually can't). Overall, really reallly yummy tasting foods (but not sure if they are worth the price to you)! I probably won't eat here again unless taken by my work place, but that's because I have cheap taste buds ;) As I can remember, the service is quick and friendly!
author: Anna L.

description: Came here for a work lunch. The place is open  windows and high ceilings and lots of natural light. We got there at 1130 am because we heard that it filled up quickly. They sat us right away and were really friendly. We ordered Thai iced tea which came with this amazing ball of frozen condensed milk floating in the tea like a root beer float. It was perfect because you could add or leave as much milk as you would like. We then shared the vegan spring rolls which came with a nice thick rice paper wrap and the best peanut sauce I have ever had. For entree I got the crab fried rice which had sooo much fresh crab, it was a really great value for money. The portion was also huge and easily enough for two people. Finally a note on the bathroom, which is important and usually the mark of establishment. Cause let's face it if even the bathroom is beautiful, trendy and smells good then the owners and staff are truly committed not just to great food but the company. The bathroom is beautiful and spacious and yup it has a guest list.  I highly recommend trying this place. The food is fantastic and it's great for vegetarians and gluten free folks.
author: Anne S.

description:
I ordered $90 worth of food for delivery because of all the good reviews about this place. 

Unfortunately, I did not get to taste it because the delivery woman she said she could not find the where I was. I work at a hospital nearby and stood outside trying to navigate her to me for 10 minutes. She was extremely impatient and disrespectful. She finally said," DO YOU JUST WANT TO CANCEL THIS THEN?!" Like really?
 
I WILL RECIEVE A REFUND from Eat24 thankfully. BUT I DID NOT RECEIVE AN APOLOGY FOR THE RUDE CUSTOMER SERVICE I GOT FROM THE DELIVERY WOMAN OR THE RESTAURANT WHEN I CALLED THEM.


No bueno
author: Joanne I.

description: Food is extremely expensive for what it is but the environment is amazing it is extremely hip Thai restaurant. My girlfriend absolutely loved it.  Great for parties and cocktails with friends.
author: Josh N.

description: Good, with a nice range of dishes beyond the ordinary Thai restaurant in the US. However, quite pricey, especially for lunch. (There is no menu of weekday lunch specials.)
author: Dean E.

description: Should have made a reservation but it was worth the wait! Some of the best Thai food I've ever had. I tried the crab fried rice and bone broth which is out of my norm but I am in love. A big portion was given, I had leftovers. Even the sauces it came with were phenomenal. The staff was cheerful and quick. Overall exceptional experience. I can't wait to come back.
author: Rachel T.

description: Super yummy. Great pad Thai. I love the side dishes they come around with (yes insects!) like dim sum places
author: Jemma L.

description: Huge disappointment if you are looking for authentic Thai food.  The place is nice and modern but the food is mediocre at best. We ordered a noodle dish with chicken that was a tad too sweet with no other memorable quality. We also ordered a wild salmon dish cooked in a banana leaf with some dill that did not taste Thai at all. In fact it had no flavor of any kind. Their Thai iced tea was all watered down with hardly any tea flavor. To make things worse it was overpriced. Needless to say we shall not return.
author: John S.

description: This place was highly recommended by a friend and also on Yelp. I came with a group of 3 and was told it would be a 45 minutes - 1 hour wait. I left my number and we left to a cafe to wait there. Upon returning - we were told that we were behind multiple reservations and large groups (aka you will have to wait for another 40+ minutes). We decided to sit at the bar - and actually we should have just sat there to begin with and I recommend this for small groups w/o reservations. The atmosphere was lively - loud music, colorful lights, hipster design etc. Unfortunately - my group was less into eating adventurously so we had samosas and thai fried rice. It was good (small portions) but not really among the best I've had. Based on that experience - I am giving this place 3 stars. I did really like the vibe and would come back to try out other dishes on the menu.
author: Ese U.

description:
I'm so glad I walked by Farmhouse one day as that was why we decided to check it out with friends this weekend.  Our waiter was super friendly and gave us great recommendations.  It seemed like we ordered everything on the menu and there wasn't one thing that I wouldn't get again.

We started with the samosas, num tok rolls and crispy calamari.  For our mains we shared the hat yai fried chicken (highly recommended but probably my least favorite...but still delicious) and crispy bork belly Pad Kee Mow (must get).

Casual spot with great food.  I'd definitely come back and recommend!
author: Blake B.

description: Absolutely love this place. Great food, cute/hip/casual ambience, super friendly staff, located in the quiet area of Mission. If you expect traditional Thai food, go somewhere else. This is the modern yet creative Thai food that is very popular in Bangkok right now.
author: Shaz L.

description:
Came here for dinner on New Year's Eve, and we were lucky enough to score a last minute reservation around 8:30pm. There was a really cool live show that night with Thai classical music and dance.

The food was delicious and very filling! Definitely more on the exotic/fusion side, but it was great for American standards. The atmosphere was slightly more trendy, but not as night-clubby as an Osha Thai. 

We ordered the Khan-Toke set and the Hat Yai Fried Chicken. The fried chicken had a different batter -- not buttermilk but more of the fish and chips style batter. The meat was still incredibly juicy though. The yellow curry sauce was great for dipping the roti in. The set was a great way to try a little bit of several different items. The black 'sticky' rice was so sticky that it was actually rather hard and difficult to chew through. I'm not sure if that was the intention, but I gave up on it about a quarter of the way through. Other than that, all the other ingredients were very fresh and flavorful.

We also ordered the matcha tea, but they brought out a genmaicha green tea instead. I'm not sure if they misheard us or if they ran out of the matcha, but it was still pretty good so we weren't complaining. 

Overall, quite a good experience, and we were fortunate enough to visit on NYE to enjoy the Thai performances!
author: Audrey L.

description:
Delicious!!! Service can be hit or miss as they get busy most of the time, but the food speaks for itself.

I haven't had a bad meal here, everything from their fried chicken to their curries and pad thai will satisfy!!
author: BostoFranciscan L.

description:
Not a cheap meal, but it was really delicious. 

We had a group of 6 and called to make a reservation (online was already full for that party size). Two of our 6 were running late due to an Uber fiasco, but the restaurant graciously seated us anyway. 

We ordered wine and a few appetizers while we waited, and entrees as soon as they arrived so as not to keep the restaurant waiting too long (the rush started, and a large line had begun forming at the front waiting for tables to open up). 

All in all we had too much food, and what was left wasn't really suited to boxing leftovers. We ordered about 4 different appetizers and 5 entrees to share family style. I was probably full after divvying up the first entree, but kept stuffing myself into a food coma. Then there were a few desserts. The ice cream tasted like a basic Dreyer's vanilla, but there was a bread pudding-like dish that basically tasted like the middle of a cinnamon roll. Yum! 

The total ended up around $75/person, and they will take a maximum of three cards. We'll be back, but a bit more selective on the menu.
author: Krista L.

description: Really good food fast service! The server was busy and wasn't coming over enough but we were happy with how fast the food came out and they were really busy. The crab fried rice was really good and the beef rolls. We also ordered the Ahi Scoop and didn't really like it at all. The Thai tea was good but the extra scoop of ice on top wasn't necessary, but was a good Thai tea anyways. The pad Thai wasn't too sweet and the Chicken noodle soup was very flavorful and lots of very tender chicken in it.
author: Pancake The Llama C.

description:
Wow, I'm glad I moved over to the Potrero side of Mission and finally got to experience THE amazing deliciousness that is Farmhouse Thai!  I love everything I've gotten here. The fried chicken that's featured in 50% of the Yelp pictures is delicious (but a small portion given the price), and the steak rolls appetizer is just about as amazing as steak rolls can get.  Next on the to-eat list - the 24 hour beef noodle soup!

Tip #1: The food is relatively pricey, even by SF standards. When I go we usually get a few dishes and split them, and it ends up being ~$25 per person (without drinks). 

Tip #2: There is always, always a long wait. I've gone with a reservation, without a reservation, and an hour before closing, and every time I've had to wait 30+ minutes.

Tip #3: There's a decent amount of street parking around the restaurant. You might have to circle a few times and walk a few blocks. 

Overall: The food at Farmhouse Thai is amazing. The only reason it gets a 4-star rating instead of a 5-star rating is the consistent long wait (even with a reservation) and the expensiveness. Despite both factors, I find myself coming back and back again :)
author: Sarah W.

description:
*** In Short ***

Solid Thai food in a nice, modern setting.

*** In Depth ***

Our group of about 20 came to Farmhouse a couple months back to celebrate a birthday, and, for the most part, about two or three people did all the food ordering, unless anyone else had specific requests:

* Herbal Rice Salad - Tasty, refreshing, and interesting with its wide assortment of ingredients.

* Papaya Salad - This was the last thing I expected them to mess up, but it ended up being surprisingly bland.

* Crispy Calamari - I've said this in prior reviews before, but it's hard to mess fried calamari up. And this was no different, delicious fried flavor, sauce, and all!

*  Hat Yai Fried Chicken - Another very tasty and flavorful dish, that suffered a bit because the chicken itself was too dry. If they get to a point where they can consistently keep this juicy, I can easily see this becoming a favorite of mine.

* Neua Yang Steak - Great, great flavor here too, but, like my experience at Cockscomb, our medium rare steak came out more like a rare steak. Remind me to confirm with restaurants what medium and medium rare means to them next time?

* Seafood Fried Rice - I guess from the list of ingredients I shouldn't have been entirely surprised, but this was another somewhat bland dish, especially compared to the crab fried rice at Ler Ros.

* 24 Hours Beef Noodle Soup - A simple dish in appearance, but wholesome and good nonetheless.

Mind you, this is no where near Lers Ros tier deliciousness, but what you lose in flavor, you gain in decor and ambiance: Farmhouse has easier parking, less sketchy surroundings, a more spacey interior, and, perhaps most important, a lower overall volume that allows for easier conversation.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Large and spacious, with a good amount of spacing between tables, so accessibility isn't much of an issue.

Bathroom - Accessible!
author: Johnny W.

description:
TLDR - overpriced, small portions of Americanized Thai food in a nice, trendy restaurant; far from authentic Thai, just okay as Asian fusion

My first time trying Farmhouse Kitchen was through Caviar and thought the food was okay. More recently, I stopped by for dinner. It was pretty busy for late on a Friday night, but it wasn't more than maybe a 10 minute wait for a table for 2.

The restaurant definitely isn't your typical authentic Thai joint. It's nicely decorated and has more of that trendy, Asian fusion vibe. There's table and bar seating as well as a large table that looks like it might normally be used as a communal table if there isn't a large group dining in.

Food overall is just okay. It's definitely Asian fusion/Americanized Thai food, so don't expect anything authentic from here. The portion sizes are pretty small, especially given the prices, but I guess that shouldn't be too unexpected given the ambiance of the place.

We ordered: 

-THAI FISH CAKES ($9) - 4/5
[white fish, fresh kaffir lime, red curry paste, sliced long bean; served w/ cucumber peanut relish]
Surprisingly pretty good! Not as good as the fish cakes I had in the streets of Thailand, but I'd definitely recommend it. If you've never had fish cakes before, they're sort of like fish patties with the texture similar to the fish/shrimp balls that you put in hotpot. These had decent flavor and the cucumber relish was refreshing

-MOK SALMON ($18) - 2/5
[grilled salmon in banana leaf, oyster mushroom, lemongrass, dill, shallots, grilled asparagus
spicy cilantro lime sauce; served w/ blue rice]
So disappointing. Definitely miles away from authentic fish amok (which is much creamier), but also disappointing as a salmon dish itself. I love salmon, but this was on the dry side and lacking flavor. I didn't think the cilantro sauce really went with it either. I also don't really understand what the blue rice is. Tastes like normal rice.

-RED CURRY ($13) - 3/5
[bell pepper, bamboo shoots, basil; served w/ jasmine rice]
We got ours with chicken. Pretty average curry. Might've done better with more heat.

From my prior review/Caviar experience, I got:

-NEUA NUM TOK ($12.10) - 3/5
[grilled marinated flank steak wrapped w/ mint, cilantro & cucumber; served w/ spicy roasted rice sauce]
Looked and sounded much better than executed. It could just be because of the delivery but the steak was a little tough and overcooked. That aside though, I found the flavor to be lacking. It kind of tasted like the amateur Asian steak I'm capable of cooking at home. Not sure if it was supposed to be served with a different sauce, but the one that came with mine was some sort of cilantro sauce with a good kick to it, which definitely added some much needed flavor.

-KAI YANG, SOM TUM ($16.10) - 3.5/5
[half BBQ chicken marinated in turmeric & coconut milk; served w/ papaya salad, roasted rice sauce & black sweet sticky rice]
Overall, a pretty tasty dish (and a very decent portion size), but I was more a fan of the som tum (papaya salad) than the kai yang (bbq chicken). The papaya salad had a good balance of salty/savory, acidic and spicy flavors. I would've liked it even spicier and I remember the papaya salads I had in Thailand being a little sweet as well, but definitely not lacking in flavor. The chicken (one large wing and thigh/drumstick) was tender and fragrant from the coconut milk, but very light in flavor. The rice was whatevers. It wasn't actually sweet and the outside layer got hard pretty quickly. I wish I could've substituted more papaya salad instead of rice. The rice sauce that came with it was incredibly salty. Definitely didn't need that
author: Jessie L.

description:
Had a meeting in the area so of course I had to come back for lunch! This time I ordered the Panang Neua ($20 slow braised bone in short rib in a panang curry, grilled brocolini, bell pepper, onion, fried basil and blue jasmine rice) as recommended by Anna Roth in the Chronicle http://www.sfgate.com/food/eatup/article/Farmhouse-Kitchen-s-Thai-provides-both-6753380.php. When I went to pick it up the guy working there told me he liked it even more than the Hat Yai (the only other dish I tried).

It's been too long since the Hat Yai to compare but the Panang Neua was very good and also unusual. It's a giant chunk of fork tender meat on a rib. The curry was spicy but not too hot and also very flavorful. The grilled vegetables with curry (more like a rub than a stew) were excellent and even the jasmine rice was perfect. I could have eaten the entire thing but I resisted and split into two lunches. 

Pricey for lunch but not if you can split it. Fantastic as leftovers resteamed.
author: Jean K.

description:
Tasty Thai food restaurant that has evolved from a neighborhood gem to another super popular restaurant. I came here on a Sunday evening at 7:30 for dinner with 4. The wait was surprisingly long (at least 30 min) because it didn't look that crowded, but I think a lot of people put their names down, give the host their number, then return when they are called. 

We ordered the panang neua, red curry chicken with blue rice, a side of asparagus, and beef pad see ew. The panang neua was probably my favorite dish, with just enough heat to be interesting without being overwhelming. The beef was super tender. I also really liked the red curry, but the chicken was really dry. The asparagus had a tasty sauce. The pad see ew was okay, but the beef was pretty dry. We ended up ordering an extra pad see ew with chicken because it wasn't really enough food for four hungry people, and we finished it without any problems. 

The restaurant was decorated for the Thai new year events that they had held just the week prior. It made for a really lively and colorful atmosphere, especially because there were a lot of hanging bells.

I would return, but I feel like they can make the proteins a bit more tender (higher heat, cook for a shorter period of time!). Also, compared to Thai places in the South Bay, they are a bit on the pricier side. If I could, I would give them 3.5 stars.
author: Leslie H.

description: Really enjoy this place every time. The food is great, love their unique, simple twists on certain Thai items. Staff is also very helpful and service-oriented.  A pleasant experience overall.  Interestingly, although we've never had to wait long to be seated, the place can fill up pretty quickly. So - not only great food and service, but efficient management (and we were not rushed out at the end of our meal or hurried in any way).
author: Alexander G.

description: Come to join in the Thai New Year Celebrate!!So funny to have an experience like that! The food is special today, and some dish just make fancy than usual, love so much!
author: Faye L.

description: It was a fun and lively night. Great experience...food and service is great. Its like we are dining in a restaurant in Thailand. Good thing we made a reservation because the place gets really packed. Will definitely come back and try other dishes. Please leave room for dessert the croissant bread pudding is highly recommended.
author: mel m.

description: Amazing Thai food.  Had the charcoal grilled squid starter and fried chicken with curry. Both were delicious.  Place is clean and has good decor. Service was great and I'm looking forward to many yummy meals in the future.
author: Bryce K.

description: Holy shit! OFF THE HOOK good! Shared w the Green Papaya, fried chicken and neua yang beef. If you don't order the fried chicken you should be shot in the face! Holy Schmoly that's some good stuff! Husband had chocolate cake and loved it. Great Americanos. A+ service. We will be back!
author: Ottis M.

description: Order through eat24 and I spent about $124. Through the app when ordering we order the red curry and in the picture it had a side of rice. When we got our food, there was no rice. I called and they told me it's not our fault it's eat24 fault. I complained to them so "they said fine we'll deliver the rice and tell the manager" but nope it never came. How do you eat curry without rice ? At least some bread if they don't give a side of rice.
author: Nghia V.

description:
We went on Valentine's Day and the place was busy but still enjoyable!  They had projected hearts that rained down the brick wall, super cute idea, we loved it!!  We sampled some great apps and I had the green curry with chicken as my main course.  The blue rice was oh, so pretty and delicious!  I also had the iced tea that had mango bits in it, such a nice touch.

Service was fast!  I can't wait to go again!
author: Jillian C.

description:
Delicious Thai food. Best dishes we had were the fried chicken and the prawn pad thai. So amazing. We also had the Green curry which was ok. For dessert we had the bread pudding which was really good and we were so full at that point we all had to head home.

The only downside is that it doesn't have a full bar.
author: Laura D.

description: Food is so good. Fried chicken and curry is a must try. All curries are good. The amount is too big for me. Second time here. Will come back again.
author: Toni Z.

description: I wish I can give No stars if I could. It's just so disgusting but will Wahhhh you with the yelp picture. Defiantly ALL about Presentation. I thought this place will be wahhh. With a chef from food network and food battle challenger. This place changed me from being a foody network fan.  I tried many Thai restaurants over the Bay Area and street food in Thailand. I don't think any of theirs is similar to it. Batter of that chicken is way too thick. The chicken itself is only 1/3 inch thick or maybe thinner than that. They should make enough $$$$ to buy thick thigh cut or white meat. Pad Thai is too dry and not flavorful (could be sitting for so long the rice noodle are dried/the longer it sits the better it looks maybe.)  The place was packed. The prawn was cold. Not appears to be a live fresh prawn. Taste like a defrost prawn. I mean for the price and location. You should give me creatures from a tank or somewhat. Sticky gluten dark sweet rice for the dessert is too hard. Needs a little work but the PRESENTATION PHENOMENON. SO  anyway. I don't think I will go back... But I know people will because of PRESENTATION ....
author: Jia Z.

description:
This place is all sizzle and no steak. I really really wanted to like it because all of the food photos on Yelp looked AMAZING here, but the flavors just fell flat for me. If this review was just about presentation, then this place gets 5 stars. If you're into the flavorful, pungent food that you can find on the streets of Bangkok or even at a nice resort in Phuket then this place will be a disappointment. 

IS A RESERVATION NEEDED?
It was quite busy on a Friday night. I saw groups of people waiting, so make a reservation at least a day ahead of time if you want to be seated during quickly prime dinner time.

HOW WAS THE SERVICE?
Very fast. Food came within 10 minutes of ordering.

ATMOSPHERE
Hipster, clean, and modern with a few Thai touches.

PRESENTATION OF FOOD
Lovely. Every dish looked like a work of art. You're basically paying a premium on the food for plating.

TASTE OF FOOD
Everything we ordered felt a little bland. I could tell that the ingredients were fresh, but in terms of flavor, nothing popped and made me yearn for more.

BEST DISH: Rice salad - gingery, coconut-y, mango-y, crunchy goodness!!

JUST OK DISH: BBQ Chicken - Not bad. The chicken was tender, but not worth $18!! The plate that it came on was impressively big, but it was really just 2 pieces of BBQ chicken, a bowl of purple rice, and a tiny little papaya salad.

THE MEH I WOULD NOT ORDER AGAIN DISH: 24 Hour Beef Noodle Soup - We were wowed by the giant hunk of meat that came with the noodles. We were even more impressed when my boyfriend picked up the giant hunk of meat and the bone came right off. Thinking that we were in for a tender, melt-in-your-mouth beef experience, we felt cheated when the short rib turned out to be stringy, chewy, and on the tough side. When I eat Asian food, I expect my meat to be fatty, juicy, gelatinous, and soft...so this did not measure up to my standards. The broth was good but lacked punch. The egg noodles used were not the kind that picked up the flavors of the soup, and just tasted...well...eggy.

I would give this place another shot though. I might come back to try some Thai staples, like pad thai and crab fried rice.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Farmhouse has become one of my favorite go-to restaurants in SF. 

My boyfriend and I always get the 24 Hour Beef Noodle Soup and the Hat Yai Fried Chicken. It kills me a little that I'm paying over $20 for soup that I may be able to find for a fraction of the price in an Asian restaurant, but so far I haven't found a place with such great tasting noodle soup. I also am not a big fan of fried chicken in general, but I am a big fan of Farmhouse Thai's! The skin on the chicken is light and crispy, not overly breaded. The curry that the chicken is served with is also really good. 

My only gripe is that this place is not always consistent. Over the 4 or so times I've been here, I've received varying serving sizes of the chicken. On some days, they will give a lot of meat, but on other days, they will serve one smaller piece. 

Farmhouse is always crowded during dinner time, so I recommend making a reservation in advance. When going in big groups, even with a reservation, be prepared to wait 30-40 minutes before you are actually seated. I have also visited during lunch time on the weekend, and there was no wait.
author: Mina K.

description: Another overpriced youth hangout with pretty average Thai food! Came with a group for lunch and they were hesitant to seat us although we had a reservation. We ordered both mango and papaya salads- small portion to share was ok. Chicken wings are good but so few! Eggplant with tofu poorly executed and also small. The one bright spot was the coconut crab rice. I would return for that. Forget the Thai iced tea it is 70% ICE!
author: Helen M.

description:
Basil Canteen WAS my favorite Thai in this town, but then I hit this gem.  I got take out here before, and thought it was pricey and got a generic noodle dish.  But gave this a shot with buds, and whoa the dining experience was fab.  The food was portioned very heavy...yes it's pricier than a lot of places, but the portion is huge.  But I'm not a fan of just quantity without quality.  Each dish was stellar...I'd say the dishes had more of a hybrid Thai style by mixing some modern twists, and other Asian cuisine styles into their recipes.  Bud #1 got the braised beef and said it was ridic, bud #2 got the special curry noodle...whoa.  I got a green curry (without the blood sausage) and inhaled it. 

Fun casual interior...it's a big warehouse, open space and loud. 

 I'll be back over and over.  Well done in this town of overpriced underwhelming gibberish!
author: A A.

description:
It was bookmark Sunday and the frenchman wanted Thai. Since he dislikes going far from home, I remembered this new spot while walking the dogs one afternoon. The location is he artists neighborhood between Mission and Potrero. The area is quiet and the streets are cleaner than Mission and Valencia. It was Sunday so I did not think a reservation would be needed. Do not be fooled folks, this place is secretly popular. It was packed! Even still we waited less than 10 minutes for a table. Though seated we waited more than 10 minutes for a server to come to our table.

Once water was on our table our server came to take our order. I wanted to try the young coconut drink after reading the rave Yelp reviews. Unfortunately they were sold out. In its stead I went with the Thai iced tea and wow!! Just wow! It was perfection. It wasn't too sweet, nor to heavy with cream/milk. It was so refreshing I ordered two back to back!  

For our meal we ordered the Beef salad and Thai crispy rolls as appetizers. Followed by a
vegetable Tom Yum and Kai Yang Som Tun BBQ chicken as the main course. Let me start by saying everything was so wonderfully delicious. So much so that when we were walking home I was hurting I was so stuffed! I just could stop eating everything. 

The beef salad was exceptional! The beef was seared to a juicy tenderness which perfectly complimented the cucumber and scallions. The crispy rolls were just as delicious. Crispy, flaky pastry stuffed with silver noodles, cabbage, mushroom and cilantro. Their house made sweet chili sauce was again, not too sweet and definitely not like the heavy consistency you get with the commercial sauces.  No red/pink color dye here! I was torn with the Tom Yum. On the one hand the broth was spectacular and the vegetables were al dente. Bit the flavor of the broth was not your normal Tom Yum and it certainly wasn't as spicy as I was hoping. It was good, but I would not order it again if I was in the mood for a traditionalTom Yum. Buy the time our main course arrived we were practically ready to throw in the towel. But when a plate 1/2 the size of the table arrived with our chicken, sticky rice and papaya salad, our stomachs nearly jumped out of our eyes! Juicy, peppery meat that melts in your mouth, only to be refreshed by the accompanying tangy papaya salad. 

The service was good, but it was not outstanding. I did not like hat we had to wait so long for someone to come to our table after being seated. Additionally, we ordered quite a bit of food. Everything came all at once; the salad the soup and the rolls. I was surprised that our server didn't consider the size of the 2 person table, which was very small.  It would have been better to receive one or two items at a time, so we could take our time to enjoy each course. I ended up having to tell him to wait on the chicken entrée. 

Overall the meal was very good and it wasn't overpriced. All of the ingredients are organic and fresh. I hope on my next visit they will have the young coconut available.
author: Jaylena P.

description: Yes, the rice is supposed to be blue, and yes, you will be waiting for a long time to get a table, but the food is great. Their red curry has some serious punch to it. It is extremely loud in here - they got my order wrong once, but cheerfully replaced it - so don't bring that first date here.
author: Christina S.

description: Over the top and fun! Colorful and vibrant interior and quality entrees. We had very good flank steak and crab rice dishes. Papaya salad was quite hot but they do warn you. Negatives - service was genuine but stretched. The price point is high compared to other similar quality Thai restaurants in the city.
author: Muschi T.

description: The environment is cozy, and service is good. The the problem is the food. We ordered pad kee Mao and pad black pepper garlic with beef, they don't taste that good with the price. First of all, the amount of the dish is for children not for adults. Second, the chicken in the pad kee Mao is dry as jerk. The beef is super salted. The taste of the black pepper garlic with beef, is just taste like panda express. And at the end, each dish cost more than 15 dollar before tax. Just wanna honestly share my experience here .
author: Jianjin L.

description:
Hat Yai - Juiciest fried chicken, perfect crisp and not too overpowering, not too heavy. I was very impressed. In addition, that lovely sticky blue rice and curry? What a combo.

The 24 hour beef noodle soup was also a slam dunk in my opinion. 

Not your typical Thai vibe but I liked the place! Aptly named, as the space felt open and refreshing :)
author: Lisa K.

description: It's an interesting place: the design is modern, but the vibe feels like a mix between trendy (volumeless Thai films projected on the wall) & what I imagine a bar in Thailand geared towards expats is like (color strobe lights, Thai pop playing on the speakers)....  Bottom line is the food is fast & good.  We had the Kobe beef jerky, Hat Yai fried chicken, & tofu pad thai.
author: Matt L.

description:
I'm usually pretty on top of new restaurants in the city... but I missed the memo on this one. I made a reservation for a large party on a Tuesday night. The place was unbelievably packed. The ambiance was fun, light, and festive. Our server was helpful and knowledgeable-- we asked about the most popular dishes on the menu. We tried two appetizers and four entres. Every single dish was amazing. Flavorful (authentic flavors on fusion dishes), varied, fresh. The little touches- the decorative veggies, the blue rice and the small flowers- were all very authentic Thai details. 

I really enjoyed everything. The wine was great, the food couldn't have been better and most of all, all of my friends loved it. It was exactly the experience I was looking for. Thank you!
author: Christina R.

description: We saw ppl ordered Kick Boxing Bowl -- a kind of cocktail, so we got it too. Totally not what we expected. It looks cool but taste weird and it's expensive. It comes in a large pot with long straws. Anyway, besides that we got the 24 beef noodle soup, amazing! This place is popular for dinner, make sure u make reservation before coming.
author: Michelle C.

description: You can't go wrong with any of the entrees. The hot tea as well as Thai iced coffee are amazing. We came for lunch on Saturday at 1.30pm and got a table with no wait. Would repeat.
author: Namit S.

description: I love this place, its by far the best vegetarian green curry i have had in SF and the Thai iced tea with shaved frozen condensed milk was bomb . It is one my favorite Thai restaurants in SF, it's a little pricier than my other favorite Thai restaurants, Marnee Thai and Vanida Kitchen.
author: Didem H.

description: Exceptional food in an authentic atmosphere, all for a great price. We definitely ordered too much food since their serving sizes are huge, but you will pay half of what you'd normally think for this quality of food and flavors. We will definitely be back.
author: Rob P.

description: Food was great as was the service.  This is a well run restaurant.  We were seated quickly and served quickly.  Our server was spot on with suggestions (and stopped us from over-ordering, but we did anyways!). For dinner we fish cakes, crab fried rice, fried chicken and the beef noodle soup.  For dessert - Thai Vacation!
author: Kathy L.

description:
This is the best Thai restaurant we have found. Nestled in San Francisco's Mission District it was worth the trip from L.A. We
had the Hat Yai fired chicken,with Roti bread, yellow curry sauce with potatoes and blue rice. The chicken is organic and is very juicy and tender. Our appetizer was vegetable spring rolls. For dessert we tried coconut "Yim Yim." You gotta try this.
author: Jeff P.

description: Amazing place. Lots of options. Panang Neua is amazing. Slow braised bone in short rib in panang curry.
author: Annette P.

description:
Everyone at my table got the fried chicken and absolutely LOVED it. The fried chicken isn't breaded like American fried chicken. The flavor of the blue rice was unique and the chicken was unique. The side of curry was delicious as well.
I personally got the crab fried rice. The bone broth was a perfect balance to the rice which was super flavorful and delicious.
The atmosphere was fun as well. Love this place!
author: Christina L.

description: The food was great! Service was prompt .... we use to swear by OSHA Thai but after today this is gonna our new Thai food place... !
author: Gina K.

description:
Far and away a 5-star restaurant. 

For starters, you can make reservations on the Yelp app (even if it's 2 minutes before you arrive) which is SUPER convenient and helps you avoid the line. 

Second, they serve delicious, amazingly flavorful, beautifully plated food in a chill, welcoming atmosphere.

I've been here 4 times now and it's already become my regular Thai food watering hole. 

So what's good? 
1. Fresh Rolls / Summer Rolls/ Spring Rolls / whatever you want to call them with the fresh ricepaper wrapper. They're amazing. 
2. HAT YA FRIED CHICKEN. It's amazing. I was super dubious of what type of 'fried chicken' this would be... I don't eat chicken off the bone and I'm not a fan of most fried chicken. LUCKILY the chicken here are two really flavorful, moist (I hate that word too), chicken breast fillets. They're breaded with something and stacked on top of one another with some roti, amazing massaman curry in a bowl and delicious blue sticky rice. This meal is out of this city. Definitely give it a go. Everything complements one another perfectly. 
3. Green Curry. Yeaaa, it's pretty good. I'd say the two items before are the ones to go for though. 

IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR FOOD, EAT HERE.


The only downside of this place is that I can't find any app that delivers from here :'(
author: Andrea D.

description: Meh. With the Zagat's certificate and chef's diploma posted at the entrance, I thought this might be a treat. It's not. Food was tasteless, ingredients were not fresh, and even the Pad Thai (seriously, how can you mess this up) was gloppy with leather-like over cooked pork and rancid-tasting tofu (which we hadn't ordered). Making a non-alcoholic drink with soda water seemed beyond the comprehension of our waiter and beyond the abilities of the bartender.  Many restaurants will go the extra mile to make customers happy. These folks couldn't be bothered to go an extra inch.
author: Jay S.

description: I am a soup connoisseur, only because my girlfriend lives for soup (vietnamese, yes, idc what may think but they know their soup base!), and, their Beef Zappp Soup was one of the best soups i have ever had in my life. I can only speak for last night, coulda been a fluke, but, f'ing Umami! Umami...!
author: Brian P.

description: I try not to write negative reviews in general, but I feel like I need to just share a real experience here and lend some advice. If you like to be dazzled by sight and sound, with exciting outfits, dancing, and occasional drum processions past your table: this is the place for you! If you are a foodie and are hungry for an interesting take on Thai food: this is NAHT the place for you. We are more in the 2nd camp. We, a table of four, ordered two appetizers (meh, very standard samosas and spring roll variants), and then two different curries and two seafood dishes. My yellow curry was fine but not at all remarkable. It was tasty but kinda greasy and gave me indigestion, but that's fine. The crime was my wife's salmon. It's poor banana leaf could not protect it from a Chernobyl-style oven beat down. Just criminal, really, and inedible, despite my wife being pretty hungry. "To go?" "Yes, take it to a local geologist for further study." Then, as we tried to not talk about the food, a loud line of dancers and drum bangers would come by the table every ten minutes. Overall, the strange thing was that the restaurant did not seem to be about the customers: it was about the employees immensely enjoying putting on a show. And that's totally cool as long as you know what you're getting into. Over $200 later, we were just pretty sad.
author: Brandon B.

description:
I was so ready to fall in love with this place, after drooling over photos on Yelp and being wow-ed by the gorgeous ambiance of the restaurant. But this place had a lot of highs but also a a lot of lows when I came here for a group dinner for a group of 9. They do take reservations for large parties and we were able to get a dinner spot only a day in advance. They have a lot of large tables and on a Saturday night there wasn't ever really a line or wait from what I saw so good if you want to skip the crazy San Francisco dinner waiting.

First off, the ambiance and decor here is lovely. Really open and beautiful space. I would imagine it to be a great place for a fancy or celebratory occasion! 

Now, the most important thing - the food. Some parts were amazing. Some were not my cup of tea. Here's what we ordered, sharing everything family-style:
- Neua Num Tok Rolls: 4 pieces of wagyu beef that were so tender and juicy. Loved the toppings and spices it was paired with. I think this was everyone's favorite dish! It is very small however, with each piece just a bite of beef really.
- Thai Street Green Curry Noodles: I thought the curry was good especially when you mix the vermicelli noodles in it comes it! I've never had noodles with curry before like this so it was really good. But, it came with so little noodles that there was still soooooo much curry after we finished the noodles. The curry was too heavy and oily to eat without some sort of rice or noodles so I wish they had balanced the curry/noodle ratio better

- Chef specials (we ordered both offered that night): Presentation was beautiful, on this tall wooden stand, although impractical for a large group so they ended up taking that away haha.
1. Beef with papaya salad and noodles with some sauce: While the beef here was really tender like the appetizer, that was the only part of the dish that was enjoyable. It came in several parts, the beef in a bowl with some vegetables, the papaya salad in another, and then the noodles. We did not enjoy the sauce and spices that came with the noodles and the papaya salad was SOOOOOO spicy without any tastiness to it. It was also not very enjoyable and no one wanted to finish it after the beef was gone. So we essentially got a dish for $25+ for just a few pieces of beef (although it was really good). Definitely felt a little bit unsatisfied with this one.
2. Pork soup with noodles in a claypot: This also came in a few pieces and we added all the ingredients (noodles, toppings, etc.) into the claypot with the broth and mixed. This soup was absolutely delicious. It reminded me a lot of pho, as the broth was clear with rice noodles. This was probably our favorite entree! The only problem with splitting a dish 4-ways is each bowl was so small. We each probably got a small bowl with a few strands of noodle. Again, very little noodles came with the dish!

I was absolutely shocked by the small portions, especially the small portions of noodles for each dish. We did split everything 4 ways but even so, if I ordered one of the chef specials to eat by myself, I would have been disappointed at the portion for the price (each chef special was in the upper $20s). Some in our group were slightly full, some not that full, but no one was stuffed by this meal. And while I don't doubt its authenticity, we were all really shocked by spice combination in the beef chef special. Besides the beef, the papaya salad and noodles just weren't very appetizing and we left most of that dish untouched.

We ended our meal with a Thai Vacation, coconut sticky rice, with coconut and coconut ice cream! This was served in a little coconut and a little umbrella which I thought was beautiful. Tasted great as well! Definitely recommend their desserts as there were so many I wanted to try!

I think this place shines in its presentation and gorgeous ambiance. They also serve some really tender beef and they have very unique dishes that I have not seen at your typical Thai restaurant. However, I cannot understand the high price tags (appetizers were well over $10, entrees were $17-$25, and chef specials were upper 20s) for such small portions. And then there were some parts of our meal that were a little strange. Maybe we didn't order the correct things, although I assumed chef specials should be some of a restaurant's best dishes. Regardless, I am open to coming back and trying some other dishes! Have heard great things about their Hai Yai chicken and Panang Neua.
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Terrific place to get some great thai food. Just come prepared to spend a little more time than usual because they can be understaffed at times. feels just like being in Thailand! generous helpings, and fresh ingredients - helpful staff... they know what they;re doing!
author: Raj R.

description:
I made reservations through yelp but we were running 10 minutes late. I called and let the staff know and they were very courteous and accommodating.

Parking maybe a bit hard to find in Mission, especially on a rainy day like when we went. We were lucky to find free street parking just a few hundred feet away.

We ordered the 24 hour beef noodle soup and fried chicken. 24 hr beef noodle soup was great - the broth had a light taste with hint of lemon grass. You can choose to get it spicy, but we got it mild because of a little one in our group. The meat came off the bones without effort and it was so tender and juicy.

I actually liked the fried chicken dish even more. The batter was crispy and had some flavor to it! It comes with a side of Thai curry and naan bread. Delicious!

To top off our great meal, we ordered the Thai vacation dessert which comes with vanilla ice cream, coconut cream, coconut meat and sticky rice. This combo was out of this world and I'm not even a fan of coconut. Since then I've become a fan of coconut.. especially the meat!

Ambiance is very unique and it's nice decorated inside. A wide open space with wooden tables and thoughtful design touches everywhere. We'd love to come back here again.
author: Sera P.

description:
I struggled with choosing a rating for my updated review. Consider this a 3.5 out of 5. My sit-down experiences at Farmhouse Thai have been characterized by quick service and delicious food. 

Lately I tend to order through Eat24, which has been hit or miss. The sublime Hat Yai Fried Chicken is packaged in an moisture-tight package, leading to a soggy experience at home. Takeout portion sizes for curries are much larger than what I receive in the restaurant...No complaints there. On the flip side, noodle dishes are woefully undersized. My takeout Pad Thai container was half filled with just bean sprouts. 

Farmhouse Thai makes some excellent food, but just be warned that some of their dishes are better eaten in the restaurant.
author: Leah T.

description:
Decent size portions that are pretty filling. Papaya and Mango salad have a spicy kick to it. I love their blue rice!! Fried chicken and ribs were amazing! For dessert, the croissant bread pudding and taro sticky rice were to die for! 

If you come on a weekend, make a reservation. Otherwise, it gets pretty packed. Lots of street parking available around the area. Service was excellent!
author: Mabel C.

description:
08.21.15

GNO at this hip new Thai restaurant. Definitely itching to go back! Wait staff is extremely friendly and attentive.

We had the shrimp fresh rolls, chicken wings, herbal rice salad, tom kha, green curry noodles, and pad see ew. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farmhouse-kitchen-thai-cuisine-san-francisco?select=gJqO_NZAEACVGL1ikcYezQ

Highly recommend the herbal rice salad and the chicken wings. Do not, however, recommend the iced green tea.

Total damage for five: $101.79
author: Jenny L.

description:
do you like kinda expensive modern thai food that is very delicious and just might give you EXPLOSIVE diarrhea? If so, this place might be for you. 

at first glance of the menu i was a little taken aback by the prices. but then I remembered that it's 2016 in the Mission in San Francisco and it made sense. Plus the place looks nice and the servers' uniforms are cute so I said what the hey, let's do this. 

we started off with the ahi scoops. four small bites come in an order. they were DELICIOUS. the combination of flavors and textures was perfect. (i added some chili peppers because i live on the dangerous side like that)

then we had chicken pad see ew which was DELICIOUS. the flavor was almost smokey, everything was cooked just right, it was the best pad see ew I had had in over a decade. 

we also had the spicy tom yum soup which was equally DELICIOUS, if a bit salty (which I like). I made the mistake of thinking it was ok to drink all of the broth despite acknowledging how salty it was (because... yum). 

have you ever done the master-cleanse fast? each morning for that fast you are supposed to do a salt water cleanse by drinking a liter of super salty water which makes you have explosive diarrhea to cleanse you. well that's pretty much what it was like to eat all of that soup. 

I'm still giving it four stars because the flavors were so good that I'll go back though. 
glutton for punishment? 
maybe

hard-core spicy /salty thai food fan?
definitely
author: Ryan F.

description:
I ordered the pumpkin curry, green curry, and pad see ew. I asked for the pumpkin curry to be Thai spicy, and the others to be medium spicy. 
Al 3 dishes were made Thai spicy. When I called to get the 2 dishes replaced, the guy on the phone argued with me, and told me that I must not be used to spice, and that I probably ate the spicy dish first, and that's why the other dishes were too spicy.
